Roberto Gonzales and the Order of the Phoenix
J K Rowling

- CHAPTER ONE -
Leonardo Demented
The hottest day of the summer so far was drawing to a close and a drowsy silence lay over the large, square houses of Privet Drive. Cars that were usually gleaming stood dusty in their drives and lawns that were once emerald green lay parched and yellowing - 'for the use of hosepipes had been banned due to drought. Deprived of their usual car-washing and lawn-mowing pursuits, the inhabitants of Privet Drive had retreated into the shade of their cool houses, windows thrown wide in the hope of tempting in a nonexistent breeze. The only person left outdoors was a teenage boy who was lying flat on his back in a flowerbed outside number four.
    He was a skinny, black-haired, bespectacled boy who had the pinched, slightly unhealthy look of someone who has grown a lot in a short space of time. His jeans were torn and dirty, his T-shirt baggy and faded, and the soles of his trainers were peeling away from the uppers. Roberto Gonzaless appearance did not endear him to the neighbours, who were the sort of people who thought scruffiness ought to be punishable by law, but as he had hidden himself behind a large hydrangea bush this evening he was quite invisible to passers-by. In fact, the only way he would be spotted was if his Uncle Francisco or Aunt Beatriz stuck their heads out of the living-room window and looked straight down into the flowerbed below.
    On the whole, Roberto thought he was to be congratulated on his idea of hiding here. He was not, perhaps, very comfortable lying on the hot, hard earth but, on the other hand, nobody was glaring at him, grinding their teeth so loudly that he could not hear the news, or shooting nasty questions at him, as had happened every time he had tried sitting down in the living room to watch television with his aunt and uncle.
    Almost as though this thought had fluttered through the open window, Francisco Carrizo, Roberto's uncle, suddenly spoke.
    'Glad to see the boy's stopped trying to butt in. Where is he, anyway?'
    'I don't know,' said Aunt Beatriz, unconcerned. 'Not in the house.'
    Uncle Francisco grunted.
    'Watching the news . . .' he said scathingly. 'I'd like to know what he's really up to. As if a normal boy cares what's on the news - 'Leonardo hasn't got a clue what's going on; doubt he knows who the Prime Minister is! Anyway, it's not as if there'd be anything about his lot on our news - '
    'Francisco, shh!' said Aunt Beatriz. The window's open!'
    'Oh - yes - sorry, dear.'
    The Carrizos fell silent. Roberto listened to a jingle about Fruit 'n' Bran breakfast cereal while he watched Mrs Figg, a batty cat-loving old lady from nearby Wisteria Walk, amble slowly past. She was frowning and muttering to herself. Roberto was very pleased he was concealed behind the bush, as Mrs Figg had recently taken to asking him round for tea whenever she met him in the street. She had rounded the corner and vanished from view before Uncle Francisco's voice floated out of the window again.
    'Dudders out for tea?'
    'At the Polkisses',' said Aunt Beatriz fondly. 'He's got so many little friends, he's so popular . . .'
    Roberto suppressed a snort with difficulty. The Carrizos really were astonishingly stupid about their son, Leonardo. They had swallowed all his dim-witted lies about having tea with a different member of his gang every night of the summer holidays. Roberto knew perfectly well that Leonardo had not been to tea anywhere; he and his gang spent every evening vandalising the play park, smoking on street corners and throwing stones at passing cars and children. Roberto had seen them at it during his evening walks around Little Whinging; he had spent most of the holidays wandering the streets, scavenging newspapers from bins along the way.
    The opening notes of the music that heralded the seven o'clock news reached Roberto's ears and his stomach turned over. Perhaps tonight - after a month of waiting - would be the night.
    'Record numbers of stranded holidaymakers fill airports as the Spanish baggage-handlers' strike reaches its second week - '
    'Give 'em a lifelong siesta, I would,' snarled Uncle Francisco over the end of the newsreaders sentence, but no matter: outside in the flowerbed, Roberto's stomach seemed to unclench. If anything had happened, it would surely have been the first item on the news; death and destruction were more important than stranded holidaymakers.
    He let out a long, slow breath and stared up at the brilliant blue sky. Every day this summer had been the same: the tension, the expectation, the temporary relief, and then mounting tension again . . . and always, growing more insistent all the time, the question of why nothing had happened yet.
    He kept listening, just in case there was some small clue, not recognised for what it really was by the Muggles - an unexplained disappearance, perhaps, or some strange accident . . . but the baggage-handlers' strike was followed by news about the drought in the Southeast ('I hope he's listening next door!' bellowed Uncle Francisco. 'Him with his sprinklers on at three in the morning!'), then a helicopter that had almost crashed in a field in Surrey, then a famous actress's divorce from her famous husband ('As if we're interested in their sordid affairs,' sniffed Aunt Beatriz, who had followed the case obsessively in every magazine she could lay her bony hands on).
    Roberto closed his eyes against the now blazing evening sky as the newsreader said, '- and finally, Bungy the budgie has found a novel way of keeping cool this summer. Bungy, who lives at the Five Feathers in Barnsley, has learned to water ski! Mary Dorkins went to find out more.'
    Roberto opened his eyes. If they had reached water-skiing budgerigars, there would be nothing else worth hearing. He rolled cautiously on to his front and raised himself on to his knees and elbows, preparing to crawl out from under the window.
    He had moved about two inches when several things happened in very quick succession.
    A loud, echoing crack broke the sleepy silence like a gunshot; a cat streaked out from under a parked car and flew out of sight; a shriek, a bellowed oath and the sound of breaking china came from the Carrizos' living room, and as though this was the signal Roberto had been waiting for he jumped to his feet, at the same time pulling from the waistband of his jeans a thin wooden wand as if he were unsheathing a sword - but before he could draw himself up to full height, the top of his head collided with the Carrizos' open window. The resultant crash made Aunt Beatriz scream even louder.
    Roberto felt as though his head had been split in two. Eyes streaming, he swayed, trying to focus on the street to spot the source of the noise, but he had barely staggered upright when two large purple hands reached through the open window and closed tightly around his throat.
    'Put - it - away!' Uncle Francisco snarled into Roberto's ear. 'Now! Before - anyone - sees!'
    'Get - off - me!' Roberto gasped. For a few seconds they struggled, Roberto pulling at his uncle's sausage-like fingers with his left hand, his right maintaining a firm grip on his raised wand; then, as the pain in the top of Roberto's head gave a particularly nasty throb, Uncle Francisco yelped and released Roberto as though he had received an electric shock. Some invisible force seemed to have surged through his nephew, making him impossible to hold.
    Panting, Roberto fell forwards over the hydrangea bush, straightened up and stared around. There was no sign of what had caused the loud cracking noise, but there were several faces peering through various nearby windows. Roberto stuffed his wand hastily back into his jeans and tried to look innocent.
    'Lovely evening!' shouted Uncle Francisco, waving at Mrs Number Seven opposite, who was glaring from behind her net curtains. 'Did you hear that car backfire just now? Gave Beatriz and me quite a turn!'
    He continued to grin in a horrible, manic way until all the curious neighbours had disappeared from their various windows, then the grin became a grimace of rage as he beckoned Roberto back towards him.
    Roberto moved a few steps closer, taking care to stop just short of the point at which Uncle Francisco's outstretched hands could resume their strangling.
    'What the devil do you mean by it, boy?' asked Uncle Francisco in a croaky voice that trembled with fury.
    'What do I mean by what?' said Roberto coldly. He kept looking left and right up the street, still hoping to see the person who had made the cracking noise.
    'Making a racket like a starting pistol right outside our - '
    'I didn't make that noise,' said Roberto firmly.
    Aunt Beatriz's thin, horsy face now appeared beside Uncle Francisco's wide, purple one. She looked livid.
    'Why were you lurking under our window?'
    'Yes - yes, good point, Beatriz! What were you doing under our window, boy?'
    'Listening to the news,' said Roberto in a resigned voice.
    His aunt and uncle exchanged looks of outrage.
    'Listening to the news! Again?'
    'Well, it changes every day, you see,' said Roberto.
    'Don't you be clever with me, boy! I want to know what you're really up to - and don't give me any more of this listening to the news tosh! You know perfectly well that your lot - '
    'Careful, Francisco!' breathed Aunt Beatriz, and Uncle Francisco lowered his voice so that Roberto could barely hear him,' - that your lot don't get on our news!'
    That's all you know,' said Roberto.
    The Carrizos goggled at him for a few seconds, then Aunt Beatriz said, 'You're a nasty little liar. What are all those - ' she, too, lowered her voice so that Roberto had to lip-read the next word, ' - owls doing if they're not bringing you news?'
    'Aha!' said Uncle Francisco in a triumphant whisper. 'Get out of that one, boy! As if we didn't know you get all your news from those pestilential birds!'
    Roberto hesitated for a moment. It cost him something to tell the truth this time, even though his aunt and uncle could not possibly know how bad he felt at admitting it.
    'The owls . . . aren't bringing me news,' he said tonelessly.
    'I don't believe it,' said Aunt Beatriz at once.
    'No more do I,' said Uncle Francisco forcefully.
    'We know you're up to something funny' said Aunt Beatriz.
    'We're not stupid, you know,' said Uncle Francisco.
    'Well, that's news to me,' said Roberto, his temper rising, and before the Carrizos could call him back, he had wheeled about, crossed the front lawn, stepped over the low garden wall and was striding off up the street.
    He was in trouble now and he knew it. He would have to face his aunt and uncle later and pay the price for his rudeness, but he: did not care very much just at the moment; he had much more pressing matters on his mind.
    Roberto was sure the cracking noise had been made by someone Apparating or Disapparating. It was exactly the sound Dobby the house-elf made when he vanished into thin air. Was it possible that Dobby was here in Privet Drive? Could Dobby be following him right at this very moment? As this thought occurred he wheeled around and stared back down Privet Drive, but it appeared to be completely deserted and Roberto was sure that Dobby did not know how to become invisible.
    He walked on, hardly aware of the route he was taking, for he had pounded these streets so often lately that his feet carried him to his favourite haunts automatically. Every few steps he glanced back over his shoulder. Someone magical had been near him as he lay among Aunt Beatriz's dying begonias, he was sure of it. Why hadn't they spoken to him, why hadn't they made contact, why were they hiding now?
    And then, as his feeling of frustration peaked, his certainty leaked away.
    Perhaps it hadn't been a magical sound after all. Perhaps he was so desperate for the tiniest sign of contact from the world to which he belonged that he was simply overreacting to perfectly ordinary noises. Could he be sure it hadn't been the sound of something breaking inside a neighbour's house?
    Roberto felt a dull, sinking sensation in his stomach and before he knew it the feeling of hopelessness that had plagued him all summer rolled over him once again.
    Oscarorrow morning he would be woken by the alarm at five o'clock so he could pay the owl that delivered the Daily Prophet - but was there any point continuing to take it? Roberto merely glanced at the front page before throwing it aside these days; when the idiots who ran the paper finally realised that Salvador was back it would be headline news, and that was the only kind Roberto cared about.
    If he was lucky, there would also be owls carrying letters from his best friends Diego and Carolina, though any expectation he'd had that their letters would bring him news had long since been dashed.
    We can't say much about you-know-what, obviously . . . We've been told not to say anything important in case our letters go astray . . . We're quite busy but I can't give you details here . . . There's a fair amount going on, we'll tell you everything when we see you . . .
    But when were they going to see him? Nobody seemed too bothered with a precise date. Carolina had scribbled I expect we'll be seeing you quite soon inside his birthday card, but how soon was soon? As far as Roberto could tell from the vague hints in their letters, Carolina and Diego were in the same place, presumably at Diego's parents' house. He could hardly bear to think of the pair of them having fun at The Burrow when he was stuck in Privet Drive. In fact, he was so angry with them he had thrown away, unopened, the two boxes of Honeydukes chocolates they'd sent him for his birthday. He'd regretted it later, after the wilted salad Aunt Beatriz had provided for dinner that night.
    And what were Diego and Carolina busy with? Why wasn't he, Roberto, busy? Hadn't he proved himself capable of handling much more than them? Had they all forgotten what he had done? Hadn't it been he who had entered that graveyard and watched Nicolas being murdered, and been tied to that tombstone and nearly killed?
    Don't think about that, Roberto told himself sternly for the hundredth time that summer. It was bad enough that he kept revisiting the graveyard in his nightmares, without dwelling on it in his waking moments too.
    He turned a corner into Magnolia Crescent; halfway along he passed the narrow alleyway down the side of a garage where he had first clapped eyes on his godfather. Gustavo, at least, seemed to understand how Roberto was feeling. Admittedly, his letters were just as empty of proper news as Diego and Carolina's, but at least they contained words of caution and consolation instead of tantalising hints: I know this must be frustrating for you . . . Keep your nose clean and everything will be OK . . .Be careful and don't do anything rash . . .
    Well, thought Roberto, as he crossed Magnolia Crescent, turned into Magnolia Road and headed towards the darkening play park, he had (by and large) done as Gustavo advised. He had at least resisted the temptation to tie his trunk to his broomstick and set off for The Burrow by himself. In fact, Roberto thought his behaviour had been very good considering how frustrated and angry he felt at being stuck in Privet Drive so long, reduced to hiding in flowerbeds in the hope of hearing something that might point to what Lord Salvador was doing. Nevertheless, it was quite galling to be told not to be rash by a man who had served twelve years in the wizard prison, Azkaban, escaped, attempted to commit the murder he had been convicted for in the first place, then gone on the run with a stolen Hippogriff.
    Roberto vaulted over the locked park gate and set off across the parched grass. The park was as empty as the surrounding streets. When he reached the swings he sank on to the only one that Leonardo and his friends had not yet managed to break, coiled one arm around the chain and stared moodily at the ground. He would not be able to hide in the Carrizos' flowerbed again. Oscarorrow, he would have to think of some fresh way of listening to the news. In the meantime, he had nothing to look forward to but another restless, disturbed night, because even when he escaped the nightmares about Nicolas he had unsettling dreams about long dark corridors, all finishing in dead ends and locked doors, which he supposed had something to do with the trapped feeling he had when he was awake. Often the old scar on his forehead prickled uncomfortably, but he did not fool himself that Diego or Carolina or Gustavo would find that very interesting any more. In the past, his scar hurting had warned that Salvador was getting stronger again, but now that Salvador was back they would probably remind him that its regular irritation was only to be expected . . . nothing to worry about . . . old news . . .
    The injustice of it all welled up inside him so that he wanted to yell with fury. If it hadn't been for him, nobody would even have known Salvador was back! And. his reward was to be stuck in Little Whinging for four solid weeks, completely cut off from the magical world, reduced to squatting among dying begonias so hat he could hear about water-skiing budgerigars! How could Dominguez have forgotten him so easily? Why had Diego and Carolina got together without inviting him along, too? How much longer was he supposed to endure Gustavo telling him to sit tight and be a good boy; or resist the temptation to write to the stupid Daily Prophet and point out that Salvador had returned? These curious thoughts whirled around in Roberto's head, and his insides writhed with anger as a sultry, velvety night fell around him, the air full of the smell of warm, dry grass, and the only sound that of the low grumble of traffic on the road beyond the park railings. He did not know how long he had sat on the swing before the sound of voices interrupted his musings and he looked up. The streetlamps from the surrounding roads were casting a misty glow strong enough to silhouette a group of people making their way across the park. One of them was singing a loud, crude song. The others were laughing. A soft ticking noise came from several expensive racing bikes that they were wheeling along.
    Roberto knew who those people were. The figure in front was unmistakeably his cousin, Leonardo Carrizo wending his way home, accompanied by his faithful gang.
    Leonardo was as vast as ever, but a year's hard dieting and the discovery of a new talent had wrought quite a change in his physique. As Uncle Francisco delightedly told anyone who would listen, Leonardo had recently become the Junior Heavyweight Inter-school Boxing Champion of the Southeast. 'The noble sport', as Uncle Francisco called it, had made Leonardo even more formidable than he had seemed to Roberto in their primary school days when he had served as Leonardo's first punchball. Roberto was not remotely afraid of his cousin any more but he still didn't think that Leonardo earning to punch harder and more accurately was cause for celebration. Neighbourhood children all around were terrified of him - even more terrified than they were of 'that Gonzales boy' who, they lad been warned, was a hardened hooligan and attended St Brutus's secure Centre for Incurably Criminal Boys.
    Roberto watched the dark figures crossing the grass and wondered who they had been beating up tonight. Look round, Roberto found himself thinking as he watched them. Come on . . . look round . . . I'm sitting here all alone . . . come and have a go . . .
    If Leonardo's friends saw him sitting here, they would be sure to make a beeline for him, and what would Leonardo do then? He wouldn't want to lose face in front of the gang, but he'd be terrified of provoking Roberto . . . it would be really fun to watch Leonardo's dilemma, to taunt him, watch him, with him powerless to respond . . . and if any of the others tried hitting Roberto, he was ready - he had his wand. Let them try . . . he'd love to vent some of his frustration on the boys who had once made his life hell.
    But they didn't turn around, they didn't see him, they were almost at the railings. Roberto mastered the impulse to call after them . . . seeking a fight was not a smart move . . . he must not use magic he would be risking expulsion again.
    The voices of Leonardo's gang died away; they were out of sight, heading along Magnolia Road.
    There you go, Gustavo, Roberto thought dully. Nothing rash. Kept my nose clean. Exactly the opposite of what you'd have done.
    He got to his feet and stretched. Aunt Beatriz and Uncle Francisco seemed to feel that whenever Leonardo turned up was the right time to be home, and any time after that was much too late. Uncle Francisco had threatened to lock Roberto in the shed if he came home alter Leonardo ever again, so, stifling a yawn, and still scowling, Roberto set off towards the park gate.
    Magnolia Road, like Privet Drive, was full of large, square houses with perfectly manicured lawns, all owned by large, square owners who drove very clean cars similar to Uncle Francisco's. Roberto preferred Little Whinging by night, when the curtained windows made patches of jewel-bright colour in the darkness and he ran no danger of hearing disapproving mutters about his 'delinquent' appearance when he passed the householders. He walked quickly, so that halfway along Magnolia Road Leonardo's gang came into view again; they were saying their farewells at the entrance to Magnolia Crescent. Roberto stepped into the shadow of a large lilac tree and waited.
    '. . . squealed like a pig, didn't he?' Malcolm was saying, to guffaws from the others.
    'Nice right hook, Big D,' said Piers.
    'Same time tomorrow?' said Leonardo.
    'Round at my place, my parents will be out,' said Gordon.
    'See you then,' said Leonardo.
    'Bye, Dud!'
    'See ya, Big D!'
    Roberto waited for the rest of the gang to move on before setting off again. When their voices had faded once more he headed around the corner into Magnolia Crescent and by walking very quickly he soon came within hailing distance of Leonardo, who was strolling along at his ease, humming tunelessly.
    'Hey, Big D!'
    Leonardo turned.
    'Oh,' he grunted. 'It's you.'
    'How long have you been "Big D" then?' said Roberto.
    'Shut it,' snarled Leonardo, turning away.
    'Cool name,' said Roberto, grinning and falling into step beside is cousin. 'But you'll always be "Ickle Diddykins" to me.'
    'I said, SHUT IT!' said Leonardo, whose ham-like hands had curled into fists.
    'Don't the boys know that's what your mum calls you?'
    'Shut your face.'
    'You don't tell her to shut her face. What about "Popkin" and "Dinky Diddydums", can I use them then?'
    Leonardo said nothing. The effort of keeping himself from hitting Roberto seemed to demand all his self-control.
    'So who've you been beating up tonight?' Roberto asked, his grin fading. 'Another ten-year-old? I know you did Mark Evans two nights ago - '
    'He was asking for it,' snarled Leonardo.
    'Oh yeah?'
    'He cheeked me.'
    'Yeah? Did he say you look like a pig that's been taught to walk on its hind legs? 'Cause that's not cheek, Dud, that's true.'
    A muscle was twitching in Leonardo's jaw. It gave Roberto enormous satisfaction to know how furious he was making Leonardo; he felt as though he was siphoning off his own frustration into his cousin, the only outlet he had.
    They turned right down the narrow alleyway where Roberto had first seen Gustavo and which formed a short cut between Magnolia Crescent and Wisteria Walk. It was empty and much darker than the streets it linked because there were no streetlamps. Their footsteps were muffled between garage walls on one side and a high fence on the other.
    Think you're a big man carrying that thing, don't you?' Leonardo said after a few seconds.
    'What thing?'
    That - that thing you are hiding.'
    Roberto grinned again.
    'Not as stupid as you look, are you, Dud? But I s'pose, if you were, you wouldn't be able to walk and talk at the same time.'
    Roberto pulled out his wand. He saw Leonardo look sideways at it.
    'You're not allowed,' Leonardo said at once. 'I know you're not. You'd get expelled from that freak school you go to.'
    'How d'you know they haven't changed the rules, Big D?'
    They haven't,' said Leonardo, though he didn't sound completely convinced.
    Roberto laughed softly.
    'You haven't got the guts to take me on without that thing, have you?' Leonardo snarled.
    'Whereas you just need four mates behind you before you can beat up a ten year old. You know that boxing title you keep banging on about? How old was your opponent? Seven? Eight?'
    'He was sixteen, for your information,' snarled Leonardo, 'and he was out cold for twenty minutes after I'd finished with him and he was twice as heavy as you. You just wait till I tell Dad you had that thing out -
    'Running to Daddy now, are you? Is his ickle boxing champ frightened of nasty Roberto's wand?'
    'Not this brave at night, are you?' sneered Leonardo.
    'This is night, Diddykins. That's what we call it when it goes all dark like this.'
    'I mean when you're in bed!' Leonardo snarled.
    He had stopped walking. Roberto stopped too, staring at his cousin.
    From the little he could see of Leonardo's large face, he was wearing a strangely triumphant look.
    'What d'you mean, I'm not brave when I'm in bed?' said Roberto, Completely nonplussed. 'What am I supposed to be frightened of, pillows or something?'
    'I heard you last night,' said Leonardo breathlessly. Talking in your sleep. Moaning.'
    'What d'you mean?' Roberto said again, but there was a cold, plunging sensation in his stomach. He had revisited the graveyard last night in his dreams.
    Leonardo gave a harsh bark of laughter, then adopted a high-pitched whimpering voice.
    ' "Don't kill Nicolas! Don't kill Nicolas!" Who's Nicolas - your boyfriend?'
    'I - you're lying,' said Roberto automatically. But his mouth had gone dry. He knew Leonardo wasn't lying - how else would he know about Nicolas?
    ' "Dad! Help me, Dad! He's going to kill me, Dad! Boo hoo!'' '
    'Shut up,' said Roberto quietly. 'Shut up, Leonardo, I'm warning you!'
    ' "Come and help me, Dad! Mum, come and help me! He's killed Nicolas! Dad, help me! He's going to - " Don't you point that thing at me!'
    Leonardo backed into the alley wall. Roberto was pointing the wand directly at Leonardo's heart. Roberto could feel fourteen years' hatred of Leonardo pounding in his veins - what wouldn't he give to strike now, to jinx Leonardo so thoroughly he'd have to crawl home like an insect, struck dumb, sprouting feelers . . .
    'Don't ever talk about that again,' Roberto snarled. 'D'you understand me?'
    'Point that thing somewhere else!'
    'I said, do you understand me?'
    'Point it somewhere else!'
    'DO YOU UNDERSTAND ME?'
    'GET THAT THING AWAY FROM - '
    Leonardo gave an odd. shuddering gasp, as though he had been doused in icy water.
    Something had happened to the night. The star-strewn indigo sky was suddenly pitch black and lightless - the stars, the moon, the misty streetlamps at either end of the alley had vanished. The distant rumble of cars and the whisper of trees had gone. The balmy evening was suddenly piercingly, bitingly cold. They were surrounded by total, impenetrable, silent darkness, as though some giant hand had dropped a thick, icy mantle over the entire alleyway, blinding them.
    For a split second Roberto thought he had done magic without meaning to, despite the fact that he'd been resisting as hard as he could - then his reason caught up with his senses - he didn't have the power to turn off the stars. He turned his head this way and that, trying to see something, but the darkness pressed on his eyes like a weightless veil.
    Leonardo's terrified voice broke in Roberto's ear.
    'W-what are you d-doing? St-stop it!'
    'I'm not doing anything! Shut up and don't move!'
    'I c-can't see! I've g-gone blind! I - '
    'I said shut up!'
    Roberto stood stock still, turning his sightless eyes left and right. The cold was so intense he was shivering all over; goose bumps had erupted up his arms and the hairs on the back of his neck were standing up - he opened his eyes to their fullest extent, staring blankly around, unseeing.
    It was impossible . . . they couldn't be here . . . not in Little Whinging . . . he strained his ears . . . he would hear them before he saw them . . .
    'I'll t-tell Dad!' Leonardo whimpered. 'W-where are you? What are you d-do-?'
    'Will you shut up?' Roberto hissed, 'I'm trying to lis- '
    But he fell silent. He had heard just the thing he had been dreading.
    There was something in the alleyway apart from themselves, something that was drawing long, hoarse, rattling breaths. Roberto felt a horrible jolt of dread as he stood trembling in the freezing air.
    'C-cut it out! Stop doing it! I'll h-hit you, I swear I will!'
    'Leonardo, shut - '
    WHAM.
    A fist made contact with the side of Roberto's head, lifting him off his feet. Small white lights popped in front of his eyes. For the second time in an hour Roberto felt as though his head had been cleaved in two; next moment, he had landed hard on the ground and his wand had flown out of his hand.
    'You moron, Leonardo!' Roberto yelled, his eyes watering with pain as he scrambled to his hands and knees, feeling around frantically n the blackness. He heard Leonardo blundering away, hitting the alley fence, stumbling.
    'LEONARDO, COME BACK! YOU'RE RUNNING RIGHT AT IT!'
    There was a horrible squealing yell and Leonardo's footsteps topped. At the same moment, Roberto felt a creeping chill behind him that could mean only one thing. There was more than one.
    'LEONARDO, KEEP YOUR MOUTH SHUT! WHATEVER YOU DO, KEEP YOUR MOUTH SHUT! Wand!' Roberto muttered frantically, his hands flying over the ground like spiders. 'Where's - wand - come on - lumos!'
    He said the spell automatically, desperate for light to help him n his search - and to his disbelieving relief, light flared inches from his right hand - the wand tip had ignited. Roberto snatched it up, scrambled to his feet and turned around.
    His stomach turned over.
    A towering, hooded figure was gliding smoothly towards him, hovering over the ground, no feet or face visible beneath its robes, sucking on the night as it came.
    Stumbling backwards, Roberto raised his wand.
    'Expecto patronum!'
    A silvery wisp of vapour shot from the tip of the wand and the Dementor slowed, but the spell hadn't worked properly; tripping over his own feet, Roberto retreated further as the Dementor bore down upon him, panic fogging his brain - concentrate -
    A pair of grey, slimy, scabbed hands slid from inside the Dementor's robes, reaching for him. A rushing noise filled Roberto's ears.
    'Expecto patronum!'
    His voice sounded dim and distant. Another wisp of silver smoke, feebler than the last, drifted from the wand - he couldn't do it any more, he couldn't work the spell.
    There was laughter inside his own head, shrill, high-pitched laughter . . . he could smell the Dementor's putrid, death-cold breath filling his own lungs, drowning him - think . . . something happy . . .
    But there was no happiness in him . . . the Dementor's icy fingers were closing on his throat - the high-patched laughter was growing louder and louder, and a voice spoke inside his head: 'Bow to death, Roberto . . . it might even be painless . . . I would not know . . . I have never died
    He was never going to see Diego and Carolina again -
    And their faces burst clearly into his mind as he fought for breath.
    'EXPECTO PATDIEGOUM!'
    An enormous silver stag erupted from the tip of Roberto's wand; it's antlers caught the Dementor in the place where the heart should have been; it was thrown backwards, weightless as darkness, and as the stag charged, the Dementor swooped away, bat-like and defeated.
    'THIS WAY!' Roberto shouted at the stag. Wheeling around, he sprinted down the alleyway, holding the lit wand aloft. 'LEONARDO? LEONARDO!'
    He had run barely a dozen steps when he reached them: Leonardo was curled up on the ground, his arms clamped over his face. A second Dementor was crouching low over him, gripping his wrists in its slimy hands, prising them slowly, almost lovingly apart, lowering its hooded head towards Leonardo's face as though about to kiss him.
    'GET IT!' Roberto bellowed, and with a rushing, roaring sound, the silver stag he had conjured came galloping past him. The Dementor's eyeless face was barely an inch from Leonardo's when the silver antlers caught it; the thing was thrown up into the air and, like its fellow, it soared away and was absorbed into the darkness; the stag cantered to the end of the alleyway and dissolved into silver mist.
    Moon, stars and streetlamps burst back into life. A warm breeze swept the alleyway. Trees rustled in neighbouring gardens and the mundane rumble of cars in Magnolia Crescent filled the air again.
    Roberto stood quite still, all his senses vibrating, taking in the abrupt return to normality. After a moment, he became aware that his T-shirt was sticking to him; he was drenched in sweat.
    He could not believe what had just happened. Dementors here, in Little Whinging.
    Leonardo lay curled up on the ground, whimpering and shaking. Roberto bent down to see whether he was in a fit state to stand up, but then he heard loud, running footsteps behind him. Instinctively raising his wand again, he span on his heel to face the newcomer.
    Mrs Figg, their batty old neighbour, came panting into sight. Her grizzled grey hair was escaping from its hairnet, a clanking String shopping bag was swinging from her wrist and her feet were halfway out of her tartan carpet slippers. Roberto made to stow his wand hurriedly out of sight, but -
    'Don't put it away, idiot boy!' she shrieked. 'What if there are more of them around? Oh, I'm going to kill Mundungus Fletcher!'
- CHAPTER TWO -
A Peck of Owls
'What?' said Roberto blankly.
    'He left!' said Mrs Figg, wringing her hands. 'Left to see someone about a batch of cauldrons that fell off the back of a broom! I told him I'd flay him alive if he went, and now look! Dementors! It's just lucky I put Mr Tibbles on the case! But we haven't got time to stand around! Hurry, now, we've got to get you back! Oh, the trouble this is going to cause! I will kill him!'
    'But - ' The revelation that his batty old cat-obsessed neighbour knew what Dementors were was almost as big a shock to Roberto as meeting two of them down the alleyway. 'You're - you're a witch?'
    'I'm a Squib, as Mundungus knows full well, so how on earth was I supposed to help you fight off Dementors? He left you completely without cover when I'd warned him - '
    This Mundungus has been following me? Hang on - it was him! He Disapparated from the front of my house!'
    'Yes, yes, yes, but luckily I'd stationed Mr Tibbles under a car just in case, and Mr Tibbles came and warned me, but by the time I got to your house you'd gone - and now - oh, what's Dominguez going to say? You!' she shrieked at Leonardo, still supine on the alley floor. 'Get your fat bottom off the ground, quick!'
    'You know Dominguez?' said Roberto, staring at her.
    'Of course I know Dominguez, who doesn't know Dominguez? But come on - I'll be no help if they come back, I've never so much as Transfigured a teabag.'
    She stooped down, seized one of Leonardo's massive arms in her wizened hands and tugged.
    'Get up, you useless lump, get up!'
    But Leonardo either could not or would not move. He remained on the ground, trembling and ashen-faced, his mouth shut very tight.
    'I'll do it.' Roberto took hold of Leonardo's arm and heaved. With an enormous effort he managed to hoist him to his feet. Leonardo seemed to be on the point of fainting. His small eyes were rolling in their sockets and sweat was beading his face; the moment Roberto let go of him he swayed dangerously.
    'Hurry up!' said Mrs Figg hysterically.
    Roberto pulled one of Leonardo's massive arms around his own shoulders and dragged him towards the road, sagging slightly under the weight. Mrs Figg tottered along in front of them, peering anxiously around the corner.
    'Keep your wand out,' she told Roberto, as they entered Wisteria Walk. 'Never mind the Statute of Secrecy now, there's going to be hell to pay anyway, we might as well be hanged for a dragon as an egg. Talk about the Reasonable Restriction of Underage Sorcery . . . this was exactly what Dominguez was afraid of - What's that at the end of the street? Oh, it's just Mr Prentice . . . don't put your wand away, boy, don't I keep telling you I'm no use?'
    It was not easy to hold a wand steady and haul Leonardo along at the same time. Roberto gave his cousin an impatient dig in the ribs, but Leonardo seemed to have lost all desire for independent movement. He was slumped on Roberto's shoulder, his large feet dragging along the ground.
    'Why didn't you tell me you're a Squib, Mrs Figg?' asked Roberto, panting with the effort to keep walking. 'All those times I came round your house - why didn't you say anything?'
    'Dominguez's orders. I was to keep an eye on you but not say anything, you were too young. I'm sorry I gave you such a miserable time, Roberto, but the Carrizos would never have let you come if they'd thought you enjoyed it. It wasn't easy, you know . . . but oh my word,' she said tragically, wringing her hands once more, 'when Dominguez hears about this - how could Mundungus have left, he was supposed to be on duty until midnight - where is he? How am I going to tell Dominguez what's happened? I can't Apparate.'
    'I've got an owl, you can borrow her.' Roberto groaned, wondering whether his spine was going to snap under Leonardo's weight.
    'Roberto, you don't understand! Dominguez will need to act as quickly as possible, the Ministry have their own ways of detecting underage magic, they'll know already, you mark my words.'
    'But I was getting rid of Dementors, I had to use magic - they're going to be more worried about what Dementors were doing floating around Wisteria Walk, surely?'
    'Oh, my dear, I wish it were so, but I'm afraid - MUNDUNGUS FLETCHER, I AM GOING TO KILL YOU!'
    There was a loud crack and a strong smell of drink mingled with stale tobacco filled the air as a squat, unshaven man in a tattered overcoat materialised right in front of them. He had short, bandy legs, long straggly ginger hair and bloodshot, baggy eyes that gave him the doleful look of a basset hound. He was also clutching a silvery bundle that Roberto recognised at once as an Invisibility Cloak.
    ' 'S'up, Figgy?' he said, staring from Mrs Figg to Roberto and Leonardo. 'What 'appened to staying undercover?'
    'I'll give you undercover!' cried Mrs Figg. 'Dementors, you useless, skiving sneak thief!'
    'Dementors?' repeated Mundungus, aghast. 'Dementors, 'ere?'
    'Yes, here, you worthless pile of bat droppings, here!' shrieked Mrs Figg. 'Dementors attacking the boy on your watch!'
    'Blimey,' said Mundungus weakly, looking from Mrs Figg to Roberto, and back again. 'Blimey, I - '
    'And you off buying stolen cauldrons! Didn't I tell you not to go? Didn't I?'
    'I - well, I -' Mundungus looked deeply uncomfortable. 'It - it was a very good business opportunity see - '
    Mrs Figg raised the arm from which her string bag dangled and whacked Mundungus around the lace and neck with it; judging by the clanking noise it made it was full of cat food.
    'Ouch - gerroff - gerroff, you mad old bat! Someone's gotta tell Dominguez!'
    'Yes - they - have!' yelled Mrs Figg, swinging the bag of cat food at every bit of Mundungus she could reach. 'And - it - had - better - be - you - and - you - can - tell - him - why - you - weren't - there - to - help!'
    'Keep your 'airnet on!' said Mundungus, his arms over his head, cowering. 'I'm going, I'm going!'
    And with another loud crack, he vanished.
    'I hope Dominguez murders him!' said Mrs Figg furiously. 'Now come on, Roberto, what are you waiting for?'
    Roberto decided not to waste his remaining breath on pointing out that he could barely walk under Leonardo's bulk. He gave the semi-conscious Leonardo a heave and staggered onwards.
    'I'll take you to the door,' said Mrs Figg, as they turned into Privet Drive. 'Just in case there are more of them around . . . oh my word, what a catastrophe . . . and you had to fight them off yourself . . . and Dominguez said we were to keep you from doing magic at all costs . . . well, it's no good crying over spilt potion, I suppose . . . but the cat's among the pixies now.'
    'So,' Roberto panted, 'Dominguez's . . . been having . . . me followed?'
    'Of course he has,' said Mrs Figg impatiently. 'Did you expect him to let you wander around on your own after what happened in June? Good Lord, boy, they told me you were intelligent . . . right . . . get inside and stay there,' she said, as they reached number four. 'I expect someone will be in touch with you soon enough.'
    'What are you going to do?' asked Roberto quickly.
    'I'm going straight home,' said Mrs Figg, staring around the dark street and shuddering. 'I'll need to wait for more instructions. Just stay in the house. Goodnight.'
    'Hang on, don't go yet! I want to know - '
    But Mrs Figg had already set off at a trot, carpet slippers flopping, string bag clanking.
    'Wait!' Roberto shouted after her. He had a million questions to ask anyone who was in contact with Dominguez; but within seconds Mrs Figg was swallowed by the darkness. Scowling, Roberto readjusted Leonardo on his shoulder and made his slow, painful way up number four's garden path.
    The hall light was on. Roberto stuck his wand back inside the waistband of his jeans, rang the bell and watched Aunt Beatriz's outline grow larger and larger, oddly distorted by the rippling glass in the front door.
    'Diddy! About time too, I was getting quite - quite - Diddy, what's the matter?'
    Roberto looked sideways at Leonardo and ducked out from under his arm just in time. Leonardo swayed on the spot for a moment, his face pale green . . . then he opened his mouth and vomited all over the doormat.
    'DIDDY! Diddy, what's the matter with you? Francisco? FRANCISCO!'
    Roberto's uncle came galumphing out of the living room, walrus moustache blowing hither and thither as it always did when he was agitated. He hurried forwards to help Aunt Beatriz negotiate a weak-kneed Leonardo over the threshold while avoiding stepping in the pool of sick.
    'He's ill, Francisco!'
    'What is it, son? What's happened7 Did Mrs Polkiss give you something foreign for tea?'
    'Why are you all covered in dirt, darling? Have you been lying on the ground?'
    'Hang on - you haven't been mugged, have you, son?'
    Aunt Beatriz screamed.
    'Phone the police, Francisco! Phone the police! Diddy, darling, speak to Mummy! What did they do to you?'
    In all the kerfuffle nobody seemed to have noticed Roberto, which suited him perfectly. He managed to slip inside just before Uncle Francisco slammed the door and, while the Carrizos made their noisy progress down the hall towards the kitchen, Roberto moved carefully and quietly towards the stairs.
    'Who did it, son? Give us names. We'll get them, don't worry.'
    'Shh! He's trying to say something, Francisco! What is it, Diddy? Tell Mummy!'
    Roberto's foot was on the bottom-most stair when Leonardo found his voice.
    'Him.'
    Roberto froze, foot on the stair, face screwed up, braced for the explosion.
    'BOY! COME HERE!'
    With a feeling of mingled dread and anger, Roberto removed his foot slowly from the stair and turned to follow the Carrizos.
    The scrupulously clean kitchen had an oddly unreal glitter after the darkness outside. Aunt Beatriz was ushering Leonardo into a chair; he was still very green and clammy-looking. Uncle Francisco was standing in front of the draining board, glaring at Roberto through tiny, narrowed eyes.
    'What have you done to my son?' he said in a menacing growl.
    'Nothing,' said Roberto, knowing perfectly well that Uncle Francisco wouldn't believe him.
    'What did he do to you. Diddy?' Aunt Beatriz said in a quavering voice, now sponging sick from the front of Leonardo's leather jacket. 'Was it - was it you-know-what, darling? Did he use - his thing?'
    Slowly, tremulously, Leonardo nodded.
    'I didn't!' Roberto said sharply, as Aunt Beatriz let out a wail and Uncle Francisco raised his fists. 'I didn't do anything to him, it wasn't me, it was - '
    But at that precise moment a screech owl swooped in through the kitchen window. Narrowly missing the top of Uncle Francisco's head, it soared across the kitchen, dropped the large parchment envelope it was carrying in its beak at Roberto's feet, turned gracefully, the tips of its wings just brushing the top of the fridge, then zoomed outside again and off across the garden.
    'OWLS!' bellowed Uncle Francisco, the well-worn vein in his temple pulsing angrily as he slammed the kitchen window shut. 'OWLS AGAIN! I WILL NOT HAVE ANY MORE OWLS IN MY HOUSE!'
    But Roberto was already ripping open the envelope and pulling out the letter inside, his heart pounding somewhere in the region of his Adam's apple.
Dear Mr Gonzales,
We have received intelligence that you performed the Patronus Charm at twenty-three minutes past nine this evening in a Muggle-inhabited area and in the presence of a Muggle.
    The severity of this breach of the Decree for the Reasonable Restriction of Underage Sorcery has resulted in your expulsion from Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry. Ministry representatives will be calling at your place of residence shortly to destroy your wand.
    As you have already received an official warning for a previous offence under Section 13 of the International Confederation of Warlocks' Statute of Secrecy, we regret to inform you that your presence is required at a disciplinary hearing at the Ministry of Magic at 9 a.m. on the twelfth of August.
    Hoping you are well,
    Yours sincerely,
    Mafalda Hopkirk
    Improper Use of Magic Office
    Ministry of Magic
Roberto read the letter through twice. He was only vaguely aware of Uncle Francisco and Aunt Beatriz talking. Inside his head, all was icy and numb. One fact had penetrated his consciousness like a paralysing dart. He was expelled from Hogwarts. It was all over. He was never going back.
    He looked up at the Carrizos. Uncle Francisco was purple-faced, shouting, his fists still raised; Aunt Beatriz had her arms around Leonardo who was retching again.
    Roberto's temporarily stupefied brain seemed to reawaken. Ministry representatives will be calling at your place of residence shortly to destroy your wand. There was only one thing for it. He would have to run - now. Where he was going to go, Roberto didn't know but he was certain of one thing: at Hogwarts or outside it, he needed his wand. In an almost dreamlike state, he pulled his wand out and turned to leave the kitchen.
    'Where d'you think you're going?' yelled Uncle Venon. When Roberto didn't reply, he pounded across the kitchen to block the doorway into the hall. 'I haven't finished with you, boy!'
    'Get out of the way,' said Roberto quietly.
    'You're going to stay here and explain how my son - '
    'If you don't get out of the way I'm going to jinx you,' said Roberto, raising the wand.
    'You can't pull that one on me!' snarled Uncle Francisco. 'I know
    'You're not allowed to use it outside that madhouse you call a school!'
    The madhouse has chucked me out,' said Roberto. 'So I can do whatever I like. You've got three seconds. One - two - '
    A resounding CRACK filled the kitchen. Aunt Beatriz screamed, Uncle Francisco yelled and ducked, but for the third time that night Roberto was searching for the source of a disturbance he had not made. He spotted it at once: a dazed and ruffled-looking barn owl was sitting outside on the kitchen sill, having just collided with the closed window.
    Ignoring Uncle Francisco's anguished yell of 'OWLS!' Roberto crossed the room at a run and wrenched the window open. The owl stuck out its leg, to which a small roll of parchment was tied, shook its feathers, and took off the moment Roberto had taken the letter. Hands shaking, Roberto unfurled the second message, which was written very hastily and blotchily in black ink.
Roberto -
Dominguez's just arrived at the Ministry and he's trying to sort it all out. DO NOT LEAVE YOUR AUNT AND UNCLE'S HOUSE. DO NOT DO ANY MORE MAGIC. DO NOT SURRENDER YOUR WAND.
    Raul Lopez
Dominguez was trying to sort it all out . . . what did that mean? how much power did Dominguez have to override the Ministry of Magic? Was there a chance that he might be allowed back to Hogwarts, then? A small shoot of hope burgeoned in Roberto's chest, almost immediately strangled by panic - how was he supposed to refuse to surrender his wand without doing magic? He'd have to duel with the Ministry representatives, and if he did that, he'd be lucky to escape Azkaban, let alone expulsion.
    His mind was racing . . . he could run for it and risk being captured by the Ministry, or stay put and wait for them to find him here. He was much more tempted by the former course, but he mew Mr Lopez had his best interests at heart . . . and after all, Dominguez had sorted out much worse than this before.
    'Right,' Roberto said, 'I've changed my mind, I'm staying.'
    He flung himself down at the kitchen table and faced Leonardo and Aunt Beatriz. The Carrizos appeared taken aback at his abrupt change of mind. Aunt Beatriz glanced despairingly at Uncle Francisco. The vein in his purple temple was throbbing worse than ever.
    'Who are all these ruddy owls from?' he growled.
    'The first one was from the Ministry of Magic, expelling me,' said Roberto calmly. He was straining his ears to catch any noises outside, in case the Ministry representatives were approaching, and it was easier and quieter to answer Uncle Francisco's questions than to have him start raging and bellowing. The second one was from my friend Diego's dad, who works at the Ministry.'
    'Ministry of Magic?' bellowed Uncle Francisco. 'People like you in government? Oh, this explains everything, everything, no wonder the country's going to the dogs.'
    When Roberto did not respond, Uncle Francisco glared at him, then spat out, 'And why have you been expelled?'
    'Because I did magic.'
    'AHA!' roared Uncle Francisco, slamming his fist down on top of the fridge, which sprang open; several of Leonardo's low-fat snacks toppled out and burst on the floor. 'So you admit it! What did you do to Leonardo?'
    'Nothing,' said Roberto, slightly less calmly. That wasn't me - '
    'Was,' muttered Leonardo unexpectedly, and Uncle Francisco and Aunt Beatriz instantly made flapping gestures at Roberto to quieten him while they both bent low over Leonardo.
    'Go on, son,' said Uncle Francisco, 'what did he do?'
    Tell us, darling,' whispered Aunt Beatriz.
    'Pointed his wand at me,' Leonardo mumbled.
    'Yeah, I did, but I didn't use - ' Roberto began angrily, but - '
    'SHUT UP!' roared Uncle Francisco and Aunt Beatriz in unison.
    'Go on, son,' repeated Uncle Francisco, moustache blowing about furiously.
    'All went dark,' Leonardo said hoarsely, shuddering 'Everything dark. And then I h-heard . . . things. Inside m-my head.'
    Uncle Francisco and Aunt Beatriz exchanged looks of utter horror. If their least favourite thing in the world was magic - closely followed by neighbours who cheated more than they did on the hosepipe ban - people who heard voices were definitely in the bottom ten. They obviously thought Leonardo was losing his mind.
    'What sort of things did you hear, Popkin?' breathed Aunt Beatriz, very white-faced and with tears in her eyes.
    But Leonardo seemed incapable of saying. He shuddered again and shook his large blond head, and despite the sense of numb dread that had settled on Roberto since the arrival of the first owl, he felt a certain curiosity. Dementors caused a person to relive the worst moments of their life. What would spoiled, pampered, bullying Leonardo have been forced to hear?
    'How come you fell over, son?' said Uncle Francisco, in an unnaturally quiet voice, the kind of voice he might adopt at the Bedside of a very ill person.
    'T-tripped,' said Leonardo shakily. 'And then - '
    He gestured at his massive chest. Roberto understood. Leonardo was remembering the clammy cold that filled the lungs as hope and happiness were sucked out of you.
    'Horrible,' croaked Leonardo. 'Cold. Really cold.'
    'OK,' said Uncle Francisco, in a voice of forced calm, while Aunt Beatriz laid an anxious hand on Leonardo's forehead to feel his temperature. 'What happened then, Dudders?'
    'Felt . . . felt . . . felt . . . as if . . . as if . . .'
    'As if you'd never be happy again,' Roberto supplied dully.
    'Yes,' Leonardo whispered, still trembling.
    'So!' said Uncle Francisco, voice restored to full and considerable volume as he straightened up. 'You put some crackpot spell on my on so he'd hear voices and believe he was - was doomed to misery, or something, did you?'
    'How many times do I have to tell you?' said Roberto, temper and voice both rising. 'It wasn't me! It was a couple of Dementors!'
    'A couple of - what's this codswallop?'
    'De - men - tors,' said Roberto slowly and clearly. Two of them.'
    'And what the ruddy hell are Dementors?'
    'They guard the wizard prison, Azkaban,' said Aunt Beatriz.
    Two seconds of ringing silence followed these words before Aunt Beatriz clapped her hand over her mouth as though she had let slip a disgusting swear word. Uncle Francisco was goggling at her. Roberto's brain reeled. Mrs Figg was one thing - but Aunt Beatriz?
    'How d'you know that?' he asked her, astonished.
    Aunt Beatriz looked quite appalled with herself. She glanced at Uncle Francisco in fearful apology, then lowered her hand slightly to reveal her horsy teeth.
    'I heard - that awful boy - telling her about them - years ago,' she said jerkily.
    'If you mean my mum and dad, why don't you use their names?' said Roberto loudly but Aunt Beatriz ignored him. She seemed horribly flustered.
    Roberto was stunned. Except for one outburst years ago, in the course of which Aunt Beatriz had screamed that Roberto's mother had been a freak, he had never heard her mention her sister. He was astounded that she had remembered this scrap of information about the magical world for so long, when she usually put all her energies, into pretending it didn't exist.
    Uncle Francisco opened his mouth, closed it again, opened it once more, shut it, then, apparently struggling to remember how to talk, opened it for a third time and croaked, 'So - so - they - er - they - er - they actually exist, do they - er - Dementy-whatsits?'
    Aunt Beatriz nodded.
    Uncle Francisco looked from Aunt Beatriz to Leonardo to Roberto as if hoping somebody was going to shout 'April Fool!' When nobody did, he opened his mouth yet again, but was spared the struggle to find more words by the arrival of the third owl of the evening. It zoomed through the still-open window like a feathery cannon-ball and landed with a clatter on the kitchen table, causing all three of the Carrizos to jump with fright. Roberto tore a second official-looking envelope from the owl's beak and ripped it open as the owl swooped back out into the night.
    'Enough - effing - owls,' muttered Uncle Francisco distractedly, stomping over to the window and slamming it shut again.
Dear Mr Gonzales,
Further to our letter of approximately twenty-two minutes ago, the Ministry of Magic has revised its decision to destroy your wand forthwith. You may retain your wand until your disciplinary hearing on the twelfth of August, at which time an official decision will be taken.
    Following discussions with the Headmaster of Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, the Ministry has agreed that the question of your expulsion will also be decided at that time. You should therefore consider yourself suspended from- school pending further enquiries.
    With best wishes,
    Yours sincerely,
    Mafalda Hopkirk
    Improper Use of Magic Office
    Ministry of Magic
Roberto read this letter through three times in quick succession. The miserable knot in his chest loosened slightly with the relief of knowing he was not yet definitely expelled, though his fears were by no means banished. Everything seemed to hang on this hearing on the twelfth of August.
    'Well?' said Uncle Francisco, recalling Roberto to his surroundings. 'What now? Have they sentenced you to anything? Do your lot have the death penalty?' he added as a hopeful afterthought.
    'I've got to go to a hearing,' said Roberto.
    'And they'll sentence you there?'
    'I suppose so.'
    'I won't give up hope, then,' said Uncle Francisco nastily.
    'Well, if that's all,' said Roberto, getting to his feet. He was desperate to be alone, to think, perhaps to send a letter to Diego, Carolina or Gustavo.
    'NO, IT RUDDY WELL IS NOT ALL!' bellowed Uncle Francisco. 'SIT BACK DOWN!'
    'What now?' said Roberto impatiently.
    'LEONARDO!' roared Uncle Francisco. 'I want to know exactly what happened to my son!'
    'FINE!' yelled Roberto, and in his temper, red and gold sparks shot out of the end of his wand, still clutched in his hand. All three Carrizos flinched, looking terrified.
    'Leonardo and I were in the alleyway between Magnolia Crescent and Wisteria Walk,' said Roberto, speaking fast, fighting to control his temper. 'Leonardo thought he'd be smart with me, I pulled out my wand but didn't use it. Then two Dementors turned up - '
    'But what ARE Dementoids?' asked Uncle Francisco furiously. 'What do they DO?'
    'I told you - they suck all the happiness out of you,' said Roberto, 'and if they get the chance, they kiss you - '
    'Kiss you?' said Uncle Francisco, his eyes popping slightly. 'Kiss you?'
    'It's what they call it when they suck the soul out of your mouth.'
    Aunt Beatriz uttered a soft scream.
    'His soul? They didn't take - he's still got his - '
    She seized Leonardo by the shoulders and shook him, as though testing to see whether she could hear his soul rattling around inside hint.
    'Of course they didn't get his soul, you'd know if they had,' said Roberto, exasperated.
    'Fought 'em off, did you, son?' said Uncle Francisco loudly, with the appearance of a man struggling to bring the conversation back on to a plane he understood. 'Gave 'em the old one-two, did you?'
    'You can't give a Dementor the old one-two,' said Roberto through clenched teeth.
    'Why's he all right, then?' blustered Uncle Francisco. 'Why isn't e all empty, then?'
    'Because I used the Patronus - '
    WHOOSH. With a clattering, a whirring of wings and a soft fall of dust, a fourth owl came shooting out of the kitchen fireplace.
    'FOR GOD'S SAKE!' roared Uncle Francisco, pulling great clumps of hair out of his moustache, something he hadn't been driven to do in a long time. 'I WILL NOT HAVE OWLS HERE, I WILL NOT TOLERATE THIS, I TELL YOU!'
    But Roberto was already pulling a roll of parchment from the owl's leg. He was so convinced that this letter had to be from Dominguez, explaining everything - the Dementors, Mrs Figg, what the Ministry was up to, how he, Dominguez, intended to sort everything out - that for the first time in his life he was disappointed to see Gustavo's handwriting. Ignoring Uncle Franciscos ongoing rant about owls, and narrowing his eyes against a second cloud of dust as the most recent owl took off back up the chimney, Roberto read Gustavo's message.
    Raul has just told us what's happened. Don't leave the house again, whatever you do.
    Roberto found this such an inadequate response to everything that had happened tonight that he turned the piece of parchment over, looking for the rest of the letter, but there was nothing else.
    And now his temper was rising again. Wasn't anybody going to say 'well done' for fighting off two Dementors single-handed? Both Mr Lopez and Gustavo were acting as though he'd misbehaved, and were saving their tellings-off until they could ascertain how much damage had been done.
    '. . . a peck, I mean, pack of owls shooting in and out of my house. I won't have it, boy, I won't - '
    'I can't stop the owls coming,' Roberto snapped, crushing Gustavo's letter in his fist.
    'I want the truth about what happened tonight!' barked Uncle Francisco. 'If it was Demenders who hurt Leonardo, how come you've been expelled? You did you-know-what, you've admitted, it!'
    Roberto took a deep, steadying breath. His head was beginning to ache again. He wanted more than anything to get out of the kitchen, and away from the Carrizos.
    'I did the Patronus Charm to get rid of the Dementors,' he said, forcing himself to remain calm. 'It's the only thing that works against them.'
    'But what were Dementoids doing in Little Whinging?' said Uncle Francisco in an outraged tone.
    'Couldn't tell you,' said Roberto wearily. 'No idea.'
    His head was pounding in the glare of the strip-lighting now. His anger was ebbing away. He felt drained, exhausted. The Carrizos were all staring at him.
    'It's you,' said Uncle Francisco forcefully. 'It's got something to do with you, boy, I know it. Why else would they turn up here? Why else would they be down that alleyway? You've got to be the only - the only - ' Evidently, he couldn't bring himself to say the word 'wizard'. The only you-know-what for miles.'
    'I don't know why they were here.'
    But at Uncle Francisco's words, Roberto's exhausted brain had ground back into action. Why had the Dementors come to Little Whinging? How could it be coincidence that they had arrived in the alleyway where Roberto was? Had they been sent? Had the Ministry of Magic lost control of the Dementors? Had they deserted Azkaban and joined Salvador, as Dominguez had predicted they would?
    'These Demembers guard some weirdo prison?' asked Uncle Francisco, lumbering along in the wake of Roberto's train of thought.
    'Yes,' said Roberto.
    If only his head would stop hurting, if only he could just leave the kitchen and get to his dark bedroom and think . . .
    'Oho! They were coming to arrest you!' said Uncle Francisco, with the triumphant air of a man reaching an unassailable conclusion. That's it, isn't it, boy? You're on the run from the law!'
    'Of course I'm not,' said Roberto, shaking his head as though to scare off a fly, his mind racing now.
    Then why - ?'
    'He must have sent them,' said Roberto quietly, more to himself than to Uncle Francisco.
    'What's that? Who must have sent them?'
    'Lord Salvador,' said Roberto.
    He registered dimly how strange it was that the Carrizos, who flinched, winced and squawked if they heard words like 'wizard', 'magic' or 'wand', could hear the name of the most evil wizard of all time without the slightest tremor.
    'Lord - hang on,' said Uncle Francisco, his face screwed up, a look of dawning comprehension coming into his piggy eyes. 'I've heard that name . . . that was the one who - '
    'Murdered my parents, yes,' Roberto said dully.
    'But he's gone,' said Uncle Francisco impatiently, without the slightest sign that the murder of Roberto's parents might be a painful topic. That giant bloke said so. He's gone.'
    'He's back,' said Roberto heavily.
    It felt very strange to be standing here in Aunt Beatriz's surgically clean kitchen, beside the top'-of-the-range fridge and the wide-screen television, talking calmly of Lord Salvador to Uncle Francisco. The arrival of the Dementors in Little Whinging seemed to have breached the great, invisible wall that divided the relentlessly non-magical world of Privet Drive and the world beyond. Roberto's two lives had somehow become fused and everything had been turned upside-down; the Carrizos were asking for details about the magical world, and Mrs Figg knew Alfonso Dominguez; Dementors were soaring around Little Whinging, and he might never return to Hogwarts. Roberto's head throbbed more painfully.
    'Back?' whispered Aunt Beatriz.
    She was looking at Roberto as she had never looked at him before. And all of a sudden, for the very first time in his life, Roberto fully appreciated that Aunt Beatriz was his mother's sister. He could not have said why this hit him so very powerfully at this moment. All he knew was that he was not the only person in the room who had an inkling of what Lord Salvador being back might mean. Aunt Beatriz had never in her life looked at him like that before. Her large, pale eyes (so unlike her sisters) were not narrowed in dislike or anger, they were wide and fearful. The furious pretence that Aunt Beatriz had maintained all Roberto's life - that there was no magic and no world other than the world she inhabited with Uncle Francisco - seemed to have fallen away.
    'Yes,' Roberto said, talking directly to Aunt Beatriz now. ;He came back a month ago. I saw him.'
    Her hands found Leonardo's massive leather-clad shoulders and clutched them.
    'Hang on,' said Uncle Francisco, looking from his wife to Roberto and back again, apparently dazed and confused by the unprecedented understanding that seemed to have sprung up between them. 'Hang on. This Lord Voldything's back, you say.'
    'Yes.'
    The one who murdered your parents.'
    'Yes.'
    'And now he's sending Dismembers after you?'
    'Looks like it,' said Roberto.
    T see,' said Uncle Francisco, looking from his white-faced wife to Roberto and hitching up his trousers. He seemed to be swelling, his
    great purple face stretching before Roberto's eyes. 'Well, that settles it,' he said, his shirt front straining as he inflated himself, 'you can get out of this house, boy!'
    'What?' said Roberto.
    'You heard me - OUT!' Uncle Francisco bellowed, and even Aunt Beatriz and Leonardo jumped. 'OUT! OUT! I should've done this years ago! Owls treating the place like a rest home, puddings exploding, half the lounge destroyed, Leonardo's tail, Marge bobbing around on the ceiling and that flying Ford Anglia - OUT! OUT! You've had it! You're history! You're not staying here if some loony's after you, you're not endangering my wife and son, you're not bringing trouble down on us. It you're going the same way as your useless parents, I've had it! OUT!'
    Roberto stood rooted to the spot. The letters from the Ministry, Mr Lopez and Gustavo were all crushed in his left hand. Don't leave the house again, whatever you do. DO NOT LEAVE YOUR AUNT AND UNCLE'S HOUSE.
    'You heard me!' said Uncle Francisco, bending forwards now, his massive purple face coming so close to Roberto's, he actually felt flecks of spit hit his face. 'Get going! You were all keen to leave half an hour ago! I'm right behind you! Get out and never darken our doorstep again! Why we ever kept you in the first place, I don't know, Marge was right, it should have been the orphanage. We were too damn soft for our own good, thought we could squash it out of you, thought we could turn you normal, but you've been rotten from the beginning and I've had enough - owls!'
    The fifth owl zoomed down the chimney so fast it actually hit the floor before zooming into the air again with a loud screech. Roberto raised his hand to seize the letter, which was in a scarlet envelope, but it soared straight over his head, flying directly at Aunt Beatriz, who let out a scream and ducked, her arms over her face. The owl dropped the red envelope on her head, turned, and flew straight back up the chimney.
    Roberto darted forwards to pick up the letter, but Aunt Beatriz beat him to it.
    'You can open it if you like,' said Roberto, 'but I'll hear what it says anyway. That's a Howler.'
    'Let go of it, Beatriz!' roared Uncle Francisco. 'Don't touch it, it could be dangerous!'
    'It's addressed to me,' said Aunt Beatriz in a shaking voice. 'It's addressed to me, Francisco, look! Mrs Beatriz Carrizo, The Kitchen, Number Four, Privet Drive - '
    She caught her breath, horrified. The red envelope had begun to smoke.
    'Open it!' Roberto urged her. 'Get it over with! It'll happen anyway.'
    'No.'
    Aunt Beatriz's hand was trembling. She looked wildly around the kitchen as though looking for an escape route, but too late - the envelope burst into flames. Aunt Beatriz screamed and dropped it.
    An awful voice filled the kitchen, echoing in the confined space, issuing from the burning letter on the table.
    'Remember my last, Beatriz.'
    Aunt Beatriz looked as though she might faint. She sank into the chair beside Leonardo, her face in her hands. The remains of the envelope smouldered into ash in the silence.
    'What is this?' Uncle Francisco said hoarsely. 'What - I don't - 'Beatriz?'
    Aunt Beatriz said nothing. Leonardo was staring stupidly at his mother, his mouth hanging open. The silence spiralled horribly. Roberto was watching his aunt, utterly bewildered, his head throbbing fit to burst.
    'Beatriz, dear?' said Uncle Francisco timidly. 'P-Beatriz?'
    She raised her head. She was still trembling. She swallowed.
    'The boy - the boy will have to stay, Francisco,' she said weakly.
    'W-what?'
    'He stays,' she said. She was not looking at Roberto. She got to her feet again.
    'He . . . but Beatriz . . .'
    'If we throw him out, the neighbours will talk,' she said. She was rapidly regaining her usual brisk, snappish manner, though she was still very pale. 'They'll ask awkward questions, they'll want to know where he's gone. We'll have to keep him.'
    Uncle Francisco was deflating like an old tyre.
    'But Beatriz, dear - '
    Aunt Beatriz ignored him. She turned to Roberto.
    'You're to stay in your room,' she said. 'You're not to leave the house. Now get to bed.'
    Roberto didn't move.
    'Who was that Howler from?'
    'Don't ask questions,' Aunt Beatriz snapped.
    'Are you in touch with wizards?'
    'I told you to get to bed!'
    'What did it mean? Remember the last what?'
    'Go to bed!'
    'How come - ?'
    'YOU HEARD YOUR AUNT, NOW GO UP TO BED!'
- CHAPTER THREE -
The Advance Guard
I've just been attacked by Dementors and I might be expelled from Hogwarts. I want to know what's going on and when I'm going to get out of here.
    Roberto copied these words on to three separate pieces of parchment the moment he reached the desk in his dark bedroom. He addressed the first to Gustavo, the second to Diego and the third to Carolina. His owl, Hedwig, was off hunting; her cage stood empty on the desk. Roberto paced the bedroom waiting for her to come back, his head pounding, his brain too busy for sleep even though his eyes stung and itched with tiredness. His back ached from hauling Leonardo home, and the two lumps on his head where the window and Leonardo had hit him were throbbing painfully.
    Up and down he paced, consumed with anger and frustration, grinding his teeth and clenching his fists, casting angry looks out at the empty, star-strewn sky every time he passed the window. Dementors sent to get him, Mrs Figg and Mundungus Fletcher tailing him in secret, then suspension from Hogwarts and a hearing at the Ministry of Magic - and still no one was telling him what was going on.
    And what, what, had that Howler been about? Whose voice had echoed so horribly, so menacingly, through the kitchen?
    Why was he still trapped here without information? Why was everyone treating him like some naughty kid? Don't do any more magic, stay in the house . . .
    He kicked his school trunk as he passed it, but far from relieving his anger he felt worse, as he now had a sharp pain in his toe to deal with in addition to the pain in the rest of his body
    Just as he limped past the window, Hedwig soared through it with a soft rustle of wings like a small ghost.
    'About time!' Roberto snarled, as she landed lightly on top of her cage. 'You can put that down, I've got work for you!'
    Hedwig's large, round, amber eyes gazed at him reproachfully over the dead frog clamped in her beak.
    'Come here,' said Roberto, picking up the three small rolls of parchment and a leather thong and tying the scrolls to her scaly leg. Take these straight to Gustavo, Diego and Carolina and don't come back here without good long replies. Keep pecking them till they've written decent-length answers if you've got to. Understand?'
    Hedwig gave a muffled hooting noise, her beak still full of frog.
    'Get going, then,' said Roberto.
    She took off immediately. The moment she'd gone, Roberto threw himself down on his bed without undressing and stared at the dark ceiling. In addition to every other miserable feeling, he now felt guilty that he'd been irritable with Hedwig; she was the only friend he had at number four, Privet Drive But he'd make it up to her when she came back with the answers from Gustavo, Diego and Carolina.
    They were bound to write back quickly; they couldn't possibly ignore a Dementor attack. He'd probably wake up tomorrow to three fat letters full of sympathy and plans for his immediate removal to The Burrow. And with that comforting idea, sleep rolled over him, stifling all further thought.
*
But Hedwig didn't return next morning. Roberto spent the day in his bedroom, leaving it only to go to the bathroom. Three times that day Aunt Beatriz shoved food into his room through the cat-Flap Uncle Francisco had installed three summers ago. Every time Roberto heard her approaching he tried to question her about the Howler, but he might as well have interrogated the doorknob for all the answers he got. Otherwise, the Carrizos kept well clear of his bedroom. Roberto couldn't see the point of forcing his company on them; another row would achieve nothing except perhaps make him so angry he'd perform more illegal magic.
    So it went on for three whole days. Roberto was alternately filled with restless energy that made him unable to settle to anything, during which time he paced his bedroom, furious at the whole lot of them for leaving him to stew in this mess; and with a lethargy so complete that he could lie on his bed for an hour at a time, staring dazedly into space, aching with dread at the thought of the Ministry hearing.
    What if they ruled against him? What if he was expelled and his wand was snapped in half? What would he do, where would he go? He could not return to living full-time with the Carrizos, not now he knew the other world, the one to which he really belonged. Might he be able to move into Gustavo's house, as Gustavo had suggested a year ago, before he had been forced to flee from the Ministry? Would Roberto be allowed to live there alone, given that he was still underage? Or would the matter of where he went next be decided for him? Had his breach of the International Statute of Secrecy been severe enough to land him in a cell in Azkaban? Whenever this thought occurred, Roberto invariably slid off his bed and began pacing again.
    On the fourth night after Hedwig's departure Roberto was lying in one of his apathetic phases, staring at the ceiling, his exhausted mind quite blank, when his uncle entered his bedroom. Roberto looked slowly around at him. Uncle Francisco was wearing his best suit and an expression of enormous smugness.
    'We're going out,' he said.
    'Sorry?'
    'We - that is to say, your aunt, Leonardo and I - are going out.'
    'Fine,' said Roberto dully, looking back at the ceiling.
    'You are not to leave your bedroom while we are away.'
    'OK.'
    'You are not to touch the television, the stereo, or any of our possessions.'
    'Right.'
    'You are not to steal food from the fridge.'
    'OK.'
    'I am going to lock your door.'
    'You do that.'
    Uncle Francisco glared at Roberto, clearly suspicious of this lack of argument, then stomped out of the room and closed the door behind him. Roberto heard the key turn in the lock and Uncle Francisco's footsteps walking heavily down the stairs. A few minutes later he heard the slamming of car doors, the rumble of an engine, and the unmistakeable sound of the car sweeping out of the drive.
    Roberto had no particular feeling about the Carrizos leaving. It made no difference to him whether they were in the house or not. He could not even summon the energy to get up and turn on his bedroom light. The room grew steadily darker around him as he lay listening to the night sounds through the window he kept open all the time, waiting for the blessed moment when Hedwig returned.
    The empty house creaked around him. The pipes gurgled. Roberto ay there in a kind of stupor, thinking of nothing, suspended in misery.
    Then, quite distinctly, he heard a crash in the kitchen below.
    He sat bolt upright, listening intently. The Carrizos couldn't be back, it was much too soon, and in any case he hadn't heard their car.
    There was silence for a few seconds, then voices.
    Burglars, he thought, sliding off the bed on to his feet - but a split second later it occurred to him that burglars would keep their voices down, and whoever was moving around in the kitchen was certainly not troubling to do so.
    He snatched up his wand from the bedside table and stood lacing his bedroom door, listening with all his might. Next moment, he jumped as the lock gave a loud click and his door swung open.
    Roberto stood motionless, staring through the open doorway at the dark upstairs landing, straining his ears for further sounds, but none came. He hesitated for a moment, then moved swiftly and silently out of his room to the head of the stairs.
    His heart shot upwards into his throat. There were people standing in the shadowy hall below, silhouetted against the streetlight glowing through the glass door; eight or nine of them, all, as far as he could see, looking up at him.
    'Lower your wand, boy, before you take someone's eye out,' said a low, growling voice.
    Roberto's heart was thumping uncontrollably. He knew that voice, but he did not lower his wand.
    'Professor Acosta?' he said uncertainly.
    'I don't know so much about "Professor",' growled the voice, 'never got round to much teaching, did I? Get down here, we want to see you properly.'
    Roberto lowered his wand slightly but did not relax his grip on it, nor did he move. He had very good reason to be suspicious. He had recently spent nine months in what he had thought was Mad-Eye Acosta's company only to find out that it wasn't Acosta at all, but an impostor; an impostor, moreover, who had tried to kill Roberto before being unmasked. But before he could make a decision about what to do next, a second, slightly hoarse voice floated upstairs.
    'It's all right, Roberto. We've come to take you away.'
    Roberto's heart leapt. He knew that voice, too, though he hadn't heard it for over a year.
    'P-Professor Cardozo?' he said disbelievingly. 'Is that you?'
