    'Why are we all standing in the dark?' said a third voice, this one completely unfamiliar, a woman's. 'Lumos.'
    A wand-tip flared, illuminating the hall with magical light. Roberto blinked. The people below were crowded around the loot of the stairs, gazing up at him intently, some craning their heads for a better look.
    Pedro Cardozo stood nearest to him. Though still quite young, Cardozo looked tired and rather ill; he had more grey hairs than when Roberto had last said goodbye to him and his robes were more patched and shabbier than ever. Nevertheless, he was smiling broadly at Roberto, who tried to smile back despite his state of shock.
    'Oooh, he looks just like I thought he would,' said the witch who was holding her lit wand aloft. She looked the youngest there; she had a pale heart-shaped face, dark twinkling eyes, and short spiky hair that was a violent shade of violet. Wotcher, Roberto!'
    'Yeah, I see what you mean, Pedro,' said a bald black wizard standing furthest back - he had a deep, slow voice and wore a single gold hoop in his ear - 'he looks exactly like Ricardo.'
    'Except the eyes,' said a wheezy-voiced, silver-haired wizard at the back. 'Sofia's eyes.'
    Mad-Eye Acosta, who had long grizzled grey hair and a large chunk missing from his nose, was squinting suspiciously at Roberto through his mismatched eyes. One eye was small, dark and beady, the other large, round and electric blue - the magical eye that could see through walls, doors and the back of Acosta's own head.
    'Are you quite sure it's him, Cardozo?' he growled. 'I'I'd be a nice lookout if we bring back some Death Eater impersonating him. We ought to ask him something only the real Gonzales would know. Unless anyone brought any Veritaserum?'
    'Roberto, what form does your Patronus take?' Cardozo asked.
    'A stag,' said Roberto nervously.
    That's him, Mad-Eye,' said Cardozo.
    Very conscious of everybody still staring at him, Roberto descended the stairs, stowing his wand in the back pocket of his jeans as he came.
    'Don't put your wand there, boy!' roared Acosta. 'What if it ignited? Better wizards than you have lost buttocks, you know!'
    'Who d'you know who's lost a buttock?' the violet-haired woman asked Mad-Eye interestedly.
    'Never you mind, you just keep your wand out of your back pocket!' growled Mad-Eye. 'Elementary wand-safety, nobody bothers about it any more.' He stumped off towards the kitchen. 'And I saw that,' he added irritably, as the woman rolled her eyes towards the ceiling.
    Cardozo held out his hand and shook Roberto's.
    'How are you?' he asked, looking closely at Roberto.
    'F-fine . . .'
    Roberto could hardly believe this was real. Four weeks with nothing, not the tiniest hint of a plan to remove him from Privet Drive, and suddenly a whole bunch of wizards was standing matter-of-factly in the house as though this was a long-standing arrangement. He glanced at the people surrounding Cardozo; they were still gazing avidly at him. He felt very conscious of the fact that he had riot combed his hair for four days.
    'I'm - you're really lucky the Carrizos are out . . .' he mumbled.
    'Lucky, ha!' said the violet-haired woman. 'It was me who lured them out of the way. Sent a letter by Muggle post telling them
    they'd been short-listed for the All-England Best Kept Suburban Lawn Competition. They're heading off to the prize-giving right now . . . or they think they are.'
    Roberto had a fleeting vision of Uncle Francisco's face when he realised there was no All-England Best Kept Suburban Lawn Competition.
    'We are leaving, aren't we?' he asked. 'Soon?'
    'Almost at once,' said Cardozo, 'we're just waiting for the all-clear.'
    'Where are we going? The Burrow?' Roberto asked hopefully.
    'Not The Burrow, no,' said Cardozo, motioning Roberto towards the kitchen; the little knot of wizards followed, all still eyeing Roberto curiously. Too risky. We've set up Headquarters somewhere un-detectable. It's taken a while . . .'
    Mad-Eye Acosta was now sitting at the kitchen table swigging from a hip flask, his magical eye spinning in all directions, taking in the Carrizos' many labour-saving appliances.
    This is Alastor Acosta, Roberto,' Cardozo continued, pointing towards Acosta. 'Yeah, I know,' said Roberto uncomfortably. It felt odd to be introduced to somebody he'd thought he'd known for a year.
    'And this is Viviana - '
    'Don't call me Viviana, Pedro,' said the young witch with a shudder, 'it's Perez.'
    'Viviana Perez, who prefers to be known by her surname only,' finished Cardozo.
    'So would you if your fool of a mother had called you Viviana,' muttered Perez.
    'And this is Hector Maldonado.' He indicated the tall black wizard, who bowed. 'Elphias Doge.' The wheezy-voiced wizard nodded. 'Dedalus Diggle - '
    'We've met before,' squeaked the excitable Diggle, dropping his violet-coloured top hat.
    'Emmeline Vance.' A stately-looking witch in an emerald green shawl inclined her head. 'Sturgis Podmore.' A square-jawed wizard with thick straw-coloured hair winked. 'And Hestia Jones.' A pink-cheeked, black-haired witch waved from next to the toaster.
    Roberto inclined his head awkwardly at each of them as they were introduced. He wished they would look at something other than him; it was as though he had suddenly been ushered on-stage. He also wondered why so many of their, were there.
    'A surprising number of people volunteered to come and get you,' said Cardozo, as though he had read Roberto's mind; the corners of his mouth twitched slightly.
    'Yeah, well, the more the better,' said Acosta darkly. 'We're your guard, Gonzales.'
    'We're just waiting for the signal to tell us it's safe to set off,' said Cardozo, glancing out of the kitchen window. 'We've got about fifteen minutes.'
    'Very clean, aren't they, these Muggles?' said the witch called Perez, who was looking around the kitchen with great interest. 'My dad's Muggle-born and he's a right old slob. I suppose it varies, just as it does with wizards?'
    'Er - yeah,' said Roberto. 'Look - ' he turned back to Cardozo, 'what's going on, I haven't heard anything from anyone, what's Vol-?'
    Several of the witches and wizards made odd hissing noises; Dedalus Diggle dropped his hat again and Acosta growled, 'Shut up!'
    'What?' said Roberto.
    'We're not discussing anything here, it's too risky,' said Acosta, turning his normal eye on Roberto. His magical eye remained focused on the ceiling. 'Damn it,' he added angrily, putting a hand up to the magical eye, 'it keeps getting stuck - ever since that scum wore it.'
    And with a nasty squelching sound much like a plunger being pulled from a sink, he popped out his eye.
    'Mad-Eye, you do know that's disgusting, don't you?' said Perez conversationally.
    'Get me a glass of water, would you, Roberto,' requested Acosta.
    Roberto crossed to the dishwasher, took out a clean glass and filled it with water at the sink, still watched eagerly by the band of wizards. Their relentless staring was starting to annoy him.
    'Cheers,' said Acosta, when Roberto handed him the glass. He dropped the magical eyeball into the water and prodded it up and down; the eye whizzed around, staring at them all in turn. 'I want three hundred and sixty degrees visibility on the return journey.'
    'How're we getting - wherever we're going?' Roberto asked.
    'Brooms,' said Cardozo. 'Only way. You're too young to Apparate, they'll be watching the Floo Network and it's more than our life's worth to set up an unauthorised Portkey.'
    'Pedro says you're a good flier,' said Hector Maldonado in his deep voice.
    'He's excellent,' said Cardozo, who was checking his watch. 'Anyway, you'd better go and get packed, Roberto, we want to be ready to go when the signal comes.'
    'I'll come and help you,' said Perez brightly.
    She followed Roberto back into the hall and up the stairs, looking around with much curiosity and interest.
    'Funny place,' she said. 'It's a bit too clean, d'you know what I mean? Bit unnatural. Oh, this is better,' she added, as they entered Roberto's bedroom and he turned on the light.
    His room was certainly much messier than the rest of the house. Confined to it for four days in a very bad mood, Roberto had not bothered tidying up after himself. Most of the books he owned were strewn over the floor where he'd tried to distract himself with each in turn and thrown it aside; Hedwig's cage needed cleaning out and was starting to smell; and his trunk lay open, revealing a jumbled mixture of Muggle clothes and wizards' robes that had spilled on to the floor around it.
    Roberto started picking up books and throwing them hastily into his trunk. Perez paused at his open wardrobe to look critically at her reflection in the mirror on the inside of the door.
    'You know, I don't think violets really my colour,' she said pensively, tugging at a lock of spiky hair. 'D'you think it makes me look a bit peaky?'
    'Er - ' said Roberto, looking up at her over the top of Quidditch Teams of Britain and Ireland.
    'Yeah, it does,' said Perez decisively. She screwed up her eyes in a strained expression as though she was struggling to remember something. A second later, her hair had turned bubble-gum pink.
    'How did you do that?' said Roberto, gaping at her as she opened her eyes again.
    'I'm a Metamorphmagus,' she said, looking back at her reflection and turning her head so that she could see her hair from all directions. 'It means I can change my appearance at will,' she added, spotting Roberto's puzzled expression in the mirror behind her. 'I was born one. I got top marks in Concealment and Disguise during Auror training without any study at all, it was great.'
    'You're an Auror?' said Roberto, impressed. Being a Dark-wizard-catcher was the only career he'd ever considered after Hogwarts.
    'Yeah,' said Perez, looking proud. 'Hector is as well, he's a bit higher up than me, though. I only qualified a year ago. Nearly failed on Stealth and Tracking. I'm dead clumsy, did you hear me break that plate when we arrived downstairs?'
    'Can you learn how to be a Metamorphmagus?' Roberto asked her, straightening up, completely forgetting about packing.
    Perez chuckled.
    'Bet you wouldn't mind hiding that scar sometimes, eh?'
    Her eyes found the lightning-shaped scar on Roberto's forehead.
    'No, I wouldn't mind,' Roberto mumbled, turning away. He did rot like people staring at his scar.
    'Well, you'll have to learn the hard way, I'm afraid,' said Perez. 'Metamorphmagi are really rare, they're born, not made. Most wizards reed to use a wand, or potions, to change their appearance. But we've got to get going, Roberto, we're supposed to be packing,' she added guiltily, looking around at all the mess on the floor.
    'Oh - yeah,' said Roberto, grabbing a few more books.
    'Don't be stupid, it'll be much quicker if I - pack!' cried Perez, waving her wand in a long, sweeping movement over the floor.
    Books, clothes, telescope and scales all soared into the air and flew pell-mell into the trunk.
    'It's not very neat,' said Perez, walking over to the trunk and looking down at the jumble inside. 'My mum's got this knack of getting stuff to fit itself in neatly - she even gets the socks to fold themselves - but I've never mastered how she does it - it's a kind of flick - ' She flicked her wand hopefully.
    One of Roberto's socks gave a feeble sort of wiggle and flopped back on top of the mess in the trunk.
    'Ah, well,' said Perez, slamming the trunk's lid shut, 'at least it's all in. That could do with a bit of cleaning, too.' She pointed her wand at Hedwig's cage. 'Scourgify.' A few feathers and droppings vanished. Well, that's a bit better - I've never quite got the hang of these householdy sort of spells. Right - got everything? Cauldron? Broom? Wow! - A Firebolt?'
    Her eyes widened as they fell on the broomstick in Roberto's right hand. It was his pride and joy, a gift from Gustavo, an international-standard broomstick.
    'And I'm still riding a Comet Two Sixty,' said Perez enviously. 'Ah well . . . wand still in your jeans? Both buttocks still on? OK, let's go. Locomotor trunk.'
    Roberto's trunk rose a few inches into the air. Holding her wand like a conductors baton, Perez made the trunk hover across the room and out of the door ahead of them, Hedwig's cage in her left hand. Roberto followed her down the stairs carrying his broomstick.
    Back in the kitchen Acosta had replaced his eye, which was spinning so fast after its cleaning it made Roberto feel sick to look at it. Hector Maldonado and Sturgis Podmore were examining the microwave and Hestia Jones was laughing at a potato peeler she had come across while rummaging in the drawers. Cardozo was sealing a letter addressed to the Carrizos.
    'Excellent,' said Cardozo, looking up as Perez and Roberto entered. 'We've got about a minute, I think. We should probably get out into the garden so we're ready. Roberto, I've left a letter telling your aunt and uncle not to worry - '
    They won't,' said Roberto.
    ' - that you're safe - '
    That'll just depress them.'
    - and you'll see them next summer.'
    'Do I have to?'
    Cardozo smiled but made no answer.
    'Come here, boy,' said Acosta gruffly, beckoning Roberto towards him with his wand. 'I need to Disillusion you.'
    'You need to what?' said Roberto nervously.
    'Disillusionment Charm,' said Acosta, raising his wand. 'Cardozo says you've got an Invisibility Cloak, but it won't stay on while we're flying; this'll disguise you better. Here you go - '
    He rapped him hard on the top of the head and Roberto felt a curious sensation as though Acosta had just smashed an egg there; cold trickles seemed to be running down his body from the point the wand had struck.
    'Nice one, Mad-Eye,' said Perez appreciatively, staring at Roberto's midriff.
    Roberto looked down at his body, or rather, what had been his body, for it didn't look anything like his any more. It was not invisible; it had simply taken on the exact colour and texture of the kitchen unit behind him. He seemed to have become a human chameleon.
    'Come on,' said Acosta, unlocking the back door with his wand.
    They all stepped outside on to Uncle Francisco's beautifully kept lawn.
    'Clear night,' grunted Acosta, his magical eye scanning the heavens. 'Could've done with a bit more cloud cover. Right, you,' he barked at Roberto, 'we're going to be flying in close formation. Perez'll be right in front of you, keep close on her tail. Cardozo'll be covering you from below. I'm going to be behind you. The rest'll be circling us. We don't break ranks for anything, got me? If one of us is killed - '
    'Is that likely?' Roberto asked apprehensively, but Acosta ignored him.
    ' - the others keep flying, don't stop, don't break ranks. If they take out all of us and you survive, Roberto, the rear guard are standing by to take over; keep flying east and they'll join you.'
    'Stop being so cheerful, Mad-Eye, he'll think we're not taking this seriously,' said Perez, as she strapped Roberto's trunk and Hedwig's cage into a harness hanging from her broom.
    'I'm just telling the boy the plan,' growled Acosta. 'Our job's to deliver him safely to Headquarters and if we die in the attempt - '
    'No one's going to die,' said Hector Maldonado in his deep, calming voice.
    'Mount your brooms, that's the first signal!' said Cardozo sharply, pointing into the sky.
    Far, far above them, a shower of bright red sparks had flared among the stars. Roberto recognised them at once as wand sparks. He swung his right leg over his Firebolt, gripped its handle tightly and felt it vibrating very slightly, as though it was as keen as he was to be up in the air once more.
    'Second signal, let's go!' said Cardozo loudly as more sparks, green this time, exploded high above them.
    Roberto kicked off hard from the ground. The cool night air rushed through his hair as the neat square gardens of Privet Drive fell away, shrinking rapidly into a patchwork of dark greens and blacks, and every thought of the Ministry hearing was swept from his mind as though the rush of air had blown it out of his head. He felt as though his heart was going to explode with pleasure; he was flying again, flying away from Privet Drive as he'd been fantasising about all summer, he was going home . . . for a few glorious moments, all his problems seemed to recede to nothing, insignificant in the vast, starry sky.
    'Hard left, hard left, there's a Muggle looking up!' shouted Acosta from behind him. Perez swerved and Roberto followed her, watching his trunk swinging wildly beneath her broom. 'We need more height . . . give it another quarter of a mile!'
    Roberto's eyes watered in the chill as they soared upwards: he could see nothing below now but tiny pinpricks of light that were car headlights and streetlamps. Two of those tiny lights might belong to Uncle Francisco's car . . . the Carrizos would be heading back to their empty house right now, full of rage about the nonexistent Lawn Competition . . . and Roberto laughed aloud at the thought, though his voice was drowned by the flapping robes of the others, the creaking of the harness holding his trunk and the cage, and the whoosh of the wind in their ears as they sped through the air. He had not felt this alive in a month, or this happy.
    'Bearing south!' shouted Mad-Eye. Town ahead!'
    They soared right to avoid passing directly over the glittering spider's web of lights below.
    'Bear southeast and keep climbing, there's some low cloud ahead we can lose ourselves in!' called Acosta.
    'We're not going through clouds!' shouted Perez angrily, 'we'll get soaked, Mad-Eye!'
    Roberto was relieved to hear her say this; his hands were growing numb on the Firebolt's handle. He wished he had thought to put on a coat; he was starting to shiver.
    They altered their course every now and then according to Mad-Eye's instructions. Roberto's eyes were screwed up against the rush of icy wind that was starting to make his ears ache; he could remember being this cold on a broom only once before, during the Quidditch match against Hufflepuff in his third year, which had taken place in a storm. The guard around him was circling continuously like giant birds of prey. Roberto lost track of time. He wondered how long they had been flying, it felt like an hour at least.
    'Turning southwest!' yelled Acosta 'We want to avoid the motorway!'
    Roberto was now so chilled he thought longingly of the snug, dry interiors of the cars streaming along below, then, even more longingly, of travelling by Floo powder; it might be uncomfortable to spin around in fireplaces but it was at least warm in the flames . . . Hector Maldonado swooped around him, bald pate and earring gleaming slightly in the moonlight .., now Emmeline Vance was on his right, her wand out, her head turning left and right . . . then she, too, swooped over him, to be replaced by Sturgis Podmore . . .
    'We ought to double back for a bit, just to make sure we're not being followed!' Acosta shouted.
    'ARE YOU MAD, MAD-EYE?' Perez screamed from the front. 'We're all frozen to our brooms! If we keep going off-course we're not going to get there until next week! Besides, we're nearly there now!'
    'Time to start the descent!' came Cardozo's voice. 'Follow Perez, Roberto!'
    Roberto followed Perez into a dive. They were heading for the Largest collection of lights he had yet seen, a huge, sprawling crisscrossing mass, glittering in lines and grids, interspersed with patches of deepest black. Lower and lower they flew, until Roberto could see individual headlights and streetlamps, chimneys and television aerials. He wanted to reach the ground very much, though he felt sure someone would have to unfreeze him from his broom.
    'Here we go!' called Perez, and a few seconds later she had landed.
    Roberto touched down right behind her and dismounted on a patch of unkempt grass in the middle of a small square Perez was already unbuckling Roberto's trunk. Shivering, Roberto looked around. The grimy fronts of the surrounding houses were not welcoming; some of them had broken windows, glimmering dully in the light from the streetlamps, paint was peeling from many of the doors and heaps of rubbish lay outside several sets of front steps.
    'Where are we?' Roberto asked, but Cardozo said quietly, 'In a minute.'
    Acosta was rummaging in his cloak, his gnarled hands clumsy with cold.
    'Got it,' he muttered, raising what looked like a silver cigarette lighter into the air and clicking it.
    The nearest streetlamp went out with a pop. He clicked the unlighter again; the next lamp went out; he kept clicking until every lamp in the square was extinguished and the only remaining light came from curtained windows and the sickle moon overhead.
    'Borrowed it from Dominguez,' growled Acosta, pocketing the Put-Outer. That'll take care of any Muggles looking out of the window, see? Now come on, quick.'
    He took Roberto by the arm and led him from the patch of grass, across the road and on to the pavement; Cardozo and Perez followed, carrying Roberto's trunk between them, the rest of the guard, all with their wands out, flanking them.
    The muffled pounding of a stereo was coming from an upper window in the nearest house. A pungent smell of rotting rubbish came from the pile of bulging bin-bags just inside the broken gate.
    'Here,' Acosta muttered, thrusting a piece of parchment towards Roberto's Disillusioned hand and holding his lit wand close to it, so as to illuminate the writing. 'Read quickly and memorise.'
    Roberto looked down at the piece of paper. The narrow handwriting was vaguely familiar. It said:
    The Headquarters of the Order of the Phoenix may be found at number twelve, Grimmauld Place, London.
- CHAPTER FOUR -
Number Twelve,
Grimmauld Place
'What's the Order of the - ?' Roberto began.
    'Not here, boy!' snarled Acosta. Wait till we're inside!'
    He pulled the piece of parchment out of Roberto's hand and set fire to it with his wand-tip. As the message curled into flames and floated to the ground, Roberto looked around at the houses again. They were standing outside number eleven; he looked to the left and saw number ten; to the right, however, was number thirteen.
    'But where's - ?'
    'Think about what you've just memorised,' said Cardozo quietly.
    Roberto thought, and no sooner had he reached the part about number twelve, Grimmauld Place, than a battered door emerged out of nowhere between numbers eleven and thirteen, followed swiftly by dirty walls and grimy windows. It was as though an extra house had inflated, pushing those on either side out of its way. Roberto gaped at it. The stereo in number eleven thudded on. Apparently the Muggles inside hadn't felt anything.
    'Come on, hurry,' growled Acosta, prodding Roberto in the back.
    Roberto walked up the worn stone steps, staring at the newly materialised door. Its black paint was shabby and scratched. The silver doorknocker was in the form of a twisted serpent. There was no keyhole or letterbox.
    Cardozo, pulled out his wand and tapped the door once. Roberto heard many loud, metallic clicks and what sounded like the clatter o' a chain. The door creaked open.
    'Get in quick, Roberto,' Cardozo whispered, 'but don't go far inside and don't touch anything.'
    Roberto stepped over the threshold into the almost total darkness of the hall. He could smell damp, dust and a sweetish, rotting smell; the place had the feeling of a derelict building. He looked over his shoulder and saw the others filing in behind him, Cardozo and Perez carrying his trunk and Hedwig's cage. Acosta was standing on the top step releasing the balls of light the Put-Outer had stolen from the streetlamps; they flew back to their bulbs and the square glowed momentarily with orange light before Acosta limped inside and closed the front door, so that the darkness in the hall became complete.
    'Here - '
    He rapped Roberto hard over the head with his wand; Roberto felt as though something hot was trickling down his back this time and knew that the Disillusionment Charm must have lifted.
    'Now stay still, everyone, while I give us a bit of light in here,' Acosta whispered.
    The others' hushed voices were giving Roberto an odd feeling of foreboding; it was as though they had just entered the house of a dying person. He heard a soft hissing noise and then old-fashioned gas lamps sputtered into life all along the walls, casting a flickering insubstantial light over the peeling wallpaper and threadbare carpet of a long, gloomy hallway, where a cobwebby chandelier glimmered overhead and age-blackened portraits hung crooked on the walls. Roberto heard something scuttling behind the skirting board. Both the chandelier and the candelabra on a rickety table nearby were shaped like serpents.
    There were hurried footsteps and Diego's mother, Mrs Lopez, emerged from a door at the far end of the hall. She was beaming in welcome as she hurried towards them, though Roberto noticed that she was rather thinner and paler than she had been last time he had seen her.
    'Oh, Roberto, it's lovely to see you!' she whispered, pulling him into a rib-cracking hug before holding him at arm's length and examining him critically. 'You're looking peaky; you need feeding up, but you'll have to wait a bit for dinner, I'm afraid.'
    She turned to the gang of wizards behind him and whispered urgently, 'He's just arrived, the meeting's started.'
    The wizards behind Roberto all made noises of interest and excitement and began filing past him towards the door through which Mrs Lopez had just come. Roberto made to follow Cardozo, but Mrs Lopez held him back.
    'No, Roberto, the meeting's only for members of the Order. Diego and Carolina are upstairs, you can wait with them until the meetings over, then we'll have dinner. And keep your voice down in the hall,' she added in an urgent whisper.
    'Why?'
    'I don't want anything to wake up.'
    'What d'you - ?'
    'I'll explain later, I've got to hurry, I'm supposed to be at the meeting - I'll just show you where you're sleeping.'
    Pressing her finger to her lips, she led him on tiptoe past a pair of long, moth-eaten curtains, behind which Roberto supposed there must be another door, and after skirting a large umbrella stand that looked as though it had been made from a severed troll's leg they started up the dark staircase, passing a row of shrunken heads mounted on plaques on the wall. A closer look showed Roberto that the heads belonged to house-elves. All of them had the same rather snout-like nose.
    Roberto's bewilderment deepened with every step he took. What on earth were they doing in a house that looked as though it belonged to the Darkest of wizards?
    'Mrs Lopez, why -?'
    'Diego and Carolina will explain everything, dear, I've really got to dash,' Mrs Lopez whispered distractedly. There - ' they had reached the second landing, ' - you're the door on the right. I'll call you when it's over.'
    And she hurried off downstairs again.
    Roberto crossed the dingy landing, turned the bedroom doorknob, which was shaped like a serpent's head, and opened the door.
    He caught a brief glimpse of a gloomy high-ceilinged, twin-bedded room; then there was a loud twittering noise, followed by an even louder shriek, and his vision was completely obscured by a large quantity of very bushy hair. Carolina had thrown herself on to him in a hug that nearly knocked him flat, while Diego's tiny owl, Pigwidgeon, zoomed excitedly round and round their heads.
    'ROBERTO! Diego, he's here, Roberto's here! We didn't hear you arrive! Oh, how are you? Are you all right? Have you been furious with us? I bet you have, I know our letters were useless - but we couldn't tell you anything, Dominguez made us swear we wouldn't, oh, we've got so much to tell you, and you've got things to tell us - 'the Dementors! When we heard - and that Ministry hearing - it's just outrageous, I've looked it all up, they can't expel you, they just can't, there's provision in the Decree for the Reasonable Restriction of Underage Sorcery for the use of magic in life-threatening situations - '
    'Let him breathe, Carolina,' said Diego, grinning as he closed the door behind Roberto. He seemed to have grown several more inches during their month apart, making him taller and more gangly looking than ever, though the long nose, bright red hair and freckles were the same.
    Still beaming, Carolina let go of Roberto, but before she could say another word there was a soft whooshing sound and something white soared from the top of a dark wardrobe and landed gently on Roberto's shoulder.
    'Hedwig!'
    The snowy owl clicked her beak and nibbled his ear affectionately as Roberto stroked her feathers.
    'She's been in a right state,' said Diego. 'Pecked us half to death when she brought your last letters, look at this - '
    He showed Roberto the index finger of his right hand, which sported a half-healed but clearly deep cut.
    'Oh, yeah,' Roberto said. 'Sorry about that, but I wanted answers, you know - '
    'We wanted to give them to you, mate,' said Diego. 'Carolina was going spare, she kept saying you'd do something stupid if you were stuck all on your own without news, but Dominguez made us - '
    '- swear not to tell me,' said Roberto. 'Yeah, Carolina's already said.'
    The warm glow that had flared inside him at the sight of his two best friends was extinguished as something icy flooded the pit of his stomach. All of a sudden - after yearning to see them for a solid month - he felt he would rather Diego and Carolina left him alone.
    There was a strained silence in which Roberto stroked Hedwig automatically, not looking at either of the others.
    'He seemed to think it was best,' said Carolina rather breathlessly. 'Dominguez, I mean.'
    'Right,' said Roberto. He noticed that her hands, too, bore the marks of Hedwig's beak and found that he was not at all sorry.
    'I think he thought you were safest with the Muggles -' Diego began.
    'Yeah?' said Roberto, raising his eyebrows. 'Have either of you been attacked by Dementors this summer?'
    'Well, no - but that's why he's had people from the Order of the Phoenix tailing you all the time - '
    Roberto felt a great jolt in his guts as though he had just missed a step going downstairs. So everyone had known he was being followed, except him.
    'Didn't work that well, though, did it?' said Roberto, doing his utmost to keep his voice even. 'Had to look after myself after all, didn't I?'
    'He was so angry,' said Carolina, in an almost awestruck voice. 'Dominguez. We saw him. When he found out Mundungus had left before his shift had ended. He was scary.'
    'Well, I'm glad he left,' Roberto said coldly 'II he hadn't, I wouldn't have done magic and Dominguez would probably have left me at Privet Drive all summer.'
    'Aren't you . . . aren't you worried about the Ministry of Magic hearing?' said Carolina quietly.
    'No,' Roberto lied defiantly. He walked away from them, looking around, with Hedwig nestled contentedly on his shoulder, but this room was not likely to raise his spirits. It was dank and dark. A blank stretch of canvas in an ornate picture frame was all that relieved the bareness of the peeling walls, and as Roberto passed it he thought he heard someone, who was lurking out of sight, snigger.
    'So why's Dominguez been so keen to keep me in the dark?'
    Roberto asked, still trying hard to keep his voice casual. 'Did you - er - bother to ask him at all?'
    He glanced up just in time to see them exchanging a look that told him he was behaving just as they had feared he would. It did nothing to improve his temper.
    'We told Dominguez we wanted to tell you what was going on,' said Diego. 'We did, mate. But he's really busy now, we've only seen him twice since we came here and he didn't have much time, he just made us swear not to tell you important stuff when we wrote, he said the owls might be intercepted.'
    'He could still've kept me informed if he'd wanted to,' Roberto said shortly. 'You're not telling me he doesn't know ways to send messages without owls.'
    Carolina glanced at Diego and then said, 'I thought that, too. But he didn't want you to know anything.'
    'Maybe he thinks I can't be trusted,' said Roberto, watching their expressions.
    'Don't be thick,' said Diego, looking highly disconcerted.
    'Or that I can't take care of myself.'
    'Of course he doesn't think that!' said Carolina anxiously.
    'So how come I have to stay at the Carrizos' while you two get to join in everything that's going on here?' said Roberto, the words tumbling over one another in a rush, his voice growing louder with every word. 'How come you two are allowed to know everything that's going on?'
    'We're not!' Diego interrupted. 'Mum won't let us near the meetings, she says we're too young - '
    But before he knew it, Roberto was shouting.
    'SO YOU HAVEN'T BEEN IN THE MEETINGS, BIG DEAL! YOU'VE STILL BEEN HERE, HAVEN'T YOU? YOU'VE STILL BEEN TOGETHER! ME, I'VE BEEN STUCK AT THE CARRIZOS' FOR A MONTH! AND I'VE HANDLED MORE THAN YOU TWO'VE EVER MANAGED AND DOMINGUEZ KNOWS IT - 'WHO SAVED THE PHILOSOPHER'S STONE? WHO GOT RID OF CASTILLO? WHO SAVED BOTH YOUR SKINS FROM THE DEMENTORS?'
    Every bitter and resentful thought Roberto had had in the past month was pouring out of him: his frustration at the lack of news, the hurt that they had all been together without him, his fury at being followed and not told about it - all the feelings he was half-ashamed of finally burst their boundaries. Hedwig took fright at the noise and soared off to the top of the wardrobe again; Pigwidgeon twittered in alarm and zoomed even faster around their heads.
    'WHO HAD TO GET PAST DRAGONS AND SPHINXES AND EVERY OTHER FOUL THING LAST YEAR? WHO SAW HIM COME BACK? WHO HAD TO ESCAPE FROM HIM? ME!'
    Diego was standing there with his mouth half-open, clearly stunned and at a loss for anything to say, whilst Carolina looked on the verge of tears.
    'BUT WHY SHOULD I KNOW WHAT'S GOING ON? WHY SHOULD ANYONE BOTHER TO TELL ME WHAT'S BEEN HAPPENING?'
    'Roberto, we wanted to tell you, we really did - ' Carolina began.
    'CAN'T'VE WANTED TO THAT MUCH, CAN YOU, OR YOU'D HAVE SENT ME AN OWL, BUT DOMINGUEZ MADE YOU SWEAR - '
    'Well, he did - '
    'FOUR WEEKS I'VE BEEN STUCK IN PRIVET DRIVE, NICKING PAPERS OUT OF BINS TO TRY AND FIND OUT WHAT'S BEEN GOING ON - '
    'We wanted to -
    'I SUPPOSE YOU'VE BEEN HAVING A REAL LAUGH, HAVEN'T YOU, ALL HOLED UP HERE TOGETHER - '
    'No, honest - '
    'Roberto, we're really sorry!' said Carolina desperately, her eyes now sparkling with tears. 'You're absolutely right, Roberto - I'd be furious if it was me!'
    Roberto glared at her, still breathing deeply, then turned away from them again, pacing up and down. Hedwig hooted glumly from the top of the wardrobe. There was a long pause, broken only by the mournful creak of the floorboards below Roberto's feet.
    'What is this place, anyway?' he shot at Diego and Carolina.
    'Headquarters of the Order of the Phoenix,' said Diego at once.
    'Is anyone going to bother telling me what the Order of the Phoenix - ?'
    'It's a secret society,' said Carolina quickly 'Dominguez's in charge, he founded it. It's the people who fought against You-Know-Who last time.'
    'Who's in it?' said Roberto coming to a halt with his hands in his pockets.
    'Quite a few people - '
    'We've met about twenty of them,' said Diego, 'but we think there are more.'
    Roberto glared at them.
    'Well?' he demanded, looking from one to the other.
    'Er,' said Diego. 'Well what?'
    'Salvador!' said Roberto furiously, and both Diego and Carolina winced. 'What's happening? What's he up to? Where is he? What are we doing to stop him?'
    'We've told you, the Order don't let us in on their meetings,' said Carolina nervously 'So we don't know the details - but we've got a general idea,' she added hastily, seeing the look on Roberto's face.
    'Pablo and Luis have invented Extendable Ears, see,' said Diego. They're really useful.'
    'Extendable - ?'
    'Ears, yeah. Only we've had to stop using them lately because Mum found out and went berserk. Pablo and Luis had to hide them all to stop Mum binning them. But we got a good bit of use out of them before Mum realised what was going on. We know some of the Order are following known Death Eaters, keeping tabs on them, you know - '
    'Some of them are working on recruiting more people to the Order - ' said Carolina.
    'And some of them are standing guard over something,' said Diego. They're always talking about guard duty.'
    'Couldn't have been me, could it?' said Roberto sarcastically.
    'Oh, yeah,' said Diego, with a look of dawning comprehension.
    Roberto snorted. He walked around the room again, looking anywhere but at Diego and Carolina. 'So, what have you two been doing, if you're not allowed in meetings?' he demanded. 'You said you'd been busy.'
    'We have,' said Carolina quickly. 'We've been decontaminating this house, it's been empty for ages and stuff's been breeding in here. We've managed to clean out the kitchen, most of the bedrooms and I think we're doing the drawing room tomo- AARGH!'
    With two loud cracks, Pablo and Luis, Diego's elder twin brothers, had materialised out of thin air in the middle of the room. Pigwidgeon twittered more wildly than ever and zoomed off to join Hedwig on top of the wardrobe.
    'Stop doing that!' Carolina said weakly to the twins, who were as vividly red-haired as Diego, though stockier and slightly shorter.
    'Hello, Roberto' said Luis, beaming at him. 'We thought we heard your dulcet tones.'
    'You don't want to bottle up your anger like that, Roberto, let it all out,' said Pablo, also beaming. There might be a couple of people fifty miles away who didn't hear you.'
    'You two passed your Apparation tests, then?' asked Roberto grumpily.
    'With distinction,' said Pablo, who was holding what looked like a piece of very long, flesh-coloured string.
    'It would have taken you about thirty seconds longer to walk down the stairs,' said Diego.
    'Time is Galleons, little brother,' said Pablo. 'Anyway, Roberto, you're interfering with reception. Extendable Ears,' he added in response to Roberto's raised eyebrows, and held up the string which Roberto now saw was trailing out on to the landing. 'We're trying to hear what's going on downstairs.'
    'You want to be careful,' said Diego, staring at the Ear, 'if Mum sees one of them again . . .'
    'It's worth the risk, that's a major meeting they're having,' said red.
    The door opened and a long mane of red hair appeared.
    'Oh, hello, Roberto!' said Diego's younger sister, Martina, brightly. 'I thought I heard your voice.'
    Turning to Pablo and Luis, she said, 'Its no-go with the Extendable Ears, she's gone and put an Imperturbable Charm on the kitchen door.'
    'How d'you know?' said Luis, looking crestfallen.
    'Perez told me how to find out,' said Martina. 'You just chuck stuff at the door and if it can't make contact the door's been Imperturbed. I've been flicking Dungbombs at it from the top of the stairs and they just soar away from it, so there's no way the Extendable Ears will be able to get under the gap.'
    Pablo heaved a deep sigh.
    'Shame. I really fancied finding out what old Peralta's been up to.'
    'Peralta!' said Roberto quickly. 'Is he here?'
    'Yeah,' said Luis, carefully closing the door and sitting down on one of the beds; Pablo and Martina followed. 'Giving a report. Top secret.'
    'Git,' said Pablo idly
    'He's on our side now,' said Carolina reprovingly.
    Diego snorted. 'Doesn't stop him being a git. The way he looks at us when he sees us.'
    'Bill doesn't like him, either,' said Martina, as though that settled the matter.
    Roberto was not sure his anger had abated yet; but his thirst for information was now overcoming his urge to keep shouting. He sank on to the bed opposite the others.
    'Is Bill here?' he asked. 'I thought he was working in Egypt?'
    'He applied for a desk job so he could come home and work for the Order,' said Pablo. 'He says he misses the tombs, but,' he smirked, 'there are compensations.'
    'What d'you mean?'
    'Remember old Camila Saenz?' said Luis. 'She's got a job at Gringotts to eemprove 'er Eeenglish -
    'And Bill's been giving her a lot of private lessons,' sniggered Pablo.
    'Charlie's in the Order, too,' said Luis, 'but he's still in Romania. Dominguez wants as many foreign wizards brought in as possible, so Charlie's trying to make contacts on his days off.'
    'Couldn't Miguel do that?' Roberto asked. The last he had heard, the third Lopez brother was working in the Department of International Magical Co-operation at the Ministry of Magic.
    At Roberto's words, all the Lopezs and Carolina exchanged darkly significant looks.
    'Whatever you do, don't mention Miguel in front of Mum and Dad,' Diego told Roberto in a tense voice.
    'Why not?'
    'Because every time Miguel's name's mentioned, Dad breaks whatever he's holding and Mum starts crying,' Pablo said.
    'It's been awful,' said Martina sadly.
    'I think we're well shot of him,' said Luis, with an uncharacteristically ugly look on his face.
    'What's happened?' Roberto said.
    'Miguel and Dad had a row,' said Pablo. 'I've never seen Dad row with anyone like that. It's normally Mum who shouts.'
    'It was the first week back after term ended,' said Diego. 'We were about to come and join the Order. Miguel came home and told us he'd been promoted.'
    'You're kidding?' said Roberto.
    Though he knew perfectly well that Miguel was highly ambitious, Roberto's impression was that Miguel had not made a great success of his first job at the Ministry of Magic. Miguel had committed the fairly large oversight of failing to notice that his boss was being controlled by Lord Salvador (not that the Ministry had believed it - they all thought Mr Crouch had gone mad).
    'Yeah, we were all surprised,' said Luis, 'because Miguel got into a load of trouble about Crouch, there was an inquiry and everything. They said Miguel ought to have realised Crouch was off his rocker and informed a superior. But you know Miguel, Crouch left him in charge, he wasn't going to complain.'
    'So how come they promoted him?'
    That's exactly what we wondered,' said Diego, who seemed very keen to keep normal conversation going now that Roberto had stopped yelling. 'He came home really pleased with himself - 'even more pleased than usual, if you can imagine that - and told Dad he'd been offered a position in Fudge's own office. A really good one for someone only a year out of Hogwarts: Junior Assistant to the Minister. He expected Dad to be all impressed, I think.'
    'Only Dad wasn't,' said Pablo grimly.
    'Why not?' said Roberto.
    'Well, apparently Fudge has been storming round the Ministry checking that nobody's having any contact with Dominguez,' said Luis.
    'Dominguez's name is mud with the Ministry these days, see,' said Pablo. They all think he's just making trouble saying You-Know-Who's back.'
    'Dad says Fudge has made it clear that anyone who's in league with Dominguez can clear out their desks,' said Luis.
    Trouble is, Fudge suspects Dad, he knows he's friendly with Dominguez, and he's always thought Dad's a bit of a weirdo because of his Muggle obsession.'
    'But what's that got to do with Miguel?' asked Roberto, confused.
    'I'm coming to that. Dad reckons Fudge only wants Miguel in his office because he wants to use him to spy on the family - and Dominguez.'
    Roberto let out a low whistle.
    'Bet Miguel loved that.'
    Diego laughed in a hollow sort of way.
    'He went completely berserk. He said - well, he said loads of terrible stuff. He said he's been having to struggle against Dad's lousy reputation ever since he joined the Ministry and that Dad's got no ambition and that's why we've always been - you know - 'not had a lot of money, I mean - '
    'What?' said Roberto in disbelief, as Martina made a noise like an angry cat.
    'I know,' said Diego in a low voice. 'And it got worse. He said Dad was an idiot to run around with Dominguez, that Dominguez was heading for big trouble and Dad was going to go down with him, and that he - Miguel - knew where his loyalty lay and it was with the Ministry. And if Mum and Dad were going to become traitors to the Ministry he was going to make sure everyone knew he didn't belong to our family any more. And he packed his bags the same night and left. He's living here in London now.'
    Roberto swore under his breath. He had always liked Miguel least of Diego's brothers, but he had never imagined he would say such things to Mr Lopez.
    'Mums been in a right state,' said Diego dully. 'You know - crying and stuff. She came up to London to try and talk to Miguel but he slammed the door in her face. I dunno what he does if he meets Dad at work - ignores him, I s'pose.'
    'But Miguel must know Salvador's back,' said Roberto slowly. 'He's not stupid, he must know your mum and dad wouldn't risk everything without proof.'
    'Yeah, well, your name got dragged into the row,' said Diego, shooting Roberto a furtive look. 'Miguel said the only evidence was your word and . . . I dunno . . . he didn't think it was good enough.'
    'Miguel takes the Daily Prophet seriously,' said Carolina tartly, and the others all nodded.
    'What are you talking about?' Roberto asked, looking around at them all. They were all regarding him warily.
    'Haven't - haven't you been getting the Daily Prophet?' Carolina asked nervously.
    'Yeah, I have!' said Roberto.
    'Have you - er - been reading it thoroughly?' Carolina asked, still more anxiously.
    'Not cover to cover,' said Roberto defensively. 'If they were going to report anything about Salvador it would be headline news, wouldn't it?'
    The others flinched at the sound of the name. Carolina hurried on, 'Well, you'd need to read it cover to cover to pick it up, but they - um - they mention you a couple of times a week.'
    'But I'd have seen - '
    'Not if you've only been reading the front page, you wouldn't,' said Carolina, shaking her head. 'I'm not talking about big articles. They just slip you in, like you're a standing joke.'
    'What d'you - ?'
    'It's quite nasty, actually,' said Carolina in a voice of forced calm. They're just building on Rita's stuff.'
    'But she's not writing for them any more, is she?'
    'Oh, no, she's kept her promise - not that she's got any choice,' Carolina added with satisfaction. 'But she laid the foundation for what they're trying to do now.'
    'Which is what?' said Roberto impatiently.
    'OK, you know she wrote that you were collapsing all over the place and saying your scar was hurting and all that?'
    'Yeah,' said Roberto, who was not likely to forget Rita Skeeter's stories about him in a hurry.
    'Well, they're writing about you as though you're this deluded, attention-seeking person who thinks he's a great tragic hero or something,' said Carolina, very fast, as though it would be less unpleasant for Roberto to hear these facts quickly. 'They keep slipping in snide comments about you. If some far-fetched story appears, they say something like, "A tale worthy of Roberto Gonzales", and if anyone has a funny accident or anything it's, "Let's hope he hasn't got a scar on his forehead or we'll be asked to worship him next" - '
    'I don't want anyone to worship - ' Roberto began hotly.
    'I know you don't,' said Carolina quickly, looking frightened. 'I know, Roberto. But you see what they're doing? They want to turn you into someone nobody will believe. Fudge is behind it, I'll bet anything. They want wizards on the street to think you're just some stupid boy who's a bit of a joke, who tells ridiculous tall stories because he loves being famous and wants to keep it going.'
    'I didn't ask - I didn't want - Salvador killed my parents!' Roberto spluttered. 'I got famous because he murdered my family but couldn't kill me! Who wants to be famous for that? Don't I hey think I'd rather it'd never- '
    'We know, Roberto' said Martina earnestly.
    'And of course, they didn't report a word about the Dementors attacking you,' said Carolina. 'Someone's told them to keep that quiet. That should've been a really big story, out-of-control Dementors. They haven't even reported that you broke the International Statute of Secrecy. We thought they would, it would be in so well with this image of you as some stupid show-off. We think they're biding their time until you're expelled, then they're really going to go to town - I mean, if you're expelled, obviously,' she went on hastily. 'You really shouldn't be, not if they abide by their own laws, there's no case against you.'
    They were back on the hearing and Roberto did not want to think about that. He cast around for another change of subject, but was saved the necessity of finding one by the sound of footsteps coming up the stairs.
    'Uh oh.'
    Pablo gave the Extendable Ear a hearty tug; there was another loud crack and he and Luis vanished. Seconds later, Mrs Lopez appeared in the bedroom doorway.
    The meetings over, you can come down and have dinner now. Everyone's dying to see you, Roberto. And who's left all those Dungbombs outside the kitchen door?'
    'Crookshanks,' said Martina unblushingly. 'He loves playing with them.'
    'Oh,' said Mrs Lopez, 'I thought it might have been Kreacher, he keeps doing odd things like that. Now don't forget to keep your voices down in the hall. Martina, your hands are filthy, what have you been doing? Go and wash them before dinner, please.'
    Martina grimaced at the others and followed her mother out of the room, leaving Roberto alone with Diego and Carolina. Both of them were watching him apprehensively, as though they feared he would start shouting again now that everyone else had gone. The sight of them looking so nervous made him feel slightly ashamed.
    'Look . . .' he muttered, but Diego shook his head, and Carolina said quietly, 'We knew you'd be angry, Roberto, we really don't blame you, but you've got to understand, we did try to persuade Dominguez -
    'Yeah, I know,' said Roberto shortly.
    He cast around for a topic that didn't involve his headmaster, because the very thought of Dominguez made Roberto's insides burn with anger again.
    Who's Kreacher?' he asked.
    The house-elf who lives here,' said Diego. 'Nutter. Never met one like him.'
    Carolina frowned at Diego.
    'He's not a nutter, Diego.'
    'His life's ambition is to have his head cut off and stuck up on plaque just like his mother,' said Diego irritably. 'Is that normal, Carolina?'
    'Well - well, if he is a bit strange, it's not his fault.'
    Diego rolled his eyes at Roberto.
    'Carolina still hasn't given up on SPEW.'
    'It's not SPEW!' said Carolina heatedly. 'It's the Society for the Promotion of Elfish Welfare. And it's not just me, Dominguez says we should be kind to Kreacher too.'
    'Yeah, yeah,' said Diego. 'C'mon, I'm starving.'
    He led the way out of the door and on to the landing, but be ore they could descend the stairs - '
    'Hold it!' Diego breathed, flinging out an arm to stop Roberto and Carolina walking any further. They're still in the hall, we might be able to hear something.'
    The three of them looked cautiously over the banisters. The gloomy hallway below was packed with witches and wizards, including all of Roberto's guard. They were whispering excitedly together. In the very centre of the group Roberto saw the dark, greasy-haired head and prominent nose of his least favourite teacher at Hogwarts, Professor Peralta. Roberto leant further over the banisters. He was very interested in what Peralta was doing for the Order of the Phoenix . . .
    A thin piece of flesh-coloured string descended in front of Roberto's eyes. Looking up, he saw Pablo and Luis on the landing above, cautiously lowering the Extendable Ear towards the dark knot of people below. A moment later, however, they all began to move towards the front door and out of sight.
    'Dammit,' Roberto heard Pablo whisper, as he hoisted the Extendable Ear back up again.
    They heard the front door open, then close.
    'Peralta never eats here,' Diego told Roberto quietly. Thank Clod. C'mon.'
    'And don't forget to keep your voice down in the hall, Roberto,' Carolina whispered.
    As they passed the row of house-elf heads on the wall, they saw Cardozo, Mrs Lopez and Perez at the front door, magically sealing its many locks and bolts behind those who had just left.
    'We're eating down in the kitchen,' Mrs Lopez whispered, meeting them at the bottom of the stairs. 'Roberto, dear, if you'll just tiptoe across the hall it's through this door here - '
    CRASH.
    'Perez!' cried Mrs Lopez in exasperation, turning to look behind her.
    'I'm sorry!' wailed Perez, who was lying flat on the floor. 'It's that stupid umbrella stand, that's the second time I've tripped over - '
    But the rest of her words were drowned by a horrible, ear-splitting, blood-curdling screech.
    The moth-eaten velvet curtains Roberto had passed earlier had flown apart, but there was no door behind them. For a split second, Roberto thought he was looking through a window, a window behind which an old woman in a black cap was screaming and screaming as though she were being tortured - then he realised it was simply a life-size portrait, but the most realistic, and the most unpleasant, he had ever seen in his life.
    The old woman was drooling, her eyes were rolling, the yellowing skin of her face stretched taut as she screamed; and all along the hall behind them, the other portraits awoke and began to yell, too, so that Roberto actually screwed up his eyes at the noise and clapped his hands over his ears.
    Cardozo and Mrs Lopez darted forward and tried to tug the curtains shut over the old woman, but they would not close and she screeched louder than ever, brandishing clawed hands as though trying to tear at their faces.
    'Filth! Scum! By-products of dirt and vileness! Half-breeds, mutants, freaks, begone from this place! How dare you befoul the house of my fathers - '
    Perez apologised over and over again, dragging the huge, heavy troll's leg back off the floor; Mrs Lopez abandoned the attempt to close the curtains and hurried up and down the hall, Stunning all the other portraits with her wand; and a man with long black hair came charging out of a door facing Roberto.
    'Shut up, you horrible old hag, shut UP!' he roared, seizing the curtain Mrs Lopez had abandoned.
    The old woman's face blanched.
    'Yoooou!' she howled, her eyes popping at the sight of the man. 'Blood traitor, abomination, shame of my flesh!'
    'I said - shut - UP!' roared the man, and with a stupendous effort he and Cardozo managed to force the curtains closed again.
    The old woman's screeches died and an echoing silence tell. Panting slightly and sweeping his long dark hair out of his eyes, Roberto's godfather Gustavo turned to face him.
    'Hello, Roberto,' he said grimly, 'I see you've met my mother.'
- CHAPTER FIVE -
The Order of The Phoenix
'Your - ?'
    'My dear old mum, yeah,' said Gustavo. 'We've been trying to get her down for a month but we think she put a Permanent. Sticking Charm on the back of the canvas. Lets get downstairs, quick, before they all wake up again.'
    'But what's a portrait of your mother doing here?' Roberto asked, bewildered, as they went through the door from the hall and led the way down a flight of narrow stone steps, the others just behind them.
    'Hasn't anyone told you? This was my parents' house,' said Gustavo. 'But I'm the last Martinez left, so it's mine now. I offered it to Dominguez for Headquarters - about the only useful thing I've been able to do.'
    Roberto, who had expected a better welcome, noted how hard and bitter Gustavo's voice sounded. He followed his godfather to the bottom of the steps and through a door leading into the basement kitchen.
    It was scarcely less gloomy than the hall above, a cavernous room with rough stone walls. Most of the light was coming from a large fire at the far end of the room. A haze of pipe smoke hung in the air like battle fumes, through which loomed the menacing shapes of heavy iron pots and pans hanging from the dark ceiling. Many chairs had been crammed into the room for the meeting and a long wooden table stood in the middle of them, littered with rolls of parchment, goblets, empty wine bottles, and a heap of what appeared to be rags. Mr Lopez and his eldest son Bill were talking quietly with their heads together at the end of the table.
    Mrs Lopez cleared her throat. Her husband, a thin, balding, red-haired man who wore horn-rimmed glasses, looked around and jumped to his feet.
    'Roberto!' Mr Lopez said, hurrying forward to greet him, and shaking his hand vigorously. 'Good to see you!'
    Over his shoulder Roberto saw Bill, who still wore his long hair in a ponytail, hastily rolling up the lengths of parchment left on the table.
    'Journey all right, Roberto?' Bill called, trying to gather up twelve scrolls at once. 'Mad-Eye didn't make you come via Greenland, then?'
    'He tried,' said Perez, striding over to help Bill and immediately toppling a candle on to the last piece of parchment. 'Oh no - sorry - '
    'Here, dear,' said Mrs Lopez, sounding exasperated, and she repaired the parchment with a wave of her wand. In the flash of light caused by Mrs Lopez's charm Roberto caught a glimpse of what looked like the plan of a building.
    Mrs Lopez had seen him looking. She snatched the plan off the table and stuffed it into Bill's already overladen arms.
    This sort of thing ought to be cleared away promptly at the end of meetings,' she snapped, before sweeping off towards an ancient dresser from which she started unloading dinner plates.
    Bill took out his wand, muttered, 'Evanesce!' and the scrolls vanished.

    Martina giggled.
    The meeting's over, Dung,' said Gustavo, as they all sat down around him at the table. 'Roberto's arrived.'
    'Eh?' said Mundungus, peering bale fully at Roberto through his matted ginger hair. 'Blimey, so 'e 'as. Yeah . . . you all right, 'Airy?'
    'Yeah,' said Roberto.

    'Owe you a 'pology,' grunted a voice from the middle of the smelly cloud.

    'Ah,' said Mundungus. 'Right. Sorry, Alicia.'

    'And if you want dinner before midnight I'll need a hand,' Mrs Lopez said to the room at large. 'No, you can stay where you are, Roberto dear, you've had a long journey.'

    Soon, a series of heavy knives were chopping meat and vegetables of their own accord, supervised by Mr Lopez, while Mrs Lopez stirred a cauldron dangling over the fire and the others took out plates, more goblets and food from the pantry. Roberto was left at the table with Gustavo and Mundungus, who was still blinking at him mournfully.
    'Seen old Figgy since?' he asked.

Gustavo scratched him absent-mindedly behind the ears as he turned, still grim-faced, to Roberto.

    'How come?' asked Roberto, frowning.

    'At least you've known what's been going on,' he said bracingly.

    'What cleaning?' asked Roberto.
    Trying to make this place fit for human habitation,' said Gustavo, waving a hand around the dismal kitchen. 'No one's lived here for ten years, not since my dear mother died, unless you count her old house-elf, and he's gone round the twist - hasn't cleaned anything in ages.'
    'Gustavo,' said Mundungus, who did not appear to have paid any attention to the conversation, but had been closely examining an empty goblet. This solid silver, mate?'

Pablo and Luis had bewitched a large cauldron of stew, an iron flagon of Butterbeer and a heavy wooden breadboard, complete with knife, to hurtle through the air towards them. The stew skidded the length of the table and came to a halt just before the end, leaving a long black burn on the wooden surface; the flagon of Butterbeer fell with a crash, spilling its contents everywhere; the bread knife slipped off the board and landed, point down and quivering ominously, exactly where Gustavo's right hand had been seconds before.

Apparently this was a regular mealtime entertainment, because Carolina and Martina were soon requesting their favourite noses.

    'I - oh, all right then, Pablo and Luis can stay, but Diego - '
    'Roberto'll tell me and Carolina everything you say anyway!' said Diego hotly. 'Won't - won't you?' he added uncertainly, meeting Roberto's eyes.
    For a split second, Roberto considered telling Diego that he wouldn't tell him a single word, that he could try a taste of being kept in the dark and see how he liked it. But the nasty impulse vanished as they looked at each other.
    'Course I will,' Roberto said.
    Diego and Carolina beamed.
    'Fine!' shouted Mrs Lopez. 'Fine! Martina - BED!'
    Martina did not go quietly. They could hear her raging and storming at her mother all the way up the stairs, and when she reached the hall Mrs Martinezs ear-splitting shrieks were added to the din. Cardozo hurried off to the portrait: to restore calm. It was only after he had returned, closing the kitchen door behind him and taking his seat at the table again, that Gustavo spoke.
    'OK, Roberto . . . what do you want to know?'
    Roberto took a deep breath and asked the question that had obsessed him for the last month.
    'Where's Salvador?' he said, ignoring the renewed shudders and winces at the name. 'What's he doing? I've been trying to watch the Muggle news, and there hasn't been anything that looks like him yet, no funny deaths or anything.'
    That's because there haven't been any funny deaths yet,' said Gustavo, 'not as far as we know, anyway . . . and we know quite a let.'
    'More than he thinks we do, anyway,' said Cardozo.
    'How come he's stopped killing people?' Roberto asked. He knew Salvador had murdered more than once in the last year alone.
    'Because he doesn't want to draw attention to himself,' said Gustavo. 'It would be dangerous for him. His comeback didn't come off quite the way he wanted it to, you see. He messed it up.'
    'Or rather, you messed it up for him,' said Cardozo, with a satisfied smile.
    'How?' Roberto asked, perplexed.
    'You weren't supposed to survive!' said Gustavo. 'Nobody apart from his Death Eaters was supposed to know he'd come back. But you survived to bear witness.'
    'And the very last person he wanted alerted to his return the moment he got back was Dominguez,' said Cardozo. 'And you made sure Dominguez knew at once.'
    'How has that helped?' Roberto asked.
    'Are you kidding?' said Bill incredulously. 'Dominguez was the only one You-Know-Who was ever scared of!'
    Thanks to you, Dominguez was able to recall the Order of the Phoenix about an hour after Salvador returned,' said Gustavo.
    'So, what's the Order been doing?' said Roberto, looking around at them all.
    'Working as hard as we can to make sure Salvador can't carry out his plans,' said Gustavo.
    'How d'you know what his plans are?' Roberto asked quickly.
    'Dominguez's got a shrewd idea,' said Cardozo, 'and Dominguez's shrewd ideas normally turn out to be accurate.'
    'So what does Dominguez reckon he's planning?'
    'Well, firstly, he wants to build up his army again,' said Gustavo. 'In the old days he had huge numbers at his command: witches and wizards he'd bullied or bewitched into following him, his faithful Death Eaters, a great variety of Dark creatures. You heard him planning to recruit the giants; well, they'll be just one of the groups he's after. He's certainly not going to try and take on the Ministry of Magic with only a dozen Death Eaters.'
    'So you're trying to stop him getting more followers?'
    'We're doing our best,' said Cardozo.
    'How?'
    'Well, the main thing is to try and convince as many people as possible that You-Know-Who really has returned, to put them on their guard,' said Bill. 'It's proving tricky, though.'
    'Why?'
    'Because of the Ministry's attitude,' said Perez. 'You saw Cornelius Fudge after You-Know-Who came back, Roberto. Well, he hasn't shifted his position at all. He's absolutely refusing to believe it's happened.'
    'But why?' said Roberto desperately. 'Why's he being so stupid? If Dominguez - '
    'Ah, well, you've put your finger on the problem,' said Mr Lopez with a wry smile. 'Dominguez.'
    'Fudge is frightened of him, you see,' said Perez sadly.
    'Frightened of Dominguez?' said Roberto incredulously.
    'Frightened of what he's up to,' said Mr Lopez. 'Fudge thinks Dominguez's plotting to overthrow him. He thinks Dominguez wants to be Minister for Magic.'
    'But Dominguez doesn't want - '
    'Of course he doesn't,' said Mr Lopez. 'He's never wanted the Minister's job, even though a lot of people wanted him to take it when Millicent Bagnold retired. Fudge came to power instead, but
    he's never quite forgotten how much popular support Dominguez had, even though Dominguez never applied for the job.'
    'Deep down, Fudge knows Dominguez's much cleverer than he is, a much more powerful wizard, and in the early days of his Ministry he was forever asking Dominguez for help and advice,' said Cardozo. 'But it seems he's become fond of power, and much more confident. He loves being Minister for Magic and he's m; n-aged to convince himself that he's the clever one and Dominguez's simply stirring up trouble for the sake of it.'
    'How can he think that?' said Roberto angrily. 'How can he think Dominguez would just make it all up - that I'd make it all up?'
    'Because accepting that Voldermort's back would mean trouble like the Ministry hasn't had to cope with for nearly fourteen yea 's,' said Gustavo bitterly. 'Fudge just can't bring himself to face it. It's so much more comfortable to convince himself Dominguez's lying to destabilise him.'
    'You see the problem,' said Cardozo. 'While the Ministry insists there is nothing to fear from Salvador it's hard to convince people he's back, especially as they really don't want to believe it in the first place. What's more, the Ministry's leaning heavily on the Daily Prophet not to report any of what they're calling Dominguez's rumour-mongering, so most of the wizarding community are completely unaware anything's happened, and that makes them easy targets for the Death Eaters if they're using the Imperius Curse.'
    'But you're telling people, aren't you?' said Roberto, looking around at Mr Lopez, Gustavo, Bill, Mundungus, Cardozo and Perez. 'You're letting people know he's back?'
    They all smiled humourlessly.
    'Well, as everyone thinks I'm a mad mass-murderer and the Ministry's put a ten thousand Galleon price on my head, I can hardly stroll up the street and start handing out leaflets, can I?' said Gustavo restlessly.
    'And I'm not a very popular dinner guest with most of the community,' said Cardozo. 'It's an occupational hazard of being a werewolf.'
    'Perez and Raul would lose their jobs at the Ministry if they started shooting their mouths off,' said Gustavo, 'and it's very important
    for us to have spies inside the Ministry, because you can bet Salvador will have them.'
    'We've managed to convince a couple of people, though,' said Mr Lopez. Perez here, for one - she's too young to have been in the Order of the Phoenix last time, and having Aurors on our side is a huge advantage - Hector Maldonado's been a real asset, too; he's in charge of the hunt for Gustavo, so he's been feeding the Ministry information that Gustavo is in Tibet.'
    'But if none of you are putting the news out that Salvador's back - ' Roberto began.
    'Who said none of us are putting the news out?' said Gustavo. 'Why d'you think Dominguez's in such trouble?'
    'What d'you mean?' Roberto asked.
    They're trying to discredit him,' said Cardozo. 'Didn't you see the Daily Prophet last week? They reported that he'd been voted out of the Chairmanship of the International Confederation of Wizards because he's getting old and losing his grip, but it's not true; he was voted out by Ministry wizards after he made a speech announcing Salvador's return. They've demoted him from Chief Warlock on the Wizengamot - that's the Wizard High Court - and they're talking about taking away his Order of Merlin, First Class, too.'
    'But Dominguez says he doesn't care what they do as long as they don't take him off the Paulacolate Frog Cards,' said Bill, grinning.
    'It's no laughing matter,' said Mr Lopez sharply. 'If he carries on defying the Ministry like this he could end up in Azkaban, and the last thing we want is to have Dominguez locked up. While You-Know-Who knows Dominguez's out there and wise to what he's up to he's going to go cautiously. If Dominguez's out of the way - well, You-Know-Who will have a clear field.'
    'But if Salvador's trying to recruit more Death Eaters it's bound to get out that he's come back, isn't it?' asked Roberto desperately.
    'Salvador doesn't march up to people's houses and bang on their front doors, Roberto,' said Gustavo. 'He tricks, jinxes and blackmails them. He's well-practised at operating in secret. In any case, gathering followers is only one thing he's interested in. He's got other plans too, plans he can put into operation very quietly indeed, and he's concentrating on those for the moment.'
    'What's he after apart from followers?' Roberto asked swiftly. He thought he saw Gustavo and Cardozo exchange the most fleeting of looks before Gustavo answered.
    'Stuff he can only get by stealth.'
    When Roberto continued to look puzzled, Gustavo said, 'Like a weapon. Something he didn't have last time.'
    'When he was powerful before?'
    'Yes.'
    'Like what kind of weapon?' said Roberto. 'Something worse than the Avada Kedavra - ?'
    That's enough!'
    Mrs Lopez spoke from the shadows beside the door. Roberto hadn't noticed her return from taking Martina upstairs. Her arms were crossed and she looked furious.
    'I want you in bed, now. All of you,' she added, looking around at Pablo, Luis, Diego and Carolina.
    'You can't boss us - ' Pablo began.
    'Watch me,' snarled Mrs Lopez. She was trembling slightly as she looked at Gustavo. 'You've given Roberto plenty of information. Any more and you might just as well induct him into the Order straightaway.'
    'Why not?' said Roberto quickly. 'I'll join, I want to join, I want to fight.'
    'No.'
    It was not Mrs Lopez who spoke this time, but Cardozo.
    The Order is comprised only of overage wizards,' he said. 'Wizards who have left school,' he added, as Pablo and Luis opened their mouths. There are dangers involved of which you can have no idea, any of you . . . I think Alicia's right, Gustavo. We've said enough.'
    Gustavo half-shrugged but did not argue. Mrs Lopez beckoned imperiously to her sons and Herrnione. One by one they stood up and Roberto, recognising defeat, followed suit.
- CHAPTER SIX -
The Noble and Most
Ancient House of Martinez
Mrs Lopez followed them upstairs looking grim.
    'I want you all to go straight to bed, no talking,' she said as they reached the first landing, 'we've got a busy clay tomorrow. I expect Martina's asleep,' she added to Carolina, 'so try not to wake her up.'
    'Asleep, yeah, right,' said Pablo in an undertone, after Carolina bade them goodnight and they were climbing to the next floor. 'If Martina's not lying awake waiting for Carolina to tell her everything they said downstairs then I'm a Flobberworm . . .'
    'All right, Diego, Roberto,' said Mrs Lopez on the second landing, pointing them into their bedroom. 'Off to bed with you.'
    "Night,' Roberto and Diego said to the twins.
    'Sleep tight,' said Pablo, winking.
    Mrs Lopez closed the door behind Roberto with a sharp snap. The bedroom looked, if anything, even danker and gloomier than it had on first sight. The blank picture on the wall was now breathing very slowly and deeply, as though its invisible occupant was asleep. Roberto put on his pyjamas, took off his glasses and climbed into his chilly bed while Diego threw Owl Treats up on top of the wardrobe to pacify Hedwig and Pigwidgeon, who were clattering around and rustling their wings restlessly.
    'We can't let them out to hunt every night,' Diego explained as he pulled on his maroon pyjamas. 'Dominguez doesn't want too many owls swooping around the square, thinks it'll look suspicious. Oh yeah . . . I forgot . . .'
    He crossed to the door and bolted it.
    'What're you doing that for?'
    'Kreacher,' said Diego as he turned off the light. 'First night I was here he came wandering in at three in the morning. Trust me, you don't want to wake up and find him prowling around your room. Anyway . . .' he got into his bed, settled down under the co\ers then turned to look at Roberto in the darkness; Roberto could see his outline by the moonlight filtering in through the grimy window, 'what d'you reckon?'
    Roberto didn't need to ask what Diego meant.
    'Well, they didn't tell us much we couldn't have guessed, did they?' he said, thinking of all that had been said downstairs. 'I mean, all they've really said is that the Order's trying to stop pec pie joining Vol-'
    There was a sharp intake of breath from Diego. -demon,' said Roberto firmly. 'When are you going to start using his name? Gustavo and Cardozo do.'
    Diego ignored this last comment.
    'Yeah, you're right,' he said, 'we already knew nearly everything they told us, from using the Extendable Ears. The only new bit was - '
    Crack.
    'OUCH!'
    'Keep your voice down, Diego, or Mum'll be back up here.'
    'You two just Apparated on my knees!'
    'Yeah, well, it's harder in the dark.'
    Roberto saw the blurred outlines of Pablo and Luis leaping down from Diego's bed. There was a groan of bedsprings and Roberto's mattress descended a few inches as Luis sat down near his feet.
    'So, got there yet?' said Luis eagerly.
    The weapon Gustavo mentioned?' said Roberto.
    'Let slip, more like,' said Pablo with relish, now sitting next to Diego. 'We didn't hear about that on the old Extendables, did we?'
    'What d'you reckon it is?' said Roberto.
    'Could be anything,' said Pablo.
    'But there can't be anything worse than the Avada Kedavra Curse, can there?' said Diego. 'What's worse than death?'
    'Maybe it's something that can kill loads of people at once,' suggested Luis.
    'Maybe it's some particularly painful way of killing people,' said Diego learfully.
    'He's got the Cruciatus Curse for causing pain,' said Roberto, 'he doesn't need anything more efficient than that.'
    There was a pause and Roberto knew that the others, like him, were wondering what horrors this weapon could perpetrate.
    'So who d'you think's got it now?' asked Luis.
    'I hope it's our side,' said Diego, sounding slightly nervous.
    'If it is, Dominguez's probably keeping it,' said Pablo.
    'Where?' said Diego quickly. 'Hogwarts?'
    'Bet it is!' said Luis. That's where he hid the Philosopher's Stone.'
    'A weapons going to be a lot bigger than the Stone, though!' said Diego.
    'Not necessarily,' said Pablo.
    'Yeah, size is no guarantee of power,' said Luis. 'Look at Martina'
    'What d'you mean?' said Roberto.
    'You've never been on the receiving end of one of her Bat-Bogey Hexes, have you?'
    'Shhh!' said Pablo, half-rising from the bed. 'Listen!'
    They fell silent. Footsteps were coming up the stairs.
    'Mum,' said Luis and without further ado there was a loud crack and Roberto felt the weight vanish from the end of his bed. A few seconds later, they heard the floorboard creak outside their door; Mrs Lopez was plainly listening to check whether or not they were talking.
    Hedwig and Pigwidgeon hooted dolefully. The floorboard creaked again and they heard her heading upstairs to check on Pablo and Luis.
    'She doesn't trust us at all, you know,' said Diego regretfully.
    Roberto was sure he would not be able to fall asleep; the evening had been so packed with things to think about that he fully expected to lie awake for hours mulling it all over. He wanted to continue talking to Diego, but Mrs Lopez was now creaking back downstairs again, and once she had gone he distinctly heard others making their way upstairs . . . in fact, many-legged creatures were cantering softly up and down outside the bedroom door, and Villalba the Care of Magical Creatures teacher was saying, 'Beauties, aren'ti they, eh, Roberto? We'll be studyin' weapons this term . . .' and Roberto saw hat the creatures had cannons for heads and were wheeling to ace him . . . he ducked . . .
    The next thing he knew, he was curled into a warm ball under his bedclothes and Luis's loud voice was filling the room.
    'Mum says get up, your breakfast is in the kitchen and then she needs you in the drawing room, there are loads more Doxys than she thought and she's found a nest of dead Puffskeins under the sofa.'
    Half an hour later Roberto and Diego, who had dressed and breakfasted quickly, entered the drawing room, a long, high-ceilinged room on the first floor with olive green walls covered in dirty .ap-estries. The carpet exhaled little clouds of dust every time someone put their foot on it and the long, moss green velvet curtains were buzzing as though swarming with invisible bees. It was aroand these that Mrs Lopez, Carolina, Martina, Pablo and Luis were grouped, all looking rather peculiar as they had each tied a cloth over their nose and mouth. Each of them was also holding a large bottle of black liquid with a nozzle at the end
    'Cover your faces and take a spray,' Mrs Lopez said to Roberto and Diego the moment she saw them, pointing to two more boitles of black liquid standing on a spindle-legged table. 'It's Doxycide. I've never seen an infestation this bad - what that house-elf's Veen doing for the last ten years - '
    Carolina's face was half concealed by a tea towel but Roberto distinctly saw her throw a reproachful look at Mrs Lopez.
    'Kreachers really old, he probably couldn't manage - '
    'You'd be surprised what Kreacher can manage when he wnnts to, Carolina,' said Gustavo, who had just entered the room carrying a bloodstained bag of what appeared to be dead rats. 'I've just been feeding Buckbeak,' he added, in reply to Roberto's enquiring look. 'I keep him upstairs in my mother's bedroom. Anyway . . . this writing desk . . .'
    He dropped the bag of rats into an armchair, then bent over to examine the locked cabinet which, Roberto now noticed for the first time, was shaking slightly.
    'Well, Alicia, I'm pretty sure this is a Boggart,' said Gustavo, peering through the keyhole, 'but perhaps we ought to let Mad-Eye have a shifty at it before we let it out - knowing my mother, it could be something much worse.'
    'Right you are, Gustavo,' said Mrs Lopez.
    They were both speaking in carefully light, polite voices that told Roberto quite plainly that neither had forgotten their disagreement of the night before.
