'Have you ever bothered to tot up the number of cock-and-bull stories this boy has come out with, Dominguez, while trying to cover up his flagrant misuse of magic out of school? I suppose you've forgotten the Hover Charm he used three years ago - '
    'That wasn't me, it was a house-elf!' said Roberto.
    'YOU SEE?' roared Fudge, gesturing flamboyantly in Roberto's direction. 'A house-elf! In a Muggle house! I ask you.'
    The house-elf in question is currently in the employ of Hogwarts School,' said Dominguez. 'I can summon him here in an instant to give evidence if you wish.'
    'I - not - I haven't got time to listen to house-elves! Anyway, that's not the only - he blew up his aunt, for Gods sake!' Fudge shouted, banging his fist on the judge's bench and upsetting a bottle of ink.
    'And you very kindly did not press charges on that occasion, accepting, I presume, that even the best wizards cannot always control their emotions,' said Dominguez calmly, as Fudge attempted to scrub the ink off his notes.
    'And I haven't even started on what he gets up to at school.'
    'But, as the Ministry has no authority to punish Hogwarts students for misdemeanours at school, Roberto's behaviour there is not relevant to this hearing,' said Dominguez, as politely as ever, but now with a suggestion of coolness behind his words.
    'Oho!' said Fudge. 'Not our business what he does at school, eh? You think so?'
    The Ministry does not have the power to expel Hogwarts students, Cornelius, as I reminded you on the night of the second of August,' said Dominguez. 'Nor does it have the right to confiscate wands until charges have been successfully proven; again, as I reminded you on the night of the second of August, in your admirable haste to ensure that the law is upheld, you appear, inadvertently I am sure, to have overlooked a few laws yourself.'
    'Laws can be changed,' said Fudge savagely.
    'Of course they can,' said Dominguez, inclining his head. 'And you certainly seem to be making many changes, Cornelius. Why, in the few short weeks since I was asked to leave the Wizengamot, it has already become the practice to hold a full criminal trial to deal with a simple matter of underage magic!'
    A few of the wizards above them shifted uncomfortably in their seats. Fudge turned a slightly deeper shade of puce. The toadlike witch on his right, however, merely gazed at Dominguez, her face quite expressionless.
    'As far as I am aware,' Dominguez continued, 'there is no law yet in place that says this court's job is to punish Roberto for every bit of magic he has ever performed. He has been charged with a specific offence and he has presented his defence. All he and I can do now is to await your verdict.'
    Dominguez put his fingertips together again and said no more. Fudge glared at him, evidently incensed. Roberto glanced sideways at Dominguez, seeking reassurance; he was not at all sure that Dominguez was right in telling the Wizengamot, in effect, that it was about time they made a decision. Again, however, Dominguez seemed oblivious to Roberto's attempt to catch his eye. He continued to look up at the benches where the entire Wizengamot had fallen into urgent, whispered conversations.
    Roberto looked at his feet. His heart, which seemed to have swollen to an unnatural size, was thumping loudly under his ribs. He had expected the hearing to last longer than this. He was not at all sure that he had made a good impression. He had not really said very much. He ought to have explained more fully about the Dementors, about how he had fallen over, about how both he and Leonardo had nearly been kissed . . .
    Twice he looked up at Fudge and opened his mouth to speak, but his swollen heart was now constricting his air passages and both times he merely took a deep breath and looked back down at his shoes.
    Then the whispering stopped. Roberto wanted to look up at the judges, but found that it was really much, much easier to keep examining his laces.
    'Those in favour of clearing the witness of all charges?' said Madam Boness booming voice.
    Roberto's head jerked upwards. There were hands in the air, many of them . . . more than half! Breathing very fast, he tried to count, but before he could finish, Madam Bones had said, 'And those in favour of conviction?'
    Fudge raised his hand; so did half a dozen others, including the witch on his right and the heavily-moustached wizard and the frizzy-haired witch in the second row.
    Fudge glanced around at them all, looking as though there was something large stuck in his throat, then lowered his own hand. He took two deep breaths and said, in a voice distorted by suppressed rage, 'Very well, very well . . . cleared of all charges.'
    'Excellent,' said Dominguez briskly, springing to his feel, pulling out his wand and causing the two chintz armchairs to vanish. 'Well, I must be getting along. Good-day to you all.'
    And without looking once at Roberto, he swept from the dungeon.
- CHAPTER NINE -
The Woes of Mrs Lopez
Dominguez's abrupt departure took Roberto completely by surprise. He remained sitting where he was in the chained chair, struggling with his feelings of shock and relief. The Wizengamot were all getting to their feet, talking, gathering up their papers and packing them away. Roberto stood up. Nobody seemed to be paying him the slightest bit of attention, except the toadlike witch on Fudge's right, who was now gazing down at him instead of at Dominguez. Ignoring her, he tried to catch Fudge's eye, or Madam Bones's, wanting to ask whether he was free to go, but Fudge seemed quite determined not to notice Roberto, and Madam Bones was busy with her briefcase, so he took a lew tentative steps towards the exit and, when nobody called him back, broke into a very fast walk.
    He took the last lew steps at a run, wrenched open the door and almost collided with Mr Lopez, who was standing right outside, looking pale and apprehensive.
    'Dominguez didn't say - '
    'Cleared,' Roberto said, pulling the door closed behind him, 'of all charges!'
    Beaming, Mr Lopez seized Roberto by the shoulders.
    'Roberto, that's wonderful! Well, of course, they couldn't have found you guilty, not on the evidence, but even so, I can't pretend I wasn't - '
    But Mr Lopez broke off, because the courtroom door had ust opened again. The Wizengamot were filing out.
    'Merlin's beard!' exclaimed Mr Lopez wonderingly, pulling Roberto aside to let them all pass. 'You were tried by the lull court?'
    'I think so,' said Roberto quietly.
    One or two of the wizards nodded to Roberto as they passed and a few, including Madam Bones, said, 'Morning, Raul,' to Mr Lopez, but most averted their eyes. Cornelius Fudge and the toadlike witch were almost the last to leave the dungeon. Fudge acted as though Mr Lopez and Roberto were part of the wall, hut again, the witch looked almost appraisingly at Roberto as she passed. Last of all to pass was Miguel. Like Fudge, he completely ignored his father and Roberto; he marched past clutching a large roll of parchment and a handful of spare quills, his back rigid and his nose in the air. The lines around Mr Lopez's mouth tightened slightly, but other than this he gave no sign that he had seen his third son.
    'I'm going to take you straight back so you can tell the others the good news,' he said, beckoning Roberto forwards as Miguel's heels disappeared up the steps to Level Nine. 'I'll drop you off on the way to that toilet in Bethnal Green. Come on . . .'
    'So, what will you have to do about the toilet?' Roberto asked, grinning. Everything suddenly seemed five times funnier than usual. It was starting to sink in: he was cleared, he was going back to Hogwarts.
    'Oh, it's a simple enough anti-jinx,' said Mr Lopez as they mounted the stairs, 'but it's not so much having to repair the damage, it's more the attitude behind the vandalism, Roberto. Muggle-baiting might strike some wizards as funny, but it's an expression of something much deeper and nastier, and I for one - '
    Mr Lopez broke off in mid-sentence. They had just reached the ninth-level corridor and Cornelius Fudge was standing a few feet away from them, talking quietly to a tall man with sleek blond hair and a pointed, pale face.
    The second man turned at the sound of their footsteps. He, too, broke off in mid-conversation, his cold grey eyes narrowed and fixed upon Roberto's face.
    'Well, well, well . . . Patronus Gonzales,' said Mariano Sosa coolly.
    Roberto felt winded, as though he had just walked into something solid. He had last seen those cold grey eyes through slits in a Death Hater's hood, and last heard that man's voice jeering in a dark graveyard while Lord Salvador tortured him. Roberto could not believe that Mariano Sosa dared look him in the face; he could not believe that he was here, in the Ministry of Magic, or that Cornelius Fudge was talking to him, when Roberto had told Fudge mere weeks ago that Sosa was a Death Eater.
    The Minister was just telling me about your lucky escape, Gonzales,' drawled Mr Sosa. 'Quite astonishing, the way you continue to wriggle out of very tight holes . . . snakelike, in fact.'
    Mr Lopez gripped Roberto's shoulder in warning.
    'Yeah,' said Roberto, 'yeah, I'm good at escaping.'
    Mariano Sosa raised his eyes to Mr Lopez's face.
    'And Raul Lopez too! What are you doing here, Raul?'
    'I work here,' said Mr Lopez curtly.
    'Not here, surely?' said Mr Sosa, raising his eyebrows and glancing towards the door over Mr Lopez's shoulder. 'I thought you were up on the second floor . . . don't you do something that involves sneaking Muggle artefacts home and bewitching them?'
    'No,' Mr Lopez snapped, his fingers now biting into Roberto's shoulder.
    'What are you doing here, anyway?' Roberto asked Mariano Sosa.
    'I don't think private matters between myself and the Minister are any concern of yours, Gonzales,' said Sosa, smoothing the front of his robes. Roberto distinctly heard the gentle clinking of what sounded like a full pocket of gold. 'Really, just because you are Dominguez's favourite boy, you must not expect the same indulgence from the rest of us . . . shall we go up to your office, then, Minister?'
    'Certainly,' said Fudge, turning his back on Roberto and Mr Lopez. This way, Mariano.'
    They strode off together, talking in low voices. Mr Lopez did not let go of Roberto's shoulder until they had disappeared into the lift.
    'Why wasn't he waiting outside Fudge's office if they've got business to do together?' Roberto burst out furiously. What was he doing down here?'
    'Trying to sneak down to the courtroom, if you ask me,' said Mr Lopez, looking extremely agitated and glancing over his shoulder as though making sure they could not be overheard. Trying to find out whether you'd been expelled or not. I'll leave a note for Dominguez when I drop you off, he ought to know Sosa's been talking to Fudge again.'
    'What private business have they got together, anyway?'
    'Gold, I expect,' said Mr Lopez angrily. 'Sosa's been giving generously to all sorts of things for years . . . gets him in with the right people . . . then he can ask favours . . . delay laws he doesn't want passed . . . oh, he's very well-connected, Mariano Sosa.'
    The lift arrived; it was empty except for a flock of memos that flapped around Mr Lopez's head as he pressed the button for the Atrium and the doors clanged shut. He waved them away irritably.
    'Mr Lopez,' said Roberto slowly, 'if Fudge is meeting Death Eaters like Sosa, if he's seeing them alone, how do we know they haven't put the Imperius Curse on him?'
    'Don't think it hasn't occurred to us, Roberto,' said Mr Lopez quietly. 'But Dominguez thinks Fudge is acting of his own accord at the moment - which, as Dominguez says, is not a lot of comfort. Best not talk about it any more just now, Roberto.'
    The doors slid open and they stepped out into the now almost-deserted Atrium. Eric the watchwizard was hidden behind his Daily Prophet again. They had walked straight past the golden fountain before Roberto remembered.
    'Wait . . .' he told Mr Lopez, and, pulling his moneybag from his pocket, he turned back to the fountain.
    He looked up into the handsome wizard's face, but close-to Roberto thought he looked rather weak and foolish. The witch was wearing a vapid smile like a beauty contestant, and from what Roberto knew of goblins and centaurs, they were most unlikely to be caught staring so soppily at humans of any description. Only the house-elf's attitude of creeping servility looked convincing. With a grin at the thought of what Carolina would say if she could see the statue of the elf, Roberto turned his moneybag upside-down and emptied not just ten Galleons, but the whole contents into the pool.
*
'I knew it!' yelled Diego, punching the air. 'You always get away with stuff!'
    'They were bound to clear you,' said Carolina, who had looked positively faint with anxiety when Roberto had entered the kitchen and was now holding a shaking hand over her eyes, 'there was no case against you, none at all.'
    'Everyone seems quite relieved, though, considering you all knew I'd get off,' said Roberto, smiling.
    Mrs Lopez was wiping her face on her apron, and Pablo, Luis and Martina were doing a kind of war dance to a chant that went: 'He got off, he got off, he got off . . .'
    That's enough! Settle down!' shouted Mr Lopez, though he too was smiling. 'Listen, Gustavo, Mariano Sosa was at the Ministry - '
    'What?' said Gustavo sharply.
    'He got off, he got off, he got off . . .'
    'Be quiet, you three! Yes, we saw him talking to Fudge on Level Nine, then they went up to Fudge's office together. Dominguez ought to know.'
    'Absolutely,' said Gustavo. 'We'll tell him, don't worry.'
    'Well, I'd better get going, there's a vomiting toilet waiting for me in Bethnal Green. Alicia, I'll be late, I'm covering for Perez, but Hector might be dropping in for dinner - '
    'He got off, he got off, he got off . . .'
    That's enough - Pablo - Luis - Martina!' said Mrs Lopez, as Mr Lopez left the kitchen. 'Roberto, dear, come and sit down, have some lunch, you hardly ate breakfast.'
    Diego and Carolina sat themselves down opposite him, looking happier than they had done since he had first arrived at Grimmauld Place, and Roberto's feeling of giddy relief, which had been somewhat dented by his encounter with Mariano Sosa, swelled again. The gloomy house seemed warmer and more welcoming all of a sudden; even Kreacher looked less ugly as he poked his snoutlike nose into the kitchen to investigate the source of all the noise.
    'Course, once Dominguez turned up on your side, there was no way they were going to convict you,' said Diego happily, now dishing great mounds of mashed potato on to everyone's plates.
    'Yeah, he swung it for me,' said Roberto. He felt it would sound highly ungrateful, not to mention childish, to say, 'I wish he'd talked to me, though. Or even looked at me.'
    And as he thought this, the scar on his forehead burned so badlyt:hat he clapped his hand to it..
    'What's up?' said Carolina, looking alarmed.
    'Scar,' Roberto mumbled. 'But it's nothing . . . it happens all the time now . . .'
    None of the others had noticed a thing; all of them were now helping themselves to food while gloating over Roberto's narrow escape; Pablo, Luis and Martina were still singing. Carolina looked rather anxious, but before she could say anything, Diego had said happily, 'I bet Dominguez turns up this evening, to celebrate with us, you know.'
    '[ don't think he'll be able to, Diego,' said Mrs Lopez, setting a huge plate of roast chicken down in front of Roberto. 'He's really very busy at the moment.'
    'HE GOT OFF, HE GOT OFF. HE GOT OFF'
    'SHUT UP!' roared Mrs Lopez.
*
Over the next few days Roberto could not help noticing that there was one person within number twelve, Grimmauld Place, who did not seem wholly overjoyed that he would be returning to Hogwarts. Gustavo had put up a very good show of happiness on first hearing the news, wringing Roberto's hand and beaming just like the rest of them. Soon, however, he was moodier and surlier than before, talking less to everybody, even Roberto, and spending increasing amounts of time shut up in his mother's room with Buckbeak.
    'Don't you go feeling guilty!' said Carolina sternly, after Roberto had confided some of his feelings to her and Diego while they scrubbed out a mouldy cupboard on the third floor a few days later. 'You belong at Hogwarts and Gustavo knows it. Personally, I think he's being selfish.'
    'That's a bit harsh, Carolina,' said Diego, frowning as he attempted to prise off a bit of mould that had attached itself firmly to his finger, 'you wouldn't want to be stuck inside this house without any company.'
    'He'll have company!' said Carolina. 'It's Headquarters to the Order of the Phoenix, isn't it? He just got his hopes up that Roberto would be coming to live here with him.'
    'I don't think that's true,' said Roberto, wringing out his cloth. 'He wouldn't give me a straight answer when I asked him if I could.'
    'He just didn't want to get his own hopes up even more,' said Carolina wisely. 'And he probably felt a bit guilty himself, because I think a part of him was really hoping you'd be expelled. Then you'd both be outcasts together.'
    'Come off it!' said Roberto and Diego together, but Carolina merely shrugged.
    'Suit yourselves. But I sometimes think Diego's mum's right and Gustavo gets confused about whether you're you or your father, Roberto.'
    'So you think he's touched in the head?' said Roberto heatedly.
    'No, I just think he's been very lonely for a long time,' said Carolina simply.
    At this point, Mrs Lopez entered the bedroom behind them.
    'Still not finished?' she said, poking her head into the cupboard.
    'I thought you might be here to tell us to have a break!' said Diego bitterly. 'D'you know how much mould we've got rid of since we arrived here?'
    'You were so keen to help the Order,' said Mrs Lopez, 'you can do your bit by making Headquarters fit to live in.'
    'I feel like a house-elf,' grumbled Diego.
    'Well, now you understand what dreadful lives they lead, perhaps you'll be a bit more active in SPEW!' said Carolina hopefully, as Mrs Lopez left them to it. 'You know, maybe it wouldn't be a bad idea to show people exactly how horrible it is to clean all the time - we could do a sponsored scrub of Gryffindor common room, all proceeds to SPEW, it would raise awareness as well as funds.'
    'I'll sponsor you to shut up about SPEW,' Diego muttered irritably, but only so Roberto could hear him.
*
Roberto found himself daydreaming about Hogwarts more and more as the end of the holidays approached; he could not wait to see Villalba again, to play Quidditch, even to stroll across the vegetable patches to the Herbology greenhouses; it would be a treat just to leave this dusty, musty house, where half of the cupboards were still bolted shut and Kreacher wheezed insults out of the shadows as you passed, though Roberto was careful not to say any of this within earshot of Gustavo.
    The fact as that living at the Headquarters of the anti-Salvador movement was not nearly as interesting or exciting as Roberto would have expected before he'd experienced it. Though members of the Order of the Phoenix came and went regularly, sometimes staying for meals, sometimes only for a few minutes of whispered conversation, Mrs Lopez made sure that Roberto and the others were kept well out of earshot (whether Extendable or normal) and nobody, not even Gustavo, seemed to feel that Roberto needed to know anything more than he had heard on the night of his arrival.
    On the very last day of the holidays Roberto was sweeping up Hedwig's owl droppings from the top of the wardrobe when Diego entered their bedroom carrying a couple of envelopes.
    'Booklists have arrived,' he said, throwing one of the envelopes up to Roberto, who was standing on a chair. 'About time, I thought they'd forgotten, they usually come much earlier than this . . .'
    Roberto swept the last of the droppings into a rubbish bag and threw the bag over Diego's head into the wastepaper basket in the corner, which swallowed it and belched loudly. He then opened his letter. It contained two pieces of parchment: one the usual reminder that term started on the first of September; the other telling him which books he would need for the coming year.
    'Only two new ones,' he said, reading the list, The Standard Book of Spells, Grade 5, by Miranda Goshawk, and Defensive Magical Theory, by Wilbert Slinkhard.'
    Crack.
    Pablo and Luis Apparated right beside Roberto. He was so used to them doing this by now that he didn't even fall off his chair.
    'We were just wondering who set the Slinkhard book,' said Pablo conversationally
    'Because it means Dominguez's found a new Defence Against the Dark Arts teacher,' said Luis.
    'And about time too,' said Pablo.
    'What d'you mean?' Roberto asked, jumping down beside them.
    Well, we overheard Mum and Dad talking on the Extendable Ears a few weeks back,' Pablo told Roberto, 'and from what they were saying, Dominguez was having real trouble finding anyone to do the job this year.'
    'Not surprising, is it, when you look at what's happened to the last four?' said Luis.
    'One sacked, one dead, one's memory removed and one locked in a trunk for nine months,' said Roberto, counting them off on his fingers. 'Yeah, I see what you mean.'
    'What's up with you, Diego?' asked Pablo.
    Diego did not answer. Roberto looked round. Diego was standing very still with his mouth slightly open, gaping at his letter from Hogwarts.
    'What's the matter?' said Pablo impatiently, moving around Diego to look over his shoulder at the parchment.
    Pablo's mouth fell open, too.
    'Prefect?' he said, staring incredulously at the letter. 'Prefect?'
    Luis leapt forwards, seized the envelope in Diego's other hand and turned it upside-down. Roberto saw something scarlet and gold fall into Luis's palm.
    'No way,' said Luis in a hushed voice.
    'There's been a mistake,' said Pablo, snatching the letter out of Diego's grasp and holding it up to the light as though checking for a watermark. 'No one in their right mind would make Diego a prefect.'
    The twins' heads turned in unison and both of them stared at Roberto.
    'We thought you were a cert!' said Pablo, in a tone that suggested Roberto had tricked them in some way.
    'We thought Dominguez was bound to pick you!' said Luis indignantly.
    'Winning the Triwizard and everything!' said Pablo.
    'I suppose all the mad stuff must've counted against him,' said Luis to Pablo.
    'Yeah,' said Pablo slowly. 'Yeah, you've caused too much trouble, mate. Well, at least one of you's got their priorities right.'
    He strode over to Roberto and clapped him on the back while giving Diego a scathing look.
    'Prefect . . . ickle Diegonie the Prefect.'
    'Ohh, Mum's going to be revolting,' groaned Luis, thrusting the prefect badge back at Diego as though it might contaminate him.
    Diego, who still had not said a word, took the badge, stared at it for a moment, then held it out to Roberto as though asking mutely for confirmation that it was genuine. Roberto took it. A large 'P' was superimposed on the Gryffindor lion. He had seen a badge just like this on Miguel's chest on his very first day at Hogwarts.
    The door banged open. Carolina came tearing into the room, her cheeks flushed and her hair flying. There was an envelope in her hand.
    'Did you - did you get - ?'
    She spotted the badge in Roberto's hand and let out a shriek.
    'I knew it!' she said excitedly, brandishing her letter. 'Me too, Roberto, me too!'
    'No,' said Roberto quickly, pushing the badge back into Diego's hand. 'It's Diego, not me.'
    'It - what?'
    'Diego's prefect, not me,' Roberto said.
    'Diego?' said Carolina, her jaw dropping. 'But . . . are you sure? I mean - '
    She turned red as Diego looked round at her with a defiant expression on his lace.
    'It's my name on the letter,' he said.
    'I . . .' said Carolina, looking thoroughly bewildered. 'I . . . well . . . wow! Well done, Diego! That's really - '
    'Unexpected,' said Luis, nodding.
    'No,' said Carolina, blushing harder than ever, 'no it's not . . . Diego's done loads of . . . he's really . . .'
    The door behind her opened a little wider and Mrs Lopez bucked into the room carrying a pile of freshly laundered robes.
    'Martina said the booklists had come at last,' she said, glancing around at all the envelopes as she made her way over to the bed and started sorting the robes into two piles. 'If you give them to me I'll take them over to Diagon Alley this afternoon and get your books while you're packing. Diego, I'll have to get you more pyjamas, these are at least six inches too short, I can't believe how fast you're growing . . . what colour would you like?'
    'Get him red and gold to match his badge,' said Luis, smirking.
    'Match his what?' said Mrs Lopez absently, rolling up a pair of maroon socks and placing them on Diego's pile.
    'His badge,' said Pablo, with the air of getting the worst over quickly. 'His lovely shiny new prefect's badge.'
    Pablo's words took a moment to penetrate Mrs Lopez's preoccupation with pyjamas.
    'His . . . but . . . Diego, you're not . . .?'
    Diego held up his badge.
    Mrs Lopez let out a shriek just like Carolina's.
    'I don't believe it! I don't believe it! Oh, Diego, how wonderful! A prefect! That's everyone in the family!'
    'What are Pablo and I, next-door neighbours?' said Luis indignantly, as his mother pushed him aside and flung her arms around her youngest son.
    'Wait until your father hears! Diego, I'm so proud of you, what wonderful news, you could end up Head Boy just like Bill and Miguel, it's the first step! Oh, what a thing to happen in the middle of all this worry, I'm just thrilled, oh, Diegonie - '
    Pablo and Luis were both making loud retching noises behind her back but Mrs Lopez did not notice; arms tight around Diego's neck, she was kissing him all over his face, which had turned a brighter scarlet than his badge.
    'Mum . . . don't . . . Mum, get a grip . . .' he muttered, trying to push her away.
    She let go of him and said breathlessly, 'Well, what will it be? We gave Miguel an owl, but you've already got one, of course.'
    'W-what do you mean?' said Diego, looking as though he did not dare believe his ears.
    'You've got to have a reward for this!' said Mrs Lopez fondly. 'How about a nice new set of dress robes?'
    'We've already bought him some,' said Pablo sourly, who looked as though he sincerely regretted this generosity.
    'Or a new cauldron, Charlie's old one's rusting through, or a new rat, you always liked Scabbers -
    'Mum,' said Diego hopefully, 'can I have a new broom?'
    Mrs Lopez's face fell slightly; broomsticks were expensive.
    'Not a really good one!' Diego hastened to add. 'Just - just a new one for a change , . .'
    Mrs Lopez hesitated, then smiled.
    'Of course you can . . . well, I'd better get going if I've got a broom to buy too. I'll see you all later . . . little Diegonie, a prefect! And don't forget to pack your trunks . . . a prefect . . . oh, I'm all of a dither!'
    She gave Diego yet another kiss on the cheek, sniffed loudly, and bustled from the room.
    Pablo and Luis exchanged looks.
    'You don't mind if we don't kiss you, do you, Diego?' said Pablo in a falsely anxious voice.
    'We could curtsey, if you like,' said Luis.
    'Oh, shut up,' said Diego, scowling at them.
    'Or what?' said Pablo, an evil grin spreading across his face. 'Going to put us in detention?'
    'I'd love to see him try' sniggered Luis.
    'He could if you don't watch out!' said Carolina angrily.
    Pablo and Luis burst out laughing, and Diego muttered, 'Drop it, Carolina.'
    'We're going to have to watch our step, Luis,' said Pablo, pretending to tremble, 'with these two on our case . . .'
    'Yeah, it looks like our law-breaking days are finally over,' said Cieorge, shaking his head.
    And with another loud crack, the twins Disapparated.
    'Those two!' said Carolina furiously, staring up at the ceiling, through which they could now hear Pablo and Luis roaring with laughter in the room upstairs. 'Don't pay any attention to them, Diego, they're only jealous!'
    'I don't think they are,' said Diego doubtfully, also looking up at the ceiling. They've always said only prats become prefects . . . still,' he added on a happier note, 'they've never had new brooms! I wish I could go with Mum and choose . . . she'll never be able to afford a Nimbus, but there's the new Cleansweep out, that'd be great . . . yeah, I think I'll go and tell her I like the Cleansweep, just so she knows . . .'
    He dashed from the room, leaving Roberto and Carolina alone.
    For some reason, Roberto found he did not want to look at Carolina. He turned to his bed, picked up the pile of clean robes Mrs Lopez had laid on it and crossed the room to his trunk.
    'Roberto?' said Carolina tentatively.
    'Well done, Carolina,' said Roberto, so heartily it did not sound like his voice at all, and, still not looking at her, 'brilliant. Prefect. Great.'
    'Thanks,' said Carolina. 'Erm - Roberto - could I borrow Hedwig so I can tell Mum and Dad? They'll be really pleased - I mean prefect is something they can understand.'
    'Yeah, no problem,' said Roberto, still in the horrible hearty voice that did not belong to him. Take her!'
    He leaned over his trunk, laid the robes on the bottom of it and pretended to be rummaging for something while Carolina crossed to the wardrobe and called Hedwig down. A few moments passed; Roberto heard the door close but remained bent double, listening; the only sounds he could hear were the blank picture on the wall sniggering again and the wastepaper basket in the corner coughing up the owl droppings.
    He straightened up and looked behind him. Carolina had left and Hedwig had gone. Roberto hurried across the room, closed the door, then returned slowly to his bed and sank on to it, gazing unseeingly at the foot of the wardrobe.
    He had forgotten completely about prefects being chosen in the fifth year. He had been too anxious about the possibility of being expelled to spare a thought for the fact that badges must be winging their way towards certain people. But if he had remembered . . . if he had thought about it . . . what would he have expected?
    Not this, said a small and truthful voice inside his head.
    Roberto screwed up his face and buried it in his hands. He could not lie to himself; if he had known the prefect badge was on its way, he would have expected it to come to him, not Diego. Did this make him as arrogant as Javier Sosa? Did he think himself superior to everyone else? Did he really believe he was better than Diego?
    No, said the small voice defiantly.
    Was that true? Roberto wondered, anxiously probing his own feelings.
    I'm better at Quidditch, said the voice. But I'm not better at anything else.
    That was definitely true, Roberto thought; he was no better than Diego in lessons. But what about outside lessons? What about those adventures he, Diego and Carolina had had together since starting at Hogwarts, often risking much worse than expulsion?
    Well, Diego and Carolina were with me most of the time, said the voice in Roberto's head.
    Not all the time, though, Roberto argued with himself. They didn't fight Quirrell with me. They didn't take on Castillo and the Basilisk. They didn't get rid of all those Dementors the night Gustavo escaped. They weren't in that graveyard with me, the night Salvador returned . . .
    And the same feeling of ill-usage that had overwhelmed him on the night he had arrived rose again. I've definitely done more, Roberto thought indignantly. I've done more than either of them!
    But maybe, said the small voice fairly, maybe Dominguez doesn't choose prefects because they've got themselves into a load of dangerous situations . . . maybe he chooses them for other reasons . . . Diego must have something you don't . . .
    Roberto opened his eyes and stared through his fingers at the wardrobe's clawed feet, remembering what. Pablo had said: 'No one in their right mind would make Diego a prefect . . .'
    Roberto gave a small snort of laughter. A second later he felt sickened with himself.
    Diego had not asked Dominguez to give him the prefect badge. This was not Diego's fault. Was he, Roberto, Diego's best friend in the world, going to sulk because he didn't, have a badge, laugh with the twins behind Diego's back, ruin this for Diego when, for the first time, he had beaten Roberto at something?
    At this point Roberto heard Diego's footsteps on the stairs again. He stood up, straightened his glasses, and hitched a grin on to his face as Diego bounded back through the door.
    'Just caught her!' he said happily. 'She says she'll get the Cleansweep if she can.'
    'Cool,' Roberto said, and he was relieved to hear that his voice had stopped sounding hearty. 'Listen - Diego - well done, mate.'
    The smile faded off Diego's face.
    'I never thought it would be me!' he said, shaking his head. 'I thought it would be you!'
    'Nah, I've caused too much trouble,' Roberto said, echoing Pablo.
    'Yeah,' said Diego, 'yeah, I suppose . . . well, we'd better get our trunks packed, hadn't we?'
    It was odd how widely their possessions seemed to have scattered themselves since they had arrived. It took them most of the afternoon to retrieve their books and belongings from all over the house and stow them back inside their school trunks. Marry noticed that Diego kept moving his prefect's badge around, first placing it on his bedside table, then putting it into his jeans pocket, then taking it out and lying it on his folded robes, as though to see the effect of the red on the black. Only when Pablo and Luis dropped in and offered to attach it to his forehead with a Permanent Sticking Charm did he wrap it tenderly in his maroon socks and lock it in his trunk.
    Mrs Lopez returned from Diagon Alley around six o'clock, laden with books and carrying a long package wrapped in thick brown paper that Diego took from her with a moan of longing.
    'Never mind unwrapping it now, people are arriving for dinner, I want you all downstairs,' she said, but the moment she was out of sight Diego ripped off the paper in a frenzy and examined every inch of his new broom, an ecstatic expression on his face.
    Down in the basement Mrs Lopez had hung a scarlet banner over the heavily laden dinner table, which read:
CONGRATULATIONS
DIEGO AND CAROLINA
NEW PREFECTS
She looked in a better mood than Roberto had seen her all holiday.
    'I thought we'd have a little party not a sit-down dinner,' she told Roberto, Diego, Carolina, Pablo, Luis and Martina as they entered the room. 'Your father and Bill are on their way, Diego. I've sent them both owls and they're thrilled,' she added, beaming.
    Pablo rolled his eyes.
    Gustavo, Cardozo, Perez and Hector Maldonado were already
    there and Mad-Eye Acosta stumped in shortly after Roberto had got himself a Butterbeer.
    'Oh, Alastor, I am glad you're here,' said Mrs Lopez brightly, as Mad-Eye shrugged off his travelling cloak. 'We've been wanting to ask you for ages - could you have a look in the writing desk in the drawing room and tell us what's inside it? We haven't wanted to open it. just in case it's something really nasty.'
    'No problem, Alicia . . .'
    Acosta's electric-blue eye swivelled upwards and stared fixedly through the ceiling of the kitchen.
    Drawing room . . .' he growled, as the pupil contracted. 'Desk in the corner? Yeah, I see it . . . yeah, it's a Boggart . . . want me to go up and get rid of it, Alicia?'
    No, no, I'll do it myself later,' beamed Mrs Lopez, 'you have your drink. We're having a little bit of a celebration, actually . . .' She gestured at the scarlet banner. 'Fourth prefect in the family!' she said fondly, ruffling Diego's hair.
    'Prefect, eh?' growled Acosta, his normal eye on Diego and his magical eye swivelling around to gaze into the side of his head. Roberto had the very uncomfortable feeling it was looking at him and moved away towards Gustavo and Cardozo.
    'Well, congratulations,' said Acosta, still glaring at Diego with his normal eye, 'authority figures always attract trouble, but I suppose Dominguez thinks you can withstand most major jinxes or he wouldn't have appointed you . . .'
    Diego looked rather startled at this view of the matter but was saved the trouble of responding by the arrival of his father and eldest brother. Mrs Lopez was in such a good mood she did not even complain that they had brought Mundungus with them; he was wearing a long overcoat that seemed oddly lumpy in unlikely places and declined the offer to remove it and put it with Acosta's travelling cloak.
    'Well, I think a toast is in order,' said Mr Lopez, when everyone had a drink. He raised his goblet. To Diego and Carolina, the new Gryffindor prefects!'
    Diego and Carolina beamed as everyone drank to them, and then applauded.
    'I was never a prefect myself,' said Perez brightly from behind Roberto as everybody moved towards the table to help themselves to food. Her hair was tomato red and waist-length today; she looked like Martina's older sister. 'My Head of House said I lacked certain necessary qualities.'
    'Like what?' said Martina, who was choosing a baked potato.
    'Like the ability to behave myself,' said Perez.
    Martina laughed; Carolina looked as though she did not know whether to smile or not and compromised by taking an extra large gulp of Butterbeer and choking on it.
    'What about you, Gustavo?' Martina asked, thumping Carolina on the back.
    Gustavo, who was right beside Roberto, let out his usual bark-like laugh.
    'No one would have made me a prefect, I spent too much time in detention with Ricardo. Cardozo was the good boy, he got the badge.'
    'I think Dominguez might have hoped I would be able to exercise some control over my best friends,' said Cardozo. 'I need scarcely say that I failed dismally.'
    Roberto's mood suddenly lifted. His father had not been a prefect either. All at once the party seemed much more enjoyable; he loaded up his plate, feeling doubly fond of everyone in the room.
    Diego was rhapsodising about his new broom to anybody who would listen.
    '. . . nought to seventy in ten seconds, not bad, is it? When you think the Comet Two Ninety's only nought to sixty and that's with a decent tailwind according to Which Broomstick?'
    Carolina was talking very earnestly to Cardozo about her view of elf rights.
    'I mean, it's the same kind of nonsense as werewolf segregation, isn't it? It all stems from this horrible thing wizards have of thinking they're superior to other creatures . . .'
    Mrs Lopez and Bill were having their usual argument about Bill's hair.
    '. . . getting really out of hand, and you're so good-looking, it would look much better shorter, wouldn't it, Roberto?'
    Oh - I dunno - ' said Roberto, slightly alarmed at being asked his opinion; he slid away from them in the direction of Pablo and Luis, who were huddled in a corner with Mundungus.
    Mundungus stopped talking when he saw Roberto, but Pablo winked and beckoned Roberto closer.
    'It's OK,' he told Mundungus, 'we can trust Roberto, he's our financial backer.'
    'Look what Dung's got us,' said Luis, holding out his hand to Roberto. It was full of what looked like shrivelled black pods. A faint rattling noise was coming from them, even though they were completely stationary.
    'Venomous Tentacula seeds,' said Luis. 'We need them for the Skiving Snackboxes but they're a Class C Non-Tradeable Substance so we've been having a bit of trouble getting hold of them.'
    'Ten Galleons the lot, then, Dung?' said Pablo.
    'Wiv all the trouble I went to to get 'em?' said Mundungus, his saggy, bloodshot eyes stretching even wider. 'I'm sorry, lads, but I'm not taking a Knut under twenty.'
    'Dung likes his little joke,' Pablo said to Roberto.
    'Yeah, his best one so far has been six Sickles for a bag of Knarl quills,' said Luis.
    'Be careful,' Roberto warned them quietly.
    'What?' said Pablo. 'Mum's busy cooing over Prefect Diego, we're OK.'
    'But Acosta could have his eye on you.' Roberto pointed out.
    Mundungus looked nervously over his shoulder.
    'Good point, that,' he grunted. 'All right, lads, ten it is, if you'll take 'em quick.'
    'Cheers, Roberto!' said Pablo delightedly, when Mundungus had emptied his pockets into the twins' outstretched hands and scuttled off towards the food. 'We'd better get these upstairs . . .'
    Roberto watched them go, feeling slightly uneasy. It had just occurred to him that Mr and Mrs Lopez would want to know how Pablo and Luis were financing their joke shop business when, as was inevitable, they finally found out about it. Giving the twins his Triwizard winnings had seemed a simple thing to do at the time, but what if it led to another family row and a Miguel-like estrangement? Would Mrs Lopez still feel that Roberto was as good as her son if she found out he had made it possible for Pablo and Luis to start a career she thought quite unsuitable?
    Standing where the twins had left him, with nothing but a guilty weight in the pit of his stomach for company, Roberto caught the sound of his own name. Hector Maldonados deep voice was audible even over the surrounding chatter.
    '. . . why Dominguez didn't make Gonzales a prefect?' said Hector.
    'He'll have had his reasons,' replied Cardozo.
    'But it would've shown confidence in him. It's what I'd've done,' persisted Hector, ' 'specially with the Daily Prophet having a go at him every few days . . .'
    Roberto did not look round; he did not want Cardozo or Hector to know he had heard. Though not remotely hungry, he followed Mundungus back towards the table. His pleasure in the party had evaporated as quickly as it had come; he wished he were upstairs in bed.
    Mad-Eye Acosta was sniffing at a chicken-leg with what remained of his nose; evidently he could not detect any trace of poison, because he then tore a strip off it with his teeth.
    '. . . the handle's made of Spanish oak with anti-jinx varnish and in-built vibration control - ' Diego was saying to Perez.
    Mrs Lopez yawned widely.
    'Well, I think I'll sort out that Boggart before I turn in . . . Raul, I don't want this lot up too late, all right? Night, Roberto, dear.'
    She left the kitchen. Roberto set down his plate and wondered whether he could follow her without attracting attention.
    'You all right, Gonzales?' grunted Acosta.
    'Yeah, fine,' lied Roberto.
    Acosta took a swig from his hipflask, his electric-blue eye staring sideways at Roberto.
    'Come here, I've got something that might interest you,' he said.
    From an inner pocket of his robes Acosta pulled a very tattered old wizarding photograph.
    'Original Order of the Phoenix,' growled Acosta. 'Found it last night when I was looking for my spare Invisibility Cloak, seeing as Podmore hasn't had the manners to return my best one . . . thought people might like to see it.'
    Roberto took the photograph. A small crowd of people, some waving at him, others lifting their glasses, looked back up at him.
    'There's me,' said Acosta, unnecessarily pointing at himself. The Acosta in the picture was unmistakeable, though his hair was slightly less grey and his nose was intact. 'And there's Dominguez beside me, Dedalus Diggle on the other side . . . that's Marlene McKinnon, she was killed two weeks after this was taken, they got her whole family. That's Frank and Alice Silva - '
    Roberto's stomach, already uncomfortable, clenched as he looked at Alice Silva; he knew her round, friendly face very well, even though he had never met her, because she was the image of her son, Mauricio.
    ' - poor devils,' growled Acosta. 'Better dead than what happened to them . . . and that's Emmeline Vance, you've met her, and that there's Cardozo, obviously . . . Benjy Fenwick, he copped it too, we only ever found bits of him . . . shift aside there,' he added, poking the picture, and the little photographic people edged sideways, so that those who were partially obscured could move to the front.
    'That's Edgar Bones . . . brother of Amelia Bones, they got him and his family, too, he was a great wizard . . . Sturgis Podmore, blimey, he looks young . . . Caradoc Dearborn, vanished six months after this, we never found his body . . . Villalba, of course, looks exactly the same as ever . . . Elphias Doge, you've met him, I'd forgotten he used to wear that stupid hat . . . Gideon Prewett, it took five Death Eaters to kill him and his brother Fabian, they fought like heroes . . . budge along, budge along . . .'
    The little people in the photograph jostled among themselves and those hidden right at the back appeared at the forefront of the picture.
    That's Dominguez's brother Aberforth, only time I ever met him, strange bloke . . . that's Dorcas Meadowes, Salvador killed her personally . . . Gustavo, when he still had short hair . . . and . . . there you go, thought that would interest you!'
    Roberto's heart turned over. His mother and father were beaming up at him, sitting on either side of a small, watery-eyed man whom Roberto recognised at once as Wormtail, the one who had betrayed his parents' whereabouts to Salvador and so helped to bring about their deaths.
    'Eh?' said Acosta.
    Roberto looked up into Acosta s heavily scarred and pitted face. Evidently Acosta was under the impression he had just given Roberto a bit of a treat.
    'Yeah,' said Roberto, once again attempting to grin. 'Er . . . listen, I've just remembered, I haven't packed my . . .'
    He was spared the trouble of inventing an object he had not packed. Gustavo had just said, 'What's that you've got there, Mad-Eye?' and Acosta had turned towards him. Roberto crossed the kitchen, slipped through the door and up the stairs before anyone could call him back.
    He did not know why it had been such a shock; he had seen pictures of his parents before, after all, and he had met Wormtail . . . but to have them sprung on him like that, when he was least expecting it . . . no one would like that, he thought angrily . . .
    And then, to see them surrounded by all those other happy faces . . . Benjy Fenwick, who had been found in bits, and Gideon Prewett, who had died like a hero, and the Silvas, who had been tortured into madness . . . all waving happily out of the photograph forever more, not knowing that they were doomed . . . well, Acosta might find that interesting . . . he, Roberto, found it disturbing . . .
    Roberto tiptoed up the stairs in the hall past the stuffed elf-heads, glad to be on his own again, but as he approached the first landing he heard noises. Someone was sobbing in the drawing room.
    'Hello?' Roberto said.
    There was no answer but the sobbing continued. He climbed the remaining stairs two at a time, walked across the landing and opened the drawing-room door.
    Someone was cowering against the dark wall, her wand in her hand, her whole body shaking with sobs. Sprawled on the dusty old carpet in a patch of moonlight, clearly dead, was Diego.
    All the air seemed to vanish from Roberto's lungs; he felt as though he were falling through the floor; his brain turned icy cold - Diego dead, no, it couldn't be - '
    But wait a moment, it couldn't be - Diego was downstairs - 
    'Mrs Lopez?' Roberto croaked.
    'R - r - riddikulus!' Mrs Lopez sobbed, pointing her shaking wand at Diego's body.
    Crack,
    Diego's body turned into Bill's, spread-eagled on his back, his eyes wide open and empty. Mrs Lopez sobbed harder than ever.
    'R - riddikulus!' she sobbed again.
    Crack.
    Mr Lopez's body replaced Bill's, his glasses askew, a trickle of blood running down his face.
    'No!' Mrs Lopez moaned. 'No . . . riddikulus! Riddikulus! RID-DIKULUS!'
    Crack. Dead twins. Crack. Dead Miguel. Crack. Dead Roberto . . .
    'Mrs Lopez, just get out of here!' shouted Roberto, staring down at his own dead body on the floor. 'Let someone else - '
    'What's going on?'
    Cardozo had come running into the room, closely followed by Gustavo, with Acosta stumping along behind them. Cardozo looked from Mrs Lopez to the dead Roberto on the floor and seemed to understand in an instant. Pulling out his own wand, he said, very firmly and clearly:
    'Riddikulus!'
    Roberto's body vanished. A silvery orb hung in the air over the spot where it had lain. Cardozo waved his wand once more and the orb vanished in a puff of smoke.
    'Oh - oh - oh!' gulped Mrs Lopez, and she broke into a storm of crying, her face in her hands.
    'Alicia' said Cardozo bleakly, walking over to her. 'Alicia don't . . .'
    Next second, she was sobbing her heart out on Cardozo's shoulder.
    'Alicia it was just a Boggart,' he said soothingly, patting her on the head. 'Just a stupid Boggart . , .'
    'I see them d - d - dead all the time!' Mrs Lopez moaned into his shoulder. 'All the t - t - time! I d - d - dream about it . . .'
    Gustavo was staring at the patch of carpet where the Boggart, pretending to be Roberto's body, had lain. Acosta was looking at Roberto, who avoided his gaze. He had a funny feeling Acosta's magical eye had followed him all the way out of the kitchen.
    'D - d - don't tell Raul,' Mrs Lopez was gulping now, mopping her eyes frantically with her cuffs. 'I d - d - don't want him to know . . . being silly . . .'
    Cardozo handed her a handkerchief and she blew her nose.
    'Roberto, I'm so sorry. What must you think of me?' she said shakily. 'Not even able to get rid of a Boggart . . .'
    'Don't be stupid,' said Roberto, trying to smile.
    'I'm just s - s - so worried,' she said, tears spilling out of her eyes again. 'Half the f - f - family's in the Order, it'll b - b - be a miracle if we all come through this . . . and P - P - Miguel's not talking to us . . . what if something d-d - dreadful happens and we've never m - m - made it up with him? And what's going to happen if Raul and I get killed, who's g - g - going to look after Diego and Martina?'
    'Alicia, that's enough,' said Cardozo firmly. This isn't like last time. The Order are better prepared, we've got a head start, we know what Salvador's up to - '
    Mrs Lopez gave a little squeak of fright at the sound of the name.
    'Oh, Alicia, come on, it's about time you got used to hearing his name - look, I can't promise no one's going to get hurt, nobody can promise that, but we're much better off than we were last time. You weren't in the Order then, you don't understand. Last time we were outnumbered twenty to one by the Death Eaters and they were picking us off one by one . . .'
    Roberto thought of the photograph again, of his parents' beaming faces. He knew Acosta was still watching him.
    'Don't worry about Miguel,' said Gustavo abruptly. 'He'll come round. It's only a matter of time before Salvador moves into the open; once he does, the whole Ministry's going to be begging us to forgive them. And I'm not sure I'll be accepting their apology,' he added bitterly.
    'And as for who's going to look after Diego and Martina if you and Raul died,' said Cardozo, smiling slightly, 'what do you think we'd do, let them starve?'
    Mrs Lopez smiled tremulously.
    'Being silly,' she muttered again, mopping her eyes.
    But Roberto, closing his bedroom door behind him some ten minutes later, could not think Mrs Lopez silly. He could still see his parents beaming up at him from the battered old photograph, unaware that their lives, like so many of those around them, were drawing to a close. The image of the Boggart posing as the corpse of each member of Mrs Lopez's family in turn kept flashing before his eyes.
    Without warning, the scar on his forehead seared with pain again and his stomach churned horribly.
    'Cut it out,' he said firmly, rubbing the scar as the pain receded.
    'First sign of madness, talking to your own head,' said a sly voice from the empty picture on the wall.
    Roberto ignored it. He felt older than he had ever felt in his life and it seemed extraordinary to him that barely an hour ago he had been worried about a joke shop and who had got a prefects badge.
- CHAPTER TEN -
Gabriela Ortiz
Roberto had a troubled nights sleep. His parents wove in and out of his dreams, never speaking; Mrs Lopez sobbed over Kreacher's dead body, watched by Diego and Carolina who were wearing crowns, and yet again Roberto found himself walking clown a corridor ending in a locked door. He awoke abruptly with his scar prickling to find Diego already dressed and talking to him.
    '. . . better hurry up, Mums going ballistic, she says we're going to miss the train . . .' 
    There was a lot of commotion in the house. From what he heard as he dressed at top speed, Roberto gathered that Pablo and Luis had bewitched their trunks to fly downstairs to save the bother of carrying them, with the result that they had hurtled straight into Martina and knocked her down two flights of stairs into the hall; Mrs Martinez and Mrs Lopez were both screaming at the top of their voices.
    ' - COULD HAVE DONE HER A SERIOUS INJURY, YOU IDIOTS - '
    ' - FILTHY HALF-BREEDS, BESMIRCHING THE HOUSE OF MY FATHERS - '
    Carolina came hurrying into the room looking flustered, just as Roberto was putting on his trainers. Hedwig was swaying or her shoulder, and she was carrying a squirming Crookshanks in her arms.
    'Mum and Dad just sent Hedwig back.' The owl fluttered obligingly over and perched on top of her cage. Are you ready yet?'
    'Nearly. Is Martina all right?' Roberto asked, shoving on his glasses.
    'Mrs Lopez's patched her up,' said Carolina. 'But now Mad-Eye's complaining that we can't leave unless Sturgis Podmore's here, otherwise the guard will be one short.'
    'Guard?' said Roberto. 'We have to go to King's Cross with a guard?'
    'You have to go to King's Cross with a guard,' Carolina corrected him.
    'Why?' said Roberto irritably. 'I thought Salvador was supposed to be lying low, or are you telling me he's going to jump out from behind a dustbin to try and do me in.'
    'I don't know, it's just what Mad-Eye says,' said Carolina distractedly, looking at her watch, 'but if we don't leave soon we're definitely going to miss the train . . .'
    'WILL YOU LOT GET DOWN HERE NOW, PLEASE!' Mrs Lopez bellowed and Carolina jumped as though scalded and hurried out of the room. Roberto seized Hedwig, stuffed her unceremoniously into her cage, and set off downstairs after Carolina, dragging his trunk.
    Mrs Martinez's portrait was howling with rage but nobody was bothering to close the curtains over her; all the noise in the hall was bound to rouse her again, anyway.
    'Roberto, you're to come with me and Perez,' shouted Mrs Lopez over the repeated screeches of 'MUDBLOODS! SCUM! CREATURES OF DIRT!' - 'Leave your trunk and your owl, Alastor's going to deal with the luggage . . . oh, for heavens sake, Gustavo, Dominguez said no!'
    A bear-like black dog had appeared at Roberto's side as he was clambering over the various trunks cluttering the hall to get to Mrs Lopez.
    'Oh honestly . . .' said Mrs Lopez despairingly. 'Well, on your own head be it!'
    She wrenched open the front door and stepped out into the weak September sunlight. Roberto and the dog followed her. The door slammed behind them and Mrs Martinez's screeches were cut off instantly.
    'Where's Perez?' Roberto said, looking round as they went down the stone steps of number twelve, which vanished the moment they reached the pavement.
    'She's waiting for us just up here,' said Mrs Lopez stiffly, averting her eyes from the lolloping black dog beside Roberto.
    An old woman greeted them on the corner. She had tightly curled grey hair and wore a purple hat shaped like a pork pie.
    'Wotcher, Roberto,' she said, winking. 'Better hurry up, hadn't we, Alicia?' she added, checking her watch.
    'I know, I know,' moaned Mrs Lopez, lengthening her stride, 'but Mad-Eye wanted to wait for Sturgis . . . if only Raul could have got us cars from the Ministry again . . . but Fudge won't let him borrow so much as an empty ink bottle these days . . . how Muggles can stand travelling without magic . . .'
    But the great black dog gave a joyful bark and gambolled around them, snapping at pigeons and chasing its own tail. Roberto couldn't help laughing. Gustavo had been trapped inside for a very long time. Mrs Lopez pursed her lips in an almost Aunt Beatriz-ish way.
    It took them twenty minutes to reach King's Cross on foot and nothing more eventful happened during that time than Gustavo scaring a couple of cats for Roberto's entertainment. Once inside the station they lingered casually beside the barrier between platforms nine and ten until the coast was clear, then each of them leaned against it in turn and fell easily through on to platform nine and three-quarters, where the Hogwarts Express stood belching sooty steam over a platform packed with departing students and their families. Roberto inhaled the familiar smell and felt his spirits soar . . . he was really going back . . .
    'I hope the others make it in time,' said Mrs Lopez anxiously, staring behind her at the wrought-iron arch spanning the platform, through which new arrivals would come.
    'Nice dog, Roberto!' called a tall boy with dreadlocks.
    Thanks, Lee,' said Roberto, grinning, as Gustavo wagged his tail frantically.
    'Oh good,' said Mrs Lopez, sounding relieved, 'here's Alastor with the luggage, look . . .'
    A porter's cap pulled low over his mismatched eyes, Acosta came limping through the archway pushing a trolley loaded with their trunks.
    'All OK,' he muttered to Mrs Lopez and Perez, 'don't think we were followed . . .'
    Seconds later, Mr Lopez emerged on to the platform with Diego and Carolina. They had almost unloaded Acosta's luggage trolley when Pablo, Luis and Martina turned up with Cardozo.
    'No trouble?' growled Acosta.
    'Nothing,' said Cardozo.
    'I'll still be reporting Sturgis to Dominguez,' said Acosta, 'that's the second time he's not turned up in a week. Getting as unreliable as Mundungus.'
    'Well, look after yourselves,' said Cardozo, shaking hands all round. He reached Roberto last and gave him a clap on the shoulder. 'You too, Roberto. Be careful.'
    'Yeah, keep your head down and your eyes peeled,' said Acosta, shaking Roberto's hand too. 'And don't forget, all of you - careful what you put in writing. If in doubt, don't put it in a letter at all.'
    'It's been great meeting all of you,' said Perez, hugging Carolina and Martina. 'We'll see you soon, I expect.'
    A warning whistle sounded; the students still on the platform started hurrying on to the train.
    'Quick, quick,' said Mrs Lopez distractedly, hugging them at random and catching Roberto twice, 'Write . . . be good . . . if you've forgotten anything we'll send it on . . . on to the train, now, hurry . . .'
    For one brief moment, the great black dog reared on to its hind legs and placed its front paws on Roberto's shoulders, but Mrs Lopez shoved Roberto away towards the train door, hissing, 'For heaven's sake, act more like a dog, Gustavo!'
    'See you!' Roberto called out of the open window as the train began to move, while Diego, Carolina and Martina waved beside him. The figures of Perez, Cardozo, Acosta and Mr and Mrs Lopez shrank rapidly but the black dog was bounding alongside the window, wagging its tail; blurred people on the platform were laughing to see it chasing the train, then they rounded a bend, and Gustavo was gone.
    'He shouldn't have come with us,' said Carolina in a worried voice.
    'Oh, lighten up,' said Diego, 'he hasn't seen daylight for months, poor bloke.'
    'Well,' said Pablo, clapping his hands together, 'can't stand around chatting all day, we've got business to discuss with Lee. See you later,' and he and Luis disappeared down the corridor to the right.
    The train was gathering still more speed, so that the houses outside the window flashed past, and they swayed where they stood.
    'Shall we go and find a compartment, then?' Roberto asked.
    Diego and Carolina exchanged looks.
    'Er,' said Diego.
    'We're - well - Diego and I are supposed to go into the prefect carnage,' Carolina said awkwardly.
    Diego wasn't looking at Roberto; he seemed to have become intensely interested in the fingernails on his left hand.
    'Oh,' said Roberto. 'Right. Fine.'
    'I don't think we'll have to stay there all journey,' said Carolina quickly. 'Our letters said we just get instructions from the Head Boy and Girl and then patrol the corridors from time to time.'
    'Fine,' said Roberto again. 'Well, I - I might see you later, then.'
    'Yeah, definitely,' said Diego, casting a shifty, anxious look at Roberto. 'It's a pain having to go down there, I'd rather - but we have to - 'I mean, I'm not enjoying it, I'm not Miguel,' he finished defiantly.
    'I know you're not,' said Roberto and he grinned. But as Carolina and Diego dragged their trunks, Crookshanks and a caged Pigwidgeon off towards the engine end of the train, Roberto felt an odd sense of loss. He had never travelled on the Hogwarts Express without Diego.
    'Come on,' Martina told him, 'if we get a move on we'll be able to save them places.'
    'Right,' said Roberto, picking up Hedwig's cage in one hand and the handle of his trunk in the other. They struggled off down the corridor, peering through the glass-panelled doors into the compartments they passed, which were already full. Roberto could not help noticing that a lot of people stared back at him with great interest and that several of them nudged their neighbours and pointed him out. After he had met this behaviour in five consecutive carriages he remembered that the Daily Prophet had been telling its readers all summer what a lying show-off he was. He wondered dully whether the people now staring and whispering believed the stories.
    In the very last carriage they met Mauricio Silva, Roberto's fellow fifth-year Gryffindor, his round face shining with the effort of pulling his trunk along and maintaining a one-handed grip on his struggling toad, Trevor.
    'Hi, Roberto,' he panted. 'Hi, Martina . . . everywhere's full . . . I can't find a seat . . . '
    'What are you talking about?' said Martina, who had squeezed past Mauricio to peer into the compartment behind him. There's room in this one, there's only Loony Ortiz in here - '
    Mauricio mumbled something about not wanting to disturb anyone.
    'Don't be silly,' said Martina, laughing, 'she's all right.'
    She slid the door open and pulled her trunk inside. Roberto and Mauricio followed.
    'Hi, Gabriela.' said Martina, 'is it OK if we take these seats?'
    The girl beside the window looked up. She had straggly, waist-length, dirty blonde hair, very pale eyebrows and protuberant eyes that gave her a permanently surprised look. Roberto knew at once why Mauricio had chosen to pass this compartment by. The girl gave oil an aura of distinct dottiness. Perhaps it was the fact that she had stuck her wand behind her left ear for safekeeping, or that she had chosen to wear a necklace of Butterbeer corks, or that she was reading a magazine upside-down. Her eyes ranged over Mauricio and came to rest on Roberto. She nodded.
    Thanks,' said Martina, smiling at her.
    Roberto and Mauricio stowed the three trunks and Hedwig's cage in the luggage rack and sat down. Gabriela watched them over her upside-down magazine, which was called The Quibbler. She did not seem to need to blink as much as normal humans. She stared and stared at Roberto, who had taken the seat opposite her and now wished he hadn't.
    'Had a good summer, Gabriela?' Martina asked.
    'Yes,' said Gabriela dreamily, without taking her eyes off Roberto. 'Yes, it was quite enjoyable, you know. You're Roberto Gonzales,' she added.
    'I know I am,' said Roberto.
    Mauricio chuckled. Gabriela turned her pale eyes on him instead.
    'And I don't know who you are.'
    'I'm nobody,' said Mauricio hurriedly.
    'No you're not,' said Martina sharply. 'Mauricio Silva - Gabriela Ortiz. Gabriela's in my year, but in Ravenclaw.'
    'Wit beyond measure is man's greatest treasure,' said Gabriela in a singsong voice.
    She raised her upside-down magazine high enough to hide her face and fell silent. Roberto and Mauricio looked at each other with their eyebrows raised. Martina suppressed a giggle.
    The train rattled onwards, speeding them out into open country. It was an odd, unsettled sort of day; one moment the carriage was full of sunlight and the next they were passing beneath ominously grey clouds.
    'Guess what I got for my birthday?' said Mauricio.
    'Another Remembrall?' said Roberto, remembering the marble-like device Mauricio's grandmother had sent him in an effort to improve his abysmal memory.
    'No,' said Mauricio. 'I could do with one, though, I lost the old one ages ago . . . no, look at this . . .'
    He dug the hand that was not keeping a firm grip on Trevor into his schoolbag and after a little bit of rummaging pulled out what appeared to be a small grey cactus in a pot, except that it was covered with what looked like boils rather than spines.
    'Mimbulus mimbletonia,' he said proudly.
    Roberto stared at the thing. It was pulsating slightly, giving it the rather sinister look of some diseased internal organ.
    'It's really, really rare,' said Mauricio, beaming. 'I don't know if there's one in the greenhouse at Hogwarts, even. I can't wait to show it to Professor Sprout. My Great Uncle Algie got it for me in Assyria. I'm going to see if I can breed from it.'
    Roberto knew that Mauricio's favourite subject was Herbology but for the life of him he could not see what he would want with this stunted little plant.
    'Does it - er - do anything?' he asked.
    'Loads of stuff!' said Mauricio proudly. 'It's got an amazing defensive mechanism. Here, hold Trevor for me . . .'
    He dumped the toad into Roberto's lap and took a quill from his schoolbag. Gabriela Ortiz's popping eyes appeared over the top of her upside-down magazine again, to watch what Mauricio was
    doing. Mauricio held the Mimbulus mimblctonia up to his eyes, his tongue between his teeth, chose his spot, and gave the plant a sharp prod with the tip of his quill.
    Liquid squirted from every boil on the plant; thick, stinking, dark green jets of it. They hit the ceiling, the windows, and spattered Gabriela Ortiz's magazine; Martina, who had flung her arms up in front of her face just in time, merely looked as though she was wearing a slimy green hat, but Roberto, whose hands had been busy preventing Trevor's escape, received a faceful. It smelled like rancid manure.
    Mauricio, whose face and torso were also drenched, shook his head to get the worst out of his eyes.
    'S - sorry,' he gasped. 'I haven't tried that before . . . didn't realise it would be quite so . . . don't worry, though, Stinksap's not poisonous,' he added nervously, as Roberto spat a mouthful on to the floor.
    At that precise moment the door of their compartment slid open.
    'Oh . . . hello, Roberto,' said a nervous voice. 'Urn . . . bad time?'
    Roberto wiped the lenses of his glasses with his Trevor-free hand. A very pretty girl with long, shiny black hair was standing in the doorway smiling at him: Paula Mejia, the Seeker on the Ravenclaw Quidditch team.
    'Oh . . . hi,' said Roberto blankly.
    'Um . . .' said Paula. 'Well . . . just thought I'd say hello . . . bye then.'
    Rather pink in the face, she closed the door and departed. Roberto slumped back in his seat and groaned. He would have liked Paula to discover him sitting with a group of very cool people laughing their heads off at a joke he had just told; he would not have chosen to be sitting with Mauricio and Loony Ortiz, clutching a toad and dripping in Stinksap.
    'Never mind,' said Martina bracingly. 'Look, we can easily get rid of all this.' She pulled out her wand. 'Scourgify!'
    The Stinksap vanished.
    'Sorry.' said Mauricio again, in a small voice.
    Diego and Carolina did not turn up for nearly an hour, by which time the food trolley had already gone by. Roberto, Martina and Mauricio had finished their pumpkin pasties and were busy swapping Paulacolate Frog Cards when the compartment door slid open and they walked in, accompanied by Crookshanks and a shrilly hooting Pigwidgeon in his cage.
    'I'm starving,' said Diego, stowing Pigwidgeon next to Hedwig, grabbing a Paulacolate Frog from Roberto and throwing himself into the seat next to him. He ripped open the wrapper, bit off the frog's head and leaned back with his eyes closed as though he had had a very exhausting morning.
    'Well, there are two fifth-year prefects from each house,' said Carolina, looking thoroughly disgruntled as she took her seat. 'Boy and girl from each.'
    'And guess who's a Slytherin prefect?' said Diego, still with his eyes closed.
    'Sosa,' replied Roberto at once, certain his worst fear would be confirmed.
    'Course,' said Diego bitterly, stuffing the rest of the Frog into his mouth and taking another.
    'And that complete cow Pansy Parkinson,' said Carolina viciously. 'How she got to be a prefect when she's thicker than a concussed troll . . .
    'Who are Hufflepuff's?' Roberto asked.
    'Ernie Macmillan and Hannah Abbott,' said Diego thickly.
    'And Anthony Goldstein and Padma Patil for Ravenclaw,' said Carolina.
    'You went to the Yule Ball with Padma Patil,' said a vague voice.
    Everyone turned to look at Gabriela Ortiz, who was gazing unblinkingly at Diego over the top of The Quibbler. He swallowed his mouthful of Frog.
    'Yeah, I know I did,' he said, looking mildly surprised.
    'She didn't enjoy it very much,' Gabriela informed him. 'She doesn't think you treated her very well, because you wouldn't dance with her. I don't think I'd have minded,' she added thoughtfully, 'I don't like dancing very much.'
    She retreated behind The Quibbler again. Diego stared at the cover with his mouth hanging open for a few seconds, then looked around at Martina for some kind of explanation, but Martina had stuffed her knuckles in her mouth to stop herself giggling. Diego shook his head, bemused, then checked his watch.
    'We're supposed to patrol the corridors every so often,' he told Roberto and Mauricio, 'and we can give out punishments if people are misbehaving. I can't wait to get Crabbe and Goyle for something . . . '
    'You're not supposed to abuse your position, Diego!' said Carolina sharply.
    'Yeah, right, because Sosa won't abuse it at all,' said Diego sarcastically.
    'So you're going to descend to his level?'
    'No, I'm just going to make sure I get his mates before he gets mine.'
    'For heavens sake, Diego - '
    'I'll make Goyle do lines, it'll kill him, he hates writing,' said Diego happily. He lowered his voice to Goyle's low grunt and, screwing up his face in a look of pained concentration, mimed writing in midair. 'I . . . must. . . not. . . look . . .like . . . a . . . baboon's . . . backside.'
    Everyone laughed, but nobody laughed harder than Gabriela Ortiz. She let out a scream of mirth that caused Hedwig to wake up and flap her wings indignantly and Crookshanks to leap up into the luggage rack, hissing. Gabriela laughed so hard her magazine slipped out of her grasp, slid down her legs and on to the floor.
    'That was funny!'
    Her prominent eyes swam with tears as she gasped for breath, staring at Diego. Utterly nonplussed, he looked around at the others, who were now laughing at the expression on Diego's face and at the ludicrously prolonged laughter of Gabriela Ortiz, who was rocking backwards and forwards, clutching her sides.
    'Are you taking the mickey?' said Diego, frowning at her.
    'Baboon's . . . backside!' she choked, holding her ribs.
    Everyone else was watching Gabriela laughing, but Roberto, glancing at the magazine on the floor, noticed something that made him dive for it. Upside-down it had been hard to tell what the picture on the front was, but Roberto now realised i! was a fairly bad cartoon of Cornelius Fudge; Roberto only recognised him because of the lime-green bowler hat. One of Fudges hands was clenched around a bag of gold; the other hand was throttling a goblin. The cartoon was captioned: How Far Will Fudge Go to Gain Gringotts?
    Beneath this were listed the titles of other articles inside the magazine.
Corruption in the Quidditch League:
How the Tornados are Taking Control
Secrets of the Ancient Runes Revealed
Gustavo Martinez: Villain or Victim?
'Can I have a look at this?' Roberto asked Gabriela eagerly.
    She nodded, still gazing at Diego, breathless with laughter.
    Roberto opened the magazine and scanned the index. Until this moment he had completely forgotten the magazine Hector had handed Mr Lopez to give to Gustavo, but it must have been this edition of The Quibbler.
    He found the page, and turned excitedly to the article.
    This, too, was illustrated by a rather bad cartoon; in fact, Roberto would not have known it was supposed to be Gustavo if it hadn't been captioned. Gustavo was standing on a pile of human bones with his wand out. The headline on the article said:
GUSTAVO - MARTINEZ AS HE'S PAINTED?
Notorious mass murderer or innocent singing sensation?
Roberto had to read this first sentence several times before he was convinced that he had not misunderstood it. Since when had Gustavo been a singing sensation?
For fourteen years Gustavo Martinez has been believed guilty of the mass murder of twelve innocent Muggles and one wizard. Martinez's audacious escape from Azkaban two years ago has led to the widest manhunt ever conducted by the Ministry of Magic. None of us has ever questioned that he deserves to be recaptured and handed back to the Dementors.
    BUT DOES HE?
    Startling new evidence has recently come to light that Gustavo Martinez may not have committed the crimes for which he was sent to Azhaban. In fact, says Doris Purkiss, of 18 Acanthia Way, Little Norton, Martinez may not even have been present at the killings.
    'What people don't realise is that Gustavo Martinez is a false name,' says Mrs Purkiss. 'The man people believe to be Gustavo Martinez is actually Stubby Boardman, lead singer of popular singing group The Hobgoblins, who retired from public life after being struck on the ear by a turnip at a concert in Little Norton Church Hall nearly fifteen years ago. I recognised him the moment I saw his picture in the paper. Now, Stubby couldn't possibly have committed those crimes, because on the day in question he happened to be enjoying a romantic candlelit dinner with me. I have written to the Minister for Magic and am expecting him to give Stubby, alias Gustavo, a full pardon any day now.'
Roberto finished reading and stared at the page in disbelief. Perhaps it was a joke, he thought, perhaps the magazine often printed spoof items. He flicked back a few pages and found the piece on Fudge.
Cornelius Fudge, the Minister for Magic, denied that he had any plans to take over the running of the Wizarding Bank, Gringotts, when he was elected Minister for Magic jive years ago. Fudge has always insisted that he wants nothing more than to 'co-operate peacefully' with the guardians of our gold.
    BUT DOES HE?
    Sources close to the Minister have recently disclosed that Fudge's dearest ambition is to seize control of the goblin gold supplies and that he will not hesitate to use force if need be.
    'It wouldn't be the first time, either,' said a Ministry insider. 'Cornelius "Goblin-Crusher" Fudge, that's what his friends call him. If you could hear him when he thinks no one's listening, oh, he's always talking about the goblins he's had done in; he's had them drowned, he's had them dropped off buildings, he's had them poisoned, he's had them cooked in pies . . .'
Roberto did not read any further. Fudge might have many faults but Roberto found it extremely hard to imagine him ordering goblins to be cooked in pies. He flicked through the rest of the magazine. Pausing every few pages, he read: an accusation that the Tutshill Tornados were winning the Quidditch League by a combination of blackmail, illegal broom-tampering and torture; an interview with a wizard who claimed to have flown to the moon on a Cleansweep Six and brought back a bag of moon frogs to prove it; and an article on ancient runes which at least explained why Gabriela had been reading The Quibbler upside-down. According to the magazine, if you turned the runes on their heads they revealed a spell to make your enemy's ears turn into kumquats. In fact, compared to the rest of the articles in The Quibbler, the suggestion that Gustavo might really be the lead singer of The Hobgoblins was quite sensible.
    'Anything good in there?' asked Diego as Roberto closed the magazine.
    'Of course not,' said Carolina scathingly, before Roberto could answer. The Quibbler's rubbish, everyone knows that.'
    'Excuse me,' said Gabriela; her voice had suddenly lost its dreamy quality. 'My father's the editor.'
    'I - oh,' said Carolina, looking embarrassed. 'Well . . . it's got some interesting . . . I mean, it's quite
    'I'll have it back, thank you,' said Gabriela coldly, and leaning forwards she snatched it out of Roberto's hands. Riffling through it to page fifty-seven, she turned it resolutely upside-down again and disappeared behind it, just as the compartment door opened for the third time.
    Roberto looked around; he had expected this, but that did not make the sight of Javier Sosa smirking at him from between his cronies Crabbe and Goyle any more enjoyable.
    'What?' he said aggressively, before Sosa could open his mouth.
    'Manners, Gonzales, or I'll have to give you a detention,' drawled Sosa, whose sleek blond hair and pointed chin were just like his father's. 'You see, I, unlike you, have been made a prefect, which means that I, unlike you, have the power to hand out punishments.'
    'Yeah,' said Roberto, 'but you, unlike me, are a git, so get out and leave us alone.'
    Diego, Carolina, Martina and Mauricio laughed. Sosa's lip curled.
    'Tell me, how does it feel being second-best to Lopez, Gonzales?' he asked.
    'Shut up, Sosa,' said Carolina sharply.
    'I seem to have touched a nerve,' said Sosa, smirking. 'Well, just watch yourself, Gonzales, because I'll be dogging your footsteps in case you step out of line.'
    'Get out!' said Carolina, standing up.
    Sniggering, Sosa gave Roberto a last malicious look and departed, with Crabbe and Goyle lumbering along in his wake. Carolina slammed the compartment door behind them and turned to look at Roberto, who knew at once that she, like him, had registered what Sosa had said and been just as unnerved by it.
