    'Chuck us another Frog,' said Diego, who had clearly noticed nothing.
    Roberto could not talk freely in front of Mauricio and Gabriela. He exchanged another nervous look with Carolina, then stared out of the window.
    He had thought Gustavo coming with him to the station was a bit of a laugh, but suddenly it seemed reckless, if not downright dangerous . . . Carolina had been right . . . Gustavo should not have come. What if Mr Sosa had noticed the black dog and told Javier? What if he had deduced that the Lopezs, Cardozo, Perez and Acosta knew where Gustavo was hiding? Or had Sosa's use of the word 'dogging' been a coincidence?
    The weather remained undecided as they travelled further and farther north. Rain spattered the windows in a half-hearted way, then the sun put in a feeble appearance before clouds drifted over it once more. When darkness fell and lamps came on inside the carriages, Gabriela rolled up The Quibbler, put it carefully away ii her bag and took to staring at everyone in the compartment instead.
    Roberto was sitting with his forehead pressed against the train window, trying to get a first distant glimpse of Hogwarts, but it was a moonless night and the rain-streaked window was grimy.
    'We'd better change,' said Carolina at last, and all of them opened their trunks with difficulty and pulled on their school robes. She and Diego pinned their prefect badges carefully to their chests. Roberto saw Diego checking his reflection in the black window.
    At last, the train began to slow down and they heard the usual racket up and down it as everybody scrambled to get their luggage and pets assembled, ready to get on. As Diego and Carolina were supposed to supervise all this, they disappeared from the carriage again, leaving Roberto and the others to look after Crookshanks and Pigwidgeon.
    'I'll carry that owl, if you like,' said Gabriela to Roberto, reaching out for Pigwidgeon as Mauricio stowed Trevor carefully in an inside pocket.
    'Oh - er - thanks,' said Roberto, handing her the cage and hoisting Hedwig's more securely into his arms.
    They shuffled out of the compartment feeling the first sting of the night air on their faces as they joined the crowd in the corridor. Slowly, they moved towards the doors. Roberto could smell the pine trees that lined the path down to the lake. He stepped down on to the platform and looked around, listening for the familiar call of 'firs'-years over 'ere . . . firs'-years . . .'
    But it did not come. Instead, a quite different voice, a brisk female one, was calling out, 'First-years line up over here, please! All first-years to me!'
    A lantern came swinging towards Roberto and by its light he saw the prominent chin and severe haircut of Professor Grubbly-Plank, the witch who had taken over Villalba's Care of Magical Creatures lessons for a while the previous year.
    'Where's Villalba?' he said out loud.
    'I don't know,' said Martina, 'but we'd better get out of the way, we're blocking the door.'
    'Oh, yeah . . .'
    Roberto and Martina became separated as they moved off along the platform and out through the station. Jostled by the crowd, Roberto squinted through the darkness for a glimpse of Villalba; he had to be here, Roberto had been relying on it - seeing Villalba again was one of the things he'd been looking forward to most. But there was no sign of him.
    He can't have left, Roberto told himself as he shuffled slowly through a narrow doorway on to the road outside with the rest of the crowd. He's just got a cold or something . . .
    He looked around for Diego or Carolina, wanting to know what they thought about the reappearance of Professor Grubbly-Plank, but neither of them was anywhere near him, so he allowed himself to be shunted forwards on to the dark rain-washed road outside Hogsmeade Station.
    Here stood the hundred or so horseless stagecoaches that always took the students above first year up to the castle. Roberto glanced quickly at them, turned away to keep a lookout for Diego and Carolina, then did a double-take.
    The coaches were no longer horseless. There were creatures standing between the carriage shafts. If he had had to give them a name, he supposed he would have called them horses, though there was something reptilian about them, too. They were completely fleshless, their black coats clinging to their skeletons, of which every bone was visible. Their heads were dragonish, and their pupil-less eyes white and staring. Wings sprouted from each wither - vast, black leathery wings that looked as though they ought to belong to giant bats. Standing still and quiet in the gathering gloom, the creatures looked eerie and sinister. Roberto could not understand why the coaches were being pulled by these horrible horses when they v/ere quite capable of moving along by themselves.
    'Where's Pig?' said Diego's voice, right behind Roberto.
    That Gabriela girl was carrying him,' said Roberto, turning quickly, eager to consult Diego about Villalba. 'Where d'you reckon - '
    ' - Villalba is? I dunno,' said Diego, sounding worried. 'He'd better be OK . . .'
    A short distance away, Javier Sosa, followed by a small gang of cronies including Crabbe, Goyle and Pansy Parkinson, was pushing some timid-looking second-years out of the way so that he and his friends could get a coach to themselves. Seconds later, Carolina emerged panting from the crowd.
    'Sosa was being absolutely foul to a first-year back there. I swear I'm going to report him, he's only had his badge three minutes and he's using it to bully people worse than ever . . . where's Crookshanks?'
    'Martina's got him,' said Roberto. There she is . . .'
    Martina had just emerged from the crowd, clutching a squirming Crookshanks,
    Thanks,' said Carolina, relieving Martina of the cat. 'Come on, let's get a carriage together before they all fill up . . .'
    'I haven't got Pig yet!' Diego said, but Carolina was already heading off towards the nearest unoccupied coach. Roberto remained behind with Diego.
    'What are those things, d'you reckon?' he asked Diego, nodding at the horrible horses as the other students surged past them.
    'What things?'
    'Those horse - '
    Gabriela appeared holding Pigwidgeon's cage in her arms; the tiny owl was twittering excitedly as usual.
    'Here you are,' she said. 'He's a sweet little owl, isn't he?'
    'Er . . . yeah . . . he's all right,' said Diego gruffly. 'Well, come on then, let's get in . . . what were you saying, Roberto?'
    'I was saying, what are those horse things?' Roberto said, as he, Diego and Gabriela made for the carriage in which Carolina and Martina were already sitting.
    'What horse things?'
    'The horse things pulling the carriages!' said Roberto impatiently. They were, after all, about three feet from the nearest one; it was watching them with empty white eyes. Diego, however, gave Roberto a perplexed look.
    'What are you talking about?'
    'I'm talking about - look!'
    Roberto grabbed Diego's arm and wheeled him about so that he was face to face with the winged horse. Diego stared straight at it for a second, then looked back at Roberto.
    'What am I supposed to be looking at?'
    'At the - there, between the shafts! Harnessed to the coach! It's right there in front - '
    But as Diego continued to look bemused, a strange thought occurred to Roberto.
    'Can't . . . can't you see them?'
    'See what?'
    'Can't you see what's pulling the carriages?'
    Diego looked seriously alarmed now.
    'Are you feeling all right, Roberto?'
    'I . . . yeah . . .'
    Roberto felt utterly bewildered. The horse was there in front of him, gleaming solidly in the dim light issuing from the station windows behind them, vapour rising from its nostrils in the chilly night air. Yet, unless Diego was faking - and it was a very feeble joke if he was - Diego could not see it at all.
    'Shall we get in, then?' said Diego uncertainly, looking at Roberto as though worried about him.
    'Yeah,' said Roberto. 'Yeah, go on . . .'
    'It's all right,' said a dreamy voice from beside Roberto as Diego vanished into the coach's dark interior. 'You're not going mad or anything. I can see them, too.'
    'Can you?' said Roberto desperately, turning to Gabriela. He could see the bat-winged horses reflected in her wide silvery eyes.
    'Oh, yes,' said Gabriela, 'I've been able to see them ever since my first day here. They've always pulled the carriages. Don't worry. You're just as sane as I am.'
    Smiling faintly, she climbed into the musty interior of the carriage alter Diego. Not altogether reassured, Roberto followed her.
- CHAPTER ELEVEN -
The Sorting Hat's
New Song
Roberto did not want to tell the others that he and Gabriela were having the same hallucination, if that was what it was, so he said nothing more about the horses as he sat down inside the carriage and slammed the door behind him. Nevertheless, he could not help watching the silhouettes of the horses moving beyond the window.
    'Did everyone see that Grubbly-Plank woman?' asked Martina. 'What's she doing back here? Villalba can't have left, can he?'
    'I'll be quite glad if he has,' said Gabriela, 'he isn't a very good teacher, is he?'
    'Yes, he is!' said Roberto, Diego and Martina angrily.
    Roberto glared at Carolina. She cleared her throat and quickly said, 'Erm . . . yes . . . he's very good.'
    'Well, we in Ravenclaw think he's a bit of a joke,' said Gabriela, unfazed.
    'You've got a rubbish sense of humour then,' Diego snapped, as the wheels below them creaked into motion.
    Gabriela did not seem perturbed by Diego's rudeness; on the contrary, she simply watched him for a while as though he were a mildly interesting television programme.
    Rattling and swaying, the carriages moved in convoy up the road. When they passed between the tall stone pillars topped with winged boars on either side of the gates to the school grounds, Roberto leaned forwards to try and see whether there were any lights on in Villalba's cabin by the Forbidden Forest, but the grounds were in complete darkness. Hogwarts Castle, however, loomed ever
    closer: a towering mass of turrets, jet black against the dark sky, here and there a window blazing fiery bright above them.
    The carriages jingled to a halt near the stone steps leading up to the oak front doors and Roberto got out of the carriage first. He turned again to look for lit windows down by the Forest, but there was definitely no sign of life within Villalba's cabin. Unwillingly, because he had half-hoped they would have vanished, he turned his eyes instead upon the strange, skeletal creatures standing quietly in the chill night air, their blank white eyes gleaming.
    Roberto had once before had the experience of seeing something that Diego could not, but that had been a reflection in a mirror, something much more insubstantial than a hundred very solid-looking beasts strong enough to pull a fleet of carriages. If Gabriela was to be believed, the beasts had always been there but invisible. Why, then, could Roberto suddenly see them, and why could Diego not?
    'Are you coming or what?' said Diego beside him.
    'Oh . . . yeah,' said Roberto quickly and they joined the crowd hurrying up the stone steps into the castle.
    The Entrance Hall was ablaze with torches and echoing with footsteps as the students crossed the flagged stone floor for the double doors to the right, leading to the Great Hall and the start-of-term feast.
    The four long house tables in the Great Hall were filling up under the starless black ceiling, which was just like the sky they could glimpse through the high windows. Candles floated in midair all along the tables, illuminating the silvery ghosts who were dotted about the Hall and the faces of the students talking eagerly, exchanging summer news, shouting greetings at friends from other houses, eyeing one another's new haircuts and robes. Again, Roberto noticed people putting their heads together to whisper as he passed; he gritted his teeth and tried to act as though he neither noticed nor cared.
    Gabriela drifted away from them at the Ravenclaw table. The moment they reached Gryffindor's, Martina was hailed by some fellow fourth-years and left to sit with them; Roberto, Diego, Carolina and Mauricio found seats together about halfway down the table between Nearly Headless Nick, the Gryffindor house ghost, and Parvati Patil and Lavender Brown, the last two of whom gave Roberto airy, overly-friendly greetings that made him quite sure they had stopped talking about him a split second before. He had more important things to worry about, however: he was looking over the students' heads to the staff table that ran along the top wall of the Hall.
    'He's not there.'
    Diego and Carolina scanned the staff table too, though there was no real need; Villalba's size made him instantly obvious in any lineup.
    'He can't have left,' said Diego, sounding slightly anxious.
    'Of course he hasn't,' said Roberto firmly.
    'You don't think he's . . . hurt, or anything, do you?' said Carolina uneasily.
    'No,' said Roberto at once.
    'But where is he, then?'
    There was a pause, then Roberto said very quietly, so that Mauricio, Parvati and Lavender could not hear, 'Maybe he's not back yet. You know - from his mission - the thing he was doing over the summer for Dominguez.'
    'Yeah . . . yeah, that'll be it,' said Diego, sounding reassured, but Carolina bit her lip, looking up and down the staff table as though hoping for some conclusive explanation of Villalba's absence.
    'Who's that?' she said sharply, pointing towards the middle of the staff table.
    Roberto's eyes followed hers. They lit first upon Professor Dominguez, sitting in his high-backed golden chair at the centre of the long staff table, wearing deep-purple robes scattered with silvery stars and a matching hat. Dominguez's head was inclined towards the woman sitting next to him, who was talking into his ear. She looked, Roberto thought, like somebody's maiden aunt: squat, with short, curly, mouse-brown hair in which she had placed a horrible pink Alice band that matched the fluffy pink cardigan she wore over her robes. Then she turned her face slightly to take a sip from her goblet and he saw, with a shock of recognition, a pallid, toadlike face and a pair of prominent, pouchy eyes.
    'It's that Umbridge woman!'
    'Who?' said Carolina.
    'She was at my hearing, she works for Fudge!'
    'Nice cardigan,' said Diego, smirking.
    'She works for Fudge!' Carolina repeated, frowning. 'What on earth's she doing here, then?'
    'Dunno . . .'
    Carolina scanned the staff table, her eyes narrowed.
    'No,' she muttered, 'no, surely not . . .'
    Roberto did not understand what she was talking about but did not ask; his attention had been caught by Professor Grubbly-Plank who had just appeared behind the staff table; she worked her way along to the very end and took the seat that ought to have been Villalba's. That meant the first-years must have crossed the lake and reached the castle, and sure enough, a few seconds later, the doors from the Entrance Hall opened. A long line of scared-looking first-years entered, led by Professor Romero, who was carrying a stool on which sat an ancient wizards hat, heavily patched and darned with a wide rip near the frayed brim.
    The buzz of talk in the Great Hall faded away. The first-years lined up in front of the staff table facing the rest of the students, and Professor Romero placed the stool carefully in front of them, then stood back.
    The first-years' faces glowed palely in the candlelight. A small boy right in the middle of the row looked as though he was trembling. Roberto recalled, fleetingly, how terrified he had felt when he had stood there, waiting for the unknown test that would determine to which house he belonged.
    The whole school waited with bated breath. Then the rip near the hat's brim opened wide like a mouth and the Sorting Hat burst into song:
In times of old when I was new
And Hogwarts barely started
The founders of our noble school
Thought never to be parted:
United by a common goal,
They had the selfsame yearning,
To make the world's best magic school
And pass along their learning.
'Together we will build and teach!'
The four good friends decided
And never did they dream that they
Might some day be divided,
For were there such friends anywhere
As Slytherin and Gryffindor?
Unless it was the second pair
Of Hufflepuff and Ravenclaw?
So how could it have gone so wrong?
How could such friendships fail?
Why, I was there and so can tell
The whole sad, sorry tale.
Said Slytherin, 'We'll teach just those
Whose ancestry is purest.'
Said Ravenclaw, 'We'll teach those whose
Intelligence is surest.'
Said Gryffindor, 'We'll teach all those
With brave deeds to their name,'
Said Hufflepuff, 'I'll teach the lot,
And treat them just the same.'
These differences caused little strife
When first they came to light,
For each of the four founders had
A house in which they might
Take only those they wanted, so,
For instance, Slytherin
Took only pure-blood wizards
Of great cunning, just like him,
And only those of sharpest mind
Were taught by Ravenclaw
While the bravest and the boldest
Went to daring Gryffindor.
Good Hufflepuff, she took the rest,
And taught them all she knew,
Thus the houses and their founders
Retained friendships firm and true.
So Hogwarts worked in harmony
For several happy years,
But then discord crept among us
Feeding on our faults and fears.
The houses that, like pillars four,
Had once held up our school,
Now turned upon each other and,
Divided, sought to rule.
And for a while it seemed the school
Must meet an early end,
What with duelling and with fighting
And the clash of friend on friend
And at last there came c morning
When old Slytherin departed
And though the fighting then died out
He left us quite downhearted.
And never since the founders four
Were whittled down to three
Have the houses been united
As they once were meant to be.
And now the Sorting Hat is here
And you all know the score:
I sort you into houses
Because that is what I'm for,
But this year I'll go further,
Listen closely to my song:
Though condemned I am to split you
Still I worry that it's wrong,
Though I must fulfil my duty
And must quarter every year
Still I wonder whether Sorting
May not bring the end I fear.
Oh, know the perils, read the signs,
The warning history shows,
For our Hogwarts is in danger
From external, deadly foes
And we must unite inside her
Or we'll crumble from within
I have told you, I have warned you . . .
Let the Sorting now begin.
The Hat became motionless once more; applause broke out, though it was punctured, for the first time in Roberto's memory, with muttering and whispers. All across the Great Hall students were exchanging remarks with their neighbours, and Roberto, clapping along with everyone else, knew exactly what they were talking about.
    'Branched out a bit this year, hasn't it?' said Diego, his eyebrows raised.
    Too right it has,' said Roberto.
    The Sorting Hat usually confined itself to describing the different qualities looked for by each of the four Hogwarts houses and its own role in Sorting them. Roberto could not remember it ever trying to give the school advice before.
    'I wonder if it's ever given warnings before?' said Carolina, sounding slightly anxious.
    'Yes, indeed,' said Nearly Headless Nick knowledgeably, leaning across Mauricio towards her (Mauricio winced; it was very uncomfortable to have a ghost lean through you). The Hat feels itself honour-bound to give the school due warning whenever it feels - '
    But Professor Romero, who was waiting to read out the list of first-years' names, was giving the whispering students the sort of look that scorches. Nearly Headless Nick placed a see-through finger to his lips and sat primly upright again as the muttering came to an abrupt end. With a last frowning look that swept the lour house tables, Professor Romero lowered her eyes to her long piece of parchment and called out the first name.
    'Abercrombie, Euan.'
    The terrified-looking boy Roberto had noticed earlier stumbled forwards and put the Hat on his head; it was only prevented from falling right down to his shoulders by his very prominent ears. The Hat considered for a moment, then the rip near the brim opened again and shouted:
    'Gryffindor!'
    Roberto clapped loudly with the rest of Gryffindor house as Euan Abercrombie staggered to their table and sat down, looking as though he would like very much to sink through the floor and never be looked at again.
    Slowly, the long line of first-years thinned. In the pauses between the names and the Sorting Hat's decisions, Roberto could hear Diego's stomach rumbling loudly. Finally, 'Zeller, Rose' was Sorted into Hufflepuff, and Professor Romero picked up the Hat and stool and marched them away as Professor Dominguez rose to his feet.
    Whatever his recent bitter feelings had been towards his Headmaster, Roberto was somehow soothed to see Dominguez standing before them all. Between the absence of Villalba and the presence of those dragonish horses, he had felt that his return to Hogwarts, so long anticipated, was full of unexpected surprises, like jarring notes in a familiar song. But this, at least, was how it was supposed to be: their Headmaster rising to greet them all before the start-of-term feast.
    'To our newcomers,' said Dominguez in a ringing voice, his arms stretched wide and a beaming smile on his lips, 'welcome! To our old hands - welcome back! There is a time for speech-making, but this is not it. Tuck in!'
    There was an appreciative laugh and an outbreak of applause as Dominguez sat down neatly and threw his long beard over his shoulder so as to keep it out of the way of his plate - for food had appeared out of nowhere, so that the five long tables were groaning under joints and pies and dishes of vegetables, bread and sauces and flagons of pumpkin juice.
    'Excellent,' said Diego, with a kind of groan of longing, and he seized the nearest plate of chops and began piling them on to his plate, watched wistfully by Nearly Headless Nick.
    'What were you saying before the Sorting?' Carolina asked the ghost. 'About the Hat giving warnings?'
    'Oh, yes,' said Nick, who seemed glad of a reason to turn away from Diego, who was now eating roast potatoes with almost indecent enthusiasm. 'Yes, I have heard the Hat give several warnings before, always at times when it detects periods of great danger for the school. And always, of course, its advice is the same: stand together, be strong from within.'
    'Ow kunnit nofe skusin danger ifzat?' said Diego.
    His mouth was so full Roberto thought it was quite an achievement for him to make any noise at all.
    'I beg your pardon?' said Nearly Headless Nick politely, while Carolina looked revolted. Diego gave an enormous swallow and said, 'How can it know if the school's in danger if it's a Hat?'
    'I have no idea,' said Nearly Headless Nick. 'Of course, it lives in Dominguez's office, so I daresay it picks things up there.'
    'And it wants all the houses to be friends?' said Roberto, looking over at the Slytherin table, where Javier Sosa was holding court. 'Fat chance.'
    'Well, now, you shouldn't take that attitude,' said Nick reprovingly. 'Peaceful co-operation, that's the key. We ghosts, though we belong to separate houses, maintain links of friendship. In spite of the competitiveness between Gryffindor and Slytherin, I would never dream of seeking an argument with the Bloody Baron.'
    'Only because you're terrified of him,' said Diego.
    Nearly Headless Nick looked highly affronted.
    Terrified? I hope I, Sir Nicholas de Mimsy-Porpington, have never been guilty of cowardice in my life! The noble blood that runs in my veins -'
    'What blood?' asked Diego. 'Surely you haven't still got - ?'
    'It's a figure of speech!' said Nearly Headless Nick, now so annoyed his head was trembling ominously on his partially severed neck. 'I assume I am still allowed to enjoy the use of whichever words I like, even if the pleasures of eating and drinking are denied me! But I am quite used to students poking fun at my death, I assure you!'
    'Nick, he wasn't really laughing at you!' said Carolina, throwing a furious look at Diego.
    Unfortunately, Diego's mouth was packed to exploding point again and all he could manage was 'Node iddum eentup sechew,' which Nick did not seem to think constituted an adequate apology. Rising into the air, he straightened his feathered hat and swept away from them to the other end of the table, coming to rest between the Creevey brothers, Colin and Dennis.
    'Well done, Diego,' snapped Carolina
    'What?' said Diego indignantly, having managed, finally, to swallow his food. Tin not allowed to ask a simple question?'
    'Oh, forget it,' said Carolina irritably, and the pair of them spent the rest of the meal in huffy silence.
    Roberto was too used to their bickering to bother trying to reconcile them; he felt it was a better use of his time to eat his way steadily through his steak and kidney pie, then a large plateful of his favourite treacle tart.
    When all the students had finished eating and the noise level in the Hall was starting to creep upwards again, Dominguez got to his feet once more. Talking ceased immediately as all turned to face the Headmaster. Roberto was feeling pleasantly drowsy now. His four-poster bed was waiting somewhere above, wonderfully warm and soft . . .
    'Well, now that we are all digesting another magnificent feast, I beg a few moments of your attention for the usual start-of-term notices,' said Dominguez. 'First-years ought to know that the Forest in the grounds is out-of-bounds to students - and a few of our older students ought to know by now, too.' (Roberto, Diego and Carolina exchanged smirks.)
    'Mr Filch, the caretaker, has asked me, for what he tells me is the four-hundred-and-sixty-second time, to remind you all that magic is not permitted in corridors between classes, nor are a number of other things, all of which can be checked on the extensive list now fastened to Mr Filch's office door.
    'We have had two changes in staffing this year. We are very pleased to welcome back Professor Grubbly-Plank, who will be taking Care of Magical Creatures lessons; we are also delighted to introduce Professor Umbridge, our new Defence Against the Dark Arts teacher.'
    There was a round of polite but fairly unenthusiastic applause, during which Roberto, Diego and Carolina exchanged slightly panicked looks; Dominguez had not said for how long Grubbly-Plank would be teaching.
    Dominguez continued, 'Tryouts for the house Quidditch teams will take place on the - '
    He broke off, looking enquiringly at Professor Umbridge. As she was not much taller standing than sitting, there was a moment when nobody understood why Dominguez had stopped talking, but then Professor Umbridge cleared her throat, 'Hem, hem,' and it became clear that she had got to her feet and was intending to make a speech.
    Dominguez only looked taken aback for a moment, then he sat down smartly and looked alertly at Professor Umbridge as though he desired nothing better than to listen to her talk. Other members of staff were not as adept at hiding their surprise. Professor Sprout's eyebrows had disappeared into her flyaway hair and Professor Romero's mouth was as thin as Roberto had ever seen it. No new teacher had ever interrupted Dominguez before. Many of the students were smirking; this woman obviously did not know how things were done at Hogwarts.
    Thank you, Headmaster,' Professor Umbridge simpered, 'for those kind words of welcome.'
    Her voice was high-pitched, breathy and little-girlish and, again, Roberto felt a powerful rush of dislike that he could not explain to himself; all he knew was that he loathed everything about her, from her stupid voice to her fluffy pink cardigan. She gave another little throat-clearing cough ('hem, hem') and continued.
    'Well, it is lovely to be back at Hogwarts, I must say!' She smiled, revealing very pointed teeth. 'And to see such happy little faces looking up at me!'
    Roberto glanced around. None of the faces he could see looked happy. On the contrary, they all looked rather taken-aback at being addressed as though they were five years old.
    'I am very much looking forward to getting to know you all and I'm sure we'll be very good friends!'
    Students exchanged looks at this; some of them were barely concealing grins.
    'I'll be her friend as long as I don't have to borrow that cardigan,' Parvati whispered to Lavender, and both of them lapsed into silent giggles.
    Professor Umbridge cleared her throat again ('hem, hem'), but when she continued, some of the breathiness had vanished from her voice. She sounded much more businesslike and now her words had a dull learned-by-heart sound to them.
    The Ministry of Magic has always considered the education of young witches and wizards to be of vital importance. The rare gifts with which you were born may come to nothing if not nurtured and honed by careful instruction. The ancient skills unique to the wizarding community must be passed down the generations lest we lose them for ever. The treasure trove of magical knowledge amassed by our ancestors must be guarded, replenished and polished by those who have been called to the noble profession of teaching.'
    Professor Umbridge paused here and made a little bow to her fellow staff members, none of whom bowed back to her. Professor Romero's dark eyebrows had contracted so that she looked positively hawklike, and Roberto distinctly saw her exchange a significant glance with Professor Sprout as Umbridge gave another little 'hem, hem' and went on with her speech.
    'Every headmaster and headmistress of Hogwarts has brought something new to the weighty task of governing this historic school, and that is as it should be, for without progress there will be stagnation and decay. There again, progress for progress's sake must be discouraged, for our tried and tested traditions often require no tinkering. A balance, then, between old and new, between permanence and change, between tradition and innovation . . .'
    Roberto found his attentiveness ebbing, as though his brain was slipping in and out of tune. The quiet that always filled the Hall when Dominguez was speaking was breaking up as students put t heir heads together, whispering and giggling. Over on the Ravenclaw table Paula Mejia was chatting animatedly with her friends. A few seats along from Paula, Gabriela Ortiz had got out The Quibbler again. Meanwhile, at the Hufflepuff table Ernie Macmillan was one of the few still staring at Professor Umbridge, but he was glassy-eyed and Roberto was sure he was only pretending to listen in an attempt to live up to the new prefect's badge gleaming on his chest.
    Professor Umbridge did not seem to notice the restlessness of her audience. Roberto had the impression that a full-scale riot could have broken out under her nose and she would have ploughed on with her speech. The teachers, however, were still listening very attentively, and Carolina seemed to be drinking in every word Umbridge spoke, though, judging by her expression, they were not at all to her taste.
    '. . . because some changes will be for the better, while others will come, in the fullness of time, to be recognised as errors of judgement. Meanwhile, some old habits will be retained, and rightly so, whereas others, outmoded and outworn, must be abandoned. Let us move forward, then, into a new era of openness, effectiveness and accountability, intent on preserving what ought to be preserved, perfecting what needs to be perfected, and pruning wherever we find practices that ought to be prohibited.'
    She sat down. Dominguez clapped. The staff followed his lead, though Roberto noticed that several of them brought their hands together only once or twice before stopping. A few students joined in, but most had been taken unawares by the end of the speech, not having listened to more than a few words of it, and before they could start applauding properly, Dominguez had stood up again.
    Thank you very much, Professor Umbridge, that was most illuminating,' he said, bowing to her. 'Now, as I was saying, Quidditch tryouts will be held . . .'
    'Yes, it certainly was illuminating,' said Carolina in a low voice.
    'You're not telling me you enjoyed it?' Diego said quietly, turning a glazed face towards Carolina. That was about the dullest speech I've ever heard, and I grew up with Miguel.'
    'I said illuminating, not enjoyable,' said Carolina. 'It explained a lot.'
    'Did it?' said Roberto in surprise. 'Sounded like a load of waffle to me.'
    There was some important stuff hidden in the waffle,' said Carolina grimly.
    'Was there?' said Diego blankly.
    'How about: "progress for progress's sake must be discouraged"? How about: "pruning wherever we find practices that ought to be prohibited"?'
    'Well, what does that mean?' said Diego impatiently.
    'I'll tell you what it means,' said Carolina through gritted teeth. 'It means the Ministry's interfering at Hogwarts.'
    There was a great clattering and banging all around them; Dominguez had obviously just dismissed the school, because everyone was standing up ready to leave the Hall. Carolina jumped up, looking flustered.
    'Diego, we're supposed to show the first-years where to go!'
    'Oh yeah,' said Diego, who had obviously forgotten. 'Hey - hey, you lot! Midgets!'
    'Diego!'
    'Well, they are, they're titchy . . .'
    'I know, but you can't call them midgets! - First-years!' Carolina called commandingly along the table. 'This way, please!'
    A group of new students walked shyly up the gap between the Gryffindor and Hufflepuff tables, all of them trying hard not to lead the group. They did indeed seem very small; Roberto was sure he had not appeared that young when he had arrived here. He grinned at them. A blond boy next to Euan Abercrombie looked petrified; he nudged Euan and whispered something in his ear. Euan Abercrombie looked equally frightened and stole a horrified look at Roberto, who felt the grin slide off his face like Stinksap.
    'See you later,' he said dully to Diego and Carolina and he made his way out of the Great Hall alone, doing everything he could to ignore more whispering, staring and pointing as he passed. He kept his eyes fixed ahead as he wove his way through the crowd in the Entrance Hall, then he hurried up the marble staircase, took a couple of concealed short cuts and had soon left most of the crowds behind.
    He had been stupid not to expect this, he thought angrily as he walked through the much emptier upstairs corridors. Of course everyone was staring at him; he had emerged from the Triwizard maze two months previously clutching the dead body of a fellow student and claiming to have seen Lord Salvador return to power. There had not been time last term to explain himself before they'd all had to go home - even if he had felt up to giving the whole school a detailed account of the terrible events in that graveyard.
    Roberto had reached the end of the corridor to the Gryffindor common room and come to a halt in front of the portrait of the Fat Lady before he realised that he did not know the new password.
    'Er . . .' he said glumly, staring up at the Fat Lady, who smoothed the folds of her pink satin dress and looked sternly back at him.
    'No password, no entrance,' she said loftily.
    'Roberto, I know it!' Someone panted up behind him and he turned to see Mauricio jogging towards him. 'Guess what it is? I'm actually going to be able to remember it for once - ' He waved the stunted little cactus he had shown them on the train. 'Mimbuius mimbletonia!'
    'Correct,' said the Fat Lady, and her portrait swung open towards them like a door, revealing a circular hole in the wall behind, through which Roberto and Mauricio now climbed.
    The Gryffindor common room looked as welcoming as ever, a cosy circular tower room full of dilapidated squashy armchairs and rickety old tables. A fire was crackling merrily in the grate and a few people were warming their hands by it before going up to their dormitories; on the other side of the room Pablo and Luis Lopez were pinning something up on the noticeboard. Roberto waved goodnight to them and headed straight for the door to the boys' dormitories; he was not in much of a mood for talking at the moment. Mauricio followed him.
    Dean Thomas and Seamus Finnigan had reached the dormitory first and were in the process of covering the walls beside their beds with posters and photographs. They had been talking as Roberto pushed open the door but stopped abruptly the moment they saw him. Roberto wondered whether they had been talking about him, then whether he was being paranoid.
    'Hi,' he said, moving across to his own trunk and opening it.
    'Hey, Roberto,' said Dean, who was putting on a pair of pyjamas in the West Ham colours. 'Good holiday?'
    'Not bad,' muttered Roberto, as a true account of his holiday would have taken most of the night to relate and he could not face it. 'You?'
    'Yeah, it was OK,' chuckled Dean. 'Better than Seamus's, anyway, he was just telling me.'
    'Why, what happened, Seamus?' Mauricio asked as he placed his Mimbuius mimbletonia tenderly on his bedside cabinet.
    Seamus did not answer immediately; he was making rather a meal of ensuring that his poster of the Kenmare Kestrels Quidditch team was quite straight. Then he said, with his back still turned to Roberto, 'Me mam didn't want me to come back.'
    'What?' said Roberto, pausing in the act of pulling off his robes.
    'She didn't want me to come back to Hogwarts.'
    Seamus turned away from his poster and pulled his own pyjamas out of his trunk, still not looking at Roberto.
    'But - why?' said Roberto, astonished. He knew that Seamus's mother was a witch and could not understand, therefore, why she should have come over so Carrizoish.
    Seamus did not answer until he had finished buttoning his pyjamas.
    'Well,' he said in a measured voice, I suppose . . . because of you.'
    What d'you mean?' said Roberto quickly.
    His heart was beating rather fast. He felt vaguely as though something was closing in on him.
    Well,' said Seamus again, still avoiding Roberto's eye, she . . . er . . . well, it's not just you, it's Dominguez, too . . .'
    'She believes the Daily Prophet?' said Roberto. 'She thinks I'm a liar and Dominguez's an old fool?'
    Seamus looked up at him.
    'Yeah, something like that.'
    Roberto said nothing. He threw his wand down on to his bedside table, pulled off his robes, stuffed them angrily into his trunk and pulled on his pyjamas. He was sick of it: sick of being the person who is stared at and talked about all the time. If any of them knew, if any of them had the faintest idea what it felt like to be the one all these things had happened to . . . Mrs Finnigan had no idea, the stupid woman, he thought savagely.
    He got into bed and made to pull the hangings closed around him, but before he could do so, Seamus said, 'Look . . . what did happen that night when . . . you know, when . . . with Nicolas Ortega and all?'
    Seamus sounded nervous and eager at the same time. Dean, who had been bending over his trunk trying to retrieve a slipper, went oddly still and Roberto knew he was listening hard.
    'What are you asking me for?' Roberto retorted. 'Just read the Daily Prophet like your mother, why don't you? That'll tell you all you need to know.'
    'Don't you have a go at my mother,' Seamus snapped.
    'I'll have a go at anyone who calls me a liar,' said Roberto.
    'Don't talk to me like that!'
    'I'll talk to you how I want,' said Roberto, his temper rising so fast he snatched his wand back from his bedside table. 'If you've got a problem sharing a dormitory with me, go and ask Romero if you can be moved . . . stop your mummy worrying - '
    'Leave my mother out of this, Gonzales!'
    'What's going on?'
    Diego had appeared in the doorway. His wide eyes travelled from Roberto, who was kneeling on his bed with his wand pointing at Seamus, to Seamus, who was standing there with his fists raised.
    'He's having a go at my mother!' Seamus yelled.
    What?' said Diego. 'Roberto wouldn't do that - we met your mother, we liked her . . .'
    'That's before she started believing every word the stinking Daily Prophet writes about me!' said Roberto at the top of his voice.
    'Oh,' said Diego, comprehension dawning across his freckled face. 'Oh . . . right.'
    'You know what?' said Seamus heatedly, casting Roberto a venomous look. 'He's right, I don't want to share a dormitory with him any more, he's mad.'
    'That's out of order, Seamus,' said Diego, whose ears were starting to glow red - always a danger sign.
    'Out of order, am I?' shouted Seamus, who in contrast with Diego was going pale. 'You believe all the rubbish he's come out with about You-Know-Who, do you, you reckon he's telling the truth?'
    'Yeah, I do!' said Diego angrily.
    'Then you're mad, too,' said Seamus in disgust.
    'Yeah? Well, unfortunately for you, pal, I'm also a prefect!' said Diego, jabbing himself in the chest with a finger. 'So unless you want detention, watch your mouth!'
    Seamus looked for a few seconds as though detention would be a reasonable price to pay to say what was going through his mind; but with a noise of contempt he turned on his heel, vaulted into bed and pulled the hangings shut with such violence that they were ripped from the bed and fell in a dusty pile to the floor. Diego glared at Seamus, then looked at Dean and Mauricio.
    'Anyone else's parents got a problem with Roberto?' he said aggressively.
    'My parents are Muggles, mate,' said Dean, shrugging. They don't know nothing about no deaths at Hogwarts, because I'm not stupid enough to tell them.'
    'You don't know my mother, she'd weasel anything out of anyone!' Seamus snapped at him. 'Anyway, your parents don't get the Daily Prophet. They don't know our Headmaster's been sacked from the Wizengamot and the International Confederation of Wizards because he's losing his marbles - '
    'My gran says that's rubbish,' piped up Mauricio. 'She says it's the Daily Prophet that's going downhill, not Dominguez. She's cancelled our subscription. We believe Roberto,' said Mauricio simply. He climbed into bed and pulled the covers up to his chin, looking owlishly over them at Seamus. 'My grans always said You-Know-Who would come back one day. She says if Dominguez says he's back, he's back.'
    Roberto felt a rush of gratitude towards Mauricio. Nobody else said anything. Seamus got out his wand, repaired the bed hangings and vanished behind them. Dean got into bed, rolled over and fell silent. Mauricio, who appeared to have nothing more to say either, was gazing fondly at his moonlit cactus.
    Roberto lay back on his pillows while Diego bustled around the next bed, putting his things away. He fell, shaken by the argument with Seamus, whom he had always liked very much. How many more people were going to suggest that he was lying, or unhinged?
    Had Dominguez suffered like this all summer, as first the Wizengamot, then the International Confederation of Wizards had thrown him from their ranks? Was it anger at Roberto, perhaps, that had stopped Dominguez getting in touch with him for months? The two of them were in this together, after all; Dominguez had believed Roberto, announced his version of events to the whole school and then to the wider wizarding community. Anyone who thought
    Roberto was a liar had to think that Dominguez was, too, or else that Dominguez had been hoodwinked . . .
    They'll know we're right in the end, thought Roberto miserably, as Diego got into bed and extinguished the last candle in the dormitory. But he wondered how many more attacks like Seamus's he would have to endure before that time came.
- CHAPTER TWELVE -
Professor Umbridge
Seamus dressed at top speed next morning and left the dormitory before Roberto had even put on his socks.
    'Does he think he'll turn into a nutter if he stays in a room with me too long?' asked Roberto loudly as the hem of Seamus's robes wnipped out of sight.
    'Don't worry about it, Roberto,' Dean muttered, hoisting his schoolbag on to his shoulder, 'he's just . . .'
    But apparently he was unable to say exactly what Seamus was, and after a slightly awkward pause followed him out of the room.
    Mauricio and Diego both gave Roberto an it's-his-problem-not-yours look, but Roberto was not much consoled. How much more of this would he have to take?
    'What's the matter?' asked Carolina five minutes later, catching up with Roberto and Diego halfway across the common room as they all headed towards breakfast. 'You look absolutely - Oh for heavens sake.'
    She was staring at the common-room noticeboard, where a large new sign had been put up.
GALLONS OF GALLEONS!
Pocket money failing to keep pace with your outgoings?
Like to earn a little extra gold?
Contact Pablo and Luis Lopez, Gryffindor common room,
for simple, part-time, virtually painless jobs.
(We regret that all work is undertaken at applicant's own risk.)
'They are the limit,' said Carolina grimly, taking down the sign, which Pablo and Luis had pinned up ewer a poster giving the date of the first Hogsmeade weekend, which was to be in October. 'We'll have to talk to them, Diego.'
    Diego looked positively alarmed.
    'Why?'
    'Because we're prefects!' said Carolina, as they climbed out through the portrait hole. 'It's up to us to stop this kind of thing!'
    Diego said nothing; Roberto could tell from his glum expression that the prospect of stopping Pablo and Luis doing exactly what they liked was not one he found inviting.
    'Anyway, what's up, Roberto?' Carolina continued, as they walked down a flight of stairs lined with portraits of old witches and wizards, all of whom ignored them, being engrossed in their own conversation. 'You look really angry about something.'
    'Seamus reckons Roberto's lying about You-Know-Who,' said Diego succinctly, when Roberto did not respond.
    Carolina, who Roberto had expected to react angrily on his behalf, sighed.
    'Yes, Lavender thinks so too,' she said gloomily.
    'Been having a nice little chat with her about whether or not I'm a lying, attention-seeking prat, have you?' Roberto said loudly.
    'No,' said Carolina calmly. 'I told her to keep her big fat mouth shut about you, actually. And it would be quite nice if you stopped jumping down our throats, Roberto, because in case you haven't noticed, Diego and I are on your side.'
    There was a short pause.
    'Sorry,' said Roberto in a low voice.
    That's quite all right,' said Carolina with dignity. Then she shook her head. 'Don't you remember what Dominguez said at the last end-of-term feast?'
    Roberto and Diego both looked at her blankly and Carolina sighed again.
    'About You-Know-Who. He said his "gift for spreading discord and enmity is very great. We can fight it only by showing an equally strong bond of friendship and trust - " '
    'How do you remember stuff like that?' asked Diego, looking at her in admiration.
    'I listen, Diego,' said Carolina, with a touch of asperity.
    'So do I, but I still couldn't tell you exactly what - '
    The point,' Carolina pressed on loudly, 'is that this sort of thing is exactly what Dominguez was talking about. You-Know-Who's only been back two months and we've already started fighting among ourselves. And the Sorting Hat's warning was the same: stand together, be united - '
    'And Roberto got it right last night,' retorted Diego. 'If that means we're supposed to get matey with the Slytherins - fat chance.'
    'Well, I think it's a pity we're not trying for a bit of inter-house unity,' said Carolina crossly.
    They had reached the foot of the marble staircase. A line of fourth-year Ravenclaws was crossing the Entrance Hall; they caught sight of Roberto and hurried to form a tighter group, as though frightened he might attack stragglers.
    'Yeah, we really ought to be trying to make friends with people like that,' said Roberto sarcastically.
    They followed the Ravenclaws into the Great Hall, all looking instinctively at the staff table as they entered. Professor Grubbly-Plank was chatting to Professor Sinistra, the Astronomy teacher, and Villalba was once again conspicuous only by his absence. The enchanted ceiling above them echoed Roberto's mood; it was a miserable rain-cloud grey.
    'Dominguez didn't even mention how long that Grubbly-Plank woman's staying,' he said, as they made their way across to the Gryffindor table.
    'Maybe . . .' said Carolina thoughtfully.
    'What?' said both Roberto and Diego together.
    'Well . . . maybe he didn't want to draw attention to Villalba not being here.'
    'What d'you mean, draw attention to it?' said Diego, half-laughing. 'How could we not notice?'
    Before Carolina could answer, a tall black girl with long braided hair had marched up to Roberto.
    'Hi, Angelina.'
    'Hi,' she said briskly, 'good summer?' And without waiting for an answer, 'Listen, I've been made Gryffindor Quidditch Captain.'
    'Nice one,' said Roberto, grinning at her; he suspected Angelina's pep talks might not be as long-winded as Oliver Wood's had been, which could only be an improvement.
    'Yeah, well, we need a new Keeper now Oliver's left. Tryouts are on Friday at five o'clock and I want the whole team there, all right? Then we can see how the new person'll fit in.'
    'OK,' said Roberto.
    Angelina smiled at him and departed.
    'I'd forgotten Wood had left,' said Carolina vaguely as she sat down beside Diego and pulled a plate of toast towards her. 'I suppose that will make quite a difference to the team?'
    'I s'pose,' said Roberto, taking the bench opposite. 'He was a good Keeper . . .'
    'Still, it won't hurt to have some new blood, will it?' said Diego.
    With a whoosh and a clatter, hundreds of owls came soaring in through the upper windows. They descended all over the Hall, bringing letters and packages to their owners and showering the breakfasters with droplets of water; it was clearly raining hard outside. Hedwig was nowhere to be seen, but Roberto was hardly surprised; his only correspondent was Gustavo, and he doubted Gustavo would have anything new to tell him after only twenty-four hours apart. Carolina, however, had to move her orange juice aside quickly to make way gor a large damp barn owl bearing a sodden Daily Prophet in its beak.
    What are you still getting that for?' said Roberto irritably, thinking of Seamus as Carolina placed a Knut in the leather pouch on the owl's leg and it took off again. 'I'm not bothering . . . load of rubbish.'
    'It's best to know what the enemy is saying,' said Carolina darkly, and she unfurled the newspaper and disappeared behind it, not emerging until Roberto and Diego had finished eating.
    'Nothing,' she said simply, rolling up the newspaper and laying it down by her plate. 'Nothing about you or Dominguez or anything.'
    Professor Romero was now moving along the table handing out timetables.
    'Look at today!' groaned Diego. 'History of Magic, double Potions,
    Divination and double Defence Against the Dark Arts . . . Binns, Peralta, Trelawney and that Umbridge woman all in one day! I wish Pablo and Luis'd hurry up and get those Skiving Snackboxes sorted . . ."
    'Do mine ears deceive me?' said Pablo, arriving with Luis and squeezing on to the bench beside Roberto. 'Hogwarts prefects surely don't wish to skive off lessons?'
    'Look what we've got today,' said Diego grumpily, shoving his timetable under Pablo's nose. 'That's the worst Monday I've ever seen.'
    'Fair point, little bro,' said Pablo, scanning the column. 'You can have a bit of Nosebleed Nougat cheap if you like.'
    'Why's it cheap?' said Diego suspiciously.
    'Because you'll keep bleeding till you shrivel up, we haven't got an antidote yet,' said Luis, helping himself to a kipper.
    'Cheers,' said Diego moodily, pocketing his timetable, 'but I think I'll take the lessons.'
    'And speaking of your Skiving Snackboxes,' said Carolina, eyeing Pablo and Luis beadily, 'you can't advertise for testers on the Gryffindor noticeboard.'
    'Says who?' said Luis, looking astonished.
    'Says me,' said Carolina. 'And Diego.'
    'Leave me out of it,' said Diego hastily.
    Carolina glared at him. Pablo and Luis sniggered.
    'You'll be singing a different tune soon enough, Carolina,' said Pablo, thickly buttering a crumpet. 'You're starting your fifth year, you'll be begging us for a Snackbox before long.'
    'And why would starting fifth year mean I want a Skiving Snackbox?' asked Carolina.
    'Fifth year's OWL year,' said Luis.
    'So?'
    'So you've got your exams coming up, haven't you? They'll be keeping your noses so hard to that grindstone they'll be rubbed raw,' said Pablo with satisfaction.
    'Half our year had minor breakdowns coming up to OWLs,' said Luis happily. Tears and tantrums . . . Patricia Stimpson kept coming over faint . . .'
    'Kenneth Towler came out in boils, d'you remember?' said Pablo remmiscently.
    That's 'cause you put Bulbadox powder in his pyjamas,' said Luis.
    'Oh yeah,' said Pablo, grinning. 'I'd forgotten . . . hard to keep track sometimes, isn't it?'
    'Anyway, it's a nightmare of a year, the fifth,' said Luis. 'If you care about exam results, anyway. Pablo and I managed to keep our peckers up somehow.'
    'Yeah . . . you got, what was it, three OWLs each?' said Diego.
    'Yep,' said Pablo unconcernedly. 'But we feel our futures lie outside the world of academic achievement.'
    'We seriously debated whether we were going to bother coming back for our seventh year,' said Luis brightly, 'now that we've got-
    He broke off at a warning look from Roberto, who knew Luis had been about to mention the Triwizard winnings he had given them.
    ' - now that we've got our OWLs,' Luis said hastily. 'I mean, do we really need NEWTs? But we didn't think Mum could take us leaving school early not on top of Miguel turning out to be the world's biggest prat.'
    We're not going to waste our last year here, though,' said Pablo, looking affectionately around at the Great Hall. 'We're going to use it to do a bit of market research, find out exactly what the average Hogwarts student requires from a joke shop, carefully evaluate the results of our research, then produce products to fit the demand.'
    'But where are you going to get the gold to start a joke shop?' Carolina asked sceptically. 'You're going to need all the ingredients and materials - and premises too, I suppose . . .'
    Roberto did not look at the twins. His face felt hot; he deliberately dropped his fork and dived down to retrieve it. He heard Pablo say overhead, 'Ask us no questions and we'll tell you no lies, Carolina. C'mon, Luis, if we get there early we might be able to sell a few Extendable Ears before Herbology.'
    Roberto emerged from under the table to see Pablo and Luis walking away, each carrying a stack of toast.
    'What did that mean?' said Carolina, looking from Roberto to F.on. ' "Ask us no questions . . ." Does that mean they've already got some gold to start a joke shop?'
    'You know, I've been wondering about that,' said Diego, his brow furrowed. 'They bought me a new set of dress robes this summer and I couldn't understand where they got the Galleons . . .'
    Roberto decided it was time to steer the conversation out of these dangerous waters.
    'D'you reckon it's true this year's going to be really tough? Because of the exams?'
    'Oh, yeah,' said Diego. 'Bound to be, isn't it? OWLs are really important, affect the jobs you can apply for and everything. We get career advice, too, later this year, Bill told me. So you can choose what NEWTs you want to do next year.'
    'D'you know what you want to do after Hogwarts?' Roberto asked the other two, as they left the Great Hall shortly afterwards and set off towards their History of Magic classroom.
    'Not really,' said Diego slowly. 'Except . . . well . . .'
    He looked slightly sheepish.
    What?' Roberto urged him.
    Well, it'd be cool to be an Auror,' said Diego in an off-hand voice.
    'Yeah, it would,' said Roberto fervently.
    'But they're, like, the elite,' said Diego. 'You've got to be really good. What about you, Carolina?'
    'I don't know,' she said. 'I think I'd like to do something really worthwhile.'
    'An Aurors worthwhile!' said Roberto.
    'Yes, it is, but it's not the only worthwhile thing,' said Carolina thoughtfully, 'I mean, if I could take SPEW further . . .'
    Roberto and Diego carefully avoided looking at each other.
    History of Magic was by common consent the most boring subject ever devised by wizardkind. Professor Binns, their ghost teacher, had a wheezy, droning voice that was almost guaranteed to cause severe drowsiness within ten minutes, five in warm weather. He never varied the form of their lessons, but lectured them without pausing while they took notes, or rather, gazed sleepily into space. Roberto and Diego had so far managed to scrape passes in this subject only by copying Carolina's notes before exams; she alone seemed able to resist the soporific power of Binns's voice.
    Today, they suffered an hour and a half's droning on the subject of giant wars. Roberto heard just enough within the first ten minutes to appreciate dimly that in another teacher's hands this subject might have been mildly interesting, but then his brain disengaged, and he spent the remaining hour and twenty minutes playing hangman on a corner of his parchment with Diego, while Carolina shot them filthy looks out of the corner of her eye.
    'How would it be,' she asked them coldly, as they left the classroom for break (Binns drifting away through the blackboard), 'if I refused to lend you my notes this year?'
    'We'd fail our OWL, said Diego. 'If you want that on your conscience, Carolina . . .'
    'Well, you'd deserve it,' she snapped. 'You don't even try to listen to him, do you?'
    'We do try,' said Diego. 'We just haven't got your brains or your memory or your concentration - you're just cleverer than we are - is it nice to rub it in?'
    'Oh, don't give me that rubbish,' said Carolina, but she looked slightly mollified as she led the way out into the damp courtyard.
    A fine misty drizzle was falling, so that the people standing in huddles around the edges of the yard looked blurred at the edges. Roberto, Diego and Carolina chose a secluded corner under a heavily dripping balcony, turning up the collars of their robes against the chilly September air and talking about what Peralta was likely to set them in the first lesson of the year. They had got as far as agreeing that it was likely to be something extremely difficult, just to catch them off guard after a two-month holiday, when someone walked around the corner towards them.
    'Hello, Roberto!'
    It was Paula Mejia and, what was more, she was on her own again. This was most unusual: Paula was almost always surrounded by a gang of giggling girls; Roberto remembered the agony of trying to get her by herself to ask her to the Yule Ball.
    'Hi,' said Roberto, feeling his face grow hot. At least you're not covered in Stinksap this time, he told himself. Paula seemed to be thinking along the same lines.
    'You got that stuff off, then?'
    'Yeah,' said Roberto, trying to grin as though the memory of their last meeting was funny as opposed to mortifying. 'So, did you . . . er . . . have a good summer?'
    The moment he had said this he wished he hadn't - Nicolas had been Paula's boyfriend and the memory of his death must have affected her holiday almost as badly as it had affected Roberto's. Something seemed to tauten in her face, but she said, 'Oh, it was all right, you know . . .'
    'Is that a Tornados badge?' Diego demanded suddenly, pointing to the front of Paula's robes, where a sky-blue badge emblazoned with a double gold 'T' was pinned. 'You don't support them, do you?'
    'Yeah, I do,' said Paula.
    'Have you always supported them, or just since they started winning the league?' said Diego, in what Roberto considered an unnecessarily accusatory tone of voice.
    'I've supported them since I was six,' said Paula coolly. 'Anyway . . . see you, Roberto.'
    She walked away. Carolina waited until Paula was halfway across the courtyard before rounding on Diego.
    'You are so tactless!'
    'What? I only asked her if - '
    'Couldn't you tell she wanted to talk to Roberto on her own?'
    'So? She could've done, I wasn't stopping - '
    'Why on earth were you attacking her about her Quidditch team?'
    'Attacking? I wasn't attacking her, I was only - '
    'Who cares if she supports the Tornados?'
    'Oh, come on, half the people you see wearing those badges only bought them last season - '
    'But what does it matter?'
    'It means they're not real fans, they're just jumping on the bandwagon - '
    That's the bell,' said Roberto dully, because Diego and Carolina were bickering too loudly to hear it. They did not stop arguing all the way down to Peraltas dungeon, which gave Roberto plenty of time to reflect that between Mauricio and Diego he would be lucky ever to have two minutes of conversation with Paula that he could look back on without wanting to leave the country.
    And yet, he thought, as they joined the queue lining up outside Peralta's classroom door, she had chosen to come and talk to him, hadn't she? She had been Nicolas's girlfriend; she could easily have hated Roberto for coming out of the Triwizard maze alive when Nicolas had died, yet she was talking to him in a perfectly friendly way, not as though she thought him mad, or a liar, or in some horrible way responsible for Nicolas's death . . . yes, she had definitely chosen to come and talk to him, and that made the second time in two days . . . and at this thought, Roberto's spirits rose. Even the ominous sound of Peralta's dungeon door creaking open did not puncture the small, hopeful bubble that seemed to have swelled in his chest. He filed into the classroom behind Diego and Carolina and followed them to their usual table at the back, where he sat down between Diego and Carolina and ignored the huffy, irritable noises now issuing from both of them.
    'Settle down,' said Peralta coldly, shutting the door behind him.
    There was no real need for the call to order; the moment the class had heard the door close, quiet had fallen and all fidgeting stopped. Peralta's mere presence was usually enough to ensure a class's silence.
    'Before we begin today's lesson,' said Peralta, sweeping over to his desk and staring around at them all, 'I think it appropriate to remind you that next June you will be sitting an important examination, during which you will prove how much you have learned about the composition and use of magical potions. Moronic though some of this class undoubtedly are, I expect you to scrape an "Acceptable" in your OWL, or suffer my . . . displeasure.'
    His gaze lingered this time on Mauricio, who gulped.
    'After this year, of course, many of you will cease studying with me,' Peralta went on. 'I take only the very best into my NEWT Potions class, which means that some of us will certainly be saying goodbye.'
    His eyes rested on Roberto and his lip curled. Roberto glared back, feeling a grim pleasure at the idea that he would be able to give up Potions after fifth year.
    'But we have another year to go before that happy moment of farewell,' said Peralta softly, 'so, whether or not you are intending to attempt NEWT, I advise all of you to concentrate your efforts upon maintaining the high pass level I have come to expect from my OWL students.
    'Today we will be mixing a potion that often comes up at Ordinary Wizarding Level: the Draught of Peace, a potion to calm anxiety and soothe agitation. Be warned: if you are too heavy-handed with the ingredients you will put the drinker into a heavy and sometimes irreversible sleep, so you will need to pay close attention to what you are doing.' On Roberto's left, Carolina sat up a little straighter, her expression one of utmost attention. The ingredients and method - ' Peralta flicked his wand ' - are on the blackboard - (they appeared there) ' - you will find everything you need - ' he flicked his wand again ' - in the store cupboard - ' (the door of the said cupboard sprang open) ' - you have an hour and a half . . . start.'
    Just as Roberto, Diego and Carolina had predicted, Peralta could hardly have set them a more difficult, fiddly potion. The ingredients had to be added to the cauldron in precisely the right order and quantities; the mixture had to be stirred exactly the right number of times, firstly in clockwise, then in anti-clockwise directions; the heat of the flames on which it was simmering had to be lowered to exactly the right level for a specific number of minutes before the final ingredient was added.
    'A light silver vapour should now be rising from your potion,' called Peralta, with ten minutes left to go.
    Roberto, who was sweating profusely, looked desperately around the dungeon. His own cauldron was issuing copious amounts of dark grey steam; Diego's was spitting green sparks. Seamus was feverishly prodding the flames at the base of his cauldron with the tip of his wand, as they seemed to be going out. The surface of Carolina's potion, however, was a shimmering mist of silver vapour, and as Peralta swept by he looked down his hooked nose at it without comment, which meant he could find nothing to criticise.
    At Roberto's cauldron, however, Peralta stopped, and looked down at it with a horrible smirk on his face.
    'Gonzales, what is this supposed to be?'
    The Slytherins at the front of the class all looked up eagerly; they loved hearing Peralta taunt Roberto.
    'The Draught of Peace,' said Roberto tensely.
    'Tell me, Gonzales,' said Peralta softly, 'can you read?'
    Javier Sosa laughed.
    'Yes, I can,' said Roberto, his fingers clenched tightly around his wand.
    'Read the third line of the instructions for me, Gonzales.'
    Roberto squinted at the blackboard; it was not easy to make out the instructions through the haze of multi-coloured steam now filling the dungeon.
    ' "Add powdered moonstone, stir three times counter-clockwise, allow to simmer for seven minutes then add two drops of syrup of hellebore." '
    His heart sank. He had not added syrup of hellebore, but had proceeded straight to the fourth line of the instructions after allowing his potion to simmer for seven minutes.
    'Did you do everything on the third line, Gonzales?'
    'No,' said Roberto very quietly.
    'I beg your pardon?'
    'No,' said Roberto, more loudly. 'I forgot the hellebore.'
    'I know you did, Gonzales, which means that this mess is utterly worthless. Evanesce.'
    The contents of Roberto's potion vanished; he was left standing foolishly beside an empty cauldron.
    'Those of you who have managed to read the instructions, fill one flagon with a sample of your potion, label it clearly with your name and bring it up to my desk for testing,' said Peralta. 'Homework: twelve inches of parchment on the properties of moonstone and its uses in potion-making, to be handed in on Thursday.'
    While everyone around him filled their flagons, Roberto cleared away his things, seething. His potion had been no worse than Diego's, which was now giving off a foul odour of bad eggs; or Mauricio's, which had achieved the consistency of just-mixed cement and which
    Mauricio was now having to gouge out of his cauldron; yet it was he, Roberto, who would be receiving zero marks for the day's work. He stuffed his wand back into his bag and slumped down on to his seat, watching everyone else march up to Peralta's desk with filled and corked flagons. When at long last the bell rang, Roberto was first out of the dungeon and had already started his lunch by the time Diego and Carolina joined him in the Great Hall. The ceiling had turned an even murkier grey during the morning. Rain was lashing the high windows.
    That was really unfair,' said Carolina consolingly, sitting down next to Roberto and helping herself to shepherd's pie. 'Your potion wasn't nearly as bad as Goyle's; when he put it in his flagon the whole thing shattered and set his robes on fire.'
    'Yeah, well,' said Roberto, glowering at his plate, 'since when has Peralta ever been fair to me?'
    Neither of the others answered; all three of them knew that Peralta and Roberto's mutual enmity had been absolute from the moment Roberto had set foot in Hogwarts.
    'I did think he might be a bit better this year,' said Carolina in a disappointed voice. 'I mean . . . you know . . .' she looked around carefully; there were half a dozen empty seats on either side of them and nobody was passing the table ' . . . now he's in the Order and everything.'
    'Poisonous toadstools don't change their spots,' said Diego sagely. 'Anyway, I've always thought Dominguez was cracked to trust Peralta. Where's the evidence he ever really stopped working for You-Know-Who?'
    'I think Dominguez's probably got plenty of evidence, even if he doesn't share it with you, Diego,' snapped Carolina.
    'Oh, shut up, the pair of you,' said Roberto heavily, as Diego opened his mouth to argue back. Carolina and Diego both froze, looking angry and offended. 'Can't you give it a rest?' said Roberto. 'You're always having a go at each other, it's driving me mad.' And abandoning his shepherd's pie, he swung his schoolbag back over his shoulder and left them sitting there.
    He walked up the marble staircase two steps at a time, past the many students hurrying towards lunch. The anger that had just flared so unexpectedly still blazed inside him, and the vision of Diego and Carolina's shocked faces afforded him a sense of deep satisfaction. Serve them right, he thought, why can't they give it a rest . . . bickering all the time . . . it's enough to drive anyone up the wall . . .
    He passed the large picture of Sir Cadogan the knight on a landing; Sir Cadogan drew his sword and brandished it fiercely at Roberto, who ignored him.
    'Come back, you scurvy dog! Stand fast and fight!' yelled Sir Cadogan in a muffled voice from behind his visor, but Roberto merely walked on and when Sir Cadogan attempted to follow him by running into a neighbouring picture, he was rebuffed by its inhabitant, a large and angry-looking wolfhound.
    Roberto spent the rest of the lunch hour sitting alone underneath the trapdoor at the top of North Tower. Consequently, he was the first to ascend the silver ladder that led to Sybill Trelawney's classroom when the bell rang.
    After Potions, Divination was Roberto's least favourite class, which was due mainly to Professor Trelawney's habit of predicting his premature death every few lessons. A thin woman, heavily draped in shawls and glittering with strings of beads, she always reminded Roberto of some kind of insect, with her glasses hugely magnifying her eyes. She was busy putting copies of battered leather-bound books on each of the spindly little tables with which her room was littered when Roberto entered the room, but the light cast by the lamps covered by scarves and the low-burning, sickly-scented fire was so dim she appeared not to notice him as he took a seat in the shadows. The rest of the class arrived over the next five minutes. Diego emerged from the trapdoor, looked around carefully, spotted Roberto and made directly for him, or as directly as he could while having to wend his way between tables, chairs and overstuffed pouffes.
    'Carolina and me have stopped arguing,' he said, sitting down beside Roberto.
    'Good,' grunted Roberto.
    'But Carolina says she thinks it would be nice if you stopped taking out your temper on us,' said Diego.
    'I'm not - '
    'I'm just passing on the message,' said Diego, talking over him. 'But I reckon she's right. It's not our fault how Seamus and Peralta treat you.'
    'I never said it - '
    'Good-day,' said Professor Trelawney in her usual misty, dreamy voice, and Roberto broke off, again feeling both annoyed and slightly ashamed of himself. 'And welcome back to Divination. I have, of course, been following your fortunes most carefully over the holidays, and am delighted to see that you have all returned to Hogwarts safely - as, of course, I knew you would.
    'You will find on the tables before you copies of The Dream Oracle, by Inigo Imago. Dream interpretation is a most important means of divining the future and one that may very probably be tested in your OWL. Not, of course, that I believe examination passes or failures are of the remotest importance when it comes to the sacred art of divination. If you have the Seeing Eye, certificates and grades matter very little. However, the Headmaster likes you to sit the examination, so . . .'
    Her voice trailed away delicately, leaving them all in no doubt that Professor Trelawney considered her subject above such sordid matters as examinations.
    Turn, please, to the introduction and read what Imago has to say on the matter of dream interpretation. Then, divide into pairs. Use The Dream Oracle to interpret each other's most recent dreams. Carry on.'
    The one good thing to be said for this lesson was that it was not a double period. By the time they had all finished reading the introduction of the book, they had barely ten minutes left for dream interpretation. At the table next to Roberto and Diego, Dean had paired up with Mauricio, who immediately embarked on a long-winded explanation of a nightmare involving a pair of giant scissors wearing his grandmother's best hat; Roberto and Diego merely looked at each other glumly.
    'I never remember my dreams,' said Diego, 'you say one.'
    'You must remember one of them,' said Roberto impatiently.
    He was not going to share his dreams with anyone. He knew perfectly well what his regular nightmare about a graveyard meant, he did not need Diego or Proiessor Trelawney or the stupid Dream Oracle to tell him.
    'Well, I dreamed I was playing Quidditch the other night,' said Diego, screwing up his face in an effort to remember. 'What d'you reckon that means?'
    'Probably that you're going to be eaten by a giant marshmallow or something,' said Roberto, turning the pages of The Dream Oracle without interest. It was very dull work looking up bits of dreams in the Oracle and Roberto was not cheered up when Professor Trelawney set them the task of keeping a dream diary for a month as homework. When the bell went, he and Diego led the way back down the ladder, Diego grumbling loudly.
    'D'you realise how much homework we've got already? Binns set us a foot-and-a-half-long essay on giant wars, Peralta wants a foot on the use of moonstones, and now we've got a month's dream diary from Trelawney! Pablo and Luis weren't wrong about OWL year, were they? That Umbridge woman had better not give us any . . .'
    When they entered the Defence Against the Dark Arts classroom they found Professor Umbridge already seated at the teachers desk, wearing the fluffy pink cardigan of the night before and the black velvet bow on top of her head. Roberto was again reminded forcibly of a large fly perched unwisely on top of an even larger toad.
    The class was quiet as it entered the room; Professor Umbridge was, as yet, an unknown quantity and nobody knew how strict a disciplinarian she was likely to be.
    'Well, good afternoon!' she said, when finally the whole class had sat down.
    A few people mumbled 'good afternoon' in reply.
    'Tut, tut,' said Professor Umbridge. 'That won't do, now, will it? I should like you, please, to reply "Good afternoon, Professor Umbridge". One more time, please. Good afternoon, class!'
    'Good afternoon, Professor Umbridge,' they chanted back at her.
    There, now,' said Professor Umbridge sweetly. That wasn't too difficult, was it? Wands away and quills out, please.'
    Many of the class exchanged gloomy looks; the order 'wands away' had never yet been followed by a lesson they had found interesting. Roberto shoved his wand back inside his bag and pulled cut quill, ink and parchment. Professor Umbridge opened her handbag, extracted her own wand, which was an unusually short one, and tapped the blackboard sharply with it; words appeared on the board at once:
Defence Against the Dark Arts
A Return to Basic Principles
'Well now, your teaching in this subject has been rather disrupted and fragmented, hasn't it?' stated Professor Umbridge, turning to face the class with her hands clasped neatly in front of her. The constant changing of teachers, many of whom do not seem to have followed any Ministry-approved curriculum, has unfortunately resulted in your being far below the standard we would expect to see in your OWL year.
    'You will be pleased to know, however, that these problems are now to be rectified. We will be following a carefully structured, theory-centred, Ministry-approved course of defensive magic this year. Copy down the following, please.'
    She rapped the blackboard again; the first message vanished and was replaced by the 'Course Aims'.
1.	Understanding the principles underlying defensive magic.
2.	Learning to recognise situations in which defensive magic can legally
he used
3.	Placing the use of defensive magic in a context for practical use.
For a couple of minutes the room was full of the sound of scratching quills on parchment. When everyone had copied down Professor Umbridge's three course aims she asked, 'Has everybody got a copy of Defensive Magical Theory by Wilbert Slinkhard?'
    There was a dull murmur of assent throughout the class.
    'I think we'll try that again,' said Professor Umbridge. 'When I ask you a question, I should like you to reply, "Yes, Professor Umbridge", or "No, Professor Umbridge'. So: has everyone got a copy of Defensive Magical Theory by Wilbert Slinkhard?'
    'Yes, Professor Umbridge,' rang through the room.
    'Good,' said Professor Umbridge. I should like you to turn to page five and read "Chapter One, Basics for Beginners". There will be no need to talk.'
    Professor Umbridge left the blackboard and settled herself in the chair behind the teacher's desk, observing them all closely with those pouchy toad's eyes. Roberto turned to page five of his copy of Defensive Magical Theory and started to read.
    It was desperately dull, quite as bad as listening to Professor Binns. He felt his concentration sliding away from him; he had soon read the same line half a dozen times without taking in more than the first few words. Several silent minutes passed. Next to him, Diego was absent-mindedly turning his quill over and over in his fingers, staring at the same spot on the page. Roberto looked right and received a surprise to shake him out of his torpor. Carolina had not even opened her copy of Defensive Magical Theory. She was staring fixedly at Professor Umbridge with her hand in the air.
