Then he said, 'Listen . . . you don't fancy going out a bit earlier with me, do you? Just to - er - give me some practice before training? So I can, you know, get my eye in a bit.'
    'Yeah, OK,' said Roberto.
    'Look, I don't think you should,' said Carolina seriously. 'You're both really behind on homework as it - '
    But she broke off; the morning post was arriving and, as usual, the Daily Prophet was soaring towards her in the beak of a screech owl, which landed perilously close to the sugar bowl and held out a leg. Carolina pushed a Knut into its leather pouch, took the newspaper, and scanned the front page critically as the owl took off.
    'Anything interesting?' said Diego. Roberto grinned, knowing Diego was keen to keep her off the subject of homework.
    'No,' she sighed, 'just some guff about the bass player in the Weird Sisters getting married.'
    Carolina opened the paper and disappeared behind it. Roberto devoted himself to another helping of eggs and bacon. Diego was staring up at the high windows, looking slightly preoccupied.
    'Wait a moment,' said Carolina suddenly. 'Oh no . . . Gustavo!'
    'What's happened?' said Roberto, snatching at the paper so violently it ripped down the middle, with him and Carolina each holding one half.
    ' "The Ministry of Magic has received a tip-off from a reliable source that Gustavo Martinez, notorious mass murderer . . . blah blah blah . . .is currently hiding in London!" ' Carolina read from her half in an anguished whisper.
    'Mariano Sosa, I'll bet anything,' said Roberto in a low, furious voice. 'He did recognise Gustavo on the platform . . .'
    What?' said Diego, looking alarmed. 'You didn't say - '
    'Shh!' said the other two.
    '. . . "Ministry warns wizarding community that Martinez is very dangerous . . . killed thirteen people . . . broke out of Azkaban . . ." the usual rubbish,' Carolina concluded, laying down her half of the paper and looking fearfully at Roberto and Diego. 'Well, he just won't be able to leave the house again, that's all,' she whispered. 'Dominguez did warn him not to.'
    Roberto looked down glumly at the bit of the Prophet he had torn off. Most of the page was devoted to an advertisement for Madam Malkin's Robes for All Occasions, which was apparently having a sale.
    'Hey!' he said, flattening it down so Carolina and Diego could see it. 'Look at this!'
    'I've got all the robes I want,' said Diego 'No,' said Roberto. 'Look . . . this little piece here . . ." Diego and Carolina bent closer to read it; the item was barely an inch long and placed right at the bottom of a column. It was headlined:
TRESPASS AT MINISTRY
Sturgis Podmore, 38, of number two, Laburnum Gardens, Clapham, has appeared in front of the Wizcngamot charged with trespass and attempted robbery at the Ministry of Magic on 31" August. Podmore was arrested by Ministry of Magic watchwizard Eric Munch, who found him attempting to force his way through a top-security door at one o'clock in the morning. Podmore, who refused to speak, in his own defence, was convicted on both charges and sentenced to six months in Azkaban.
'Sturgis Podmore?' said Diego slowly. 'He's that bloke who looks like his head's been thatched, isn't he? He's one of the Ord-
    'Diego, shhl' said Carolina, casting a terrified look around them.
    'Six months in Azkaban!' whispered Roberto, shocked. 'Just for trying to get through a door!'
    'Don't be silly, it wasn't just for trying to get through a door. What on earth was he doing at the Ministry of Magic at one o'clock in the morning?' breathed Carolina.
    D'you reckon he was doing something for the Order?' Diego muttered.
    'Wait a moment . . .' said Roberto slowly. 'Sturgis was supposed to come and see us off, remember?'
    The other two looked at him.
    'Yeah, he was supposed to be part of our guard going to King's Cross, remember? And Acosta was all annoyed because he didn't turn up; so he couldn't have been on a job for them, could he?'
    'Well, maybe they didn't expect him to get caught,' said Carolina.
    'It could be a frame-up!' Diego exclaimed excitedly. 'No - listen!' he went on, dropping his voice dramatically at the threatening look on Carolina's face. The Ministry suspects he's one of Dominguez's lot so - I dunno - they lured him to the Ministry, and he wasn't trying to get through a door at all! Maybe they've just made something up to get him!'
    There was a pause while Roberto and Carolina considered this. Roberto thought it seemed far-fetched. Carolina, on the other hand, looked rather impressed.
    'Do you know, I wouldn't be at all surprised if that were true.'
    She folded up her half of the newspaper thoughtfully. As Roberto laid down his knife and fork, she seemed to come out of a reverie.
    'Right, well, I think we should tackle that essay for Sprout on self-fertilising shrubs first and if we're lucky we'll be able to start Romero's Inanimatus Conjurus Spell before lunch . . .'
    Roberto felt a small twinge of guilt at the thought of the pile of homework awaiting him upstairs, but the sky was a clear, exhilarating blue, and he had not been on his Firebolt for a week . . .
    'I mean, we can do it tonight,' said Diego, as he and Roberto walked down the sloping lawns towards the Quidditch pitch, their broomsticks over their shoulders, and with Carolina's dire warnings that they would fail all their OWLs still ringing in their ears. 'And we've got tomorrow. She gets too worked up about work, that's her trouble . . .' There was a pause and he added, in a slightly more anxious tone, 'D'you think she meant it when she said we weren't copying from her?'
    'Yeah, I do,' said Roberto. 'Still, this is important, too, we've got to practise if we want to stay on the Quidditch team . . .'
    'Yeah, that's right,' said Diego, in a heartened tone. 'And we have got plenty of time to do it all . . .'
    As they approached the Quidditch pitch, Roberto glanced over to his right to where the trees of the Forbidden Forest were swaying darkly. Nothing flew out of them; the sky was empty but for a few distant owls fluttering around the Owlery tower. He had enough to worry about; the flying horse wasn't doing him any harm; he pushed it out of his mind.
    They collected balls from the cupboard in the changing room and set to work, Diego guarding the three tall goalposts, Roberto playing Chaser and trying to get the Quaffle past Diego. Roberto thought Diego was pretty good; he blocked three-quarters of the goals Roberto attempted to put past him and played better the longer they practised. After a couple of hours they returned to the castle for lunch - during which Carolina made it quite clear she thought they were irresponsible - then returned to the Quidditch pitch for the real training session. All their teammates but Angelina were already in the changing room when they entered.
    All right, Diego?' said Luis, winking at him.
    Yeah,' said Diego, who had become quieter and quieter all the way down to the pitch.
    'Ready to show us all up, Ickle Prefect?' said Pablo, emerging tousle-haired from the neck of his Quidditch robes, a slightly malicious grin on his face.
    'Shut up,' said Diego, stony-faced, pulling on his own team robes for the first time. They fitted him well considering they had been Oliver Wood's, who was rather broader in the shoulder.
    'OK, everyone,' said Angelina, entering from the Captain's office, already changed. 'Let's gel to it; Alicia and Pablo, if you can jus: bring out the ball crate for us. Oh, and there are a couple of people out there watching but I want you to just ignore them, all right?'
    Something in her would-be casual voice made Roberto think he might know who the uninvited spectators were, and sure enough, when they left the changing room for the bright sunlight of the pitch it was to a storm of catcalls and jeers from the Slytherin Quidditch team and assorted hangers-on, who were grouped halfway up the empty stands and whose voices echoed loudly around the stadium.
    'What's that Lopez's riding?' Sosa called in his sneering drawl. 'Why would anyone put a flying charm on a mouldy old log like that?'
    Crabbe, Goyle and Pansy Parkinson guffawed and shrieked with laughter. Diego mounted his broom and kicked off from the ground and Roberto followed him, watching his ears turn red from behind.
    'Ignore them,' he said, accelerating to catch up with Diego, 'we'll see who's laughing after we play them . . .'
    'Exactly the attitude I want, Roberto' said Angelina approvingly soaring around them with the Quaffle under her arm and slowing to hover on the spot in front of her airborne team. 'OK, everyone, we're going to start with some passes just to warm up, the whole team please - '
    'Hey, Johnson, what's with that hairstyle, anyway?' shrieked Pansy Parkinson from below. 'Why would anyone want to look like they've got worms coming out of their head?'
    Angelina swept her long braided hair out of her face and continued calmly, 'Spread out, then, and let's see what we can do . . .'
    Roberto reversed away from the others to the far side of the pitch. Diego fell back towards the opposite goal. Angelina raised the Quaffle with one hand and threw it hard to Pablo, who passed to Luis, who passed to Roberto, who passed to Diego, who dropped it.
    The Slytherins, led by Sosa, roared and screamed with laughter. Diego, who had pelted towards the ground to catch the Quaffle before it landed, pulled out of the dive untidily, so that he slipped sideways on his broom, and returned to playing height, blushing. Roberto saw Pablo and Luis exchange looks, but uncharacteristically neither of them said anything, for which he was grateful.
    'Pass it on, Diego,' called Angelina, as though nothing had happened.
    Diego threw the Quaffle to Alicia, who passed back to Roberto, who passed to Luis . . .
    'Hey, Gonzales, how's your scar feeling?' called Sosa. 'Sure you don't need a lie down? It must be, what, a whole week since you were in the hospital wing, that's a record for you, isn't it?'
    Luis passed to Angelina; she reverse-passed to Roberto, who had not been expecting it, but caught it in the very tips of his fingers and passed it quickly to Diego, who lunged for it and missed by inches.
    'Come on now, Diego,' said Angelina crossly, as he dived for the ground again, chasing the Quaffle. 'Pay attention.'
    It would have been hard to say whether Diego's face or the Quaffle was a deeper scarlet when he again returned to playing height. Sosa and the rest of the Slytherin team were howling with laughter.
    On his third attempt, Diego caught the Quaffle; perhaps out of relief he passed it on so enthusiastically that it soared straight though Katie's outstretched hands and hit her hard in the face.
    'Sorry!' Diego groaned, zooming forwards to see whether he had done any damage.
    'Get back in position, she's fine!' barked Angelina. 'But as you're passing to a teammate, do try not to knock her off her broom, won't you? We've got Bludgers for that!'
    Katie's nose was bleeding. Down below, the Slytherins were stamping their feet and jeering. Pablo and Luis converged on Katie.
    'Here, take this,' Pablo told her, handing her something small anc purple from out of his pocket, 'it'll clear it up in no time.'
    'All right,' called Angelina, 'Pablo, Luis, go and get your bats and a Bludger. Diego, get up to the goalposts. Roberto, release the Snitch when I say so. We're going to aim for Diego's goal, obviously.'
    Roberto zoomed off after the twins to fetch the Snitch.
    'Diego's making a right pig's ear of things, isn't he?' muttered Luis, as the three of them landed at the crate containing the balls and opened it to extract one of the Bludgers and the Snitch.
    'He's just nervous,' said Roberto, 'he was fine when I was practising with him this morning.'
    'Yeah, well, I hope he hasn't peaked too soon,' said Pablo gloomily.
    They returned to the air. When Angelina blew her whistle, Roberto released the Snitch and Pablo and Luis let fly the Bludger. From that moment on, Roberto was barely aware of what the others were doing. It was his job to recapture the tiny fluttering golden ball that was worth a hundred and fifty points to the Seeker's team and doing so required enormous speed and skill. He accelerated, rolling and swerving in and out of the Chasers, the warm autumn air whipping his face, and the distant yells of the Slytherins so much meaningless roaring in his ears . . . but too soon, the whistle brought him to a halt again.
    'Stop - stop - STOP!' screamed Angelina. 'Diego - you're not covering your middle post!'
    Roberto looked round at Diego, who was hovering in front of the left-hand hoop, leaving the other two completely unprotected.
    'Oh . . . sorry . . .'
    'You keep shifting around while you're watching the Chasers!' said Angelina. 'Either stay in centre position until you have to move to defend a hoop, or else circle the hoops, but don't drift vaguely off to one side, that's how you let in the last three goals!'
    'Sorry . . .' Diego repeated, his red face shining like a beacon against the bright blue sky.
    'And Katie, can't you do something about that nosebleed?'
    'It's just getting worse!' said Katie thickly, attempting to stem the flow with her sleeve.
    Roberto glanced round at Pablo, who was looking anxious and checking his pockets. He saw Pablo pull out something purple, examine it for a second and then look round at Katie, evidently horror-struck.
    'Well, let's try again,' said Angelina. She was ignoring the Slytherins, who had now set up a chant of 'Gryffindor are losers, Gryffindor are losers,' but there was a certain rigidity about her seat on the broom nevertheless.
    This time they had been flying for barely three minutes when Angelinas whistle sounded. Roberto, who had just sighted the Snitch circling the opposite goalpost, pulled up feeling distinctly aggrieved.
    'What now?' he said impatiently to Alicia, who was nearest.
    'Katie,' she said shortly.
    Roberto turned and saw Angelina, Pablo and Luis all flying as fast as they could towards Katie. Roberto and Alicia sped towards her, too. It was plain that Angelina had stopped training just in time; Katie was now chalk white and covered in blood.
    'She needs the hospital wing,' said Angelina.
    'We'll take her,' said Pablo. 'She - er - might have swallowed a Blood Blisterpod by mistake - '
    'Well, there's no point continuing with no Beaters and a Chaser gone,' said Angelina glumly as Pablo and Luis zoomed off towards the castle supporting Katie between them. 'Come on, let's go and get changed.'
    The Slytherins continued to chant as they trailed back into the changing rooms.
    'How was practice?' asked Carolina rather coolly half an hour later, as Roberto and Diego climbed through the portrait hole into the Gryffindor common room.
    'It was - ' Roberto began.
    'Completely lousy,' said Diego in a hollow voice, sinking into a chair beside Carolina. She looked up at Diego and her frost mess seemed to melt.
    'Well, it was only your first one,' she said consolingly, 'it's bound to take time to - '
    'Who said it was me who made it lousy?' snapped Diego.
    'No one,' said Carolina, looking taken aback, 'I thought - '
    'You thought I was bound to be rubbish?'
    'No, of course I didn't! Look, you said it was lousy so I just - '
    'I'm going to get started on some homework,' said Diego angrily and stomped off to the staircase to the boys' dormitories and vanished from sight. Carolina turned to Roberto.
    'Was he lousy?'
    No,' said Roberto loyally.
    Carolina raised her eyebrows.
    'Well, I suppose he could've played better,' Roberto muttered, 'but it was only the first training session, like you said . . .'
    Neither Roberto nor Diego seemed to make much headway with their homework that night. Roberto knew Diego was too preoccupied with how badly he had performed at Quidditch practice and he himself was having difficulty in getting the 'Gryffindor are losers' chant out of his head.
    They spent the whole of Sunday in the common room, buried in ! heir books while the room around them filled up, then emptied. It was another clear, fine day and most of their fellow Gryffindors spent the day out in the grounds, enjoying what might well be some of the last sunshine that year. By the evening, Roberto felt as though somebody had been beating his brain against the inside of his skull.
    'You know, we probably should try and get more homework done during the week, Roberto muttered to Diego, as they finally laid aside Professor Romero's long essay on the Inanimatus Conjurus Spell and turned miserably to Professor Sinistra's equally long and difficult essay about Jupiter's many moons.
    'Yeah,' said Diego, rubbing slightly bloodshot eyes and throwing his fifth spoiled bit of parchment into the fire beside them. 'Listen . . . shall we just ask Carolina if we can have a look at what she's done?'
    Roberto glanced over at her; she was sitting with Crookshanks on her lap and chatting merrily to Martina as a pair of knitting needles flashed in midair in front of her, now knitting a pair of shapeless elf socks.
    'No,' he said heavily, 'you know she won't let us.'
    And so they worked on while the sky outside the windows became steadily darker. Slowly, the crowd in the common room began to thin again. At half past eleven, Carolina wandered over to them, yawning.
    'Nearly done?'
    'No,' said Diego shortly.
    'Jupiter's biggest moon is Ganymede, not Callisto,' she said, pointing over Diego's shoulder at a line in his Astronomy essay, 'and it's lo that's got the volcanoes.'
    Thanks,' snarled Diego, scratching out the offending sentences.
    'Sorry, I only - '
    'Yeah, well, if you've just come over here to criticise - '
    'Diego - '
    'I haven't got time to listen to a sermon, all right, Carolina, I'm up to my neck in it here - '
    'No - look!'
    Carolina was pointing to the nearest window. Roberto and Diego both looked over. A handsome screech owl was standing on the windowsill, gazing into the room at Diego.
    'Isn't that Hermes?' said Carolina, sounding amazed.
    'Blimey, it is!' said Diego quietly, throwing down his quill and getting to his feet. 'What's Miguel writing to me for?'
    He crossed to the window and opened it; Hermes flew inside, landed on Diego's essay and held out a leg to which a letter was attached. Diego took the letter off it and the owl departed at once, leaving inky footprints across Diego's drawing of the moon Io.
    That's definitely Miguel's handwriting,' said Diego, sinking back into his chair and staring at the words on the outside of the scroll: Diegoald Lopez, Gryffindor House, Hogwarts. He looked up at the other two. 'What d'you reckon?'
    'Open it!' said Carolina eagerly, and Roberto nodded.
    Diego unrolled the scroll and began to read. The further clown the parchment his eyes travelled, the more pronounced became his scowl. When he had finished reading, he looked disgusted. He thrust the letter at Roberto and Carolina, who leaned towards each other to read it together:
Dear Diego,
I have only just heard (from no less a person than the Minister for Magic himself, who has it from your new teacher, Professor Umbridge) that you have become a Hogwarts prefect.
    I was most pleasantly surprised when f heard this news and must firstly offer my congratulations. I must admit that I have always been afraid that you would take what we might call the 'Pablo and Luis' route, rather than following in my footsteps, so you can imagine my feelings on hearing you have stopped flouting authority and have decided to shoulder some real responsibility.
    But I want to give you more than congratulations, Diego, I want to give you some advice, which is why I am sending this at night rather than by the usual morning post. Hopefully, you will be able 'o read this away from prying eyes and avoid awkward questions.
    From something the Minister let slip when telling me you are now a prefect, I gather that you are still seeing a lot of Roberto Gonzales. I must tell you, Diego, that nothing could put you in danger of losing your badge more than continued fraternisation with that boy. Yes, I am sure you are surprised to hear this - no doubt you will say that Gonzales has always been Dominguez's favourite - but I feel bound to tell you that Dominguez may not be in charge at Hogwarts much longer and the people who count have a very different - and probably more accurate - view of Gonzales's behaviour. I shall say no more here, but if you look at the Daily Prophet tomorrow you will get a good idea of the way the wind is blowing - and see if you can spot yours truly!
    Seriously, Diego, you do not want to be tarred with the same brush as Gonzales, it could be very damaging to your future prospects, and I am talking here about life after school, too. As you must be aware, given that our father escorted him to court, Gonzales had a disciplinary hearing this summer in front of the whole Wizengamot and he did not come out of it looking too good. He got off on a mere technicality, if you ask me, and many of the people I've spoken to remain convinced of his guilt.
    It may be that you are afraid to sever ties with Gonzales - I know that he can be unbalanced and, for all I know, violent - but if you have any worries about this, or have spotted anything else in Gonzales's behaviour that is troubling you, I urge you to speak to Dolores Umbridge, a truly delightful woman who I know will be only too happy to advise you.
    This leads me to my other bit of advice. As I have hinted above, Dominguez's regime at Hogwarts may soon be over. Your loyalty, Diego, should be not to him, but to the school and the Ministry. I am very sorry to hear that, so far, Professor Umbridge is encountering very little co-operation from staff as she strives to make those necessary changes within Hogwarts that the Ministry so ardently desires (although she should find this easier from next week - again, see the Daily Prophet tomorrow!). I shall say only this - a student who shows himself willing to help Professor Umbridge now may be very well-placed for Head Boy ship in a couple of years!
    I am sorry that I was unable to see more of you over the summer. It pains me to criticise our parents, but I am afraid I can no longer live under their roof while they remain mixed up with the dangerous crowd around Dominguez. (If you are writing to Mother at any point, you might tell her that a certain Sturgis Podmore, who is a great friend of Dominguez's, has recently been sent to Azkaban for trespass at the Ministry. Perhaps that will open their eyes to the kind of petty criminals with whom they are currently rubbing shoulders.) I count myself very lucky to have escaped the stigma of association with such people - the Minister really could not be more gracious to me - and I do hope, Diego, that you will not allow family ties to blind you to the misguided nature of our parents' beliefs and actions, either. I sincerely hope that, in time, they will realise how mistaken they were and I shall, of course, be ready to accept a full apology when that day comes.
    Please think over what I have said most carefully, particularly the bit about Roberto Gonzales, and congratulations again on becoming prefect.
    Your brother,
    Miguel
Roberto looked up at Diego.
    'Well,' he said, trying to sound as though he found the whole thing a joke, 'if you want to - er - what is it?' - he checked Miguel's letter - 'Oh yeah - "sever ties" with me, I swear I won't get violent.'
    'Give it back,' said Diego, holding out his hand. 'He is - ' Diego said jerkily, tearing Miguel's letter in half 'the world's - ' he tore it into quarters 'biggest - ' he tore it into eighths 'git.' He threw the pieces into the fire.
    'Come on, we've got to get this finished sometime before dawn,' he said briskly to Roberto, pulling Professor Sinistra's essay back towards him.
    Carolina was looking at Diego with an odd expression on her face.
    'Oh, give them here,' she said abruptly.
    'What?' said Diego.
    'Give them to me, I'll look through them and correct them,' she said.
    'Are you serious? Ah, Carolina, you're a life-saver,' said Diego, 'what can I - ?'
    'What you can say is, "We promise we'll never leave our homework this late again," ' she said, holding out both hands for their essays, but she looked slightly amused all the same.
    'Thanks a million, Carolina,' said Roberto weakly, passing over his essay and sinking back into his armchair, rubbing his eyes.
    It was now past midnight and the common room was deserted but for the three of them and Crookshanks. The only sound was that of Carolina's quill scratching out sentences here and there on their essays and the ruffle of pages as she checked various facts in the reference books strewn across the table. Roberto was exhausted. He also felt an odd, sick, empty feeling in his stomach that had nothing to do with tiredness and everything to do with the letter now curling blackly in the heart of the fire.
    He knew that half the people inside Hogwarts thought him strange, even mad; he knew that the Daily Prophet had been making snide allusions to him for months, but there was something about seeing it written down like that in Miguel's writing, about knowing that Miguel was advising Diego to drop him and even to tell tales about him to Umbridge, that made his situation real to him as nothing else had. He had known Miguel for four years, had stayed in his house during the summer holidays, shared a tent with him during the Quidditch World Cup, had even been awarded full marks by him in the second task of the Triwizard Tournament last year, yet now, Miguel thought him unbalanced and possibly violent.
    And with a surge of sympathy for his godfather, Roberto thought Gustavo was probably the only person he knew who could really understand how he felt at the moment, because Gustavo was in the same situation. Nearly everyone in the wizarding world thought Gustavo a dangerous murderer and a great Salvador supporter and he had had to live with that knowledge for fourteen years . . .
    Roberto blinked. He had just seen something in the fire that could not have been there. It had flashed into sight and vanished immediately. No . . . it could not have been . . . he had imagined it because he had been thinking about Gustavo . . .
    'OK, write that down,' Carolina said to Diego, pushing his essay and a sheet covered in her own writing back to Diego, 'then add this conclusion I've written for you.'
    'Carolina, you are honestly the most wonderful person I've ever met,' said Diego weakly, 'and if I'm ever rude to you again - '
    - I'll know you're back to normal,' said Carolina. 'Roberto, yours is OK except for this bit at the end, I think you must have misheard Professor Sinistra, Europa's covered in ice, not mice - 'Roberto?'
    Roberto had slid off his chair on to his knees and was now crouching on the singed and threadbare hearthrug, gazing into the flames.
    'Er - Roberto?' said Diego uncertainly. 'Why are you down there?'
    'Because I've just seen Gustavo's head in the fire,' said Roberto.
    He spoke quite calmly; after all, he had seen Gustavo's head in this very fire the previous year and talked to it, too; nevertheless, he could not be sure that he had really seen it this time . . . it had vanished so quickly . . .
    'Gustavo's head?' Carolina repeated. 'You mean like when he wanted to talk to you during the Triwizard Tournament? But he wouldn't do that now, it would be too - Gustavo!'
    She gasped, gazing at the fire; Diego dropped his quill. There in the middle of the dancing flames sat Gustavo's head, long dark hair failing around his grinning face.
    'I was starting to think you'd go to bed before everyone else had disappeared,' he said. 'I've been checking every hour.'
    'You've been popping into the fire every hour?' Roberto said, half-laughing.
    'Just for a few seconds to check if the coast was clear.'
    'But what if you'd been seen?' said Carolina anxiously.
    'Well, I think a girl - first-year, by the look of her - might've get a glimpse of me earlier, but don't worry,' Gustavo said hastily, as Carolina clapped a hand to her mouth, '] was gone the moment she looked back at me and I'll bet she just thought I was an oddly-shaped log or something.'
    'But, Gustavo, this is taking an awful risk - ' Carolina began.
    'You sound like Alicia,' said Gustavo. This was the only way I could come up with of answering Roberto's letter without resorting to a code - and codes are breakable.'
    At the mention of Roberto's letter, Carolina and Diego both turned to stare at him.
    'You didn't say you'd written to Gustavo! said Carolina accusingly.
    'I forgot,' said Roberto, which was perfectly true; his meeting with Paula in the Owlery had driven everything before it out of his mind. 'Don't look at me like that, Carolina, there was no way anyone would have got secret information out of it, was there, Gustavo?'
    'No, it was very good,' said Gustavo, smiling. 'Anyway, we'd better be quick, just in case we're disturbed - your scar.'
    'What about - ?' Diego began, but Carolina interrupted him.
    'We'll tell you afterwards. Go on, Gustavo.'
    'Well, I know it can't be fun when it hurts, but we don't think its anything to really worry about. It kept aching all last year, didn't it?'
    'Yeah, and Dominguez said it happened whenever Salvador was feeling a powerful emotion,' said Roberto, ignoring, as usual, Diego and Carolina's winces. 'So maybe he was just, I dunno, really angry or something the night I had that detention.'
    'Well, now he's back it's bound to hurt more often,' said Gustavo.
    'So you don't think it had anything to do with Umbridge touching me when I was in detention with her?' Roberto asked.
    'I doubt it,' said Gustavo. 'I know her by reputation and I'm sure she's no Death Eater - '
    'She's foul enough to be one,' said Roberto darkly, and Diego and Carolina nodded vigorously in agreement.
    'Yes, but the world isn't split into good people and Death Eaters,' said Gustavo with a wry smile. 'I know she's a nasty piece of work, though - you should hear Pedro talk about her.'
    'Does Cardozo know her?' asked Roberto quickly, remembering Umbridge's comments about dangerous half-breeds during her first lesson.
    'No,' said Gustavo, 'but she drafted a bit of anti-werewolf legislation two years ago thai makes it almost impossible for him to get a job.'
    Roberto remembered how much shabbier Cardozo looked these days and his dislike of Umbridge deepened even further.
    'What's she got against werewolves?' said Carolina angrily.
    'Scared of them, I expect,' said Gustavo, smiling at her indignation. 'Apparently, she loathes part-humans; she campaigned to have merpeople rounded up and tagged last year, too. Imagine wasting your time and energy persecuting merpeople when there are little toerags like Kreacher on the loose.'
    Diego laughed but Carolina looked upset.
    'Gustavo!' she said reproachfully. 'Honestly, if you made a bit of an effort with Kreacher, I'm sure he'd respond. After all, you are the only member of his family he's got left, and Professor Dominguez said - '
    'So, what are Umbridge's lessons like?' Gustavo interrupted. 'Is she training you all to kill half-breeds?'
    'No,' said Roberto, ignoring Carolina's affronted look at being cut off in her defence of Kreacher. 'She's not letting us use magic at all!'
    'All we do is read the stupid textbook,' said Diego.
    'Ah, well, that figures,' said Gustavo. 'Our information from inside the Ministry is that Fudge doesn't want you trained in combat.'
    'Trained in combat!' repeated Roberto incredulously. 'What does he think we're doing here, forming some sort of wizard army?'
    That's exactly what he thinks you're doing,' said Gustavo, 'or, rather, that's exactly what he's afraid Dominguez's doing - forming his own private army, with which he will be able to take on the Ministry of Magic.'
    There was a pause at this, then Diego said, That's the most stupid thing I've ever heard, including all the stuff that Gabriela Ortiz comes out with.'
    'So we're being prevented from learning Defence Against the Dark Arts because Fudge is scared we'll use spells against the Ministry?' said Carolina, looking furious.
    'Yep,' said Gustavo. 'Fudge thinks Dominguez will stop at nothing to seize power. He's getting more paranoid about Dominguez by the day. It's a matter of time before he has Dominguez arrested on some trumped-up charge.'
    This reminded Roberto of Miguel's letter.
    'D'you know if there's going to be anything about Dominguez in the Daily Prophet tomorrow? Diego's brother Miguel reckons there will be - '
    'I don't know,' said Gustavo, 'I haven't seer, anyone from the Order all weekend, they're all busy. It's just been Kreacher and me here
    There was a definite note of bitterness in Gustavo's voice.
    'So you haven't had any news about Villalba, either?'
    'Ah . . .' said Gustavo, 'well, he was supposed to be back by now, no one's sure what's happened to him.' Then, seeing their stricken faces, he added quickly, 'But Dominguez's not worried, so don't you three get yourselves in a state; I'm sure Villalba's fine.'
    'But if he was supposed to be back by now . . .' said Carolina in a small, anxious voice.
    'Madame Maxime was with him, we've been in touch with her and she says they got separated on the journey home - but there's nothing to suggest he's hurt or - well, nothing to suggest he's not perfectly OK.'
    Unconvinced, Roberto, Diego and Carolina exchanged worried looks.
    'Listen, don't go asking too many questions about Villalba,' said Gustavo hastily, 'it'll just draw even more attention to the fact that he's not back and I know Dominguez doesn't want that. Villalba's tough, he'll be OK.' And when they did not appear cheered by this, Gustavo added, 'When's your next Hogsmeade weekend, anyway? I was thinking, we got away with the dog disguise at the station, didn't we? I thought I could - '
    'NO!' said Roberto and Carolina together, very loudly.
    'Gustavo, didn't you see the Daily Prophet?' said Carolina anxiously.
    'Oh, that,' said Gustavo, grinning, 'they're always guessing where I am, they haven't really got a clue - '
    'Yeah, but we think this time they have,' said Roberto. 'Something Sosa said on the train made us think he knew it was you, and his father was on the platform, Gustavo - you know, Mariano Sosa - so don't come up here, whatever you do. If Sosa recognises you again - '
    'All right, all right, I've got the point,' said Gustavo. He looked most displeased. 'Just an idea, thought you might like to get together.'
    'I would, I just don't want you chucked back in Azkaban!' said Roberto.
    There was a pause in which Gustavo looked out of the fire at Roberto, a crease between his sunken eyes.
    'You're less like your father than I thought,' he said finally, a definite coolness in his voice. 'The risk would've been what made it fun for Ricardo.'
    'Look - '
    'Well, I'd better get going, I can hear Kreacher coming down the stairs,' said Gustavo, but Roberto was sure he was lying. 'I'll write to tell you a time I can make it back into the fire, then, shall I? If you can stand to risk it?'
    There was a tiny pop, and the place where Gustavo's head had been was flickering flame once more.
- CHAPTER FIFTEEN -
The Hogwart's High
Inquisitor
They had expected to have to comb Carolina's Daily Prophet carefully next morning to find the article Miguel had mentioned in his letter. However, the departing delivery owl had barely cleared the top of the milk jug when Carolina let out a huge gasp and flattened the newspaper to reveal a large photograph of Dolores Umbridge, smiling widely and blinking slowly at them from beneath the headline.
MINISTRY SEEKS EDUCATIONAL REFORM
DOLORES UMBRIDGE APPOINTED
FIRST EVER HIGH INQUISITOR
'Umbridge - "High Inquisitor"?' said Roberto darkly, his half-eaten piece of toast slipping from his fingers. 'What does that mean?'
    Carolina read aloud:
'In a surprise move last night the Ministry of Magic passed new legislation giving itself an unprecedented level of control at Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry.
    ' "The Minister has been growing uneasy about goings-on at Hogwarts for some time," said Junior Assistant to the Minister, Miguel Lopez. "He is now responding to concerns, voiced by anxious parents, who feel the school may be moving in a direction they do not approve of."
    'This is not the first time in recent weeks that the Minister, Cornelius Fudge, has used new laws to effect improvements at the wizarding school. As recently as 30th August, Educational Decree Number Twenty-two was passed, to ensure that, in the event of the current Headmaster being unable to provide a candidate for a teaching post, the Ministry should select an appropriate person.
    ' "That's how Dolores Umbridge came to be appointed to the teaching staff at Hogwarts," said Lopez last night. "Dominguez couldn't find anyone so the Minister put in Umbridge, and of course, she's been an immediate success - " '
'She's been a WHAT?' said Roberto loudly.
    'Wait, there's more,' said Carolina grimly.
' "- an immediate success, totally revolutionising the teaching of Defence Against the Dark Arts and providing the Minister with on-the-ground feedback about what's really happening at Hogwarts."
    'It is this last function that the Ministry has now formalised with the passing of Educational Decree Number Twenty-three, which creates the new position of Hogwarts High Inquisitor.
    ' "This is an exciting new phase in the Minister's plan to get to grips with what some are calling the falling standards at Hogwarts," said Lopez. "The Inquisitor will have powers to inspect her fellow educators and make sure that they are coming up to scratch. Professor Umbridge has been offered this position in addition to her own teaching post and we are delighted to say that she has accepted."
    'The Ministry's new moves have received enthusiastic support from parents of students at Hogwarts.
    ' "I feel much easier in my mind now that I know Dominguez is being subjected to fair and objective evaluation," said Mr Mariano Sosa, 41, speaking from his Wiltshire mansion last night. "Many of us with our children's best interests at heart have been concerned about some of Dominguez's eccentric decisions in the last few years and are glad to know that the Ministry is keeping an eye on the situation."
    'Among those eccentric decisions are undoubtedly the controversial staff appointments previously described in this newspaper, which have included the employment of werewolf Pedro Cardozo, half-giant Matias Villalba and delusional ex-Auror, "Mad-Eye" Acosta.
    'Rumours abound, of course, that Alfonso Dominguez, once Supreme Mugwump of the International Confederation of Wizards and Chief Warlock of the Wizengamot, is no longer up to the task of managing the prestigious school of Hogwarts.
    ' "I think the appointment of the Inquisitor is a first step towards ensuring that Hogwarts has a headmaster in whom we can all repose our confidence," said a Ministry insider last night.
    'Wizengamot elders Griselda Marchbanks and Tiberius Ogden have resigned in protest at the introduction of the post of Inquisitor to Hogwarts.
    ' "Hogwarts is a school, not an outpost of Cornelius Fudge's office," said Madam Marchbanks. "This is a further, disgusting attempt to discredit Alfonso Dominguez."
    '(For a full account of Madam Marchbanks's alleged links to subversive goblin groups, turn to page seventeen.)'
Carolina finished reading and looked across the table at the other two.
    'So now we know how we ended up with Umbridge! Fudge passed this "Educational Decree" and forced her on us! And now he's given her the power to inspect the other teachers!' Carolina was breathing fast and her eyes were very bright. 'I can't believe this. It's outrageous!'
    'I know it is,' said Roberto. He looked down at his right hand, clenched on the table-top, and saw the faint white outline of the words Umbridge had forced him to cut into his skin.
    But a grin was unfurling on Diego's face.
    'What?' said Roberto and Carolina together, staring at him.
    'Oh, I can't wait to see Romero inspected,' said Diego happily. 'Umbridge won't know what's hit her.'
    'Well, come on,' said Carolina, jumping up, 'we'd better get going, if she's inspecting Binns's class we don't want to be late . . .'
    But Professor Umbridge was not inspecting their History of Magic lesson, which was just as dull as the previous Monday, nor was she in Peralta's dungeon when they arrived for double Potions, where Roberto's moonstone essay was handed back to him with a large, spiky black 'D' scrawled in an upper corner.
    'I have awarded you the grades you would have received if you presented this work in your OWL,' said Peralta with a smirk, as he swept among them, passing back their homework. 'This should give you a realistic idea of what to expect in the examination.'
    Peralta reached the front of the class and turned on his heel to face them.
    The general standard of this homework was abysmal. Most of you would have failed had this been your examination. I expect to see a great deal more effort for this week's essay on the various varieties of venom antidotes, or I shall have to start handing out detentions to those dunces who get a "D".'
    He smirked as Sosa sniggered and said in a carrying whisper, 'Some people got a "D"? Ha!'
    Roberto realised that Carolina was looking sideways to see what grade he had received; he slid his moonstone essay back into his bag as quickly as possible, feeling that he would rather keep that information private.
    Determined not to give Peralta an excuse to tail him this lesson, Roberto read and reread every line of instructions on the blackboard at least three times before acting on them. His Strengthening Solution was not precisely the clear turquoise shade of Carolina's but it was at least blue rather than pink, like Mauricio's, and he delivered a flask of it to Peralta's desk at the end of the lesson with a feeling of mingled defiance and relief.
    'Well, that wasn't as bad as last week, was it?' said Carolina, as they climbed the steps out of the dungeon and made their way across the Entrance Hall towards lunch. 'And the homework didn't go too badly, either, did it?'
    When neither Diego nor Roberto answered, she pressed on, 'I mean, all right, I didn't expect the top grade, not if he's marking to OWL standard, but a pass is quite encouraging at this stage, wouldn't you say?'
    Roberto made a non-committal noise in his throat.
    'Of course, a lot can happen between now and the exam, we've got plenty of time to improve, but the grades we're getting now are a sort of baseline, aren't they? Something we can build on . . .'
    They sat down together at the Gryffindor table.
    'Obviously, I'd have been thrilled if I'd got an "O" - '
    'Carolina,' said Diego sharply, 'if you want to know what grades we got, ask.'
    'I don't - I didn't mean - well, if you want to tell me - '
    'I got a "P",' said Diego, ladling soup into his bowl. 'Happy?'
    'Well, that's nothing to be ashamed of,' said Pablo, who had just arrived at the table with Luis and Lee Jordan and was sitting down on Roberto's right. 'Nothing wrong with a good healthy "P".'
    'But,' said Carolina, 'doesn't "P" stand for . . .'
    '"Poor", yeah,' said Lee Jordan. 'Still, better than "D", isn't it? 'Dreadful"?'
    Roberto felt his face grow warm and faked a small coughing fit over his roll. When he emerged from this he was sorry to find that Carolina was still in full flow about OWL grades.
    'So top grade's "O" for "Outstanding",' she was saying, 'and then there's "A" - '
    'No, "E",' Luis corrected her, '"E" for "Exceeds Expectations". And I've always thought Pablo and I should've got "E" in everything, because we exceeded expectations just by turning up for the exams.'
    They all laughed except Carolina, who ploughed on, 'So, after "E" it's "A" for "Acceptable", and that's the last pass grade, isn't it?'
    'Yep,' said Pablo, dunking an entire roll in his soup, transferring it to his mouth and swallowing it whole.
    'Then you get "P" for "Poor"- ' Diego raised both his arms in mock celebration - 'and "D" for "Dreadful".
    'And then "T",' Luis reminded her.
    '"T"?' asked Carolina, looking appalled. 'Even lower than a "D"? What on earth does "T" stand for?'
    '"Troll",' said Luis promptly.
    Roberto laughed again, though he was not sure whether or not Luis was joking. He imagined trying to conceal from Carolina I hat he had received 'T's in all his OWLs and immediately resolved to work harder from now on.
    'You lot had an inspected lesson yet?' Pablo asked them.
    'No,' said Carolina at once. 'Have you?'
    'Just now, before lunch,' said Luis. 'Charms.'
    'What was it like?' Roberto and Carolina asked together.
    Pablo shrugged.
    'Not that bad. Umbridge just lurked in the corner making notes on a clipboard. You know what Flitwick's like, he treated her like a guest, didn't seem to bother him at all. She didn't say much. Asked Alicia a couple of questions about what the classes are normally like, Alicia told her they were really good, that was it.'
    'I can't see old Flitwick getting marked down,' said Luis, 'he usually gets everyone through their exams all right.'
    'Who've you got this afternoon?' Pablo asked Roberto.
    Trelawney - '
    'A "T" if ever I saw one.'
    ' - and Umbridge herself.'
    'Well, be a good boy and keep your temper with Umbridge today,' said Luis. 'Angelina'll do her nut if you miss any more Quidditch practices.'
    But Roberto did not have to wait for Defence Against the Dark Arts to meet Professor Umbridge. He was pulling out his dream diary in a seat at the very back of the shadowy Divination room when Diego elbowed him in the ribs and, looking round, he saw Professor Umbridge emerging through the trapdoor in the floor. The class, which had been talking cheerily, fell silent at once. The abrupt fall in the noise level made Professor Trelawney, who had been wafting about handing out copies of The Dream Oracle, look round.
    'Good afternoon, Professor Trelawney,' said Professor Umbridge with her wide smile. "You received my note, I trust? Giving the time and date of your inspection?'
    Professor Trelawney nodded curtly and, looking very disgruntled, turned her back on Professor Umbridge and continued to give out books. Still smiling, Professor Umbridge grasped the back of the nearest armchair and pulled it to the front of the class so that it was a few inches behind Professor Trelawney's seat. She then sat down, took her clipboard from her flowery bag and looked up expectantly, waiting for the class to begin.
    Professor Trelawney pulled her shawls tight about her with slightly trembling hands and surveyed the class through her hugely magnifying lenses.
    'We shall be continuing our study of prophetic dreams today,' she said in a brave attempt at her usual mystic tones, though her voice shook slightly. 'Divide into pairs, please, and interpret each others latest night-time visions with the aid of the Oracle.'
    She made as though to sweep back to her seat, saw Professor Umbridge sitting right beside it, and immediately veered left towards Parvati and Lavender, who were already deep in discussion about Parvati's most recent dream.
    Roberto opened his copy of The Dream Oracle, watching Umbridge covertly. She was already making notes on her clipboard. After a few minutes she got to her feet and began to pace the room in "Trelawney's wake, listening to her conversations with students and posing questions here and there. Roberto bent his head hurriedly over his book.
    Think of a dream, quick,' he told Diego, 'in case the old toad comes our way.'
    'I did it last time,' Diego protested, 'it's your turn, you tell me one.'
    'Oh, I dunno . . .' said Roberto desperately, who could not remember dreaming anything at all over the last few days. 'Let's say I dreamed I was . . . drowning Peralta in my cauldron. Yeah, that'll do . . .'
    Diego chortled as he opened his Dream Oracle.
    'OK, we've got to add your age to the date you had the dream, the number of letters in the subject . . . would that be "drowning" or "cauldron" or "Peralta"?'
    'It doesn't matter, pick any of them.' said Roberto, chancing a glance behind him. Professor Umbridge was now standing at Professor Trelawney's shoulder making notes while the Divination teacher questioned Mauricio about his dream diary.
    'What night did you dream this again?' Diego said, immersed in calculations.
    'I dunno, last night, whenever you like,' Roberto told him, trying to listen to what Umbridge was saying to Professor Trelawney. They were only a table away from him and Diego now. Professor Umbridge was making another note on her clipboard and Professor Trelawney was looking extremely put out.
    'Now,' said Umbridge, looking up at Trelawney, 'you've been in this post how long, exactly?'
    Professor Trelawney scowled at her, arms crossed and shoulders hunched as though wishing to protect herself as much as possible from the indignity of the inspection. After a slight pause in which she seemed to decide that the question was not so offensive that she could reasonably ignore it, she said in a deeply resentful tone, 'Nearly sixteen years.'
    'Quite a period,' said Professor Umbridge, making a note on her clipboard. 'So it was Professor Dominguez who appointed you?'
    That's right,' said Professor Trelawney shortly.
    Professor Umbridge made another note.
    'And you are a great-great-granddaughter of the celebrated Seer Cassandra Trelawney?'
    'Yes,' said Professor Trelawney, holding her head a little higher.
    Another note on the clipboard.
    'But I think - correct me if I am mistaken - that you are the first in your family since Cassandra to be possessed of Second Sight?'
    These things often skip - er - three generations,' said Professor Trelawney.
    Professor Umbridge's toadlike smile widened.
    'Of course,' she said sweetly, making yet another note. 'Well, if you could just predict something for me, then?' And she looked up enquiringly, still smiling.
    Professor Trelawney stiffened as though unable to believe her ears. 'I don't understand you,' she said, clutching convulsively at the shawl around her scrawny neck.
    'I'd like you to make a prediction for me,' said Professor Umbridge very clearly.
    Roberto and Diego were not the only people now watching and listening sneakily from behind their books. Most of the class were staring transfixed at Professor Trelawney as she drew herself up to her lull height, her beads and bangles clinking.
    The Inner Eye does not See upon command!' she said in scandalised tones.
    'I see,' said Professor Umbridge softly, making yet another note on her clipboard.
    'I - but - but . . . wait!' said Professor Trelawney suddenly, in an attempt at her usual ethereal voice, though the mystical effect was ruined somewhat by the way it was shaking with anger. 'I . . . I think I do see something . . . something that concerns you . . . why, I sense something . . . something dark . . . some grave peril . . .'
    Professor Trelawney pointed a shaking finger at Professor Umbridge who continued to smile blandly at her, eyebrows raised.
    'I am afraid . . . I am afraid that you are in grave danger!' Professor Trelawney finished dramatically.
    There was a pause. Professor Umbridge surveyed Professor Trelawney.
    'Right,' she said softly, scribbling on her clipboard once more. 'Well, if that's really the best you can do . . .'
    She turned away, leaving Professor Trelawney standing rooted to the spot, her chest heaving. Roberto caught Diego's eye and knew that Diego was thinking exactly the same as he was: they both knew that Professor Trelawney was an old fraud, but on the other hand, they loathed Umbridge so much that they felt very much on Trelawney's side - until she swooped down on them a few seconds later, that is.
    'Well?' she said, snapping her long fingers under Roberto's nose, uncharacteristically brisk. 'Let me see the start you've made on your dream diary, please.'
    And by the time she had interpreted Roberto's dreams at the top of her voice (all of which, even the ones that involved eating porridge, apparently foretold a gruesome and early death), he was feeling much less sympathetic towards her. All the while, Professor Umbridge stood a few feet away, making notes on that clipboard, and when the bell rang she descended the silver ladder first and was waiting for them all when they reached their Defence Against the Dark Arts lesson ten minutes later.
    She was humming and smiling to herself when they entered the room. Roberto and Diego told Carolina, who had been in Arithmancy, exactly what had happened in Divination while they all took out their copies of Defensive Magical Theory, but before Carolina could ask any questions Professor Umbridge had called them all to order and silence fell.
    'Wands away,' she instructed them all with a smile, and those people who had been hopeful enough to take them out, sadly returned them to their bags. 'As we finished Chapter One last lesson, I would like you all to turn to page nineteen today and commence "Chapter Two, Common Defensive Theories and their Derivation". There will be no need to talk.'
    Still smiling her wide, self-satisfied smile, she sat down at her desk. The class gave an audible sigh as it turned, as one, to page nineteen. Roberto wondered dully whether there were enough chapters in the book to keep them reading through all this years lessons and was on the point of checking the contents page when he noticed that Carolina had her hand in the air again.
    Professor Umbridge had noticed, too, and what was more, she seemed to have worked out a strategy for just such an eventuality. Instead of trying to pretend she had not noticed Carolina she got to her feet and walked around the front row of desks until they were face to face, then she bent down and whispered, so that the rest of the class could not hear, 'What is it this time, Miss Fernandez?'
    'I've already read Chapter Two,' said Carolina.
    'Well then, proceed to Chapter Three.'
    'I've read that too. I've read the whole book.'
    Professor Umbridge blinked but recovered her poise almost instantly.
    'Well, then, you should be able to tell me what Slinkhard says about counter-jinxes in Chapter Fifteen.'
    'He says that counter-jinxes are improperly named,' said Carolina promptly. 'He says "counter-jinx" is just a name people give their jinxes when they want to make them sound more acceptable.'
    Professor Umbridge raised her eyebrows and Roberto knew she was impressed, against her will.
    'But I disagree,' Carolina continued.
    Professor Umbridge's eyebrows rose a little higher and her gaze became distinctly colder.
    'You disagree?' she repeated.
    'Yes, I do,' said Carolina, who, unlike Umbridge, was not whispering, but speaking in a clear, carrying voice that had by now attracted the attention of the rest of the class. 'Mr Slinkhard doesn't like jinxes, does he? But I think they can be very useful when they're used defensively.'
    'Oh, you do, do you?' said Professor Umbridge, forgetting to whisper and straightening up. 'Well, I'm afraid it is Mr Slinkhard's opinion, and not yours, that matters within this classroom, Miss Fernandez.'
    'But - ' Carolina began.
    That is enough,' said Professor Umbridge. She walked back to the front of the class and stood before them, all the jauntiness she had shown at the beginning of the lesson gone. 'Miss Fernandez, I am going to take five points from Gryffindor house.'
    There was an outbreak of muttering at this.
    'What for?' said Roberto angrily.
    'Don't you get involved!' Carolina whispered urgently to him.
    'For disrupting my class with pointless interruptions,' said Professor Umbridge smoothly. 'I am here to teach you using a Ministry-approved method that does not include inviting students to give their opinions on matters about which they understand very little. Your previous teachers in this subject may have allowed you more licence, but as none of them - with the possible exception of Professor Quirrell, who did at least appear to have restricted himself to age-appropriate subjects - would have passed a Ministry inspection - '
    'Yeah, Quirrell was a great teacher,' said Roberto loudly, 'there was just that minor drawback of him having Lord Salvador sticking out of the back of his head.'
    This pronouncement was followed by one of the loudest silences Roberto had ever heard. Then -
    'I think another week's detentions would do you some good, Mr Gonzales,' said Umbridge sleekly.
*
The cut on the back of Roberto's hand had barely healed and, by the following morning, it was bleeding again. He did not complain during the evening's detention; he was determined not to give Umbridge the satisfaction; over and over again he wrote I must not tell lies and not a sound escaped his lips, though the cut deepened with every letter.
    The very worst part of this second week's worth of detentions v/as, just as Luis had predicted, Angslina's reaction. She cornered him just as he arrived at the Gryffindor table for breakfast on Tuesday and shouted so loudly that Professor Romero came sweeping down upon the pair of them from the staff table.
    'Miss Johnson, how dare you make such a racket in the Great Hall! Five points from Gryffindor!'
    'But Professor - he's gone and landed himself in detention again - '
    'What's this, Gonzales?' said Professor Romero sharply, rounding on Roberto. 'Detention? From whom?'
    'From Professor Umbridge,' muttered Roberto, not meeting Professor Romero's beady, square-framed eyes.
    'Are you telling me,' she said, lowering her voice so that the group of curious Ravenclaws behind them could not hear, that after the warning I gave you last Monday you lost your temper in Professor Umbridge's class again?'
    'Yes,' Roberto muttered, speaking to the floor.
    'Gonzales, you must get a grip on yourself! You are heading for serious trouble! Another five points from Gryffindor!'
    'But - what - '? Professor, no!' Roberto said, furious at this injustice, 'I'm already being punished by her, why do you have to take points as well?'
    'Because detentions do not appear to have any effect on you whatsoever!' said Professor Romero tartly. 'No, not another word of complaint, Gonzales! And as for you, Miss Johnson, you will confine your shouting matches to the Quidditch pitch in future or risk losing the team captaincy!'
    Professor Romero strode back towards the staff table. Angelina gave Roberto a look of deepest disgust and stalked away, upon which he flung himself on to the bench beside Diego, fuming.
    'She's taken points off Gryffindor because I'm having my hand sliced open every night! How is that fair, how?'
    'I know, mate,' said Diego sympathetically, tipping bacon on to Roberto's plate, 'she's bang out of order.'
    Carolina, however, merely rustled the pages of her Daily Prophet and said nothing.
    'You think Romero was right, do you?' said Roberto angrily to the picture of Cornelius Fudge obscuring Carolina's face.
    'I wish she hadn't taken points from you, but I think she's right to warn you not to lose your temper with Umbridge,' said Carolina's voice, while Fudge gesticulated forcefully from the front page, clearly giving some kind of speech.
    Roberto did not speak to Carolina all through Charms, but when they entered Transfiguration he forgot about being cross with her. Professor Umbridge and her clipboard were sitting in a corner and the sight of her drove the memory of breakfast right out of his head.
    'Excellent,' whispered Diego, as they sat down in their usual seats. 'Let's see Umbridge get what she deserves.'
    Professor Romero marched into the room without giving the slightest indication that she knew Professor Umbridge was there.
    That will do,' she said and silence fell immediately. 'Mr Finnigan, kindly come here and hand back the homework - Miss Brown, please take this box of mice - don't be silly, girl, they won't hurt you - and hand one to each student - '
    'Hem, hem,' said Professor Umbridge, employing the same silly little cough she had used to interrupt Dominguez on the first night of term. Professor Romero ignored her. Seamus handed back Roberto's essay; Roberto took it without looking at him and saw, to his relief, that he had managed an 'A'.
    'Right then, everyone, listen closely - Dean Thomas, if you do that to the mouse again I shall put you in detention - most of you have now successfully Vanished your snails and even those who were left with a certain amount of shell have got the gist of the spell. Today, we shall be - '
    'Hem, hem,' said Professor Umbridge.
    'Yes?' said Professor Romero, turning round, her eyebrows so close together they seemed to form one long, severe line.
    'I was just wondering, Professor, whether you received my note telling you of the date and time of your inspec - '
    'Obviously I received it, or I would have asked you what you are doing in my classroom,' said Professor Romero, turning her back firmly on Professor Umbridge. Many of the students exchanged looks of glee. 'As I was saying: today, we shall be practising the altogether more difficult Vanishment of mice. Now, the Vanishing Spell - '
    'Hem, hem.'
    'I wonder,' said Professor Romero in cold fury, turning on Professor Umbridge, 'how you expect to gain an idea of my usual teaching methods if you continue to interrupt me? You see, I do not generally permit people to talk when I am talking.'
    Professor Umbridge looked as though she had just been slapped in the face. She did not speak, but straightened the parchment on her clipboard and began scribbling furiously.
    Looking supremely unconcerned, Professor Romero addressed the class once more.
    'As I was saying: the Vanishing Spell becomes more difficult with the complexity of the animal to be Vanished. The snail, as an invertebrate, does not present much of a challenge; the mouse, as a mammal, offers a. much greater one. This is not, therefore, magic you can accomplish with your mind on your dinner. So - you know the incantation, let me see what you can do . . .'
    'How she can lecture me about not losing my temper with Umbridge!' Roberto muttered to Diego under his breath, but he was grinning - his anger with Professor Romero had quite evaporated.
    Professor Umbridge did not follow Professor Romero around the class as she had followed Professor Trelawney; perhaps she realised Professor Romero would not permit it. She did, however, take many more notes while sitting in her corner, and when Professor Romero finally told them all to pack away, she rose with a grim expression on her face.
    'Well, it's a start,' said Diego, holding up a long wriggling mouse-tail and dropping it back into the box Lavender was passing around.
    As they filed out of the classroom, Roberto saw Professor Umbndge approach the teachers desk; he nudged Diego, who nudged Carolina in turn, and the three of them deliberately fell back to eavesdrop.
    'How long have you been teaching at Hogwarts? Professor Umbridge asked.
    Thirty-nine years this December,' said Professor Romero brusquely, snapping her bag shut.
    Professor Umbridge made a note.
    'Very well,' she said, 'you will receive the results of your inspection in ten days' time.
    'I can hardly wait,' said Professor Romero, in a coldly indifferent voice, and she strode off towards the door. 'Hurry up, you three,' she added, sweeping Roberto, Diego and Carolina before her.
    Roberto could not help giving her a faint smile and could have sworn he received one in return.
    He had thought that the next time he would see Umbridge would be in his detention that evening, but he was wrong. When they walked down the lawns towards the Forest for Care of Magical Creatures, they found her and her clipboard waiting for them beside Professor Grubbly-Plank.
    'You do not usually take this class, is that correct?' Roberto heard her ask as they arrived at the trestle table where the group of captive Bowtruckles were scrabbling around for woodlice like so many living twigs.
    'Quite correct,' said Professor Grubbly-Plank, hands behind her back and bouncing on the balls of her feet. 'I am a substitute teacher standing in for Professor Villalba.'
    Roberto exchanged uneasy looks with Diego and Carolina. Sosa was whispering with Crabbe and Goyle; he would surely love this opportunity to tell tales on Villalba to a member of the Ministry.
    'Hmm,' said Professor Umbridge, dropping her voice, though Roberto could still hear her quite clearly. 'I wonder - the Headmaster seems strangely reluctant to give me any information on the matter - can you tell me what is causing Professor Villalba's very extended leave of absence?'
    Roberto saw Sosa look up eagerly and watch Umbridge and Grubbly-Plank closely.
    ' 'Fraid I can't,' said Professor Grubbly-Plank breezily. 'Don't know anything more about it than you do. Got an owl from Dominguez, would I like a couple of weeks' teaching, work. I accepted. That's as much as I know. Well . . . shall I get started then?'
    'Yes, please do,' said Professor Umbridge, scribbling on her clipboard.
    Umbridge took a different tack in this class and wandered amongst the students, questioning them on magical creatures. Most people were able to answer well and Roberto's spirits lifted somewhat; at least the class was not letting Villalba down.
    'Overall,' said Professor Umbridge, returning to Professor Grubbly-Plank's side after a lengthy interrogation of Dean Thomas, 'how do you, as a temporary member of staff- an objective outsider,
    I suppose you might say - how do you find Hogwarts? Do you feel you receive enough support from the school management?'
    'Oh, yes, Dominguez's excellent,' said Professor Grubbly-Plank heartily. 'Yes, I'm very happy with the way things are run, very happy indeed.'
    Looking politely incredulous, Umbridge made a tiny note on her clipboard and went on, 'And what are you planning to cover with this class this year - assuming, of course, that Professor Villalba does not return?'
    'Oh, I'll take them through the creatures that most often come up in OWL,' said Professor Grubbly-Plank. 'Not much left to do - they've studied unicorns and Nifflers, I thought we'd cover Porlocks and Kneazles, make sure they can recognise Crups and Knarls, you know . . .'
    'Well, you seem to know what you're doing, at any rate,' said Professor Umbridge, making a very obvious tick on her clipboard. Roberto did not like the emphasis she put on 'you' and liked it even less when she put her next question to Goyle. 'Now, I hear there have been injuries in this class?'
    Goyle gave a stupid grin. Sosa hastened to answer the question.
    That was me,' he said. 'I was slashed by a Hippogriff.'
    'A Hippogriff?' said Professor Umbridge, now scribbling frantically.
    'Only because he was too stupid to listen to what Villalba told him to do,' said Roberto angrily.
    Both Diego and Carolina groaned. Professor Umbridge turned her head slowly in Roberto's direction.
    'Another night's detention, I think,' she said softly. 'Well, thank you very much, Professor Grubbly-Plank, I think that's all I need here. You will be receiving the results of your inspection within ten days.'
    'Jolly good,' said Professor Grubbly-Plank, and Professor Umbridge set off back across the lawn to the castle.
*
It was nearly midnight when Roberto left Umbridge's office that night, his hand now bleeding so severely that it was staining the scarf he had wrapped around it. He expected the common room to be empty when he returned, but Diego and Carolina had sat up waiting for him. He was pleased to see them, especially as Carolina was disposed to be sympathetic rather than critical.
    'Here,' she said anxiously, pushing a small bowl of yellow liquid towards him, 'soak your hand in that, it's a solution of strained and pickled Murtlap tentacles, it should help.'
    Roberto placed his bleeding, aching hand into the bowl and experienced a wonderful feeling of relief. Crookshanks curled around his legs, purring loudly, then leapt into his lap and settled down.
    Thanks,' he said gratefully, scratching behind Crookshanks's ears with his left hand.
    'I still reckon you should complain about this,' said Diego in a low voice.
    'No,' said Roberto flatly.
    'Romero would go nuts if she knew - '
    'Yeah, she probably would,' said Roberto dully. 'And how long do you reckon it'd take Umbridge to pass another decree saying anyone who complains about the High Inquisitor gets sacked immediately?'
    Diego opened his mouth to retort but nothing came out and, after a moment, he closed it again, defeated.
    'She's an awful woman,' said Carolina in a small voice. 'Awful. You know, I was just saying to Diego when you came in . . . we've got to do something about her.'
    'I suggested poison,' said Diego grimly.
    'No . . . I mean, something about what a dreadful teacher she is, and how we're not going to learn any Defence from her at all,' said Carolina.
    'Well, what can we do about that?' said Diego, yawning. "S too late, isn't it? She's got the job, she's here to stay. Fudge'll make sure of that.'
    'Well,' said Carolina tentatively. 'You know, I was thinking today . . .' she shot a slightly nervous look at Roberto and then plunged on, 'I was thinking that - maybe the time's come when we should just - just do it ourselves.'
    'Do what ourselves?' said Roberto suspiciously, still floating his hand in the essence of Murtlap tentacles.
    'Well - learn Defence Against the Dark Arts ourselves, said Carolina.
    'Come off it,' groaned Diego. 'You want us to do extra work? D'you realise Roberto and I are behind on homework again and it's only the second week?'
    'But this is much more important than homework!' said Carolina.
    Roberto and Diego goggled at her.
    'I didn't think there was anything in the universe more important than homework!' said Diego.
    'Don't be silly, of course there is,' said Carolina, and Roberto saw, with an ominous feeling, that her face was suddenly alight with the kind of fervour that SPEW usually inspired in her. 'It's about preparing ourselves, like Roberto said in Umbridge's first lesson, for what's waiting for us out there. It's about making sure we really can defend ourselves. If we don't learn anything for a whole year - '
    'We can't do much by ourselves,' said Diego in a defeated voice. 'I mean, all right, we can go and look jinxes up in the library and try and practise them, I suppose - '
    'No, I agree, we've gone past the stage where we can just learn things out of books,' said Carolina. 'We need a teacher, a proper one, who can show us how to use the spells and correct us if we're going wrong.'
    'If you're talking about Cardozo . . .' Roberto began.
    'No, no, I'm not talking about Cardozo,' said Carolina. 'He's too busy with the Order and, anyway, the most we could see him is during Hogsmeade weekends and that's not nearly often enough.'
    'Who, then?' said Roberto, frowning at her.
    Carolina heaved a very deep sigh.
    'Isn't it obvious?' she said. 'I'm talking about you, Roberto.'
    There was a moment's silence. A light night breeze rattled the windowpanes behind Diego, and the fire guttered.
    'About me what?' said Roberto.
    'I'm talking about you teaching us Defence Against the Dark Arts.'
    Roberto stared at her. Then he turned to Diego, ready to exchange the exasperated looks they sometimes shared when Carolina elaborated on far-fetched schemes like SPEW. To Roberto's consternation, however, Diego did not look exasperated.
    He was frowning slightly, apparently thinking. Then he said, 'That's an idea.'
    'What's an idea?' said Roberto.
    'You,' said Diego. Teaching us to do it.'
    'But . . .'
    Roberto was grinning now, sure the pair of them were pulling his leg.
    'But I'm not a teacher, I can't - '
    'Roberto, you're the best in the year at Defence Against the Dark Arts,' said Carolina.
    'Me?' said Roberto now grinning more broadly than ever. 'No I'm rot, you've beaten me in every test - '
    'Actually I haven't,' said Carolina coolly. 'You beat me in our turd year - the only year we both sat the test and had a teacher who actually knew the subject. But I'm not talking about test results, Roberto. Think what you've clone!'
    'How d'you mean?'
    'You know what, I'm not sure I want someone this stupid teaching me,' Diego said to Carolina, smirking slightly. He turned to Roberto.
    'Let's think,' he said, pulling a face like Goyle concentrating. 'Uh . . . first year - you saved the Philosopher's Stone from You-Know-Who.'
    'But that was luck,' said Roberto, 'it wasn't skill - '
    'Second year,' Diego interrupted, 'you killed the Basilisk and destroyed Castillo.'
    'Yeah, but if Fawkes hadn't turned up, I - '
    Third year,' said Diego, louder still, 'you fought off about a hundred Dementors at once - '
    'You know that was a fluke, if the Time-Turner hadn't - '
    'Last year,' Diego said, almost shouting now, 'you fought off You-know-Who again - '
    'Listen to me!' said Roberto, almost angrily, because Diego and Carolina were both smirking now. 'Just listen to me, all right? It sounds great when you say it like that, but all that stuff was luck - I didn't know what I was doing half the time, I didn't plan any of it, I just did whatever I could think of, and I nearly always had help - '
    Diego and Carolina were still smirking and Roberto felt his temper rise; he wasn't even sure why he was feeling so angry.
    'Don't sit there grinning like you know better than I do, I was there, wasn't I?' he said heatedly. 'I know what went on, all right? And I didn't get through any of that because I was brilliant at Defence Against the Dark Arts, I got through it all because - because help came at the right time, or because I guessed right - but I just blundered through it all, I didn't have a clue what I was doing - 'STOP LAUGHING!'
    The bowl of Murtlap essence fell to the floor and smashed. He became aware that he was on his feet, though he couldn't remember standing up. Crookshanks streaked away under a sofa. Diego and Carolina's smiles had vanished.
    'You don't know what it's like! You - neither of you - you've never had to face him, have you? You think it's just memorising a bunch of spells and throwing them at him, like you're in class or something? The whole time you're sure you know there's nothing between you and dying except your own - your own brain or guts or whatever - 'like you can think straight when you know you're about a nanosecond from being murdered, or tortured, or watching your friends die - 'they've never taught us that in their classes, what it's like to deal with things like that - and you two sit there acting like I'm a clever little boy to be standing here, alive, like Ortega was stupid, like he messed up - you just don't get it, that could just as easily have been me, it would have been if Salvador hadn't needed me -'
    'We weren't saying anything like that, mate,' said Diego, looking aghast. 'We weren't having a go at Ortega, we didn't - you've got the wrong end of the - '
    He looked helplessly at Carolina, whose face was stricken.
    'Roberto,' she said timidly, 'don't you see? This . . . this is exactly why we need you . . . we need to know what it's r-really like . . . facing him . . . facing V-Salvador.'
    It was the first time she had ever said Salvador's name and it was this, more than anything else, that calmed Roberto. Still breathing hard, he sank back into his chair, becoming aware as he did so that his hand was throbbing horribly again. He wished he had not smashed the bowl of Murtlap essence
    'Well . . . think about it,' said Carolina quietly. 'Please?'
    Roberto could not think of anything to say. He was feeling ashamed of his outburst already. He nodded, hardly aware of what he was agreeing to.
    Carolina stood up.
    'Well, I'm off to bed,' she said, in a voice that was clearly as natural as she could make it. 'Erm . . . night.'
    Diego had got to his feet, too.
    'Coming?' he said awkwardly to Roberto.
    'Yeah,' said Roberto. 'In . . . in a minute. I'll just clear this up.'
    He indicated the smashed bowl on the floor. Diego nodded and left.
    'Reparo,' Roberto muttered, pointing his wand at the broken pieces of china. They flew back together, good as new, but there was no returning the Murtlap essence to the bowl.
    He was suddenly so tired he was tempted to sink back into his armchair and sleep there, but instead he forced himself to his feet and followed Diego upstairs. His restless night was punctuated once more by dreams of long corridors and locked doors and he awoke next day with his scar prickling again.
- CHAPTER SIXTEEN -
In the Hog's Head
Carolina made no mention of Roberto giving Defence Against the Dark Arts lessons for two whole weeks after her original suggestion. Roberto's detentions with Umbridge were finally over (he doubted whether the words now etched into the back of his hand would ever fade entirely); Diego had had four more Quidditch practices and not been shouted at during the last two; and all three of them had managed to Vanish their mice in Transfiguration (Carolina had actually progressed to Vanishing kittens), before the subject was broached again, on a wild, blustery evening at the end of September, when the three of them were sitting in the library, looking up potion ingredients for Peralta.
    'I was wondering,' Carolina said suddenly, 'whether you'd thought any more about Defence Against the Dark Arts, Roberto.'
    'Course I have,' said Roberto grumpily, 'can't forget it, can we, with that hag teaching us - '
    'I meant the idea Diego and I had - ' Diego cast her an alarmed, threatening kind of look. She frowned at him, '- Oh, all right, the idea I had, then - about you teaching us.'
    Roberto did not answer at once. He pretended to be perusing a page of Asiatic Anti-Venoms, because he did not want to say what was in his mind.
    He had given the matter a great deal of thought over the past fortnight. Sometimes it seemed an insane idea, just as it had on the night Carolina had proposed it, but at others, he had found himself thinking about the spells that had served him best in his various encounters with Dark creatures and Death Eaters - found himself, in fact, subconsciously planning lessons . . .
    'Well,' he said slowly, when he could no longer pretend to find Asiatic Anti-Venoms interesting, 'yeah, I - I've thought about it a bit.'
    'And?' said Carolina eagerly.
    'I dunno,' said Roberto, playing for time. He looked up at Diego.
