    'I thought it was a good idea from the start,' said Diego, who seemed keener to join in this conversation now that he was sure Roberto was not going to start shouting again.
    Roberto shifted uncomfortably in his chair.
    'You did listen to what I said about a load of it being luck, didn't you?'
    'Yes, Roberto,' said Carolina gently, 'but all the same, there's no point pretending that you're not good at Defence Against the Dark Arts, because you are. You were the only person last year who could throw off the Imperius Curse completely, you can produce a Patronus, you can do all sorts of stuff that full-grown wizards can't, Viktor always said - '
    Diego looked round at her so fast he appeared to crick his neck. Rubbing it, he said, 'Yeah? What did Vicky say?'
    'Ho ho,' said Carolina in a bored voice. 'He said Roberto knew how to do stuff even he didn't, and he was in the final year at Durmstrang.'
    Diego was looking at Carolina suspiciously.
    'You're not still in contact with him, are you?'
    'So what if I am.?' said Carolina coolly, though her face was a little pink. 'I can have a pen-pal if I - '
    'He didn't only want to be your pen-pal,' said Diego accusingly.
    Carolina shook her head exasperatedly and, ignoring Diego, who was continuing to watch her, said to Roberto, 'Well, what do you think? Will you teach us?'
    'Just you and Diego, yeah?'
    'Well,' said Carolina, looking a mite anxious again. 'Well . . . now, don't fly off the handle again, Roberto, please . . . but I really think you ought to teach anyone who wants to learn. I mean, we're talking about defending ourselves against V-Salvador. Oh, don't be pathetic, Diego. It doesn't seem fair if we don't offer the chance to other people.'
    Roberto considered this for a moment, then said, 'Yeah, but I doubt anyone except you two would want to be taught by me. I'm a nutter, remember?'
    'Well, I think you might be surprised how many people would be interested in hearing what you've got to say,' said Carolina seriously. 'Look,' she leaned towards him - Diego, who was still watching her with a frown on his face, leaned forwards to listen too - 'you know the first weekend in October's a Hogsmeade weekend? How would it be if we tell anyone who's interested to meet us in the village and we can talk it over?'
    'Why do we have to do it outside school?' said Diego.
    'Because,' said Carolina, returning to the diagram of the Chinese Paulamping Cabbage she was copying, 'I don't think Umbridge would be very happy if she found out what we were up to.'
*
Roberto had been looking forward to the weekend trip into Hogsmeade, but there was one thing worrying him. Gustavo had maintained a stony silence since he had appeared in the fire at the beginning of September; Roberto knew they had made him angry by saying they didn't want him to come - but he still worried from time to time that Gustavo might throw caution to the winds and turn up anyway. What were they going to do if the great black dog came bounding up the street towards them in Hogsmeade, perhaps under the nose of Javier Sosa?
    'Well, you can't blame him for wanting to get out and about,' said Diego, when Roberto discussed his fears with him and Carolina. 'I mean, he's been on the run for over two years, hasn't he, and I know that can't have been a laugh, but at least he was free, wasn't he? And now he's just shut up all the time with that ghastly elf.'
    Carolina scowled at Diego, but otherwise ignored the slight on Kreacher.
    The trouble is,' she said to Roberto, 'until V-Salvador - oh, for heaven's sake, Diego - comes out into the open, Gustavo is going to have to stay hidden, isn't he? I mean, the stupid Ministry isn't going to realise Gustavo is innocent until they accept that Dominguez's been telling the truth about him all along. And once the fools start catching real Death Eaters again, it'll be obvious Gustavo isn't one . . . I mean, he hasn't got the Mark, for one thing.'
    'I don't reckon he'd be stupid enough to turn up,' said Diego bracingly. 'Dominguez'd go mad if he did and Gustavo listens to Dominguez even if he doesn't like what he hears.'
    When Roberto continued to look worried, Carolina said, 'Listen, Diego and I have been sounding out people who we thought might want to learn some proper Defence Against the Dark Arts, and there are a couple who seem interested. We've told them to meet us in Hogsmeade.'
    'Right,' said Roberto vaguely, his mind still on Gustavo.
    'Don't worry, Roberto,' Carolina said quietly. 'You've got enough on your plate without Gustavo, too.'
    She was quite right, of course, he was barely keeping up with his homework, though he was doing much better now that he was no longer spending every evening in detention with Umbridge. Diego was even further behind with his work than Roberto, because while they both had Quidditch practice twice a week, Diego also had his prefect duties. However, Carolina, who was taking more subjects than either of them, had not only finished all her homework but was also finding time to knit more elf clothes. Roberto had to admit that she was getting better; it was now almost always possible to distinguish between the hats and the socks.
    The morning of the Hogsmeade visit dawned bright but windy. Alter breakfast they queued up in front of Filch, who matched their names to the long list of students who had permission from their parents or guardian to visit the village. With a slight pang, Roberto remembered that if it hadn't been for Gustavo, he would not have been going at all.
    When Roberto reached Filch, the caretaker gave a great sniff as though trying to detect a whiff of something from Roberto. Then he gave a curt nod that set his jowls aquiver again and Roberto walked on, out on to the stone steps and the cold, sunlit day.
    'Er - why was Filch sniffing you?' asked Diego, as he, Roberto and Carolina set off at: a brisk pace down the wide drive to the gates.
    'I suppose he was checking for the smell of Dungbombs,' said Roberto with a small laugh. T forgot to tell you . . .'
    And he recounted the story of sending his letter to Gustavo and Filch bursting in seconds later, demanding to see the letter. To his slight surprise, Carolina found this story highly interesting, much more, indeed, than he did himself.
    'He said he was tipped off you were ordering Dungbombs? But who tipped him off?'
    'I dunno,' said Roberto, shrugging. 'Maybe Sosa he'd think it was a laugh.'
    They walked between the tall stone pillars topped with winged boars and turned left on to the road into the village, the wind whip-, ping their hair into their eyes.
    'Sosa?' said Carolina, sceptically. 'Well . . . yes . . . maybe . . .'
    And she remained deep in thought all the way into the outskirts of Hogsmeade.
    'Where are we going, anyway?' Roberto asked. The Three Broomsticks?'
    'Oh - no,' said Carolina, coming out of her reverie, 'no, it's always packed and really noisy. I've told the others to meet us in the Hog's Head, that other pub, you know the one, it's not on the main road. I think it's a bit . . . you know . . . dodgy . . . but students don't normally go in there, so I don't think we'll be overheard.'
    They walked down the main street past Zonko's Wizarding Joke Shop, where they were not surprised to see Pablo, Luis and Lee Jordan, past the post office, from which owls issued at regular intervals, and turned up a side-street at the top of which stood a small inn. A battered wooden sign hung from a rusty bracket over the door, with a picture on it of a wild boar's severed head, leaking blood on to the white cloth around it. The sign creaked in the wind as they approached. All three of them hesitated outside the door.
    'Well, come on,' said Carolina, slightly nervously. Roberto led the way inside.
    It was not at all like the Three Broomsticks, whose large bar gave an impression of gleaming warmth and cleanliness. The Hog's Head bar comprised one small, dingy and very dirty room that smelled strongly of something that might have been goats. The bay windows were so encrusted with grime that very little daylight could permeate the room, which was lit instead with the stubs of candles sitting on rough wooden tables. The floor seemed at first glance to be compressed earth, though as Roberto stepped on to it he realised that there was stone beneath what seemed to be the accumulated filth of centuries.
    Roberto remembered Villalba mentioning this pub in his first year: 'Yeh get a lot o' funny folk in the Hog's Head,' he had said, explaining how he had won a dragon's egg from a hooded stranger there. At the time Roberto had wondered why Villalba had not found it odd that the stranger kept his face hidden throughout their encounter; now he saw that keeping your face hidden was something of a fashion in the Hog's Head. There was a man at the bar whose whole head was wrapped in dirty grey bandages, though he was still managing to gulp endless glasses of some smoking, fiery substance through a slit over his mouth; two figures shrouded in hoods sat at a table in one of the windows; Roberto might have thought them Dementors if they had not been talking in strong Yorkshire accents, and in a shadowy corner beside the fireplace sat a witch with a thick, black veil that fell to her toes. They could just see the tip of her nose because it caused the veil to protrude slightly.
    'I don't know about this, Carolina,' Roberto muttered, as they crossed to the bar. He was looking particularly at the heavily veiled witch. 'Has it occurred to you Umbridge might be under that?'
    Carolina cast an appraising eye over the veiled figure.
    'Umbridge is shorter than that woman,' she said quietly. 'And anyway, even if Umbridge does come in here there's nothing she can do to stop us, Roberto, because I've double- and triple-checked the school rules. We're not out of bounds; I specifically asked Professor Flitwick whether students were allowed to come in the Hog's Head, and he said yes, but he advised me strongly to bring our own glasses. And I've looked up everything I can think of about study groups and homework groups and they're definitely allowed. I just don't think it's a good idea if we parade what we're doing.'
    'No,' said Roberto drily, 'especially as it's not exactly a homework group you're planning, is it?'
    The barman sidled towards them out of a back room. He was a grumpy-looking old man with a great deal of long grey hair and beard. He was tall and thin and looked vaguely familiar to Roberto.
    What? he grunted.
    'Three Butterbeers, please,' said Carolina.
    The man reached beneath the counter and pulled up three very dusty, very dirty bottles, which he slammed on the bar.
    'Six Sickles,' he said.
    'I'll get them,' said Roberto quickly, passing over the silver. The barman's eyes travelled over Roberto, resting for a fraction of a second on his scar. Then he turned away and deposited Roberto's money in an ancient wooden till whose drawer slid open automatically to receive it. Roberto, Diego and Carolina retreated to the furthest table from the bar and sat down, looking around. The man in the dirty grey bandages rapped the counter with his knuckles and received another smoking drink from the barman.
    'You know what?' Diego murmured, looking over at the bar with enthusiasm. 'We could order anything we liked in here. I bet that bloke would sell us anything, he wouldn't care. I've always wanted to try Firewhisky - '
    'You - are - a - prefect,' snarled Carolina.
    'Oh,' said Diego, the smile fading from his face. 'Yeah . . .'
    'So, who did you say is supposed to be meeting us?' Roberto asked, wrenching open the rusty top of his Butterbeer and taking a swig.
    'Just a couple of people,' Carolina repeated, checking her watch and looking anxiously towards the door. 'I told them to be here about now and I'm sure they all know where it is - oh, look, this might be them now.'
    The door of the pub had opened. A thick band of dusty sunlight split the room in two for a moment and then vanished, blocked by the incoming rush of a crowd of people.
    First came Mauricio with Dean and Lavender, who were closely followed by Parvati and Padma Patil with (Roberto's stomach did a back-flip) Paula and one of her usually-giggling girlfriends, then (on her own and looking so dreamy she might have walked in by accident) Gabriela Ortiz; then Katie Bell, Alicia Spinnet and Angelina Johnson, Colin and Dennis Creevey Ernie Macmillan, Justin Finch-Fletchley, Hannah Abbott, a Hufflepuff girl with a long plait clown her back whose name Roberto did not know; three Ravenclaw boys he was pretty sure were called Anthony Goldstein, Michael Corner and Terry Boot, Martina, closely followed by a tall skinny blond boy with an upturned nose whom Roberto recognised vaguely as being a member of the Hufflepuff Quidditch team and, bringing up the rear, Pablo and Luis Lopez with their friend Lee Jordan, all three of whom were carrying large paper bags crammed with Zonko's merchandise.
    'A couple of people?' said Roberto hoarsely to Carolina. 'A couple of people?'
    'Yes, well, the idea seemed quite popular,' said Carolina happily. 'Diego, do you want to pull up some more chairs?'
    The barman had frozen in the act of wiping out a glass with a rag so filthy it looked as though it had never been washed. Possibly, he had never seen his pub so full.
    'Hi,' said Pablo, reaching the bar first and counting his companions quickly, 'could we have . . . twenty-five Butterbeers, please?'
    The barman glared at him for a moment, then, throwing down his rag irritably as though he had been interrupted in something very important, he started passing up dusty Butterbeers from under the bar.
    'Cheers,' said Pablo, handing them out. 'Cough up, everyone, I haven't got enough gold for all of these . . .'
    Roberto watched numbly as the large chattering group took their beers from Pablo and rummaged in their robes to find coins. He could not imagine what all these people had turned up for until the horrible thought occurred to him that they might be expecting same kind of speech, at which he rounded on Carolina.
    'What have you been telling people?' he said in a low voice. 'What are they expecting?'
    'I've told you, they just want to hear what you've got to say,' said Carolina soothingly; but Roberto continued to look at her so furiously that she added quickly, 'you don't have to do anything yet, I'll speak to them first.'
    'Hi, Roberto' said Mauricio, beaming and taking a seat opposite him.
    Roberto tried to smile back, but did not speak; his mouth was exceptionally dry. Paula had just smiled at him and sat down on Diego's right. Her friend, who had curly reddish-blonde hair, did not smile, but gave Roberto a thoroughly mistrustful look which plainly told him that, given her way, she would not be here at all.
    In twos and threes the new arrivals settled around Roberto, Diego and Carolina, some looking rather excited, others curious, Gabriela Ortiz gazing dreamily into space. When everybody had pulled up a chair, the chatter died out. Every eye was upon Roberto.
    'Er,' said Carolina, her voice slightly higher than usual out of nerves. 'Well - er - hi.'
    The group focused its attention on her instead, though eyes continued to dart back regularly to Roberto.
    'Well . . . erm . . . well, you know why you're here. Erm . . . well, Roberto here had the idea - I mean' (Roberto had thrown her a sharp look) 'I had the idea - that it might be good if people who wanted to study Defence Against the Dark Arts - and I mean, really study it, you know, not the rubbish that Umbridge is doing with us - '(Carolina's voice became suddenly much stronger and more confident) ' - because nobody could call that Defence Against the Dark Arts - ' ('Hear, hear,' said Anthony Goldstein, and Carolina looked heartened) ' - Well, I thought it would be good if we, well, took matters into our own hands.'
    She paused, looked sideways at Roberto and went on, 'And by that I mean learning how to defend ourselves properly, not just in theory but doing the real spells - '
    'You want to pass your Defence Against the Dark Arts OWL too, though, I bet?' said Michael Corner, who was watching her closely.
    'Of course I do,' said Carolina at once. 'But more than that, I want to be properly trained in defence because . . . because . . .' she took a great breath and finished, 'because Lord Salvador is back.'
    The reaction was immediate and predictable. Clio's friend shrieked and slopped Butterbeer down herself; Terry Boot gave a kind of involuntary twitch; Padma Patil shuddered, and Mauricio gave an odd yelp that he managed to turn into a cough. All of them, however, looked fixedly, even eagerly, at Roberto.
    Well . . . that's the plan, anyway,' said Carolina. 'If you want to join us, we need to decide how we're going to -
    'Where's the proof You-Know-Who's back?' said the blond Hufflepuff player in a rather aggressive voice.
    'Well, Dominguez believes it - ' Carolina began.
    'You mean, Dominguez believes him,' said the blond boy, nodding at Roberto.
    'Who are you?' said Diego, rather rudely.
    'Zacharias Smith,' said the boy, 'and I think we've got the right to know exactly what makes him say You-Know-Who's back.'
    'Look,' said Carolina, intervening swiftly, 'that's really not what this meeting was supposed to be about - '
    'It's OK, Carolina,' said Roberto.
    It had just dawned on him why there were so many people there. He thought Carolina should have seen this coming. Some of these people - maybe even most of them - had turned up in the hopes of hearing Roberto's story firsthand.
    'What makes me say You-Know-Who's back?' he repeated, looking Zacharias straight in the face. 'I saw him. But Dominguez told the whole school what happened last year, and if you didn't believe him, you won't believe me, and I'm not wasting an afternoon trying to convince anyone.'
    The whole group seemed to have held its breath while Roberto spoke. Roberto had the impression that even the barman was listening. He was wiping the same glass with the filthy rag, making it steadily dirtier.
    Zacharias said dismissively, 'All Dominguez told us last year was that Nicolas Ortega got killed by You-Know-Who and that you brought Ortega's body back to Hogwarts. He didn't give us details, he didn't tell us exactly how Ortega got murdered, I think we'd all like to know - '
    'If you've come to hear exactly what it looks like when Salvador murders someone I can't help you,' Roberto said. His temper, always so close to the surface these days, was rising again. He did not take his eyes from Zacharias Smith's aggressive face, and was determined not to look at Paula. 'I don't want to talk about Nicolas Ortega, all right? So if that's what you're here for, you might as well clear out.'
    He cast an angry look in Carolina's direction. This was, he felt, all her fault; she had decided to display him like some sort of freak and of course they had all turned up to see just now wild his story was. But none of them left their seats, not even Zacharias Smith, though he continued to gaze intently at Roberto.
    'So,' said Carolina, her voice very high-pitched again. 'So . . . like I was saying . . . if you want to learn some defence, then we need to work out how we're going to do it, how often we're going to meet and where we're going to - '
    'Is it true,' interrupted the girl with the long plait down her back, looking at Roberto, 'that you can produce a Patronus?'
    There was a murmur of interest around the group at this.
    'Yeah,' said Roberto slightly defensively.
    'A corporeal Patronus?'
    The phrase stirred something in Roberto's memory.
    'Er - you don't know Madam Bones, do you?' he asked.
    The girl smiled.
    'She's my auntie,' she said. 'I'm Susan Bones. She told me about your hearing. So - is it really true? You make a stag Patronus?'
    'Yes,' said Roberto.
    'Blimey, Roberto!' said Lee, looking deeply impressed. 'I never knew that!'
    'Mum told Diego not to spread it around,' said Pablo, grinning at Roberto. 'She said you got enough attention as it was.'
    'She's not wrong,' mumbled Roberto, and a couple of people laughed.
    The veiled witch sitting alone shifted very slightly in her seat.
    'And did you kill a Basilisk with that sword in Dominguez's office?' demanded Terry Boot. That's what one of the portraits on the wall told me when I was in there last year . . .'
    'Er - yeah, I did, yeah,' said Roberto.
    Justin Finch-Fletchley whistled; the Creevey brothers exchanged awestruck looks and Lavender Brown said 'Wow!' softly. Roberto was feeling slightly hot around the collar now; he was determinedly looking anywhere but at Paula.
    'And in our first year,' said Mauricio to the group at large, 'he saved that Philological Stone - '
    'Philosopher's,' hissed Carolina.
    'Yes, that - from You-Know-Who,' finished Mauricio.
    Hannah Abbotts eyes were as round as Galleons.
    'And that's not to mention,' said Paula (Roberto's eyes snapped across to her; she was looking at him, smiling; his stomach did another somersault) 'all the tasks he had to get through in the Triwizard Tournament last year - getting past dragons and merpeople and Acromantula and things . . .'
    There was a murmur of impressed agreement around the table. Roberto's insides were squirming. He was trying to arrange his face so that he did not look too pleased with himself. The fact that Paula had just praised him made it much, much harder for him to say the thing he had sworn to himself he would tell them.
    'Look,' he said, and everyone fell silent at once, 'I . . . I don't want to sound like I'm trying to be modest or anything, but . . . I had a lot of help with all that stuff . . .'
    'Not with the dragon, you didn't,' said Michael Corner at once. 'That was a seriously cool bit of flying . . .'
    'Yeah, well - ' said Roberto, feeling it would be churlish to disagree.
    'And nobody helped you get rid of those Dementors this summer,' said Susan Bones.
    'No,' said Roberto, 'no, OK, I know I did bits of it without help, but the point I'm trying to make is - '
    'Are you trying to weasel out of showing us any of this stuff?' said Zacharias Smith.
    'Here's an idea,' said Diego loudly, before Roberto could speak, 'why don't you shut your mouth?'
    Perhaps the word 'weasel' had affected Diego particularly strongly. In any case, he was now looking at Zacharias as though he would like nothing better than to thump him. Zacharias flushed.
    'Well, we've all turned up to learn from him and now he's telling us he can't really do any of it,' he said.
    That's not what he said,' snarled Pablo.
    'Would you like us to clean out you: ears for you?' enquired Greorge, pulling a long and lethal-looking metal instrument from inside one of the Zonko's bags.
    'Or any part of your body, really, we're not fussy where we stick this,' said Pablo.
    'Yes, well, said Carolina hastily, moving on . . . the point is, are we agreed we want to take lessons from Roberto?'
    There was a murmur of general agreement. Zacharias folded his arms and said nothing, though perhaps this was because he was too busy keeping an eye on the instrument in Pablo's hand.
    'Right,' said Carolina, looking relieved that something had at last been settled. 'Well, then, the next question is how often we do it. I really don't think there's any point in meeting less than once a week - '
    'Hang on,' said Angelina, 'we need to make sure this doesn't clash with our Quidditch practice.'
    'No,' said Paula, 'nor with ours.'
    'Nor ours,' added Zacharias Smith.
    'I'm sure we can find a night that suits everyone,' said Carolina, slightly impatiently, 'but you know, this is rather important, we're talking about learning to defend ourselves against V-Salvador's Death Eaters - '
    'Well said!' barked Ernie Macmillan, who Roberto had been expecting to speak long before this. 'Personally, I think this is really important, possibly more important than anything else we'll do this year, even with our OWLs coming up!'
    He looked around impressively, as though waiting for people to cry 'Surely not!' When nobody spoke, he went on, 'I, personally, am at a loss to see why the Ministry has foisted such a useless teacher on us at this critical period. Obviously, they are in denial about the return of You-Know-Who, but to give us a teacher who is trying to actively prevent us from using defensive spells - '
    'We think the reason Umbridge doesn't want us trained in Defence Against the Dark Arts,' said Carolina, 'is that she's got some . . . some mad idea that Dominguez could use the students in the school as a kind of private army. She thinks he'd mobilise us against the Ministry'
    Nearly everybody looked stunned at this news; everybody except Gabriela Ortiz, who piped up, 'Well, that makes sense. After all, Cornelius Fudge has got his own private army'
    'What?' said Roberto, completely thrown by this unexpected piece of information.
    'Yes, he's got an army of Heliopaths,' said Gabriela solemnly.
    'No, he hasn't,' snapped Carolina.
    'Yes, he has,' said Gabriela.
    'What are Heliopaths?' asked Mauricio, looking blank.
    They're spirits of fire,' said Gabriela, her protuberant eyes widening so that she looked madder than ever, 'great tall flaming creatures that gallop across the ground burning everything in front of - '
    They don't exist, Mauricio,' said Carolina tartly.
    'Oh, yes, they do!' said Gabriela angrily.
    'I'm sorry, but where's the proof of that?' snapped Carolina.
    There are plenty of eye-witness accounts. Just because you're so narrow-minded you need to have everything shoved under your nose before you - '
    'Hem, hem,' said Martina, in such a good imitation of Professor Umbridge that several people looked around in alarm and then laughed. 'Weren't we trying to decide how often we're going to meet and have defence lessons?'
    'Yes,' said Carolina at once, 'yes, we were, you're right, Martina.'
    Well, once a week sounds cool,' said Lee Jordan.
    'As long as - ' began Angelina.
    'Yes, yes, we know about the Quidditch,' said Carolina in a tense voice. 'Well, the other thing to decide is where we're going to meet . . .'
    This was rather more difficult; the whole group fell silent.
    'Library?' suggested Katie Bell after a few moments.
    'I can't see Madam Pince being too chuffed with us doing jinxes in the library,' said Roberto.
    'Maybe an unused classroom?' said Dean.
    'Yeah,' said Diego, 'Romero might let us have hers, she did when Roberto was practising for the Tri wizard.'
    But Roberto was pretty certain that Romero would not be so accommodating this time. For all that Carolina had said about study and homework groups being allowed, he had the distinct feeling that this one might be considered a lot more rebellious.
    'Right, well, we'll try to find somewhere,' said Carolina. 'We'll send a message round to everybody when we've got a time and a place for the first meeting.'
    She rummaged in her bag and produced parchment and a quill, then hesitated, rather as though she was steeling herself to say something.
    'I - I think everybody should write their name down, just so we know who was here. But I also think,' she took a deep breath, 'that we all ought to agree not to shout about what we're doing. So if you sign, you're agreeing not to tell Umbridge or anybody else what we're up to.'
    Pablo reached out for the parchment and cheerfully wrote his signature, but Roberto noticed at once that several people looked less than happy at the prospect of putting their names on the list.
    'Er . . .' said Zacharias slowly, not taking the parchment that Luis was trying to pass to him, 'well . . . I'm sure Ernie will tell me when the meeting is.'
    But Ernie was looking rather hesitant about signing, too. Carolina raised her eyebrows at him.
    'I - well, we are prefects,' Ernie burst out. 'And if this list was found . . . well, I mean to say . . . you said yourself, if Umbridge finds out - '
    'You just said this group was the most important thing you'd do this year,' Roberto reminded him.
    'I - yes,' said Ernie, 'yes, I do believe that, it's just - '
    'Ernie, do you really think I'd leave that list lying around?' said Carolina testily.
    'No. No, of course not,' said Ernie, looking slightly less anxious. 'I - yes, of course I'll sign.'
    Nobody raised objections after Ernie, though Roberto saw Paula's friend give her a rather reproachful look before adding her own name. When the last person - Zacharias - had signed, Carolina took the parchment back and slipped it carefully into her bag. There was an odd feeling in the group now. It was as though they had just signed some kind of contract.
    'Well, time's ticking on,' said Pablo briskly, getting to his feet. 'Luis, Lee and I have got items of a sensitive nature to purchase, we'll be seeing you all later.'
    In twos and threes the rest of the group took their leave, too.
    Paula made rather a business of fastening the catch on her bag before leaving, her long dark curtain of hair swinging forwards to hide her face, but her friend stood beside her, arms folded, clicking her tongue, so that Paula had little choice but to leave with her. As her friend ushered her through the door, Paula looked back and waved at Roberto.
    'Well, I think that went quite well,' said Carolina happily, as she, Roberto and Diego walked out of the Hog's Head into the bright sunlight a few moments later. Roberto and Diego were clutching their bottles of Butterbeer.
    'That Zacharias bloke's a wart,' said Diego, who was glowering after the figure of Smith, just discernible in the distance.
    'I don't like him much, either,' admitted Carolina, 'but he overheard me talking to Ernie and Hannah at the Hufflepuff table and he seemed really interested in coming, so what could I say? But the more people the better really - I mean, Michael Corner and his friends wouldn't have come if he hadn't been going out with Martina - '
    Diego, who had been draining the last few drops from his Butterbeer bottle, gagged and sprayed Butterbeer down his front.
    'He's WHAT?' spluttered Diego, outraged, his ears now resembling curls of raw beef. 'She's going out with - my sister's going - what d'you mean, Michael Corner?'
    'Well, that's why he and his friends came, I think - well, they're obviously interested in learning defence, but if Martina hadn't told Michael what was going on - '
    'When did this - when did she -?'
    'They met at the Yule Ball and got together at the end of last year,' said Carolina composedly. They had turned into the High Street and she paused outside Scrivenshaft's Quill Shop, where there was a handsome display of pheasant feather quills in the window. 'Hmm . . . I could do with a new quill.'
    She turned into the shop. Roberto and Diego followed her.
    'Which one was Michael Corner?' Diego demanded furiously.
    The dark one,' said Carolina.
    'I didn't like him,' said Diego at once.
    'Big surprise,' said Carolina under her breath.
    'But, said Diego, following Carolina along a row of quills in copper pots, 'I thought Martina fancied Roberto!'
    Carolina looked at him rather pityingly and shook her head.
    'Martina used to fancy Roberto, but she gave up on him months ago. Not that she doesn't like you, of course,' she added kindly to Roberto while she examined a long black and gold quill.
    Roberto, whose head was still full of Paula's parting wave, did not find this subject quite as interesting as Diego, who was positively quivering with indignation, but it did bring something home to him that until now he had not really registered.
    'So that's why she talks now?' he asked Carolina. 'She never used to talk in front of me.'
    'Exactly,' said Carolina. 'Yes, I think I'll have this one . . .'
    She went up to the counter and handed over fifteen Sickles and two Knuts, with Diego still breathing down her neck.
    'Diego,' she said severely as she turned and trod on his feet, 'this is exactly why Martina hasn't told you she's seeing Michael, she knew you'd take it badly. So don't harp on about it, for heaven's sake.'
    'What d'you mean? Who's taking anything badly? I'm not going to harp on about anything . . .' Diego continued to chunter under his breath all the way down the street.
    Carolina rolled her eyes at Roberto and then said in an undertone, while Diego was still muttering imprecations about Michael Corner, 'And talking about Michael and Martina . . . what about Paula and you?'
    'What d'you mean?' said Roberto quickly.
    It was as though boiling water was rising rapidly inside him; a burning sensation that was causing his face to smart in the cold - had he been that obvious?
    'Well,' said Carolina, smiling slightly, 'she just couldn't keep her eyes off you, could she?'
    Roberto had never before appreciated just how beautiful the village of Hogsmeade was.
- CHAPTER SEVENTEEN -
Educational Decree
Number Twenty-four
Roberto felt happier for the rest of the weekend than he had done all term. He and Diego spent much of Sunday catching up with all their homework again, and although this could hardly be called fun, the last burst of autumn sunshine persisted, so rather than sitting hunched over tables in the common room they took their work outside and lounged in the shade of a large beech tree on the edge of the lake. Carolina, who of course was up to date with all her work, brought more wool outside with her and bewitched her knitting needles so that they flashed and clicked in midair beside her, producing more hats and scarves.
    Knowing they were doing something to resist Umbridge and the Ministry and that he was a key part of the rebellion, gave Roberto a feeling of immense satisfaction. He kept reliving Saturdays meeting in his mind: all those people, coming to him to learn Defence Against the Dark Arts . . . and the looks on their faces as they had heard some of the things he had done . . . and Paula praising his performance in the Triwizard Tournament - knowing all those people did not think him a lying weirdo, but someone to be admired, buoyed him up so much that he was still cheerful on Monday morning, despite the imminent prospect of all his least favourite classes.
    He and Diego headed downstairs from their dormitory, discussing Angelina's idea that they were to work on a new move called the Sloth Grip Roll during that nights Quidditch practice, and not until they were halfway across the sunlit common room did they notice the addition to the room that had already attracted the attention of a small group of people.
    A large sign had been affixed to the Grffindor noticeboard, so large it covered everything else on it - the lists of secondhand spellbooks for sale, the regular reminders of school rules from Argus Filch, the Quidditch team training timetable, the offers to barter certain Paulacolate Frog Cards for others, the Lopezs' latest advertisement for testers, the dates of the Hogsmeade weekends and the lost and found notices. The new sign was printed in large black letters and there was a highly official-looking seal at the bottom beside a neat and curly signature.
BY ORDER OF THE HIGH INQUISITOR OF HOGWARTS
All student organisations, societies, teams, groups and clubs are
henceforth disbanded.
An organisation, society, team, group or club is hereby defined 
as a regular meeting of three or more students.
Permission to re-form may be sought from the High Inquisitor
(Professor Umbridge).
No student organisation, society, team, group or club may exist
without the knowledge and approval of the High Inquisitor.

Any student found to have formed, or to belong to, an organisation, 
society, team, group or club that has not been approved by
 the High Inquisitor will be expelled.
The above is in accordance with Educational Decree
Number Twenty-four.
Signed: Dolores Jane Umbridge, High Inquisitor
Roberto and Diego read the notice over the heads of some anxious-looking second-years.
    'Does this mean they're going to shut down the Gobstones Club?' one of them asked his friend.
    'I reckon you'll be OK with Gobstones,' Diego said darkly, making the second-year jump. I don't think we're going to be as lucky, though, do you?' he asked Roberto as the second-years hurried away.
    Roberto was reading the notice through again. The happiness that had filled him since Saturday was gone. His insides were pulsing with rage.
    'This isn't a coincidence,' he said, his hands forming fists. 'She knows.'
    'She can't,' said Diego at once.
    There were people listening in that pub. And let's face it, we don't know how many of the people who turned up we can trust . . . any of them could have run off and told Umbridge . . .'
    And he had thought they believed him, thought they even admired him . . .
    'Zacharias Smith!' said Diego at once, punching a fist into his hand. 'Or - I thought that Michael Corner had a really shifty look, too - '
    'I wonder if Carolina's seen this yet?' Roberto said, looking round at the door to the girls' dormitories.
    'Let's go and tell her,' said Diego. He bounded forwards, pulled open the door and set off up the spiral staircase.
    He was on the sixth stair when there was a loud, wailing, klaxon-like sound and the steps melted together to make a long, smooth stone slide like a helter-skelter. There was a brief moment when Diego tried to keep running, arms working madly like windmills, then he toppled over backwards and shot down the newly created slide, coming to rest on his back at Roberto's feet.
    'Er - I don't think we're allowed in the girls' dormitories,' said Roberto, pulling Diego to his feet and trying not to laugh.
    Two fourth-year girls came zooming gleefully down the stone slide.
    'Oooh. who tried to get upstairs?' they giggled happily, leaping to their feet and ogling Roberto and Diego.
    'Me,' said Diego, who was still rather dishevelled. T didn't realise that would happen. It's not fair!' he added to Roberto, as the girls headed off for the portrait hole, still giggling madly. 'Carolina's allowed in our dormitory, how come we're not allowed - ?'
    'Well, it's an old-fashioned rule,' said Carolina, who had just slid neatly on to a rug in front of them and was now getting to her feet, 'but it says in Hogwarts: A History, that the founders thought boys were less trustworthy than girls. Anyway, why were you trying to get in there?'
    To see you - look at this!' said Diego, dragging her over to the noticeboard.
    Carolina's eyes slid rapidly down the notice. Her expression became stony.
    'Someone must have blabbed to her!' Diego said angrily.
    'They can't have done,' said Carolina in a low voice.
    'You're so naive,' said Diego, 'you think just because you're all honourable and trustworthy - '
    'No, they can't have done, because I put a jinx on that piece of parchment we all signed,' said Carolina grimly. 'Believe me, if anyone's run off and told Umbridge, we'll know exactly who they are and they will really regret it.'
    'What'll happen to them?' said Diego eagerly.
    'Well, put it this way,' said Carolina, 'it'll make Eloise Midgeon's acne look like a couple of cute freckles. Come on, let's get down to breakfast and see what the others think . . . I wonder whether this has been put up in all the houses?'
    It was immediately apparent on entering the Great Hall that Umbridge's sign had not only appeared in Gryffindor Tower. There was a peculiar intensity about the chatter and an extra measure of movement in the Hall as people scurried up and down their tables conferring on what they had read. Roberto, Diego and Carolina had barely taken their seats when Mauricio, Dean, Pablo, Luis and Martina descended upon them.
    'Did you see it?'
    'D'you reckon she knows?'
    'What are we going to do?'
    They were all looking at Roberto. He glanced around to make sure there were no teachers near them.
    'We're going to do it anyway, of course,' he said quietly.
    'Knew you'd say that,' said Luis, beaming and thumping Roberto on the arm.
    The prefects as well?' said Pablo, looking quizzically at Diego and Carolina.
    'Of course,' said Carolina coolly.
    'Here come Ernie and Hannah Abbott,' said Diego, looking over his shoulder. 'And those Ravenclaw blokes and Smith . . . and no one looks very spotty.'
    Carolina looked alarmed.
    'Never mind spots, the idiots can't come over here now, it'll look really suspicious - sit down!' she mouthed to Ernie and Hannah, gesturing frantically to them to rejoin the Hufflepuff table. 'Later! We'll - talk - to - you - later!'
    'I'll tell Michael,' said Martina impatiently, swinging herself off her bench, 'the fool, honestly . . .'
    She hurried off towards the Ravenclaw table; Roberto watched her go. Paula was sitting not far away, talking to the curly-haired friend she had brought along to the Hog's Head. Would Umbridge's notice scare her off meeting them again?
    But the full repercussions of the sign were not felt until they were leaving the Great Hall for History of Magic.
    'Roberto! Diego!'
    It was Angelina and she was hurrying towards them looking perfectly desperate.
    'It's OK,' said Roberto quietly, when she was near enough to hear him. 'We're still going to - '
    'You realise she's including Quidditch in this?' Angelina said over him. 'We have to go and ask permission to re-form the Gryffindor team!'
    'What?' said Roberto.
    'No way,' said Diego, appalled.
    'You read the sign, it mentions teams too! So listen, Roberto . . . I am saying this for the last time . . . please, please don't lose your temper with Umbridge again or she might not let us play any more!'
    'OK, OK,' said Roberto, for Angelina looked as though she was on the verge of tears. 'Don't worry, I'll behave myself . . .'
    'Bet Umbridge is in History of Magic,' said Diego grimly, as they set off for Binns's lesson. 'She hasn't inspected Binns yet . . . bet you anything she's there . . .'
    But he was wrong; the only teacher present when they entered was Professor Binns, floating an inch or so above his chair as usual and preparing to continue his monotonous drone on giant wars. Roberto did not even attempt to follow what he was saying today; he doodled idly on his parchment ignoring Carolina's frequent glares and nudges, until a particularly painful poke in the ribs made him look up angrily.
    'What?'
    She pointed at the window. Roberto looked round. Hedwig was perched on the narrow window ledge, gazing through the thick glass at him, a letter tied to her leg. Roberto could not understand it; they had just had breakfast, why on earth hadn't she delivered the letter then, as usual? Many of his classmates were pointing out Hedwig to each other, too.
    'Oh, I've always loved that owl, she's so beautiful,' Roberto heard Lavender sigh to Parvati.
    He glanced round at Professor Binns who continued to read his notes, serenely unaware that the class's attention was even less focused upon him than usual. Roberto slipped quietly off his chair, crouched down and hurried along the row to the window, where he slid the catch and opened it very slowly.
    He had expected Hedwig to hold out her leg so that he could remove the letter and then fly off to the Owlery, but the moment the window was open wide enough she hopped inside, hooting dolefully. He closed the window with an anxious glance at Professor Binns, crouched low again and sped back to his seat with Hedwig on his shoulder. He regained his seat, transferred Hedwig to his lap and made to remove the letter tied to her leg.
    Only then did he realise that Hedwig's feathers were oddly ruffled; some were bent the wrong way, and she was holding one of her wings at an odd angle.
    'She's hurt!' Roberto whispered, bending his head low over her. Carolina and Diego leaned in closer; Carolina even put down her quill. 'Look - there's something wrong with her wing - '
    Hedwig was quivering; when Roberto made to touch the wing she gave a little jump, all her feathers on end as though she was inflating herself, and gazed at him reproachfully.
    'Professor Binns,' said Roberto loudly, and everyone in the class turned to look at him. 'I'm not feeling well.'
    Professor Binns raised his eyes from his notes, looking amazed, as always, to find the room in front of him full of people.
    'Not feeling well?' he repeated hazily.
    'Not at all well,' said Roberto firmly, getting to his feet with Hedwig concealed behind his back. 'I think I need to go to the hospital wing.'
    'Yes,' said Professor Binns, clearly very much wrong-footed. 'Yes . . . yes, hospital wing . . . well, off you go, then, Perkins . . .'
    Once outside the room, Roberto returned Hedwig to his shoulder and hurried off up the corridor, pausing to think only when he was out of sight of Binns's door. His first choice of somebody to cure Hedwig would have been Villalba, of course, but as he had no idea where Villalba was his only remaining option was to find Professor Grubbly-Plank and hope she would help.
    He peered out of a window at the blustery, overcast grounds. There was no sign of her anywhere near Villalba's cabin; if she was not teaching, she was probably in the staff room. He set off downstairs, Hedwig hooting feebly as she swayed on his shoulder.
    Two stone gargoyles flanked the staff-room door. As Roberto approached, one of them croaked, 'You should be in class, Sonny Jim.'
    This is urgent,' said Roberto curtly.
    'Ooooh, urgent, is it?' said the other gargoyle in a high-pitched voice. 'Well, that's put us in our place, hasn't it?'
    Roberto knocked. He heard footsteps, then the door opened and he found himself face to face with Professor Romero.
    'You haven't been given another detention!' she said at once, her square spectacles flashing alarmingly.
    'No, Professor!' said Roberto hastily.
    'Well then, why are you out of class?'
    'It's urgent, apparently,' said the second gargoyle snidely.
    'I'm looking for Professor Grubbly-Plank,' Roberto explained. 'It's my owl, she's injured.'
    'Injured owl, did you say?'
    Professor Grubbly-Plank appeared at Professor Romero's shoulder, smoking a pipe and holding a copy of the Daily Prophet.
    'Yes,' said Roberto, lifting Hedwig carefully off his shoulder, 'she turned up after the other post owls and her wing's all funny, look - '
    Professor Grubbly-Plank stuck her pipe firmly between her teeth and took Hedwig from Roberto while Professor Romero watched.
    'Hmm,' said Professor Grubbly-Plank, her pipe waggling slightly as she talked. 'Looks like something's attacked her. Can't think what would have done it, though. Thestrals will sometimes go for birds, of course, but Villalba's got the Hogwarts Thestrals well-trained not to touch owls.'
    Roberto neither knew nor cared what Thestrals were; he just wanted to know that Hedwig was going to be all right. Professor Romero, however, looked sharply at Roberto and said, 'Do you know how far this owl's travelled, Gonzales?'
    'Er,' said Roberto. 'From London, I think.'
    He met her eyes briefly and knew, by the way her eyebrows had joined in the middle, that she understood 'London' to mean 'number twelve, Grimmauld Place'.
    Professor Grubbly-Plank pulled a monocle out of the inside of her robes and screwed it into her eye, to examine Hedwig's wing closely. 'I should be able to sort this out if you leave her with me, Gonzales,' she said, 'she shouldn't be flying long distances for a few days, in any case.'
    'Er - right - thanks,' said Roberto, just as the bell rang for break.
    'No problem,' said Professor Grubbly-Plank gruffly, turning back into the staff room.
    'Just a moment, Wilhelmina!' said Professor Romero. 'Gonzales's letter!'
    'Oh yeah!' said Roberto, who had momentarily forgotten the scroll tied to Hedwig's leg. Professor Grubbly-Plank handed it over and then disappeared into the staff room carrying Hedwig, who was staring at Roberto as though unable to believe he would give her away like this. Feeling slightly guilty, he turned to go, but Professor Romero called him back.
    'Gonzales!'
    'Yes, Professor?'
    She glanced up and down the corridor; there were students coming from both directions.
    'Bear in mind,' she said quickly and quietly, her eyes on the scroll in his hand, 'that channels of communication in and out of Hogwarts may be being watched, won't you?'
    'I - ' said Roberto, but the flood of students rolling along the
    corridor was almost upon him. Professor Romero gave him a curt nod and retreated into the staff room, leaving Roberto to be swept out into the courtyard with the crowd. He spotted Diego and Carolina already standing in a sheltered corner, their cloak collars turned up against the wind. Roberto slit open the scroll as he hurried towards them and found five words in Gustavo's handwriting:
    Today, same time, same place.
    'Is Hedwig OK?' asked Carolina anxiously, the moment he was within earshot.
    'Where did you take her?' asked Diego.
    'To Grubbly-Plank,' said Roberto. 'And I met Romero . . . listen . . .'
    And he told them what Professor Romero had said. To his surprise, neither of the others looked shocked. On the contrary, they exchanged significant looks.
    'What?' said Roberto, looking from Diego to Carolina and back again.
    'Well, I was just saying to Diego . . . what if someone had tried to intercept Hedwig? I mean, she's never been hurt on a flight before, has she?'
    'Who's the letter from, anyway?' asked Diego, taking the note from Roberto.
    'Snuffles,' said Roberto quietly.
    '"Same time, same place?" Does he mean the fire in the common room?'
    'Obviously,' said Carolina, also reading the note. She looked uneasy. 'I just hope nobody else has read this . . .'
    'But it was still sealed and everything,' said Roberto, trying to convince himself as much as her. 'And nobody would understand what it meant if they didn't know where we'd spoken to him before, would they?'
    T don't know,' said Carolina anxiously, hitching her bag back over her shoulder as the bell rang again, 'it wouldn't be exactly difficult to re-seal the scroll by magic . . . and if anyone's watching the Floo Network . . . but I don't really see how we can warn him not to come without that being intercepted, too!'
    They trudged down the stone steps to the dungeons for Potions, all three of them, lost in thought, but as they reached the bottom of the steps they were recalled to themselves by the voice of Javier Sosa, who was standing just outside Peralta's classroom door, waving around an official-looking piece of parchment and talking much louder than was necessary so that they could hear every word.
    'Yeah, Umbridge gave the Slytherin Quidditch team permission to continue playing straightaway, I went to ask her first thing this morning. Well, it was pretty much automatic, I mean, she knows my father really well, he's always popping in and out of the Ministry . . . it'll be interesting to see whether Gryffindor are allowed to keep playing, won't it?'
    'Don't rise,' Carolina whispered imploringly to Roberto and Diego, who were both watching Sosa, faces set and fists clenched. 'It's what he wants.'
    'I mean,' said Sosa, raising his voice a little more, his grey eyes glittering malevolently in Roberto and Diego's direction, 'if it's a question of influence with the Ministry, I don't think they've got much chance . . . from what my father says, they've been looking for an excuse to sack Raul Lopez for years . . . and as for Gonzales . . . my father says it's a matter of time before the Ministry has him carted off to St Mungo's . . . apparently they've got a special ward for people whose brains have been addled by magic.'
    Sosa made a grotesque face, his mouth sagging open and his eyes rolling. Crabbe and Goyle gave their usual grunts of laughter; Pansy Parkinson shrieked with glee.
    Something collided hard with Roberto's shoulder, knocking him sideways. A split second later he realised that Mauricio had just charged past him, heading straight for Sosa.
    'Mauricio, no!'
    Roberto leapt forward and seized the back of Mauricio's robes; Mauricio struggled frantically, his fists flailing, trying desperately to get at Sosa who looked, for a moment, extremely shocked.
    'Help me!' Roberto flung at Diego, managing to get an arm around Mauricio's neck and dragging him backwards, away from the Slytherins. Crabbe and Goyle were flexing their arms as they stepped in front of Sosa, ready for the fight. Diego seized Mauricio's arms, and together he and Roberto succeeded in dragging Mauricio back into the Gryffindor line. Mauricios face was scarlet; the pressure Roberto was exerting on his throat rendered him quite incomprehensible, but odd words spluttered from his mouth.
    'Not . . . funny . . . don't . . . Mungo's . . . show . . . him . . .'
    The dungeon door opened. Peralta appeared there. His black eyes swept up the Gryffindor line to the point where Roberto and Diego were wrestling with Mauricio.
    'Fighting, Gonzales, Lopez, Silva?' Peralta said in his cold, sneering voice. 'Ten points from Gryffindor. Release Silva, Gonzales, or it will be detention. Inside, all of you.'
    Roberto let go of Mauricio, who stood panting and glaring at him.
    'I had to stop you,' Roberto gasped, picking up his bag. 'Crabbe and Goyle would've torn you apart.'
    Mauricio said nothing; he merely snatched up his own bag and stalked off into the dungeon.
    'What in the name of Merlin,' said Diego slowly, as they followed Mauricio, 'was that about?'
    Roberto did not answer. He knew exactly why the subject of people who were in St Mungo's because of magical damage to their brains was highly distressing to Mauricio, but he had sworn to Dominguez that he would not tell anyone Mauricio's secret. Even Mauricio did not know Roberto knew.
    Roberto, Diego and Carolina took their usual seats at the back of the class, pulled out parchment, quills and their copies of One Thousand Magical Herbs and Fungi. The class around them was whispering about what Mauricio had just done, but when Peralta closed the dungeon door with an echoing bang, everybody immediately fell silent.
    'You will notice,' said Peralta, in his low, sneering voice, 'that we have a guest with us today.'
    He gestured towards the dim corner of the dungeon and Roberto saw Professor Umbridge sitting there, clipboard on her knee. He glanced sideways at Diego and Carolina, his eyebrows raised. Peralta and Umbridge, the two teachers he hated most. It was hard to decide which one he wanted to triumph over the other.
    'We are continuing with our Strengthening Solution today. You will find your mixtures as you left them last lesson; it correctly made they should have matured well over the weekend - instructions - ' he waved his wand again ' - on the board. Carry on.'
    Professor Umbridge spent the first half hour of the lesson making notes in her corner. Roberto was very interested in hearing her question Peralta; so interested, that he was becoming careless with his potion again.
    'Salamander blood, Roberto!' Carolina moaned, grabbing his wrist to prevent him adding the wrong ingredient for the third time, 'not pomegranate juice!'
    'Right,' said Roberto vaguely, putting down the bottle and continuing to watch the corner. Umbridge had just got to her feet. 'Ha,' he said softly, as she strode between two lines of desks towards Peralta, who was bending over Dean Thomas's cauldron.
    'Well, the class seem fairly advanced for their level,' she said briskly to Peralta's back. 'Though I would question whether it is advisable to teach them a potion like the Strengthening Solution. I think the Ministry would prefer it if that was removed from the syllabus.'
    Peralta straightened up slowly and turned to look at her.
    'Now . . . how long have you been teaching at Hogwarts?' she asked, her quill poised over her clipboard.
    'Fourteen years,' Peralta replied. His expression was unfathomable. Roberto, watching him closely, added a few drops to his potion; it hissed menacingly and turned from turquoise to orange.
    'You applied first for the Defence Against the Dark Arts post, I believe?' Professor Umbridge asked Peralta.
    'Yes,' said Peralta quietly.
    'But you were unsuccessful?'
    Peralta's lip curled.
    'Obviously.'
    Professor Umbridge scribbled on her clipboard.
    'And you have applied regularly for the Defence Against the Dark Arts post since you first joined the school, I believe?'
    'Yes,' said Peralta quietly, barely moving his lips. He looked very angry.
    'Do you have any idea why Dominguez has consistently refused to appoint you?' asked Umbridge.
    'I suggest you ask him,' said Peralta jerkily.
    'Oh, I shall,' said Professor Umbridge, with a sweet smile.
    'I suppose this is relevant?' Peralta asked, his black eyes narrowed.
    'Oh yes,' said Professor Umbridge, 'yes, the Ministry wants a thorough understanding of teachers' - er - backgrounds.'
    She turned away, walked over to Pansy Parkinson and began questioning her about the lessons. Peralta looked round at Roberto and their eyes met for a second. Roberto hastily dropped his gaze to his potion, which was now congealing foully and giving off a. strong smell of burned rubber.
    'No marks again, then, Gonzales,' said Peralta maliciously, emptying Roberto's cauldron with a wave of his wand. 'You will write me an essay on the correct composition of this potion, indicating how and why you went wrong, to be handed in next lesson, do you understand?'
    'Yes,' said Roberto furiously. Peralta had already given them homework and he had Quidditch practice this evening; this would mean another couple of sleepless nights. It did not seem possible that he had awoken that morning feeling very happy. All he felt now was a fervent desire for this day to end.
    'Maybe I'll skive off Divination,' he said glumly, as they stood in the courtyard after lunch, the wind whipping at the hems of robes and brims of hats. 'I'll pretend to be ill and do Peralta's essay instead, then I won't have to stay up half the night.'
    'You can't skive off Divination,' said Carolina severely.
    'Hark who's talking, you walked oui of Divination, you hate Trelawney!' said Diego indignantly.
    'I don't hate her,' said Carolina loftily. 'I just think she's an absolutely appalling teacher and a real old fraud. But Roberto's already missed History of Magic and I don't think he ought to miss anything else today!'
    There was too much truth in this to ignore, so half an hour later Roberto took his seat in the hot, overperfumed atmosphere of the Divination classroom, feeling angry at everybody. Professor Trelawney was yet again handing out copies of The Dream Oracle. Roberto thought he'd surely be much better employed doing Peralta's
    punishment essay than sitting here trying to nnd meaning in a lot of made-up dreams.
    It seemed, however, that he was not the only person in Divination who was in a temper. Professor Trelawney slammed a copy of the Oracle down on the table between Roberto and Diego and swept away, her lips pursed; she threw the next copy of the Oracle at Seamus and Dean, narrowly avoiding Seamus's head, and thrust the final one into Mauricio's chest with such force that he slipped off his pouffe.
    'Well, carry on!' said Professor Trelawney loudly, her voice high-pitched and somewhat hysterical, 'you know what to do! Or am I such a sub-standard teacher that you have never learned how to open a book?'
    The class stared perplexedly at her, then at each other. Roberto, however, thought he knew what was the matter. As Professor Trelawney flounced back to the high-backed teachers chair, her magnified eyes full of angry tears, he leaned his head closer to Diego's and muttered, 'I think she's got the results of her inspection back.'
    'Professor?' said Parvati Patil in a hushed voice (she and Lavender had always rather admired Professor Trelawney). 'Professor, is there anything - er - wrong?'
    'Wrong!' cried Professor Trelawney in a voice throbbing with emotion. 'Certainly not! I have been insulted, certainly . . . insinuations have been made against me . . . unfounded accusations levelled . . . but no, there is nothing wrong, certainly not!'
    She took a great shuddering breath and looked away from Parvati, angry tears spilling from under her glasses.
    'I say nothing,' she choked, 'of sixteen years of devoted service . . . it has passed, apparently, unnoticed . . . but I shall not be insulted, no, I shall not!'
    'But, Professor, who's insulting you?' asked Parvati timidly.
    The Establishment!' said Professor Trelawney, in a deep, dramatic, wavering voice. 'Yes, those with eyes too clouded by the mundane to See as I See, to Know as I Know . . . of course, we Seers have always been feared, always persecuted . . . it is - alas - 'our fate.'
    She gulped, dabbed at her wet cheeks with the end of her shawl, then she pulled a small embroidered handkerchief from her sleeve, and blew her nose very hard with a sound like Peeves blowing a raspberry.
    Diego sniggered. Lavender shot him a disgusted look.
    'Professor,' said Parvati, 'do you mean . . . is it something Professor Umbridge - ?'
    'Do not speak to me about that woman!' cried Professor Trelawney leaping to her feet, her beads rattling and her spectacles flashing. 'Kindly continue with your work!'
    And she spent the rest of the lesson striding among them, tears still leaking from behind her glasses, muttering what sounded like threats under her breath.
    '. . . may well choose to leave . . . the indignity of it . . . on probation . . . we shall see . . . how she dares . . .'
    'You and Umbridge have got something in common,' Roberto told Carolina quietly when they met again in Defence Against the Dark Arts. 'She obviously reckons Trelawney's an old fraud, too . . . looks like she's put her on probation.'
    Umbridge entered the room as he spoke, wearing her black velvet bow and an expression of great smugness.
    'Good afternoon, class.'
    'Good afternoon, Professor Umbridge,' they chanted dully.
    'Wands away, please.'
    But there was no answering flurry of movement this time; nobody had bothered to take out their wands.
    'Please turn to page thirty-four of Defensive Magical Theory and read the third chapter, entitled "The Case for Non-Offensive Responses to Magical Attack". There will be - '
    ' - no need to talk,' Roberto, Diego and Carolina said together, under their breaths.
*
'No Quidditch practice,' said Angelina in hollow tones when Roberto, Diego and Carolina entered the common room after dinner that night.
    'But I kept my temper!' said Roberto, horrified. 'I didn't say anything to her, Angelina, I swear, I - '
    'I know, I know, said Angelina miserably. 'She just said she needed a bit of time to consider.'
    'Consider what?' said Diego angrily. 'She's given the Slytherins permission, why not us?'
    But Roberto could imagine how much Umbridge was enjoying holding the threat of no Gryffindor Quidditch team over their heads and could easily understand why she would not want to relinquish that weapon over them too soon.
    'Well,' said Carolina, 'look on the bright side - at least now you'll have time to do Peralta's essay!'
    That's a bright side, is it?' snapped Roberto, while Diego stared incredulously at Carolina. 'No Quidditch practice, and extra Potions?'
    Roberto slumped down into a chair, dragged his Potions essay reluctantly from his bag and set to work. It was very hard to concentrate; even though he knew Gustavo was not due in the fire until much later, he could not help glancing into the flames every few minutes just in case. There was also an incredible amount of noise in the room: Pablo and Luis appeared finally to have perfected one type of Skiving Snackbox, which they were taking turns to demonstrate to a cheering and whooping crowd.
    First, Pablo would take a bite out of the orange end of a chew, at which he would vomit spectacularly into a bucket they had placed in front of them. Then he would force down the purple end of the chew, at which the vomiting would immediately cease. Lee Jordan, who was assisting the demonstration, was lazily Vanishing the vomit at regular intervals with the same Vanishing Spell Peralta kept using on Roberto's potions.
    What with the regular sounds of retching, cheering and the sound of Pablo and Luis taking advance orders from the crowd, Roberto was finding it exceptionally difficult to focus on the correct method for Strengthening Solution. Carolina was not helping matters; the cheers and the sound of vomit hitting the bottom of Pablo and Luis's bucket were punctuated by her loud and disapproving sniffs, which Roberto found, if anything, more distracting.
    'Just go and stop them, then!' he said irritably, after crossing out the wrong weight of powdered griffin claw for the fourth time.
    'I can't, they're not technically doing anything wrong,' said Carolina through gritted teeth. They're quite within their rights to eat the foul things themselves and I can't find a rule that says the other idiots aren't entitled to buy them, not unless they're proven to be dangerous in some way and it doesn't look as though they are.'
    She, Roberto and Diego watched Luis projectile-vomit into the bucket, gulp down the rest of the chew and straighten up, beaming with his arms wide to protracted applause.
    'You know, I don't get why Pablo and Luis only got three OWLs each,' said Roberto, watching as Pablo, Luis and Lee collected gold from the eager crowd. They really know their stuff.'
    'Oh, they only know flashy stuff that's of no real use to anyone,' said Carolina disparagingly.
    'No real use?' said Diego in a strained voice. 'Carolina, they've made about twenty-six Galleons already.'
    It was a long while before the crowd around the Lopez twins dispersed, then Pablo, Lee and Luis sat up counting their takings even longer, so it was well past midnight when Roberto, Diego and Carolina finally had the common room to themselves. At long last, Pablo had closed the doorway to the boys' dormitories behind him, rattling his box of Galleons ostentatiously so that Carolina scowled. Roberto, who was making very little progress with his Potions essay, decided to give it up for the night. As he put his books away, Diego, who was dozing lightly in an armchair, gave a muffled grunt, awoke, and looked blearily into the fire.
    'Gustavo!' he said.
    Roberto whipped round. Gustavo's untidy dark head was sitting in the fire again.
    'Hi,' he said, grinning.
    'Hi,' chorused Roberto, Diego and Carolina, all three kneeling down on the hearthrug. Crookshanks purred loudly and approached the fire, trying, despite the heat, to put his face close to Gustavo's.
    'How're things?' said Gustavo.
    'Not that good,' said Roberto, as Carolina pulled Crookshanks back to stop him singeing his whiskers. The Ministry's forced through another decree, which means we're not allowed to have Quidditch teams - '
    'Or secret Defence Against the Dark Arts groups? Said Gustavo.
    There was a short pause.
    'How did you know about that?' Roberto demanded.
    'You want to choose your meeting places more carefully,' said Gustavo, grinning still more broadly. The Hog's Head, I ask you.'
    'Well, it was better than the Three Broomsticks!' said Carolina defensively. That's always packed with people - '
    'Which means you'd have been harder to overhear,' said Gustavo. 'You've got a lot to learn, Carolina.'
    'Who overheard us?' Roberto demanded.
    'Mundungus, of course,' said Gustavo, and when they all looked puzzled he laughed. 'He was the witch under the veil.'
    That was Mundungus?' Roberto said, stunned. 'What was he doing in the Hog's Head?'
    'What do you think he was doing?' said Gustavo impatiently. 'Keeping an eye on you, of course.'
    'I'm still being followed?' asked Roberto angrily.
    'Yeah, you are,' said Gustavo, 'and just as well, isn't it, if the first thing you're going to do on your weekend off is organise an illegal defence group.'
    But he looked neither angry nor worried. On the contrary, he was looking at Roberto with distinct pride.
    'Why was Dung hiding from us?' asked Diego, sounding disappointed. 'We'd've liked to've seen him.'
    'He was banned from the Hog's Head twenty years ago,' said Gustavo, 'and that barman's got a long memory. We lost Acosta's spare Invisibility Cloak when Sturgis was arrested, so Dung's been dressing as a witch a lot lately . . . anyway . . . first of all, Diego - I've sworn to pass on a message from your mother.'
    'Oh yeah?' said Diego, sounding apprehensive.
    'She says on no account whatsoever are you to take part in an illegal secret Defence Against the Dark Arts group. She says you'll be expelled for sure and your future will be ruined. She says there will be plenty of time to learn how to defend yourself later and that you are too young to be worrying about that right now. She also' (Gustavo's eyes turned to the other two) 'advises Roberto and Carolina not to proceed with the group, though she accepts that she has no authority over either of them and simply begs them to remember that she has their best interests at heart. She would have written all this to you, but if the owl had been intercepted you'd all have been in real trouble, and she can't say it for herself because she's on duty tonight.'
    'On duty doing what?' said Diego quickly.
    'Never you mind, just stuff for the Order,' said Gustavo. 'So it's fallen to me to be the messenger and make sure you tell her I passed it all on, because I don't think she trusts me to.'
    There was another pause in which Crookshanks, mewing, attempted to paw Gustavo's head, and Diego fiddled with a hole in the hearthrug.
    'So, you want me to say I'm not going to take part in the Defence group?' he muttered finally.
    'Me? Certainly not!' said Gustavo, looking surprised. 'I think it's an excellent idea!'
    'You do?' said Roberto, his heart lifting.
    'Of course I do!' said Gustavo. 'D'you think your father and I would've lain down and taken orders from an old hag like Umbridge?'
    'But - last term all you did was tell me to be careful and not take risks - '
    'Last year, all the evidence was that someone inside Hogwarts was trying to kill you, Roberto!' said Gustavo impatiently. This year, we know there's someone outside Hogwarts who'd like to kill us all, so I think learning to defend yourselves properly is; a very good idea!'
    'And if we do get expelled?' Carolina asked, a quizzical look on her face.
    'Carolina, this whole thing was your idea!' said Roberto, staring at her.
    'I know it was. I just wondered what Gustavo thought,' she said, shrugging.
    'Well, better expelled and able to defend yourselves than sitting safely in school without a clue,' said Gustavo.
    'Hear, hear,' said Roberto and Diego enthusiastically.
    'So,' said Gustavo, 'how are you organising this group? Where are you meeting?'
    'Well, mats a bit of a problem now, said Roberto. Dunno where we're going to be able to go.'
    'How about the Shrieking Shack?' suggested Gustavo.
    'Hey, that's an idea!' said Diego excitedly, but Carolina made a sceptical noise and all three of them looked at her, Gustavo's head turning in the flames.
    'Well, Gustavo, it's just that there were only four of you meeting in the Shrieking Shack when you were at school,' said Carolina, 'and all of you could transform into animals and I suppose you could all have squeezed under a single Invisibility Cloak if you'd wanted to. But there are twenty-eight of us and none of us is an Animagus, so we wouldn't need so much an Invisibility Cloak as an Invisibility Marquee - '
    'Fair point,' said Gustavo, looking slightly crestfallen. 'Well, I'm sure you'll come up with somewhere. There used to be a pretty roomy secret passageway behind that big mirror on the fourth floor, you might have enough space to practise jinxes in there.'
    'Pablo and Luis told me it's blocked,' said Roberto, shaking his head. 'Caved in or something.'
    'Oh . . .' said Gustavo, frowning. 'Well, I'll have a think and get back to - '
    He broke off. His face was suddenly tense, alarmed. He turned sideways, apparently looking into the solid brick wall of the fireplace.
    'Gustavo?' said Roberto anxiously.
    But he had vanished. Roberto gaped at the flames for a moment, then turned to look at Diego and Carolina.
    'Why did he - ?'
    Carolina gave a horrified gasp and leapt to her feet, still staring at the fire.
    A hand had appeared amongst the flames, groping as though to catch hold of something; a stubby, short-fingered hand covered in ugly old-fashioned rings.
    The three of them ran for it. At the door of the boys' dormitory Roberto looked back. Umbridge's hand was still making snatching movements amongst the flames, as though she knew exactly where Gustavo's hair had been moments before and was determined to seize it.
- CHAPTER EIGHTEEN -
Dominguez's Army
'Umbridge has been reading your mail, Roberto. There's no other explanation.'
    'You think Umbridge attacked Hedwig?' he said, outraged.
    'I'm almost certain of it,' said Carolina grimly. 'Watch your frog, it's escaping.'
    Roberto pointed his wand at the bullfrog that had been hopping hopefully towards the other side of the table - 'Accio!' - and it zoomed gloomily back into his hand.
    Charms was always one of the best lessons in which to enjoy a private chat; there was generally so much movement and activity that the danger of being overheard was very slight. Today, with the room full of croaking bullfrogs and cawing ravens, and with a heavy downpour of rain clattering and pounding against the classroom windows, Roberto, Diego and Carolina's whispered discussion about how Umbridge had nearly caught Gustavo went quite unnoticed.
    'I've been suspecting this ever since Filch accused you of ordering Dungbombs, because it seemed such a stupid lie,' Carolina whispered. 'I mean, once your letter had been read it would have been quite clear you weren't ordering them, so you wouldn't have been in trouble at all - it's a bit of a feeble joke, isn't it? But then I thought, what if somebody just wanted an excuse to read your mail? Well then, it would be a perfect way for Umbridge to manage it - tip off Filch, let him do the dirty work and confiscate the letter, then either find a way of stealing it from him or else demand to see it - I don't think Filch would object, when's he ever stuck up for a student's rights? Roberto, you're squashing your frog.'
    Roberto looked down; he was indeed squeezing his bullfrog so tightly its eyes were popping; he replaced it hastily upon the desk.
    'It was a very, very close call last night,' said Carolina. 'I just wonder if Umbridge knows how close it was. Silendo.'
    The bullfrog on which she was practising her Silencing Charm was struck dumb mid-croak and glared at her reproachfully.
    'If she'd caught Snuffles - '
    Roberto finished the sentence for her.
    ' - He'd probably be back in Azkaban this morning.' He waved his wand without really concentrating; his bullfrog swelled like a green balloon and emitted a high-pitched whistle.
    'Silencio!' said Carolina hastily, pointing her wand at Roberto's frog, which deflated silently before them. 'Well, he mustn't do it again, that's all. I just don't know how we're going to let him know. We can't send him an owl.'
    'I don't reckon he'll risk it again,' said Diego. 'He's not stupid, he knows she nearly got him. Silencio.'
    The large and ugly raven in front of him let out a derisive caw.
    'Silencio. SILENCIO!'
    The raven cawed more loudly.
    'It's the way you're moving your wand,' said Carolina, watching Diego critically, 'you don't want to wave it, it's more a sharp jab.'
    'Ravens are harder than frogs,' said Diego through clenched teeth.
    'Fine, let's swap,' said Carolina, seizing Diego's raven and replacing it with her own fat bullfrog. 'Silencio!' The raven continued to open and close its sharp beak, but no sound came out.
    'Very good, Miss Fernandez!' said Professor Flitwick's squeaky little voice, making Roberto, Diego and Carolina all jump. 'Now, let me see you try, Mr Lopez'
    'Wha-? Oh - oh, right,' said Diego, very flustered. 'Er - silencio!'
    He jabbed at the bullfrog so hard he poked it in the eye: the frog gave a deafening croak and leapt off the desk.
    It came as no surprise to any of them that Roberto and Diego were given additional practice of the Silencing Charm for homework.
    They were allowed to remain inside over break due to the downpour outside. They found seats in a noisy and overcrowded classroom on the first floor in which Peeves was floating dreamily up near the chandelier, occasionally blowing an ink pellet at the top of somebody's head. They had barely sat down when Angelina came struggling towards them through the groups of gossiping students.
    'I've got permission!' she said. To re-form the Quidditch team!'
    'Excellent!' said Diego and Roberto together.
    'Yeah,' said Angelina, beaming. 'I went to Romero and I think she might have appealed to Dominguez. Anyway, Umbridge had to give in. Ha! So I want you down at the pitch at seven o'clock tonight, all right, because we've got to make up time. You realise we're only three weeks away from our first match?'
    She squeezed away from them, narrowly dodged an ink pellet from Peeves, which hit a nearby first-year instead, and vanished from sight.
    Diego's smile slipped slightly as he looked out of the window, which was now opaque with hammering rain.
    'Hope this clears up. What's up with you, Carolina?'
    She, too, was gazing at the window, but not as though she really saw it. Her eyes were unfocused and there was a frown on her face.
    'Just thinking . . .' she said, still frowning at the rain-washed window.
    'About Siri - Snuffles?' said Roberto.
    'No . . . not exactly . . ." said Carolina slowly. 'More . . . wondering . . . I suppose we're doing the right thing . . . I think . . . aren't
    Roberto and Diego looked at each other.
    'Well, that clears that up,' said Diego. 'It would've been really annoying if you hadn't explained yourself properly.'
    Carolina looked at him as though she had only just realised he was there.
    'I was just wondering,' she said, her voice stronger now, 'whether we're doing the right thing, starting this Defence Against the Dark Arts group.'
    'What?' said Roberto and Diego together.
    'Carolina, it was your idea in the first place!' said Diego indignantly.
    'I know,' said Carolina, twisting her fingers together. 'But after talking to Snuffles . . .'
    'But he's all for it,' said Roberto.
    'Yes,' said Carolina, staring at the window again. 'Yes, that's what made me think maybe it wasn't a good idea after all . . .'
    Peeves floated over them on his stomach, peashooter at the ready; automatically all three of them lifted their bags to cover their heads until he had passed.
