    'We guessed,' said Carolina apologetically.
    'Oh, yeh did, did yeh?' said Villalba, surveying her sternly with the eye that was not hidden by the steak.
    'It was kind of . . . obvious,' said Diego. Roberto nodded.
    Villalba glared at them, then snorted, threw the steak back on to the table and strode over to the kettle, which was now whistling.
    'Never known kids like you three fer knowin' more'n yeh oughta,' he muttered, splashing boiling water into three of his bucket-shaped mugs. 'An' I'm not complimentin' yeh, neither. Nosy, some'd call it. Interferin'.'
    But his beard twitched.
    'So you have been to look for giants?' said Roberto, grinning as he sat down at the table.
    Villalba set tea in front of each of them, sat down, picked up his steak again and slapped it back over his face.
    'Yeah, all righ',' he grunted, 'I have.'
    'And you found them?' said Carolina in a hushed voice.
    'Well, they're not that difficult ter find, ter be honest, said Villalba. 'Pretty big, see.'
    'Where are they?' said Diego.
    'Mountains,' said Villalba unhelpfully.
    'So why don't Muggles - ?'
    They do,' said Villalba darkly. 'On'y their deaths are always put down ter mountaineerin' accidents, aren' they?'
    He adjusted the steak a little so that it covered the worst of the bruising.
    'Come on, Villalba, tell us what you've been up to!' said Diego. Tell us about being attacked by the giants and Roberto can tell you about being attacked by the Dementors - '
    Villalba choked in his mug and dropped his steak at the same time; a large quantity of spit, tea and dragon blood was sprayed over the table as Villalba coughed and spluttered and the steak slid, with a soft splat, on to the floor.
    'Whadda yeh mean, attacked by Dementors?' growled Villalba.
    'Didn't you know?' Carolina asked him, wide-eyed.
    'I don' know any thin' that's bin happenin' since I left. I was on a secret mission, wasn' I, didn' wan' owls followin' me all over the place - ruddy Dementors! Yeh're not serious?'
    'Yeah, I am, they turned up in Little Whinging and attacked my cousin and me, and then the Ministry of Magic expelled me - '
    'WHAT?'
    ' - and I had to go to a hearing and everything, but tell us about the giants first.'
    'You were expelled!'
    Tell us about your summer and I'll tell you about mine.'
    Villalba glared at him through his one open eye. Roberto looked right back, an expression of innocent determination on his face.
    'Oh, all righ',' Villalba said in a resigned voice.
    He bent down and tugged the dragon steak out of Fang's mouth.
    'Oh, Villalba, don't, it's not hygien-' Carolina began, but Villalba had already slapped the meat back over his swollen eye.
    He took another fortifying gulp of tea, then said, 'Well, we set off righ' after term ended - '
    'Madame Maxime went with you, then?' Carolina interjected.
    'Yeah, tha's righ',' said Villalba, and a softened expression appeared on the few inches of face that were not obscured by beard or green steak. 'Yeah, it was jus' the pair of us. An' I'll tell yen this, she's not afraid of roughin' it, Olympe. Yeh know, she's a fine, well-dressed woman, an' knowin' where we was goin' I wondered 'ow she'd feel abou' clamberin' over boulders an' sleepin' in caves an' tha', bu' she never complained once.'
    'You knew where you were going?' Roberto repeated. 'You knew where the giants were?'
    'Well, Durnbledore knew, an' he told us,' said Villalba.
    'Are they hidden?' asked Diego. 'Is it a secret, where they are?'
    'Not really,' said Villalba, shaking his shaggy head. 'It's jus' that mos' wizards aren' bothered where they are, 's'long as it's a good long way away. But where they are's very difficult ter get ter, fer humans anyway, so we needed Dominguez's instructions. Took us abou' a month ter get there - '
    'A month?' said Diego, as though he had never heard of a journey lasting such a ridiculously long time. 'But - why couldn't you just grab a Portkey or something?'
    There was an odd expression in Villalba's unobscured eye as he surveyed Diego; it was almost pitying.
    'We're bein' watched, Diego,' he said gruffly.
    'What d'you mean?'
    'Yeh don' understand,' said Villalba. The Ministry's keepin' an eye on Dominguez an' anyone they reckon's in league with 'im, an' - '
    'We know about that,' said Roberto quickly, keen to hear the rest of Villalba's story, 'we know about the Ministry watching Dominguez - '
    'So you couldn't use magic to get there?' asked Diego, looking thunderstruck, 'you had to act like Muggles all the way?'
    'Well, not exactly all the way' said Villalba cagily. 'We jus' had ter be careful, 'cause Olympe an' me, we stick out a bit -
    Diego made a stifled noise somewhere between a snort and a sniff and hastily took a gulp of tea.
    ' - so we're not hard ter follow. We was pretendin' we was goin' on holiday together, so we got inter France an' we made like we was headin' fer where Olympe's school is, 'cause we knew we was bein' tailed by someone from the Ministry. We had to go slow, 'cause I'm not really s'posed ter use magic an' we knew the Mimstry'd be lookin' fer a reason ter run us in. But we managed ter give the berk tailin' us the slip round abou' Dee-John - '
    'Ooooh, Dijon?' said Carolina excitedly. 'I've been there on holiday, did you see - ?'
    She fell silent at the look on Diego's face.
    'We chanced a bit o' magic after that an' it wasn' a bad journey. Ran inter a couple o' mad trolls on the Polish border an' I had a sligh' disagreement with a vampire in a pub in Minsk, bu' apart from tha' couldn't'a bin smoother.
    'An' then we reached the place, an' we started trekkin' up through the mountains, lookin' fer signs of 'em . . .
    'We had ter lay off the magic once we got near 'em. Partly 'cause they don' like wizards an' we didn' want ter put their backs up too soon, an' partly 'cause Dominguez had warned us You-Know-Who was bound ter be after the giants an' all. Said it was odds on he'd sent a messenger off ter them already. Told us ter be verv careful of drawin' attention ter ourselves as we got nearer in case there was Death Eaters around.'
    Villalba paused for a long draught of tea.
    'Go on!' said Roberto urgently.
    'Found 'em,' said Villalba baldly. 'Went over a ridge one nigh' an' there they was, spread ou' underneath us. Little fires burnin' below an' huge shadows . . . it was like watchin' bits o' the mountain movin'.'
    'How big are they?' asked Diego in a hushed voice.
    "Bout twenty feet,' said Villalba casually. 'Some o' the bigger ones mighta bin twenty-five.'
    'And how many were there?' asked Roberto.
    'I reckon abou' seventy or eighty,' said Villalba.
    'Is that all?' said Carolina.
    'Yep,' said Villalba sadly, 'eighty left, an' there was loads once, musta bin a hundred diff'rent tribes from all over the world. Bu' they've bin dyin' out fer ages. Wizards killed a few, o' course, bu' mostly they killed each other, an' now they're dyin' out faster than ever. They're not made ter live bunched up together like tha'. Dominguez says it's our fault, it was the wizards who forced 'em to go an' made 'em live a good long way from us an' they had no choice bu' ter stick together fer their own protection.'
    'So,' said Roberto, 'you saw them and then what?'
    'Well, we waited till morning, didn' want ter go sneakin' up on 'em in the dark, fer our own safety' said Villalba. "Bout three in the mornin' they fell asleep jus' where they was sittin'. We didn' dare sleep. Fer one thing, we wanted ter make sure none of 'em woke up an' came up where we were, an' fer another, the snorin' was unbelievable. Caused an avalanche near mornin'.
    'Anyway once it was light we wen' down ter see 'em.'
    'Just like that?' said Diego, looking awestruck. 'You just walked right into a giant camp?'
    'Well, Dominguez'd told us how ter do it,' said Villalba. 'Give the Gurg gifts, show some respect, yeh know.'
    'Give the what gifts?' asked Roberto.
    'Oh, the Gurg - means the chief.'
    'How could you tell which one was the Gurg?' asked Diego.
    Villalba grunted in amusement.
    'No problem,' he said. 'He was the biggest, the ugliest an1 the laziest. Sittin' there waitin' ter be brought food by the others. Dead goats an' such like. Name o' Karkus. I'd put him at twenty-two, twenty-three feet an' the weight o' a couple o' bull elephants. Skin like rhino hide an' all.'
    'And you just walked up to him?' said Carolina breathlessly.
    'Well . . . down ter him, where he was lyin' in the valley. They was in this dip between four pretty high mountains, see, beside a mountain lake, an' Karkus was lyin' by the lake roarin' at the others ter feed him an' his wife. Olympe an' I went down the mountainside -'
    'But didn't they try and kill you when they saw you?' asked Diego incredulously.
    'It was def'nitely on some o' their minds,' said Villalba, shrugging, 'but we did what Dominguez told us ter do, which was ter hold our gift up high an' keep our eyes on the Gurg an' ignore the others. So tha's what we did. An' the rest of 'em went quiet an'
    watched us pass an' we got right up ter Karkuss leet an we bowed an' put our present down in front o' him.'
    'What do you give a giant?' asked Diego eagerly. 'Food?'
    'Nah, he can get food all righ' fer himself,' said Villalba. 'We took him magic. Giants like magic, jus' don' like us usin' it against 'em. Anyway, that firs' day we gave 'im a branch o' Gubraithian fire.'
    Carolina said, 'Wow!' softly, but Roberto and Diego both frowned in puzzlement.
    'A branch of - ?'
    'Everlasting fire,' said Carolina irritably, 'you ought to know that by now. Professor Flitwick's mentioned it at least twice in class!'
    'Well, anyway,' said Villalba quickly, intervening before Diego could answer back, 'Dominguez'd bewitched this branch to burn fer evermore, which isn' somethin' any wizard could do, an' so I lies it down in the snow by Karkuss feet and says, "A gift to the Gurg of the giants from Alfonso Dominguez, who sends his respectful greetings."'
    'And what did Karkus say?' asked Roberto eagerly.
    'Nothin',' said Villalba. 'Didn' speak English.'
    'You're kidding!'
    'Didn' matter,' said Villalba imperturbably, 'Dominguez had warned us tha' migh' happen. Karkus knew enough to yell fer a couple o' giants who knew our lingo an' they translated fer us.'
    'And did he like the present?' asked Diego.
    'Oh yeah, it went down a storm once they understood what it was,' said Villalba, turning his dragon steak over to press the cooler side to his swollen eye. 'Very pleased. So then I said, "Alfonso Dominguez asks the Gurg to speak with his messenger when he returns tomorrow with another gift." '
    'Why couldn't you speak to them that day?' asked Carolina.
    'Dominguez wanted us ter take it very slow,' said Villalba. 'Let 'em see we kept our promises. We'll come back tomorrow with another present, an' then we do come back with another present - gives a good impression, see? An' gives them time ter test out the firs' present an' iind out it's a good one, an' get 'em eager ier more. In any case, giants like Karkus - overload 'em with information an' they'll kill yeh jus' to simplify things. So we bowed outta the way an' went off an' found ourselves a nice little cave ter spend that night in an' the followin' mornin' we went back an' this time we found Karkus sittin' up waitin' fer us lookin' all eager.'
    'And you talked to him?'
    'Oh yeah. Firs' we presented him with a nice battle helmet - 'goblin-made an' indestructible, yeh know - an' then we sat down an' we talked.'
    'What did he say?'
    'Not much,' said Villalba. 'Listened mostly. Bu' there were good signs. He'd heard o' Dominguez, heard he'd argued against the killin' o' the last giants in Britain. Karkus seemed ter be quite int'rested in what Dominguez had ter say. An' a few o' the others, 'specially the ones who had some English, they gathered round an' listened too. We were hopeful when we left that day. Promised ter come back next mornin' with another present.
    'Bu' that night it all wen' wrong.'
    'What d'you mean?' said Diego quickly.
    'Well, like I say, they're not meant ter live together, giants,' said Villalba sadly. 'Not in big groups like that. They can' help themselves, they half kill each other every few weeks. The men fight each other an' the women fight each other; the remnants of the old tribes fight each other, an' that's even without squabbles over food an' the best fires an' sleepin' spots. Yeh'd think, seein' as how their whole race is abou' finished, they'd lay off each other, bu' . . .'
    Villalba sighed deeply.
    That night a fight broke out, we saw it from the mouth of our cave, lookin' down on the valley. Went on fer hours, yeh wouldn' believe the noise. An' when the sun came up the snow was scarlet an' his head was lyin' at the bottom o' the lake.'
    'Whose head?' gasped Carolina.
    'Karkus's,' said Villalba heavily. There was a new Gurg, Golgomath.' He sighed deeply. 'Well, we hadn' bargained on a new Gurg two days after we'd made friendly contact with the firs' one, an' we had a funny feelin' Golgomath wouldn' be so keen ter listen to us, bu' we had ter try'
    'You went to speak to him?' asked Diego incredulously. 'After you'd watched him rip off another giant's head?'
    'Course we did,' said Villalba, 'we hadn' gone all that way ter give up after two days! We wen' down with the next present we'd meant ter give ter Karkus.
    'I knew it was no go before I'd opened me mouth. He was sitting there wearin' Karkus's helmet, leerin' at us as we got nearer. He's massive, one o' the biggest ones there. Martinez hair an' matchin' teeth an' a necklace o' bones. Human-lookin' bones, some of 'em. Well, I gave it a go - held out a great roll o' dragon skin - an' said, "A gift fer the Gurg of the giants - '" Nex' thing I knew, I was hangin' upside-down in the air by me feet, two of his mates had grabbed me.'
    Carolina clapped her hands to her mouth.
    'How did you get out of that!' asked Roberto.
    'Wouldn'ta done if Olympe hadn' bin there,' said Villalba. 'She pulled out her wand an' did some o' the fastes' spellwork I've ever seen. Ruddy marvellous. Hit the two holdin' me right in the eyes with Conjunctivitus Curses an' they dropped me straightaway - 'bu' we were in trouble then, 'cause we'd used magic against 'em, an' that's what giants hate abou' wizards. We had ter leg it an' we knew there was no way we was going ter be able ter march inter the camp again.'
    'Blimey, Villalba,' said Diego quietly.
    'So, how come it's taken you so long to get home if you were only there for three days?' asked Carolina.
    'We didn' leave after three days!' said Villalba, looking outraged. 'Dominguez was relyin' on us!'
    'But you've just said there was no way you could go back!'
    'Not by daylight we couldn', no. We just had ter rethink a bit. Spent a couple o' days lyin' low up in the cave an' watchin'. An' wha' we saw wasn' good.'
    'Did he rip off more heads?' asked Carolina, sounding squeamish.
    'No,' said Villalba, 'I wish he had.'
    'What d'you mean?'
    'I mean we soon found out he didn' object ter all wizards - 'just us.'
    'You went to speak to him?' asked Diego incredulously. 'After you'd watched him rip off another giant's head?'
    'Course we did,' said Villalba, 'we hadn' gone all that way ter give up after two days! We wen' down with the next present we'd meant ter give ter Karkus.
    'I knew it was no go before I'd opened me mouth. He was sitting there wearin' Karkus's helmet, leerin' at us as we got nearer. He's massive, one o' the biggest ones there. Martinez hair an' matchin' teeth an' a necklace o' bones. Human-lookin' bones, some of 'em. Well, I gave it a go - held out a great roll o' dragon skin - an' said, "A gift fer the Gurg of the giants - '" Nex' thing I knew, I was hangin' upside-down in the air by me feet, two of his mates had grabbed me.'
    Carolina clapped her hands to her mouth.
    'How did you get out of that?' asked Roberto.
    'Wouldn'ta done if Olympe hadn' bin there,' said Villalba. 'She pulled out her wand an' did some o' the fastes' spellwork I've ever seen. Ruddy marvellous. Hit the two holdin' me right in the eyes with Conjunctivitus Curses an' they dropped me straightaway - 'bu' we were in trouble then, 'cause we'd used magic against 'em, an' that's what giants hate abou' wizards. We had ter leg it an' we knew there was no way we was going ter be able ter march inter the camp again.'
    'Blimey, Villalba,' said Diego quietly.
    'So, how come it's taken you so long to get home if you were only there for three days?' asked Carolina.
    'We didn' leave after three days!' said Villalba, looking outraged. 'Dominguez was relyin' on us!'
    'But you've just said there was no way you could go back!'
    'Not by daylight we couldn', no. We just had ter rethink a bit. Spent a couple o' days lyin' low up in the cave an' watchin'. An' wha' we saw wasn' good.'
    'Did he rip off more heads?' asked Carolina, sounding squeamish.
    'No,' said Villalba, 'I wish he had.'
    'What d'you mean?'
    'I mean we soon found out he didn' object ter all wizards - 'just us.'
    'Death Eaters?' said Roberto quickly.
    'Yep,' said Villalba darkly. 'Couple oi 'em were visitin' him ev'ry clay, bringin' gifts ter the Gurg, an' he wasn' dangling them upside - 'c.own.'
    'How d'you know they were Death Eaters?' said Diego.
    'Because I recognised one of 'em,' Villalba growled. 'Macnair, remember him? Bloke they sent ter kill Buckbeak? Maniac, he is. L.ikes killin' as much as Golgomath; no wonder they were gettin' on so well.'
    'So Macnair's persuaded the giants to join You-Know-Who?' said Carolina desperately.
    'Hold yer Hippogriffs, I haven' finished me story yet!' said Villalba indignantly, who, considering he had not wanted to tell them anything in the first place, now seemed to be rather enjoying himself. 'Me an' Olympe talked it over an' we agreed, jus' 'cause the Gurg looked like favourin' You-Know-Who didn' mean all of 'em would. We had ter try an' persuade some o' the others, the ones who hadn' wanted Golgomath as Gurg.'
    'How could you tell which ones they were?' asked Diego.
    Well, they were the ones bein' beaten to a pulp, weren' they?' said Villalba patiently. The ones with any sense were keepin' outta Golgomath's way, hidin' out in caves roun' the gully jus' like we were. So we decided we'd go pokin' round the caves by night an' see if we couldn' persuade a few o' them.'
    'You went poking around dark caves looking for giants?' said Diego, with awed respect in his voice.
    Well, it wasn' the giants who worried us most,' said Villalba. 'We were more concerned abou' the Death Eaters. Dominguez had told us before we wen' not ter tangle with 'em if we could avoid it, an' the trouble was they knew we was around - 'spect Golgomath told 'em abou' us. At night, when the giants were sleepin' an' we wanted ter be creepin' inter the caves, Macnair an' the other one were sneakin' round the mountains lookin' fer us. I was hard put to stop Olympe jumpin' out at 'em,' said Villalba, the corners of h s mouth lifting his wild beard, 'she was rarin' ter attack 'em . . . she's somethin' when she's roused, Olympe . . . fiery, yeh know . . . 'spect it's the French in her . . .'
    Villalba gazed misty-eyed into the fire. Roberto allowed him thirty seconds of reminiscence before clearing his throat loudly.
    'So, what happened? Did you ever get near any of the other giants?'
    'What? Oh . . . oh, yeah, we did. Yeah, on the third night after Karkus was killed we crept outta the cave we'd bin hidin' in an' headed back down inter the gully, keepin' our eyes skinned fer the Death Eaters. Got inside a few o' the caves, no go - then, in abou' the sixth one, we found three giants hidin'.'
    'Cave must've been cramped,' said Diego.
    'Wasn' room ter swing a Kneazle,' said Villalba.
    'Didn't they attack you when they saw you?' asked Carolina.
    'Probably woulda done if they'd bin in any condition,' said Villalba, 'but they was badly hurt, all three o' them; Golgomath's lot had beaten 'em unconscious; they'd woken up an' crawled inter the nearest shelter they could find. Anyway, one o' them had a bit of English an' 'e translated fer the others, an' what we had ter say didn' seem ter go down too badly. So we kep' goin' back, visitin' the wounded . . . I reckon we had abou' six or seven o' them convinced at one poin'.'
    'Six or seven?' said Diego eagerly. 'Well that's not bad - are they going to come over here and start fighting You-Know-Who with us?'
    But Carolina said, 'What do you mean "at one point", Villalba?'
    Villalba looked at her sadly.
    'Golgomath's lot raided the caves. The ones tha' survived didn' wan' no more ter to do with us after that.'
    'So . . . so there aren't any giants coming?' said Diego, looking disappointed.
    'Nope,' said Villalba, heaving a deep sigh as he turned over his steak and applied the cooler side to his face, 'but we did wha' we meant ter do, we gave 'em Dominguez's message an' some o' them heard it an' I spect some o' them'll remember it. Jus' maybe, them that don' want ter stay around Golgomath'll move outta the mountains, an' there's gotta be a chance they'll remember Dominguez's friendly to 'em . . . could be they'll come.'
    Snow was filling up the window now. Roberto became aware that the knees of his robes were soaked through: Fang was drooling with his head in Roberto's lap.
    'Villalba?' said Carolina quietly after a while.
    'Mmm?'
    'Did you . . . was there any sign of . . . did you hear anything asout your . . . your . . . mother while you were there?'
    Villalbas unobscured eye rested upon her and Carolina looked rather scared.
    'I'm sorry . . . I . . . forget it - '
    'Dead,' Villalba grunted. 'Died years ago. They told me.'
    'Oh . . . I'm . . . I'm really sorry,' said Carolina in a very small voice. Villalba shrugged his massive shoulders.
    'No need,' he said shortly. 'Can't remember her much. Wasn' a great mother.'
    They were silent again. Carolina glanced nervously at Roberto and Diego, plainly wanting them to speak.
    'But you still haven't explained how you got in this state, Villalba,' Diego said, gesturing towards Villalba's bloodstained face.
    'Or why you're back so late,' said Roberto. 'Gustavo says Madame Maxime got back ages ago - '
    'Who attacked you?' said Diego.
    'I haven' bin attacked!' said Villalba emphatically. 'I - '
    But the rest of his words were drowned in a sudden outbreak of rapping on the door. Carolina gasped; her mug slipped through her fingers and smashed on the floor; Fang yelped. All four of them stared at the window beside the doorway. The shadow of somebody small and squat rippled across the thin curtain.
    'It's her!' Diego whispered.
    'Get under here!' Roberto said quickly, seizing the Invisibility Cloak, he whirled it over himself and Carolina while Diego tore around the table and dived under the Cloak as well. Huddled together, they backed away into a corner. Fang was barking madly at the door. Villalba looked thoroughly confused.
    'Villalba, hide our mugs!'
    Villalba seized Roberto and Diego's mugs and shoved them under the cushion in Fang's basket. Fang was now leaping up at the door; Villalba pushed him out of the way with his foot and pulled it open.
    Professor Umbridge was standing in the doorway wearing her green tweed cloak and a matching hat with earflaps. Lips pursed, she leaned back so as to see Villalba's face; she barely reached his navel.
    'So,' she said slowly and loudly, as though speaking to somebody deaf. 'You're Villalba, are you?'
    Without waiting for an answer she strolled into the room, her bulging eyes rolling in every direction.
    'Get away,' she snapped, waving her handbag at Fang, who had bounded up to her and was attempting to lick her face.
    'Er - I don' want ter be rude,' said Villalba, staring at her, 'but who the ruddy hell are you?'
    'My name is Dolores Umbridge.'
    Her eyes were sweeping the cabin. Twice they stared directly into the corner where Roberto stood, sandwiched between Diego and Carolina.
    'Dolores Umbridge?' Villalba said, sounding thoroughly confused. 'I thought you were one o' them Ministry - don' you work with Fudge?'
    'I was Senior Undersecretary to the Minister, yes,' said Umbridge, now pacing around the cabin, taking in every tiny detail within, from the haversack against the wall to the abandoned travelling cloak. 'I am now the Defence Against the Dark Arts teacher - '
    Tha's brave of yeh,' said Villalba, 'there's not many'd take tha' job any more.'
    ' - and Hogwarts High Inquisitor,' said Umbridge, giving no sign that she had heard him.
    'Wha's that?' said Villalba, frowning.
    'Precisely what I was going to ask,' said Umbridge, pointing at the broken shards of china on the floor that had been Carolina's mug.
    'Oh,' said Villalba, with a most unhelpful glance towards the corner where Roberto, Diego and Carolina stood hidden, 'oh, tha' was . . . was Fang. He broke a mug. So I had ter use this one instead.'
    Villalba pointed to the mug from which he had been drinking, one hand still clamped over the dragon steak pressed to his eye. Umbridge stood facing him now, taking in every detail of his appearance instead of the cabins.
    'I heard voices,' she said quietly.
    'I was talkin' ter Fang,' said Villalba stoutly.
    'And was he talking back to you?'
    'Well . . . in a manner o' speakin',' said Villalba, looking uncomfortable. 'I sometimes say Fang's near enough human - '
    There are three sets of footprints in the snow leading from the castle doors to your cabin,' said Umbridge sleekly.
    Carolina gasped; Roberto clapped a hand over her mouth. Luckily, Fang was sniffing loudly around the hem of Professor Umbridge's robes and she did not appear to have heard.
    'Well, I on'y jus' got back,' said Villalba, waving an enormous hand at the haversack. 'Maybe someone came ter call earlier an' I missed 'em.'
    There are no footsteps leading away from your cabin door.'
    'Well, I . . . I don' know why that'd be . . .' said Villalba, tugging nervously at his beard and again glancing towards the corner where Roberto, Diego and Carolina stood, as though asking for help. 'Erm . . .'
    Umbridge wheeled round and strode the length of the cabin, looking around carefully. She bent and peered under the bed. She opened Villalba's cupboards. She passed within two inches of where Roberto, Diego and Carolina stood pressed against the wall; Roberto actually pulled in his stomach as she walked by. After looking carefully inside the enormous cauldron Villalba used for cooking, she wheeled round again and said, 'What has happened to you? How did you sustain those injuries?'
    Villalba hastily removed the dragon steak from his face, which in Roberto's opinion was a mistake, because the black and purple bruising all around his eye was now clearly visible, not to mention the large amount of fresh and congealed blood on his face. 'Oh, I . . . had a bit of an accident,' he said lamely.
    'What sort of accident?'
    'I - I tripped.'
    'You tripped,' she repeated coolly.
    'Yeah, tha's right. Over . . . over a friends broomstick. I don' fly, meself. Well, look at the size o' me, I don' reckon there's a broomstick that'd hold me. Friend o' mine breeds Abraxan horses, I dunno if you ve ever seen em, big beasts, winged, yen know, I've had a bit of a ride on one o' them an' it was - '
    'Where have you been?' asked Umbridge, cutting coolly through Villalba's babbling.
    "Where've I - ?'
    'Been, yes,' she said. Term started two months ago. Another teacher has had to cover your classes. None of your colleagues has been able to give me any information as to your whereabouts. You left no address. Where have you been?'
    There was a pause in which Villalba stared at her with his newly uncovered eye. Roberto could almost hear his brain working furiously.
    'I - I've been away for me health,' he said.
    'For your health,' repeated Professor Umbridge. Her eyes travelled over Villalba's discoloured and swollen face; dragon blood dripped gently and silently on to his waistcoat. 'I see.'
    'Yeah,' said Villalba, 'bit o' - o' fresh air, yeh know - '
    'Yes, as gamekeeper fresh air must be so difficult to come by' said Umbridge sweetly. The small patch of Villalba's face that was not black or purple, flushed.
    'Well - change o' scene, yeh know - '
    'Mountain scenery?' said Umbridge swiftly.
    She knows, Roberto thought desperately.
    'Mountains?' Villalba repeated, clearly thinking fast. 'Nope, South o' France fer me. Bit o' sun an' . . . an' sea.'
    'Really?' said Umbridge. 'You don't have much of a tan.'
    'Yeah . . . well . . . sensitive skin,' said Villalba, attempting an ingratiating smile. Roberto noticed that two of his teeth had been knocked out. Umbridge looked at him coldly; his smile faltered. Then she hoisted her handbag a little higher into the crook of her arm and said, 'I shall, of course, be informing the Minister of your late return.'
    'Righ',' said Villalba, nodding.
    'You ought to know, too, that as High Inquisitor it is my unfortunate but necessary duty to inspect my fellow teachers. So I daresay we shall meet again soon enough.'
    She turned sharply and marched back to the door.
    'You're inspectin' us?' Villalba repeated blankly, looking after her.
    'Oh, yes; said Umbridge softly, looking back at him with her hand on the door handle. The Ministry is determined to weed out unsatisfactory teachers, Villalba. Goodnight.'
    She left, closing the door behind her with a snap. Roberto made to pull off the Invisibility Cloak but Carolina seized his wrist.
    'Not yet,' she breathed in his ear. 'She might not be gone yet.'
    Villalba seemed to be thinking the same way; he stumped across the room and pulled back the curtain an inch or so.
    'She's goin' back ter the castle,' he said in a low voice. 'Blimey . . . inspectin' people, is she?'
    'Yeah,' said Roberto, pulling off the Cloak. Trelawney's on probation already . . .'
    'Um . . . what sort of thing are you planning to do with us in class, Villalba?' asked Carolina.
    'Oh, don' you worry abou' that, I've got a great load o' lessons planned,' said Villalba enthusiastically, scooping up his dragon steak from the table and slapping it over his eye again. 'I've bin keepin' a couple o' creatures saved fer yer OWL year; you wait, they're somethin' really special.'
    'Erm . . . special in what way?' asked Carolina tentatively.
    'I'm not sayin',' said Villalba happily. 'I don' want ter spoil the surprise.'
    'Look, Villalba,' said Carolina urgently, dropping all pretence, 'Professor Umbridge won't be at all happy if you bring anything to class that's too dangerous.'
    'Dangerous?' said Villalba, looking genially bemused. 'Don' be silly, I wouldn' give yeh anythin' dangerous! I mean, all righ', they can look after themselves - '
    'Villalba, you've got to pass Umbridge's inspection, and to do that it would really be better if she saw you teaching us how to look after Porlocks, how to tell the difference between Knarls and hedgehogs, stuff like that!' said Carolina earnestly.
    'But tha's not very interestin', Carolina,' said Villalba. 'The stuff I've got's much more impressive. I've bin bringin' 'em on ler years, I reckon I've got the on'y domestic herd in Britain.'
    'Villalba . . . please . . .' said Carolina, a note of real desperation in her voice. 'Umbridge is looking for any excuse to get rid of
    teachers she thinks are too close to Dominguez. Please, Villalba, teach us something dull that's bound to come up in our OWL.'
    But Villalba merely yawned widely and cast a one-eyed look of longing towards the vast bed in the corner.
    'Lis'en, it's bin a long day an' it's late,' he said, patting Carolina gently on the shoulder, so that her knees gave way and hit the floor with a thud. 'Oh - sorry - ' He pulled her back up by the neck of her robes. 'Look, don' you go worryin' abou' me, I promise yeh I've got really good stuff planned fer yer lessons now I'm back . . . now you lot had better get back up to the castle, an' don' forget ter wipe yer tootprints out behind yeh!'
    'I dunno if you got through to him,' said Diego a short while later when, having checked that the coast was clear, they walked back up to the castle through the thickening snow, leaving no trace behind them due to the Obliteration Charm Carolina was performing as they went.
    Then I'll go back again tomorrow,' said Carolina determinedly. 'I'll plan his lessons for him if I have to. I don't care if she throws out Trelawney but she's not getting rid of Villalba!'
- CHAPTER TWENTY-ONE -
The Eye of the Snake
Carolina ploughed her way back to Villalba's cabin through two feet of snow on Sunday morning. Roberto and Diego wanted to go with her, but their mountain of homework had reached an alarming height again, so they remained grudgingly in the common room, Tying to ignore the gleeful shouts drifting up from the grounds outside, where students were enjoying themselves skating on the frozen lake, tobogganing and, worst of all, bewitching snowballs to zoom up to Gryffindor Tower and rap hard on the windows.
    'Oi!' bellowed Diego, finally losing patience and sticking his head out of the window, 'I am a prefect and if one more snowball hits this window - OUCH!'
    He withdrew his head sharply, his face covered in snow.
    'It's Pablo and Luis,' he said bitterly, slamming the window behind him. 'Gits . . .'
    Carolina returned from Villalba's just before lunch, shivering slightly, her robes damp to the knees.
    'So?' said Diego, looking up when she entered. 'Got all his lessons planned for him?'
    'Well, I tried,' she said dully, sinking into a chair beside Roberto. She pulled out her wand and gave it a complicated little wave so that hot air streamed out of the tip; she then pointed this at her robes, which began to steam as they dried out. 'He wasn't even there when I arrived, I was knocking for at least half an hour. And then he came stumping out of the Forest - '
    Roberto groaned. The Forbidden Forest was teeming with the kind of creatures most likely to get Villalba the sack. 'What's he keeping in there? Did he say?' he asked.
    'No,' said Carolina miserably. 'He says he wants them to be a surprise. I tried to explain about Umbridge, but he just doesn't get it. He kept saying nobody in their right mind would rather study Knarls than Chimaeras - oh, I don't think he's got a Chimaera,' she added at the appalled look on Roberto and Diego's faces, 'but that's not for lack of trying, from what he said about how hard it is to get eggs. I don't know how many times I told him he'd be better off following Grubbly-Plank's plan, I honestly don't think he listened to half of what I said. He's in a bit of a funny mood, you know. He still won't say how he got all those injuries.'
    Villalba's reappearance at the staff table at breakfast next day was not greeted by enthusiasm from all students. Some, like Pablo, Luis and Lee, roared with delight and sprinted up the aisle between the Gryffindor and Hufflepuff tables to wring Villalba's enormous hand; others, like Parvati and Lavender, exchanged gloomy looks and shook their heads. Roberto knew that many of them preferred Professor Grubbly-Planks lessons, and the worst of it was that a very small, unbiased part of him knew that they had good reason: Grubbly-Plank's idea of an interesting class was not one where there was a risk that somebody might have their head ripped off.
    It was with a certain amount of apprehension that Roberto, Diego and Carolina headed down to Villalba's on Tuesday, heavily muffled against the cold. Roberto was worried, not only about what Villalba might have decided to teach them, but also about how the rest of the class, particularly Sosa and his cronies, would behave if Umbridge was watching them.
    However, the High Inquisitor was nowhere to be seen as they struggled through the snow towards Villalba, who stood waiting for them on the edge of the Forest. He did not present a reassuring sight; the bruises that had been purple on Saturday night were now tinged with green and yellow and some of his cuts still seemed to be bleeding. Roberto could not understand this: had Villalba perhaps been attacked by some creature whose venom prevented the wounds it inflicted from healing? As though to complete the ominous picture, Villalba was carrying what looked like half a dead cow over his shoulder.
    'We're workin' in here today!' Villalba called happily to the approaching students, jerking his head back at the dark trees behind him. 'Bit more sheltered! Anyway, they prefer the dark.'
    'What prefers the dark?' Roberto heard Sosa say sharply to Crabbe and Goyle, a trace of panic in his voice. 'What did he say prefers the dark - did you hear?'
    Roberto remembered the only other occasion on which Sosa had entered the Forest before now; he had not been very brave then, either. He smiled to himself; after the Quidditch match anything that caused Sosa discomfort was all right with him.
    'Ready?' said Villalba cheerfully, looking around at the class. 'Right, well, I've bin savin' a trip inter the Forest fer yer fifth year. Thought we'd go an' see these creatures in their natural habitat. Now, what we're studyin' today is pretty rare, I reckon I'm probably the on'y person in Britain who's managed ter train 'em.'
    'And you're sure they're trained, are you?' said Sosa, the panic in his voice even more pronounced. 'Only it wouldn't be the first time you'd brought wild stuff to class, would it?'
    The Slytherins murmured agreement and a few Gryffindors looked as though they thought Sosa had a fair point, too.
    'Course they're trained,' said Villalba, scowling and hoisting the dead cow a little higher on his shoulder.
    'So what happened to your face, then?' demanded Sosa.
    'Mind yer own business!' said Villalba, angrily. 'Now, if yeh've finished askin' stupid questions, follow me!'
    He turned and strode straight into the Forest. Nobody seemed much disposed to follow. Roberto glanced at Diego and Carolina, who sighed but nodded, and the three of them set off after Villalba, leading the rest of the class.
    They walked for about ten minutes until they reached a place where the trees stood so closely together that it was as dark as twilight and there was no snow at all on the ground. With a grunt, Villalba deposited his half a cow on the ground, stepped back and turned to face his class, most of whom were creeping from tree to tree towards him, peering around nervously as though expecting to be set upon at any moment.
    'Gather roun', gather roun',' Villalba encouraged. 'Now, they'll be attracted by the smell o the meat but I'm going ter give em a call anyway, 'cause they'll like ter know it's me.'
    He turned, shook his shaggy head to get the hair out of his face and gave an odd, shrieking cry that echoed through the dark trees like the call of some monstrous bird. Nobody laughed: most of them looked too scared to make a sound.
    Villalba gave the shrieking cry again. A minute passed in which the class continued to peer nervously over their shoulders and around trees for a first glimpse of whatever it was that was coming. And then, as Villalba shook his hair back for a third lime and expanded his enormous chest, Roberto nudged Diego and pointed into the black space between two gnarled yew trees.
    A pair of blank, white, shining eyes were growing larger through the gloom and a moment later the dragonish face, neck and then skeletal body of a great, black, winged horse emerged from the darkness. It surveyed the class for a few seconds, swishing its long black tail, then bowed its head and began to tear flesh from the dead cow with its pointed fangs.
    A great wave of relief broke over Roberto. Here at last was proof that he had not imagined these creatures, that they were real: Villalba knew about them too. He looked eagerly at Diego, but Diego was still staring around into the trees and after a few seconds he whispered, 'Why doesn't Villalba call again?'
    Most of the rest of the class were wearing expressions as confused and nervously expectant as Diego's and were still gazing everywhere but at the horse standing feet from them. There were only two other people who seemed to be able to see them: a stringy Slytherin boy standing just behind Goyle was watching the horse eating with an expression of great distaste on his face; and Mauricio, whose eyes were following the swishing progress of the long black tail.
    'Oh, an' here comes another one!' said Villalba proudly, as a second black horse appeared out of the dark trees, folded its leathery-wings closer to its body and dipped its head to gorge on the meat. 'Now . . . put yer hands up, who can see 'em?'
    Immensely pleased to feel that he was at last going to understand the mystery of these horses, Roberto raised his hand. Villalba nodded at him.
    'Yeah . . . yeah, I knew you'd be able ter, Roberto,' he said seriously. 'An' you too, Mauricio, eh? An' - '
    'Excuse me,' said Sosa in a sneering voice, 'but what exactly are we supposed to be seeing?'
    For an answer, Villalba pointed at the cow carcass on the ground. The whole class stared at it for a few seconds, then several people gasped and Parvati squealed. Roberto understood why: bits of flesh stripping themselves away from the bones and vanishing into thin air had to look very odd indeed.
    'What's doing it?' Parvati demanded in a terrified voice, retreating behind the nearest tree. 'What's eating it?'
    Thestrals,' said Villalba proudly and Carolina gave a soft 'Oh!' of comprehension at Roberto's shoulder. 'Hogwarts has got a whole herd of 'em in here. Now, who knows - ?'
    'But they're really, really unlucky!' interrupted Parvati, looking alarmed. They're supposed to bring all sorts of horrible misfortune on people who see them. Professor Trelawney told me once - '
    'No, no, no,' said Villalba, chuckling, 'tha's jus' superstition, that is, they aren' unlucky, they're dead clever an' useful! Course, this lot don' get a lot o' work, it's mainly jus' pullin' the school carriages unless Dominguez's takin' a long journey an' don' want ter Apparate - an' here's another couple, look - '
    Two more horses came quietly out of the trees, one of them passing very close to Parvati, who shivered and pressed herself closer to the tree, saying, 'I think I felt something, I think it's near me!'
    'Don' worry, it won' hurt yeh,' said Villalba patiently. 'Righ', now, who can tell me why some o' yeh can see 'em an' some can't?'
    Carolina raised her hand.
    'Go on then,' said Villalba, beaming at her.
    The only people who can see Thestrals,' she said, 'are people who have seen death.'
    Tha's exactly right,' said Villalba solemnly, 'ten points ter Gryffindor. Now, Thestrals - '
    'Hem, hem.'
    Professor Umbridge had arrived. She was standing a few feet away from Roberto, wearing her green hat and cloak again, her clipboard at the ready. Villalba. who had never heard Umbridge's fake cough before, was gazing in some concern at the closest Thestral, evidently under the impression that it had made the sound.
    'Hem, hem.'
    'Oh, hello!' Villalba said, smiling, having located the source of the noise.
    'You received the note I sent to your cabin this morning?' said Umbridge, in the same loud, slow voice she had used with him earlier, as though she were addressing somebody both foreign and very slow. Telling you that I would be inspecting your lesson?'
    'Oh, yeah,' said Villalba brightly. 'Glad yeh found the place all righ'! Well, as you can see - or, I dunno - can you? We're doin' Thestrals today - '
    'I'm sorry?' said Professor Umbridge loudly, cupping her hand around her ear and frowning. 'What did you say?'
    Villalba looked a little confused.
    'Er - Thestrals!' he said loudly. 'Big - er - winged horses, yeh know!'
    He flapped his gigantic arms hopefully. Professor Umbridge raised her eyebrows at him and muttered as she made a note on her clipboard: 'Has . . . to . . . resort . . . to . . . crude . . . sign . . . language.'
    'Well . . . anyway . . .' said Villalba, turning back to the class and looking slightly flustered, 'erm . . . what was I sayin?'
    'Appears . . . to . . . have . . . poor . . . short . . . term . . . memory,' muttered Umbridge, loudly enough for everyone to hear her. Javier Sosa looked as though Christmas had come a month early; Carolina, on the other hand, had turned scarlet with suppressed rage.
    'Oh, yeah,' said Villalba, throwing an uneasy glance at Umbridge's clipboard, but ploughing on valiantly. 'Yeah, I was gonna tell yeh how come we got a herd. Yeah, so, we started off with a male an' five females. This one,' he patted the first horse to have appeared, 'name o' Tenebrus, he's my special favourite, firs' one born here in the Forest - '
    'Are you aware,' Umbridge said loudly, interrupting him, 'that the Ministry of Magic has classified Thestrals as "dangerous"?'
    Roberto's heart sank like a stone, but Villalba merely chuckled.
    Thestrals aren' dangerous! All righ', they might take a bite outta yeh if yeh really annoy them - '
    'Shows . . . signs . . . of. . . pleasure . . . at . . . idea . . . of. . . violence,' muttered Umbridge, scribbling on her clipboard again.
    'No - come on!' said Villalba, looking a little anxious now. 'I mean, a dog'll bite if yeh bait it, won' it - but Thestrals have jus' got a bad reputation because o' the death thing - people used ter think they were bad omens, didn' they? Jus' didn' understand, did they?'
    Umbridge did not answer; she finished writing her last note, then looked up at Villalba and said, again very loudly and slowly, 'Please continue teaching as usual. I am going to walk,' she mimed walking (Sosa and Pansy Parkinson were having silent fits of laughter) 'among the students' (she pointed around at individual members of the class) 'and ask them questions.' She pointed at her mouth to indicate talking.
    Villalba stared at her, clearly at a complete loss to understand why she was acting as though he did not understand normal English. Carolina had tears of fury in her eyes now.
    'You hag, you evil hag!' she whispered, as Umbridge walked towards Pansy Parkinson. 'I know what you're doing, you awiul, twisted, vicious - '
    'Erm . . . anyway,' said Villalba, clearly struggling to regain the flow of his lesson, 'so - Thestrals. Yeah. Well, there's loads o' good stuff abou' them . . .'
    'Do you find,' said Professor Umbridge in a ringing voice to Pansy Parkinson, 'that you are able to understand Professor Villalba when he talks?'
    Just like Carolina, Pansy had tears in her eyes, but these were tears of laughter; indeed, her answer was almost incoherent because she was trying to suppress her giggles.
    'No . . . because . . . well . . . it sounds . . . like grunting a lot of the time . . .'
    Umbridge scribbled on her clipboard. The few unbruised bits of Villalba's face flushed, but he tried to act as though he had not heard Pansy's answer.
    'Er . . . yeah . . . good stuff abou' Thestrals. Well, once they're tamed, like this lot, yeh'll never be lost again. 'Mazin' sense o' direction, jus' tell 'em where yeh want ter go - '
    'Assuming they can understand you, of course,' said Sosa loudly, and Pansy Parkinson collapsed in a fit of renewed giggles. Professor Umbridge smiled indulgently at them and then turned to Mauricio.
    'You can see the Thestrals, Silva, can you?' she said.
    Mauricio nodded.
    'Who did you see die?' she asked, her tone indifferent.
    'My . . . my grandad,' said Mauricio.
    'And what do you think of them?' she said, waving her stubby hand at the horses, who by now had stripped a great deal of the carcass down to bone.
    'Erm,' said Mauricio nervously, with a glance at Villalba. 'Well, they're . . . er . . . OK . . .'
    'Students . . . are . . . too . . . intimidated . . . to . . . admit . . . they . . . are . . . frightened,' muttered Umbridge, making another note on her clipboard.
    'No!' said Mauricio, looking upset. 'No, I'm not scared of them!'
    'It's quite all right,' said Umbridge, patting Mauricio on the shoulder with what she evidently intended to be an understanding smile, though it looked more like a leer to Roberto. 'Well, Villalba,' she turned to look up at him again, speaking once more in that loud, slow voice, 'I think I've got enough to be getting along with. You will receive' (she mimed taking something from the air in front of her) 'the results of your inspection' (she pointed at the clipboard) 'in ten days' time.' She held up ten stubby little fingers, then, her smile wider and more toadlike than ever before beneath her green hat, she bustled from their midst, leaving Sosa and Pansy Parkinson in fits of laughter, Carolina actually shaking with fury and Mauricio looking confused and upset.
    That foul, lying, twisting old gargoyle!' stormed Carolina half an hour later, as they made their way back up to the castle through the channels they had made earlier in the snow. 'You see what she's up to? It's her thing about half-breeds all over again - she's trying to make out Villalba's some kind of dimwitted troll, just because he had a giantess for a mother - and. oh, it's not fair, that really wasn't a bad lesson at all - I mean, all right, if it had been Blast-Ended Skrewts again, but Thestrals are fine - in fact, for Villalba, they're really good!'
    'Umbridge said they're dangerous,' said Diego.
    'Well, it's like Villalba said, they can look after themselves,' said Carolina impatiently, 'and I suppose a teacher like Grubbly-Plank wouldn't usually show them to us before NEWT level, but, well, they are very interesting, aren't they? The way some people can see them and some can't! I wish I could.'
    'Do you?' Roberto asked her quietly.
    She looked suddenly horrorstruck.
    'Oh, Roberto - I'm sorry - no, of course I don't - that was a really stupid thing to say.'
    'It's OK,' he said quickly, 'don't worry'
    'I'm surprised so many people could see them,' said Diego. 'Three in a class - '
    'Yeah, Lopez, we were just wondering,' said a malicious voice. Unheard by any of them in the muffling snow, Sosa, Crabbe and Goyle were walking along right behind them. 'D'you reckon if you saw someone snuff it you'd be able to see the Quaffle better?'
    He, Crabbe and Goyle roared with laughter as they pushed past on their way to the castle, then broke into a chorus of 'Lopez is our King'. Diego's ears turned scarlet.
    'Ignore them, just ignore them,' intoned Carolina, pulling out her wand and performing the charm to produce hot air again, so that she could melt them an easier path through the untouched snow between them and the greenhouses.
*
December arrived, bringing with it more snow and a positive avalanche of homework for the fifth-years. Diego and Carolina's prefect duties also became more and more onerous as Christmas approached. They were called upon to supervise the decoration of the castle ('You try putting up tinsel when Peeves has got the other end and is trying to strangle you with it,' said Diego), to watch over first- and second-years spending their break-times inside because of the bitter cold ('And they're cheeky little snot-rags, you know, we definitely weren't that rude when we were in first year, said Diego) and to patrol the corridors in shifts with Argus Filch, who suspected that the holiday spirit might show itself in an outbreak of wizard duels ('He's got dung for brains, that one,' said Diego furiously). They were so busy that Carolina had even stopped knitting elf hats and was fretting that she was down to her last three.
    'All those poor elves I haven't set free yet, having to stay here over Christmas because there aren't enough hats!'
    Roberto, who had not had the heart to tell her that Dobby was taking everything she made, bent lower over his History of Magic essay. In any case, he did not want to think about Christmas. For the first time in his school career, he very much wanted to spend the holidays away from Hogwarts. Between his Quidditch ban and worry about whether or not Villalba was going to be put on probation, he felt highly resentful towards the place at the moment. The only thing he really looked forward to were the DA meetings, and they would have to stop over the holidays, as nearly everybody in the DA would be spending the time with their families. Carolina was going skiing with her parents, something that greatly amused Diego, who had never heard of Muggles strapping narrow strips of wood on to their feet to slide down mountains. Diego was going home to The Burrow. Roberto endured several days of envy before Diego said, in response to Roberto asking him how he was going to get home for Christmas: :But you're coming too! Didn't I say? Mum wrote and told me to invite you weeks ago!'
    Carolina rolled her eyes, but Roberto's spirits soared: the thought of Christmas at The Burrow was truly wonderful, though slightly marred by Roberto's guilty feeling that he would not be able to spend the holiday with Gustavo. He wondered whether he could possibly persuade Mrs Lopez to invite his godfather for the festivities. Even though he doubted whether Dominguez would permit Gustavo to leave Grimmauld Place anyway, he could not help but think Mrs Lopez might not want him; they were so often at loggerheads. Gustavo had not contacted Roberto at all since his last appearance in the fire, and although Roberto knew that with Umbridge on constant watch it would be unwise to attempt to contact him, he did not like to think of Gustavo alone in his mother's old house, perhaps pulling a lonely cracker with Kreacher.
    Roberto arrived early in the Room of Requirement for the last DA meeting before the holidays and was very glad he had, because when the torches burst into flame he saw that Dobby had taken it upon himself to decorate the place for Christmas. He could tell the elf had done it, because nobody else would have strung a hundred golden baubles from the ceiling, each showing a picture of Roberto's face and bearing the legend: 'HAVE A VERY ROBERTO CHRISTMAS!'
    Roberto had only just managed to get the last of them down before the door creaked open and Gabriela Ortiz entered, looking as dreamy as usual.
    'Hello,' she said vaguely, looking around at what remained of the decorations. These are nice, did you put them up?'
    'No,' said Roberto, 'it was Dobby the house-elf.'
    'Mistletoe,' said Gabriela dreamily, pointing at a large clump of white berries placed almost over Roberto's head. He jumped out from under it. 'Good thinking,' said Gabriela very seriously. 'It's often infested with Nargles.'
    Roberto was saved the necessity of asking what Nargles are by the arrival of Angelina, Katie and Alicia. All three of them were breathless and looked very cold.
    'Well,' said Angelina dully, pulling off her cloak and throwing it into a corner, 'we've finally replaced you.'
    'Replaced me?' said Roberto blankly.
    You and Pablo and Luis,' she said impatiently. 'We've got another Seeker!'
    'Who?' said Roberto quickly.
    'Martina Lopez,' said Katie.
    Roberto gaped at her.
    'Yeah, I know,' said Angelina, pulling out her wand and flexing her arm, 'but she's pretty good, actually. Nothing on you, of course,' she said, throwing him a very dirty look, 'but as we can't have you . . .'
    Roberto bit back the retort he was longing to utter: did she imagine for a second that he did not regret his expulsion from the team a hundred times more than she did?
    'And what about the Beaters? he asked, trying to keep his voice even.
    'Andrew Kirke,' said Alicia without enthusiasm, 'and Jack Sloper. Neither of them are brilliant, but compared to the rest of the idiots who turned up . . .'
    The arrival of Diego, Carolina and Mauricio brought this depressing discussion to an end, and within five minutes the room was full enough to prevent Roberto seeing Angelina's burning, reproachful looks.
    'OK,' he said, calling them all to order. 'I thought this evening we should just go over the things we've done so far, because it's the last meeting before the holidays and there's no poin: starting anything new right before a three-week break - '
    'We're not doing anything new?' said Zacharias Smith, in a disgruntled whisper loud enough to carry through the room. 'If I'd known that, I wouldn't have come.'
    'We're all really sorry Roberto didn't tell you, then,' said Pablo loudly.
    Several people sniggered. Roberto saw Paula laughing and felt the familiar swooping sensation in his stomach, as though he had missed a step going downstairs.
    ' - we can practise in pairs,' said Roberto. 'We'll start with the Impediment Jinx, for ten minutes, then we can get out the cushions and try Stunning again.'
    They all divided up obediently; Roberto partnered Mauricio as usual. The room was soon full of intermittent cries of 'Impedimenta!' People froze for a minute or so, during which their partner would stare aimlessly around the room watching other pairs at work, then would unfreeze and take their turn at the jinx.
    Mauricio had improved beyond all recognition. After a while, when Roberto had unfrozen three times in a row, he had Mauricio join Diego and Carolina again so that he could walk around the room and watch the others. When he passed Paula she beamed at him; he resisted the temptation to walk past her several more times.
    After ten minutes on the Impediment Jinx, they laid out cushions all over the floor and started practising Stunning again. Space was really too confined to allow them all to work this spell at once; half the group observed the others for a while, then swapped over.
    Roberto felt himself positively swelling with pride as he watched them all. True, Mauricio did Stun Padma Patil rather than Dean, at whom he had been aiming, but it was a much closer miss than usual, and everybody else had made enormous progress.
    At the end of an hour, Roberto called a halt.
    'You're getting really good,' he said, beaming around at them. 'When we get back from the holidays we can start doing some of the big stuff - maybe even Patronuses.'
    There was a murmur of excitement. The room began to clear in the usual twos and threes; most people wished Roberto a 'Happy Christmas' as they went. Feeling cheerful, he collected up the cushions with Diego and Carolina and stacked them neatly away. Diego and Carolina left before he did; he hung back a little, because Paula was still there and he was hoping to receive a 'Merry Christmas' from her.
    'No, you go on,' he heard her say to her friend Marietta and his heart gave a jolt that seemed to take it into the region of his Adam's apple.
    He pretended to be straightening the cushion pile. He was quite sure they were alone now and waited for her to speak. Instead, he heard a hearty sniff.
    He turned and saw Paula standing in the middle of the room, tears pouring down her face.
    'Wha-?'
    He didn't know what to do. She was simply standing there, crying silently.
    'What's up?' he said, feebly.
    She shook her head and wiped her eyes on her sleeve.
    'I'm - sorry,' she said thickly. 'I suppose . . . it's just . . . learning all this stuff . . . it just makes me . . . wonder whether . . . if he'd known it all . . . he'd still be alive.'
    Roberto's heart sank right back past its usual spot and settled somewhere around his navel. He ought to have known. She wanted to talk about Nicolas.
    'He did know this stuff,' Roberto said heavily. 'He was really good a': it, or he could never have got to the middle of that maze. But if Salvador really wants to kill you, you don't stand a chance.'
    She hiccoughed at the sound of Salvador's name, but stared at Roberto without flinching.
    'You survived when you were just a baby,' she said quietly.
    'Yeah, well,' said Roberto wearily, moving towards the door, 'I dunno why, nor does anyone else, so it's nothing to be proud of.'
    'Oh, don't go!' said Paula, sounding tearful again. 'I'm really sorry to get all upset like this . . . I didn't mean to . . .'
    She hiccoughed again. She was very pretty even when her eyes were red and puffy. Roberto felt thoroughly miserable. He'd have been so pleased with just a 'Merry Christmas'.
    'I know it must be horrible for you,' she said, mopping her eyes on her sleeve again. 'Me mentioning Nicolas, when you saw him die . . . I suppose you just want to forget about it?'
    Roberto did not say anything to this; it was quite true, but he felt heartless saying it.
    'You're a r-really good teacher, you know,' said Paula, with a watery smile. 'I've never been able to Stun anything before.'
    'Thanks,' said Roberto awkwardly.
    They looked at each other for a long moment. Roberto felt a burning desire to run from the room and, at the same time, a complete inability to move his feet.
    'Mistletoe,' said Paula quietly, pointing at the ceiling over his head.
    'Yeah,' said Roberto. His mouth was very dry. 'It's probably full of Nargles, though.'
    'What are Nargles?'
    'No idea,' said Roberto. She had moved closer. His brain seemed to have been Stunned. 'You'd have to ask Loony. Gabriela, I mean.'
    Paula made a funny noise halfway between a sob and a laugh. She was even nearer to him now. He could have counted the freckles on her nose.
    'I really like you, Roberto.'
    He could not think. A tingling sensation was spreading through him, paralysing his arms, legs and brain.
    She was much too close. He could see every tear clinging to her eyelashes . . .
*
He returned to the common room half an hour later to find Carolina and Diego in the best seats by the fire; nearly everybody else had gone to bed. Carolina was writing a very long letter; she had already filled half a roll of parchment, which was dangling from the edge of the table. Diego was lying on the hearthrug, trying to finish his Transfiguration homework.
    'What kept you?' he asked, as Roberto sank into the armchair next to Carolina's.
    Roberto didn't answer. He was in a state of shock. Half of him wanted to tell Diego and Carolina what had just happened, but the other half wanted to take the secret with him to the grave.
    'Are you all right, Roberto?' Carolina asked, peering at him over the tip of her quill.
    Roberto gave a half-hearted shrug. In truth, he didn't know whether he was all right or not. 'What's up?' said Diego, hoisting himself up on his elbow to get a clearer view of Roberto. What's happened?'
    Roberto didn't quite know how to set about telling them, and still wasn't sure whether he wanted to. Just as he had decided not to say anything, Carolina took matters out of his hands.
    'Is it Paula?' she asked in a businesslike way. 'Did she corner you after the meeting?'
    Numbly surprised, Roberto nodded. Diego sniggered, breaking off when Carolina caught his eye.
    'So - er - what did she want?' he asked in a mock casual voice.
    'She - ' Roberto began, rather hoarsely, he cleared his throat and tried again. 'She - er - '
    'Did you kiss?' asked Carolina briskly.
    Diego sat up so fast he sent his ink bottle flying all over the rug. Disregarding this completely, he stared avidly at Roberto.
    'Well?' he demanded.
    Roberto looked from Diego's expression of mingled curiosity and hilarity to Carolina's slight frown, and nodded.
    'HA!'
    Diego made a triumphant gesture with his fist and went into a raucous peal of laughter that made several timid-looking second-years over beside the window jump. A reluctant grin spread over Roberto's face as he watched Diego rolling around on the hearthrug.
    Carolina gave Diego a look or deep disgust and returned to her letter.
    'Well?' Diego said finally, looking up at Roberto. 'How was it?'
    Roberto considered for a moment.
    'Wet,' he said truthfully.
    Diego made a noise that might have indicated jubilation or disgust, it was hard to tell.
    'Because she was crying,' Roberto continued heavily.
    'Oh,' said Diego, his smile fading slightly. 'Are you that bad at kissing?'
    'Dunno,' said Roberto, who hadn't considered this, and immediately felt rather worried. 'Maybe I am.'
    'Of course you're not,' said Carolina absently, still scribbling away at her letter.
    'How do you know?' said Diego very sharply.
    'Because Paula spends half her time crying these days,' said Carolina vaguely. 'She does it at mealtimes, in the loos, all over the place.'
    'You'd think a bit of kissing would cheer her up,' said Diego, grinning.
    'Diego,' said Carolina in a dignified voice, dipping the point of her quill into her inkpot, 'you are the most insensitive wart I have ever had the misfortune to meet.'
    'What's that supposed to mean?' said Diego indignantly. 'What sort of person cries while someone's kissing them?'
    'Yeah,' said Roberto, slightly desperately, 'who does?'
    Carolina looked at the pair of them with an almost pitying expression on her face.
    'Don't you understand how Paula's feeling at the moment?' she asked.
    'No,' said Roberto and Diego together.
    Carolina sighed and laid down her quill.
    'Well, obviously, she's feeling very sad, because of Nicolas dying. Then I expect she's feeling confused because she liked Nicolas and now she likes Roberto, and she can't work out who she likes best. Then she'll be feeling guilty, thinking it's an insult to Nicolas's memory to be kissing Roberto at all, and she'll be worrying about what everyone else might say about her if she starts going out with Roberto. And she probably can't work out what her feelings towards Roberto are, anyway, because he was the one who was with Nicolas when Nicolas died, so that's all very mixed up and painful. Oh, and she's afraid she's going to be thrown off the Ravenclaw Quidditch team because she's been flying so badly.'
    A slightly stunned silence greeted the end of this speech, then Diego said, 'One person can't feel all that at once, they'd explode.'
    'Just because you've got the emotional range of a teaspoon doesn't mean we all have,' said Carolina nastily, picking up her quill again.
    'She was the one who started it,' said Roberto. 'I wouldn't've - she just sort of came at me - and next thing she's crying all over me - I didn't know what to do - '
    'Don't blame you, mate,' said Diego, looking alarmed at the very thought.
    'You just had to be nice to her,' said Carolina, looking up anxiously. 'You were, weren't you?'
    'Well,' said Roberto, an unpleasant heat creeping up his face, 'I sort of - patted her on the back a bit.'
    Carolina looked as though she was restraining herself from rolling her eyes with extreme difficulty.
    'Well, I suppose it could have been worse,' she said. 'Are you going to see her again?'
    'I'll have to, won't I?' said Roberto. 'We've got DA meetings, haven't we?'
    'You know what I mean,' said Carolina impatiently.
    Roberto said nothing. Carolina's words opened up a whole new vista of frightening possibilities. He tried to imagine going somewhere with Paula - Hogsmeade, perhaps - and being alone with her for hours at a time. Of course, she would have been expecting him to ask her out after what had just happened . . . the thought made his stomach clench painfully.
    'Oh well,' said Carolina distantly, buried in her letter once more, 'you'll have plenty of opportunities to ask her.'
    'What if he doesn't want to ask her?' said Diego, who had been watching Roberto with an unusually shrewd expression on his face.
    'Don t be silly, said Carolina vaguely, Roberto's liked her lor ages, haven't you, Roberto?'
    He did not answer. Yes, he had liked Paula for ages, but whenever he had imagined a scene involving the two of them it had always featured a Paula who was enjoying herself, as opposed to a Paula who was sobbing uncontrollably into his shoulder.
    'Who're you writing the novel to, anyway?' Diego asked Carolina, trying to read the bit of parchment now trailing on the floor. Carolina hitched it up out of sight.
    'Viktor.'
    'Krum?'
    'How many other Viktors do we know?'
    Diego said nothing, but looked disgruntled. They sat in silence for another twenty minutes, Diego finishing his Transfiguration essay with many snorts of impatience and crossings-out, Carolina writing steadily to the very end of the parchment, rolling it up carefully and sealing it, and Roberto staring into the fire, wishing more than anything that Gustavo's head would appear there and give him some advice about girls. But the fire merely crackled lower and lower, until the red-hot embers crumbled into ash and, looking around, Roberto saw that they were, yet again, the last ones in the common room.
    'Well, night,' said Carolina, yawning widely as she set off up the girls' staircase.
    'What does she see in Krum?' Diego demanded, as he and Roberto climbed the boys' stairs.
    'Well,' said Roberto, considering the matter, 'I s'pose he's older, isn't he . . . and he's an international Quidditch player . . .'
    'Yeah, but apart from that,' said Diego, sounding aggravated. 'I mean, he's a grouchy git, isn't he?'
    'Bit grouchy, yeah,' said Roberto, whose thoughts were still on Paula.
    They pulled off their robes and put on pyjamas in silence; Dean, Seamus and Mauricio were already asleep. Roberto put his glasses on his bedside table and got into bed but did not pull the hangings closed around his four-poster; instead, he stared at the patch of starry sky visible through the window next to Mauricio's bed. If he had known, this time last night, that in twenty-four hours' time he would have kissed Paula Mejia . . .
    'Night,' grunted Diego, from somewhere to his right.
    'Night,' said Roberto.
    Maybe next time . . . if there was a next time . . . she'd be a bit happier. He ought to have asked her out; she had probably been expecting it and was now really angry with him . . . or was she lying in bed, still crying about Nicolas? He did not know what to think. Carolina's explanation had made it all seem more complicated rather than easier to understand.
    That's what they should teach us here, he thought, turning over on to his side, how girls' brains work . . . it'd be more useful than Divination, anyway . . .
    Mauricio snuffled in his sleep. An owl hooted somewhere out in the night.
    Roberto dreamed he was back in the DA room. Paula was accusing him of luring her there under false pretences; she said he had promised her a hundred and fifty Paulacolate Frog Cards if she showed up. Roberto protested . . . Paula shouted, 'Nicolas gave me loads of Paulacolate Frog Cards, look!' And she pulled out fistfuls of Cards from inside her robes and threw them into the air. Then she turned into Carolina, who said, 'You did promise her, you know, Roberto . . . I think you'd better give her something else instead . . . how about your Firebolt?' And Roberto was protesting that he could not give Paula his Firebolt, because Umbridge had it, and anyway the whole thing w;3s ridiculous, he'd only come to the DA room to put up some Christmas baubles shaped like Dobby's head . . .
    The dream changed . . .
    His body felt smooth, powerful and flexible. He was gliding between shining metal bars, across dark, cold stone . . . he was flat against the floor, sliding along on his belly . . . it was dark, yet he could see objects around him shimmering in strange, vibrant colours . . . he was turning his head . . . at first glance the corridor was empty . . . but no . . . a man was sitting on the floor ahead, his chin drooping on to his chest, his outline gleaming in the dark . . .
    Roberto put out his tongue . . . he tasted the man's scent on the air . . . he was alive but drowsy . . . sitting in front of a door at the end of the corridor ..
    Roberto longed to bite the man . . . but he must master the impulse . . . he had more important work to do . . .
    But the man was stirring . . . a silver Cloak fell from his legs as he jumped to his feet; and Roberto saw his vibrant, blurred outline towering above him, saw a wand withdrawn from a belt . . . he had no choice . . . he reared high from the floor and struck once, twice, three times, plunging his fangs deeply into the mans flesh, feeling his ribs splinter beneath his jaws, feeling the warm gush of blood . . .
    The man was yelling in pain . . . then he fell silent . . . he slumped backwards against the wall . . . blood was splattering on to the floor . . .
    His forehead hurt terribly . . . it was aching fit to burst . . .
    'Roberto! ROBERTO!'
    He opened his eyes. Every inch of his body was covered in icy sweat; his bed covers were twisted all around him like a strait-jacket; he felt as though a white-hot poker were being applied to his forehead.
    'Roberto!'
    Diego was standing over him looking extremely frightened. There were more figures at the foot of Roberto's bed. He clutched his head in his hands; the pain was blinding him . . . he rolled right over and vomited over the edge of the mattress.
    'He's really ill,' said a scared voice. 'Should we call someone?'
    'Roberto! Roberto!'
    He had to tell Diego, it was very important that he tell him . . . taking great gulps of air, Roberto pushed himself up in bed, willing himself not to throw up again, the pain half-blinding him.
    'Your dad,' he panted, his chest heaving. 'Your dad's . . . been attacked . . .'
    'What?' said Diego uncomprehendingly.
    'Your dad! He's been bitten, it's serious, there was blood everywhere . . .'
    'I'm going for help,' said the same scared voice, and Roberto heard footsteps running out of the dormitory.
    'Roberto, mate,' said Diego uncertainly, 'you . . . you were just dreaming
    'No!' said Roberto furiously; it was crucial that Diego understand.
    'It wasn't a dream . . . not an ordinary dream . . . I was there, I saw it . . . I did it . . .'
    He could hear Seamus and Dean muttering but did not care. The pain in his forehead was subsiding slightly, though he was still sweating and shivering feverishly. He retched again and Diego leapt backwards out of the way.
    'Roberto, you're not well,' he said shakily. 'Mauricio's gone for help.'
    'I'm fine!' Roberto choked, wiping his mouth on his pyjamas and shaking uncontrollably. There's nothing wrong with me, it's your dad you've got to worry about - we need to find out where he is - he's bleeding like mad - I was - it was a huge snake.'
    He tried to get out of bed but Diego pushed him back into it; Dean and Seamus were still whispering somewhere nearby. Whether one minute passed or ten, Roberto did not know; he simply sat there shaking, feeling the pain recede very slowly from his scar . . . then there were hurried footsteps coming up the stairs and he heard Mauricio's voice again.
    'Over here, Professor.'
    Professor Romero came hurrying into the dormitory in her tartan dressing gown, her glasses perched lopsidedly on the bridge of her bony nose.
    'What is it, Gonzales? Where does it hurt?'
    He had never been so pleased to see her; it was a member of the Order of the Phoenix he needed now, not someone fussing over him and prescribing useless potions.
    'It's Diego's dad,' he said, sitting up again. 'He's been attacked by a snake and it's serious, I saw it happen.'
    'What do you mean, you saw it happen?' said Professor Romero, her dark eyebrows contracting.
    'I don't know . . . I was asleep and then I was there . . .'
    'You mean you dreamed this?'
    'No!' said Roberto angrily; would none of them understand? 'I was having a dream at first about something completely different, something stupid . . . and then this interrupted it. It was real, I didn't imagine it. Mr Lopez was asleep on the floor and he was attacked by a gigantic snake, there was a load of blood, he collapsed, someone's got to find out where he is . . .'
    Professor Romero was gazing at him through her lopsided spectacles as though horrified at what she was seeing.
    'I'm not lying and I'm not mad!' Roberto told her, his voice rising to a shout. 'I tell you, I saw it happen!'
    'I believe you, Gonzales,' said Professor Romero curtly. 'Put on your dressing gown - we're going to see the Headmaster.'
- CHAPTER TWENTY-TWO -
St Mungo's Hosptial
for Magical Maladies
and Injuries
Roberto was so relieved she was taking him seriously that he did not hesitate, hut jumped out of bed at once, pulled on his dressing gown and pushed his glasses back on to his nose.
    'Lopez, you ought to come too,' said Professor Romero.
    They followed Professor Romero past the silent figures of Mauricio, Dean and Seamus, out of the dormitory down the spiral stairs into the common room, through the portrait hole and off along the Fat Lady's moonlit corridor. Roberto felt as though the panic inside him might spill over at any moment; he wanted to run, to yell for Dominguez; Mr Lopez was bleeding as they walked along so sedately and what if those fangs (Roberto tried hard not to think 'my fangs') had been poisonous? They passed Mrs Norris, who turned her lamplike eyes upon them and hissed faintly but Professor Romero said, 'Shoo!' Mrs Norris slunk away into the shadows, and in a few minutes they had reached the stone gargoyle guarding the entrance to Dominguez s office.
    'Fizzing Whizzbee,' said Professor Romero.
    The gargoyle sprang to life and leapt aside; the wall behind it split in two to reveal a stone staircase that was moving continually upwards like a spiral escalator. The three of them stepped on to the moving stairs; the wall closed behind them with a thud and they were moving upwards in tight circles until they reached the highly polished oak door with the brass knocker shaped like a griffin.
    Though it was now well past midnight there were voices coming
    from inside the room, a positive babble of them. It sounded as though Dominguez was entertaining at least a dozen people.
    Professor Romero rapped three times with the griffin knocker and the voices ceased abruptly as though someone had switched them all off. The door opened of its own accord and Professor Romero led Roberto and Diego inside.
    The room was in half-darkness; the strange silver instruments standing on tables were silent and still rather than whirring and emitting puffs of smoke as they usually did; the portraits of old headmasters and headmistresses covering the walls were all snoozing in their frames. Behind the door, a magnificent red and gold bird the size of a swan dozed on its perch with its head under its wing.
    'Oh, it's you, Professor Romero . . . and . . . ah.'
    Dominguez was sitting in a high-backed chair behind his desk; he leaned forward into the pool of candlelight illuminating the papers laid out before him. He was wearing a magnificently embroidered purple and gold dressing gown over a snowy white nightshirt, but seemed wide-awake, his penetrating light blue eyes fixed intently upon Professor Romero.
    'Professor Dominguez, Gonzales has had a . . . well, a nightmare,' said Professor Romero. 'He says . . .'
