    The Healer pointed her wand at the door of the Janus Thickey Ward and muttered, 'Alohomora.' The door swung open and she led the way inside, keeping a firm grasp on Gilderoy's arm until she had settled him into an armchair beside his bed.
    This is our long-term residents' ward,' she informed Roberto, Diego,
    Carolina and Martina in a low voice. 'For permanent spell damage, you know. Of course, with intensive remedial potions and charms and a bit of luck, we can produce some improvement. Gilderoy does seem to be getting back some sense of himself; and we've seen a real improvement in Mr Bode, he seems to be regaining the power of speech very well, though he isn't speaking any language w: recognise yet. Well, I must finish giving out the Christmas presents, I'll leave you all to chat.'
    Roberto looked around. The ward bore unmistakeable signs of being a permanent home to its residents. They had many more personal effects around their beds than in Mr Lopez's ward; the wall around Gilderoy's headboard, for instance, was papered with pictures of himself, all beaming toothily and waving at the new arrivals. He had autographed many of them to himself in disjointed, childish writing. The moment he had been deposited in his chair b> the Healer, Gilderoy pulled a fresh stack of photographs towards him, seized a quill and started signing them all feverishly.
    'You can put them in envelopes,' he said to Martina, throwing the signed pictures into her lap one by one as he finished them. 'I am not forgotten, you know, no, I still receive a very great deal of fan mail . . . Gladys Gudgeon writes weekly . . . I just wish I knew why . . .' He paused, looking faintly puzzled, then beamed again and returned to his signing with renewed vigour. 'I suspect it is simply my good looks . . .'
    A sallow-skinned, mournful-looking wizard lay in the bed opposite staring at the ceiling; he was mumbling to himself and seemed quite unaware of anything around him. Two beds along was a woman whose entire head was covered in fur; Roberto remembered something similar happening to Carolina during their second year, although fortunately the damage, in her case, had not been permanent. At the far end of the ward flowery curtains had been drawn around two beds to give the occupants and their visitors some privacy.
    'Here you are, Agnes,' said the Healer brightly to the furry-faced woman, handing her a small pile of Christmas presents. 'See, not forgotten, are you? And your son's sent an owl to say he's visiting tonight, so that's nice, isn't it?'
    Agnes gave several loud barks.
    'And look, Broderick, you've been sent a pot plant and a lovely calendar with a different fancy Hippogriff for each month; they'll brighten things up, won't they?' said the Healer, bustling along to the mumbling man, setting a rather ugly plant with long, swaying tentacles on the bedside cabinet and fixing the calendar to the wall with her wand. 'And - oh, Mrs Silva, are you leaving already?'
    Roberto's head span round. The curtains had been drawn back from the two beds at the end of the ward and two visitors were walking back down the aisle between the beds: a formidable-looking old witch wearing a long green dress, a moth-eaten fox fur and a pointed hat decorated with what was unmistakeably a stuffed vulture and, trailing behind her looking thoroughly depressed - Mauricio.
    With a sudden rush of understanding, Roberto realised who the people in the end beds must be. He cast around wildly for some means of distracting the others so that Mauricio could leave the ward unnoticed and unquestioned, but Diego had also looked up at the sound of the name 'Silva', and before Roberto could stop him had called out, 'Mauricio!'
    Mauricio jumped and cowered as though a bullet had narrowly missed him.
    'It's us, Mauricio!' said Diego brightly, getting to his feet. 'Have you seen - '? Lockhart's here! Who've you been visiting?'
    'Friends of yours, Mauricio, dear?' said Mauricio's grandmother graciously, bearing down upon them all.
    Mauricio looked as though he would rather be anywhere in the world but here. A dull purple flush was creeping up his plump face and he was not making eye contact with any of them.
    'Ah, yes,' said his grandmother, looking closely at Roberto and sticking out a shrivelled, clawlike hand for him to shake. 'Yes, yes, I know who you are, of course. Mauricio speaks most highly of you.'
    'Er - thanks,' said Roberto, shaking hands. Mauricio did not look at him, but surveyed his own feet, the colour deepening in his face all the while.
    'And you two are clearly Lopezs,' Mrs Silva continued, proffering her hand regally to Diego and Martina in turn. 'Yes, I know your parents - not well, of course - but fine people, fine people . . . and you must be Carolina Fernandez?'
    Carolina looked rather startled that Mrs Silva knew her name, but shook hands all the same.
    'Yes, Mauricio's told me all about you. Helped him out of a few sticky spots, haven't you? He's a good boy,' she said, casting a sternly appraising look down her rather bony nose at Mauricio, 'but be hasn't got his father's talent, I'm afraid to say.' And she jerked her head in the direction of the two beds at the end of the ward, so that the stuffed vulture on her hat trembled alarmingly.
    'What?' said Diego, looking amazed. (Roberto wanted to stamp on Diego's foot, but that sort of thing is much harder to bring off unnoticed when you're wearing jeans rather than robes.) 'Is that your dad down the end, Mauricio?'
    'What's this?' said Mrs Silva sharply. 'Haven't you told your friends about your parents, Mauricio?'
    Mauricio took a deep breath, looked up at the ceiling and shook his head. Roberto could not remember ever feeling sorrier for anyone, but he could not think of any way of helping Mauricio out of the situation.
    Well, it's nothing to be ashamed of!' said Mrs Silva angrily. 'You should be proud, Mauricio, proud! They didn't give their health and their sanity so their only son would be ashamed of them, you know!'
    'I'm not ashamed,' said Mauricio, very faintly, still looking anywhere but at Roberto and the others. Diego was now standing on tiptoe to look over at the inhabitants of the two beds.
    Well, you've got a funny way of showing it!' said Mrs Silva. 'My son and his wife,' she said, turning haughtily to Roberto, Diego, Carolina and Martina, 'were tortured into insanity by You-Know-Who's followers.'
    Carolina and Martina both clapped their hands over their mouths. Diego stopped craning his neck to catch a glimpse of Mauricio's parents and looked mortified.
    They were Aurors, you know, and very well respected within the wizarding community,' Mrs Silva went on. 'Highly gifted, the pair of them. I - yes, Alice dear, what is it?'
    Mauricio's mother had come edging down the ward in her nightdress. She no longer had the plump, happy-looking face Roberto had seen in Acosta's old photograph of the original Order of the Phoenix. Her face was thin and worn now, her eyes seemed overlarge and her hair, which had turned white, was wispy and dead-looking. She did not seem to want to speak, or perhaps she was not able to, but she made timid motions towards Mauricio, holding something in her outstretched hand.
    'Again?' said Mrs Silva, sounding slightly weary. 'Very well, Alice dear, very well - Mauricio, take it, whatever it is.'
    But Mauricio had already stretched out his hand, into which his mother dropped an empty Drooble's Best Blowing Gum wrapper.
    'Very nice, dear,' said Mauricio's grandmother in a falsely cheery voice, patting his mother on the shoulder.
    But Mauricio said quietly, Thanks, Mum.'
    His mother tottered away, back up the ward, humming to herself. Mauricio looked around at the others, his expression defiant, as though daring them to laugh, but Roberto did not think he'd ever found anything less funny in his life.
    'Well, we'd better get back,' sighed Mrs Silva, drawing on long green gloves. 'Very nice to have met you all. Mauricio, put that wrapper in the bin, she must have given you enough of them to paper your bedroom by now.'
    But as they left, Roberto was sure he saw Mauricio slip the sweet wrapper into his pocket.
    The door closed behind them.
    'I never knew,' said Carolina, who looked tearful.
    'Nor did I,' said Diego rather hoarsely.
    'Nor me,' whispered Martina.
    They all looked at Roberto.
    'I did,' he said glumly. 'Dominguez told me but I promised I wouldn't tell anyone . . . that's what Miranda Gimenez got sent to Azkaban for, using the Cruciatus Curse on Mauricio's parents until they lost their minds.'
    'Miranda Gimenez did that?' whispered Carolina, horrified. That woman Kreacher's got a photo of in his den?'
    There was a long silence, broken by Lockhart's angry voice.
    'Look, I didn't learn joined-up writing for nothing, you know!'
- CHAPTER TWENTY-FOUR -
Occlumency
Kreacher, it transpired, had been lurking in the attic. Gustavo said he had found him up there, covered in dust, no doubt looking for more relics of the Martinez family to hide in his cupboard. Though Gustavo seemed satisfied with this story, it made Roberto uneasy. Kreacher seemed to be in a better mood on his reappearance, his bitter muttering had subsided somewhat and he submitted to orders more docilely than usual, though once or twice Roberto caught the house-elf staring at him avidly, but always looking quickly away whenever he saw that Roberto had noticed.
    Roberto did not mention his vague suspicions to Gustavo, whose cheerfulness was evaporating fast now that Christmas was over. As the date of their departure back to Hogwarts drew nearer, he became more and more prone to what Mrs Lopez called 'fits of the sullens', in which he would become taciturn and grumpy, often withdrawing to Buckbeak's room for hours at a time. His gloom seeped through the house, oozing under doorways like some noxious gas, so that all of them became infected by it.
    Roberto didn't want to leave Gustavo again with only Kreacher for company; in fact, for the first time in his life, he was not looking forward to returning to Hogwarts. Going back to school would mean placing himself once again under the tyranny of Dolores Umbridge, who had no doubt managed to force through another dozen decrees in their absence; there was no Quidditch to look forward to now that he had been banned, there was every likelihood that their burden of homework would increase as the exams drew even nearer; and Dominguez remained as remote as ever. In fact, if it hadn't been for the DA, Roberto thought he might have begged Gustavo to let him leave Hogwarts and remain in Grimmauld Place.
    Then, on the very last day of the holidays, something happened that made Roberto positively dread his return to school.
    'Roberto, dear,' said Mrs Lopez poking her head into his and Diego's bedroom, where the pair of them were playing wizard chess watched by Carolina, Martina and Crookshanks, 'could you come down to the kitchen? Professor Peralta would like a word with you.'
    Roberto did not immediately register what she had said; one of his castles was engaged in a violent tussle with a pawn of Diego's and he was egging it on enthusiastically.
    'Squash him - squash him, he's only a pawn, you idiot. Sorry, Mrs Lopez, what did you say?'
    'Professor Peralta, dear. In the kitchen. He'd like a word.'
    Roberto's mouth fell open in horror. He looked around at Diego, Carolina and Martina, all of whom were gaping back at him. Crookshanks, whom Carolina had been restraining with difficulty for the past quarter of an hour, leapt gleefully on to the board and set the pieces running for cover, squealing at the top of their voices.
    'Peralta?' said Roberto blankly.
    'Professor Peralta, dear,' said Mrs Lopez reprovingly. 'Now come on, quickly, he says he can't stay long.'
    'What's he want with you?' said Diego, looking unnerved as Mrs Lopez withdrew from the room. 'You haven't done anything, have you?'
    'No!' said Roberto indignantly, racking his brains to think what he could have done that would make Peralta pursue him to Grimmauld Place. Had his last piece of homework perhaps earned a 'T'?
    A minute or two later, he pushed open the kitchen door to find Gustavo and Peralta both seated at the long kitchen table, glaring in opposite directions. The silence between them was heavy with mutual dislike. A letter lay open on the table in front of Gustavo.
    'Er,' said Roberto, to announce his presence.
    Peralta looked around at him, his face framed between curtains of greasy black hair.
    'Sit down, Gonzales.'
    'You know,' said Gustavo loudly, leaning back on his rear chair legs and speaking to the ceiling, 'I think I'd prefer it if you didn't give orders here, Peralta. It's my house, you see.'
    An ugly flush suffused Peralta's pallid face. Roberto sat down in a chair beside Gustavo, facing Peralta across the table.
    'I was supposed to see you alone, Gonzales,' said Peralta, the familiar sneer curling his mouth, 'but Martinez - '
    'I'm his godfather,' said Gustavo, louder than ever.
    'I am here on Dominguez's orders.' said Peralta, whose voice, by contrast, was becoming more and more quietly waspish, 'but by all means stay, Martinez, I know you like lo feel . . . involved.'
    'What's that supposed to mean?' said Gustavo, letting his chair fall back on to all four legs with a loud bang.
    'Merely that I am sure you must feel - ah - frustrated by the fact that you can do nothing useful,' Peralta laid a delicate stress on the word, 'for the Order.'
    It was Gustavo's turn to flush. Peralta's lip curled in triumph as he turned to Roberto.
    The Headmaster has sent me to tell you, Gonzales, that it is his wish for you to study Occlumency this term.'
    'Study what?' said Roberto blankly.
    Peralta's sneer became more pronounced.
    'Occlumency, Gonzales. The magical defence of the mind against external penetration. An obscure branch of magic, but a highly useful one.'
    Roberto's heart began to pump very fast indeed. Defence against external penetration? But he was not being possessed, they had all agreed on that . . .
    'Why do I have to study Occlu - thing?' he blurted out.
    'Because the Headmaster thinks it a good idea,' said Peralta smoothly. 'You will receive private lessons once a week, but you will not tell anybody what you are doing, least of all Dolores Umbridge. You understand?'
    'Yes,' said Roberto. 'Who's going to be teaching me?'
    Peralta raised an eyebrow.
    'I am,' he said.
    Roberto had the horrible sensation that his insides were melting.
    Extra lessons with Peralta - what on earth had he done to deserve this? He looked quickly round at Gustavo for support.
    'Why can't Dominguez teach Roberto?' asked Gustavo aggressively. 'Why you?'
    'I suppose because it is a headmasters privilege to delegate less enjoyable tasks,' said Peralta silkily. 'I assure you I did not beg for the job.' He got to his feet. 'I will expect you at six o'clock on Monday evening, Gonzales. My office. If anybody asks, you are taking remedial Potions. Nobody who has seen you in my classes could deny you need them.'
    He turned to leave, his black travelling cloak billowing behind him.
    'Wait a moment,' said Gustavo, sitting up straighter in his chair.
    Peralta turned back to face them, sneering.
    'I am in rather a hurry, Martinez. Unlike you, I do not have unlimited leisure time.'
    'I'll get to the point, then,' said Gustavo, standing up. He was rather taller than Peralta who, Roberto noticed, balled his fist in the pocket of his cloak over what Roberto was sure was the handle of his wand. 'If I hear you're using these Occlumency lessons to give Roberto a hard time, you'll have me to answer to.'
    'How touching,' Peralta sneered. 'But surely you have noticed that Gonzales is very like his father?'
    'Yes, I have,' said Gustavo proudly.
    'Well then, you'll know he's so arrogant that criticism simply bounces off him,' Peralta said sleekly.
    Gustavo pushed his chair roughly aside and strode around the table towards Peralta, pulling out his wand as he went. Peralta whipped out his own. They were squaring up to each other, Gustavo looking livid, Peralta calculating, his eyes darting from Gustavo's wand-tip to his face.
    'Gustavo!' said Roberto loudly, but Gustavo appeared not to hear him.
    'I've warned you, Snivelus,' said Gustavo, his face barely a foot from Peralta's, 'I don't care if Dominguez thinks you've reformed, I know better - '
    'Oh, but why don't you tell him so?' whispered Peralta. 'Or are you afraid he might not take very seriously the advice of a man who has been hiding inside his mother's house for six months?'
    Tell me, how is Mariano Sosa these days? I expect he's delighted his lapdog's working at Hogwarts, isn't he?'
    'Speaking of dogs,' said Peralta softly, 'did you know that Mariano Sosa recognised you last time you risked a little jaunt outside? Clever idea, Martinez, getting yourself seen on a safe station platform . . . gave you a cast-iron excuse not to leave your hidey-hole in future, didn't it?'
    Gustavo raised his wand.
    'NO!' Roberto yelled, vaulting over the table and trying to get in between them. 'Gustavo, don't!'
    'Are you calling me a coward?' roared Gustavo, trying to push Roberto out of the way, but Roberto would not budge.
    'Why, yes, I suppose I am,' said Peralta.
    'Roberto - get - out - of - it!' snarled Gustavo, pushing him aside with his free hand.
    The kitchen door opened and the entire Lopez family, plus Carolina, came inside, all looking very happy, with Mr Lopez walking proudly in their midst dressed in a pair of striped pyjamas covered by a mackintosh.
    'Cured!' he announced brightly to the kitchen at large. 'Completely cured!'
    He and all the other Lopezs froze on the threshold, gazing at the scene in front of them, which was also suspended in mid-action, both Gustavo and Peralta looking towards the door with their wands pointing into each other's faces and Roberto immobile between them, a hand stretched out to each, trying to force them apart.
    'Merlins beard,' said Mr Lopez, the smile sliding off his face, 'what's going on here?'
    Both Gustavo and Peralta lowered their wands. Roberto looked from one to the other. Each wore an expression of utmost contempt, yet the unexpected entrance of so many witnesses seemed to have brought them to their senses. Peralta piocketed his wand, turned on his heel and swept back across the kitchen, passing the Lopezs without comment. At the door he looked back.
    'Six o'clock, Monday evening, Gonzales.'
    And he was gone. Gustavo glared after him, his wand at his side.
    'What's been going on?' asked Mr Lopez again.
    'Nothing, Raul,' said Gustavo, who was breathing heavily as though he had just run a long distance. 'Just a friendly little chat between two old school friends.' With what looked like an enormous effort, he smiled. 'So . . . you're cured? That's great news, really great.'
    'Yes, isn't it?' said Mrs Lopez, leading her husband forward to a chair. 'Healer Smethwyck worked his magic in the end, found an antidote to whatever that snake's got in its fangs, and Raul's learned his lesson about dabbling in Muggle medicine, haven't you, dear?' she added, rather menacingly.
    'Yes, Alicia dear,' said Mr Lopez meekly.
    That nights meal should have been a cheerful one, with Mr Lopez back amongst them. Roberto could tell Gustavo was trying to make it so, yet when his godfather was not forcing himself to laugh loudly at Pablo and Luis's jokes or offering everyone more food, his face fell back into a moody, brooding expression. Roberto was separated from him by Mundungus and Mad-Eye, who had dropped in to offer Mr Lopez their congratulations. He wanted to talk to Gustavo, to tell him he shouldn't listen to a word Peralta said, that Peralta was goading him deliberately and that the rest of them didn't think Gustavo was a coward for doing as Dominguez told him and remaining in Grimmauld Place. But he had no opportunity to do so, and, eyeing the ugly look on Gustavo's face, Roberto wondered occasionally whether he would have dared to mention it even if he had the chance. Instead, he told Diego and Carolina under his voice about having to take Occlumency lessons with Peralta.
    'Dominguez wants to stop you having those dreams about Salvador,' said Carolina at once. Well, you won't be sorry not to have them any more, will you?'
    'Extra lessons with Peralta?' said Diego, sounding aghast. 'I'd rather have the nightmares!'
    They were to return to Hogwarts on the Knight Bus the following day, escorted once again by Perez and Cardozo, both of whom were eating breakfast in the kitchen when Roberto, Diego and Carolina came down next morning. The adults seemed to have been mid-
    way through a whispered conversation as Roberto opened the door; a I of them looked round hastily and fell silent.
    After a hurried breakfast, they all pulled on jackets and scarves against the chilly grey January morning. Roberto had an unpleasant constricted sensation in his chest; he did not want to say goodbye to Gustavo. He had a bad feeling about this parting; he didn't know when they would next see each other and he felt it was incumbent upon him to say something to Gustavo to stop him doing anything stupid - Roberto was worried that Peralta's accusation of cowardice had stung Gustavo so badly he might even now be planning some foolhardy trip beyond Grimmauld Place. Before he could think of what to say, however, Gustavo had beckoned him to his side.
    'I want you to take this,' he said quietly, thrusting a badly wrapped package roughly the size of a paperback book into Roberto's hands.
    'What is it?' Roberto asked.
    'A way of letting me know if Peralta's giving you a hard time. No, don't open it in here!' said Gustavo, with a wary look at Mrs Lopez, who was trying to persuade the twins to wear hand-knitted mittens. 'I doubt Alicia would approve - but I want you to use it if you need me, all right?'
    'OK,' said Roberto, stowing the package away in the inside pocket of his jacket, but he knew he would never use whatever it was. It would not be he, Roberto, who lured Gustavo from his place of safety, no matter how foully Peralta treated him in their forthcoming Occlumency classes.
    'Let's go, then,' said Gustavo, clapping Roberto on the shoulder and smiling grimly, and before Roberto could say anything else, they were heading upstairs, stopping before the heavily chained and bolted front door, surrounded by Lopezs.
    'Goodbye, Roberto, take care,' said Mrs Lopez, hugging him.
    'See you, Roberto, and keep an eye out for snakes for me!' said Mr Lopez genially, shaking his hand.
    'Right - yeah,' said Roberto distractedly; it was his last chance to tell Gustavo to be careful; he turned, looked into his godfathers face and opened his mouth to speak, but before he could do so Gustavo was giving him a brief, one-armed hug, and saying gruffly, 'Look after yourself, Roberto.' Next moment, Roberto found himself being shunted out into the icy winter air, with Perez (today heavily disguised as a tall, tweedy woman with iron-grey hair) chivvying him down the steps.
    The door of number twelve slammed shut behind them. They followed Cardozo down the front steps. As he reached the pavement, Roberto looked round. Number twelve was shrinking rapidly as those on either side of it stretched sideways, squeezing it out of sight. One blink later, it had gone.
    'Come on, the quicker we get on the bus the better,' said Perez, and Roberto thought there was nervousness in the glance she threw around the square. Cardozo flung out his right arm.
    BANG.
    A violently purple, triple-decker bus had appeared out of thin air in front of them, narrowly avoiding the nearest lamppost, which jumped backwards out of its way.
    A thin, pimply, jug-eared youth in a purple uniform leapt down on to the pavement and said, 'Welcome to the - '
    'Yes, yes, we know, thank you,' said Perez swiftly. 'On, on, get on - '
    And she shoved Roberto forwards towards the steps, past the conductor, who goggled at Roberto as he passed.
    "Ere - it's 'Any - '!'
    'If you shout his name I will curse you into oblivion,' muttered Perez menacingly, now shunting Martina and Carolina forwards.
    'I've always wanted to go on this thing,' said Diego happily, joining Roberto on board and looking around.
    It had been evening the last time Roberto had travelled by Knight Bus and its three decks had been full of brass bedsteads. Now, in the early morning, it was crammed with an assortment of mismatched chairs grouped haphazardly around windows. Some of these appeared to have fallen over when the bus stopped abruptly in Grimmauld Place; a few witches and wizards were still getting to their feet, grumbling, and somebody's shopping bag had slid the length of the bus: an unpleasant mixture of frogspawn, cockroaches and custard creams was scattered all over the floor.
    'Looks like we'll have to split up,' said Perez briskly, looking a.round for empty chairs. 'Pablo, Luis and Martina, if you just take those seats at the back . . . Pedro can stay with you.'
    She, Roberto, Diego and Carolina proceeded up to the very top deck, where there were two unoccupied chairs at the very front of the bus and two at the back. Stan Shunpike, the conductor, followed Roberto and Diego eagerly to the back. Heads turned as Roberto passed and, when he sat down, he saw all the faces flick back to the front again.
    As Roberto and Diego handed Stan eleven Sickles each, the bus set off again, swaying ominously. It rumbled around Grimmauld Place, v/eaving on and off the pavement, then, with another tremendous BANG, they were all flung backwards; Diego's chair toppled right over and Pigwidgeon, who had been on his lap, burst out of his cage and flew twittering wildly up to the front of the bus where he fluttered down on to Carolina s shoulder instead. Roberto, who had narrowly avoided falling by seizing a candle bracket, looked out of the window: they were now speeding down what appeared to be a motorway.
    'Just outside Birmingham,' said Stan happily, answering Roberto's unasked question as Diego struggled up from the floor. 'You keepin' well, then, 'Any? I seen your name in the paper loads over the sammer, but it weren't never nuflink very nice. I said to Ern, I said, 'e didn't seem like a nutter when we met 'im, just goes to siow, dunnit?'
    He handed over their tickets and continued to gaze, enthralled, at Roberto. Apparently, Stan did not care how nutty somebody was, if they were famous enough to be in the paper. The Knight Bus swayed alarmingly, overtaking a line of cars on the inside. Looking towards the front of the bus, Roberto saw Carolina cover her eyes with her hands, Pigwidgeon swaying happily on her shoulder.
    BANG.
    Chairs slid backwards again as the Knight Bus jumped from the Birmingham motorway to a quiet country lane full of hairpin bends. Hedgerows on either side of the road were leaping out of their way as they mounted the verges. From here they moved to a main street in the middle of a busy town, then to a viaduct surrounded by tall hills, then to a windswept road between high-rise flats, each time with a loud BANG.
    'I've changed my mind,' muttered Diego, picking himself up from the floor for the sixth time, 'I never want to ride on this thing again.'
    'Listen, it's 'Ogwarts stop after this,' said Stan brightly, swaying towards them. That bossy woman up front 'oo got on with you, she's given us a little tip to move you up the queue. We're just gonna let Madam Marsh off first, though - ' there was a retching sound from downstairs, followed by a horrible spattering noise - she's not feeling 'er best.'
    A few minutes later, the Knight Bus screeched to a halt outside a small pub, which squeezed itself out of the way to avoid a collision. They could hear Stan ushering the unfortunate Madam Marsh out of the bus and the relieved murmurings of her fellow passengers on the second deck. The bus moved on again, gathering speed, until - '
    BANG.
    They were rolling through a snowy Hogsmeade. Roberto caught a glimpse of the Hog's Head down its side street, the severed boar's head sign creaking in the wintry wind. Flecks of snow hit the large window at the front of the bus. At last they rolled to a halt outside the gates to Hogwarts.
    Cardozo and Perez helped them off the bus with their luggage, then got off to say goodbye. Roberto glanced up at the three decks of the Knight Bus and saw all the passengers staring down at them, noses flat against the windows.
    'You'll be safe once you're in the grounds,' said Perez, casting a careful eye around at the deserted road. 'Have a good term, OK?'
    'Look after yourselves,' said Cardozo, shaking hands all round and reaching Roberto last. 'And listen . . .' he lowered his voice while the rest of them exchanged last-minute goodbyes with Perez, 'Roberto, I know you don't like Peralta, but he is a superb Occlumens and we all - Gustavo included - want you to learn to protect yourself, so work hard, all right?'
    'Yeah, all right,' said Roberto heavily, looking up into Cardozo's prematurely lined face. 'See you, then.'
    The six of them struggled up the slippery drive towards the castle, dragging their trunks. Carolina was already talking about knitting a few elf hats before bedtime. Roberto glanced back when they reached the oaken front doors; the Knight Bus had already gone and he half-wished, given what was coming the following evening, that he was still on board.
*
Roberto spent most of the next day dreading the evening. His morning double-Potions lesson did nothing to dispel his trepidation, as Peralta was as unpleasant as ever. His mood was further lowered by the DA members constantly approaching him in the corridors between classes, asking hopefully if there would be a meeting that night.
    'I'll let you know in the usual way when the next one is,' Roberto said over and over again, 'but I can't do it tonight, I've got to go to - er - remedial Potions.'
    'You take remedial Potions?' asked Zacharias Smith superciliously, having cornered Roberto in the Entrance Hall after lunch. 'Good Lord, you must be terrible. Peralta doesn't usually give extra lessons, does he?'
    As Smith strode away in an annoyingly buoyant fashion, Diego g'.ared after him.
    'Shall I jinx him? I can still get him from here,' he said, raising his wand and taking aim between Smith's shoulder blades.
    'Forget it,' said Roberto dismally. 'It's what everyone's going to think, isn't it? That I'm really stup - '
    'Hi, Roberto,' said a voice behind him. He turned round and found Paula standing there.
    'Oh,' said Roberto as his stomach leapt uncomfortably. 'Hi.'
    'We'll be in the library, Roberto,' said Carolina firmly as she seized Diego above the elbow and dragged him off towards the marble staircase.
    'Had a good Christmas?' asked Paula.
    'Yeah, not bad,' said Roberto.
    'Mine was pretty quiet,' said Paula. For some reason, she was looking rather embarrassed. 'Erm . . . there's another Hogsmeade trip next month, did you see the notice?'
    'What? Oh, no, I haven't checked the noticeboard since I got back.'
    'Yes, it's on Valentines Day . . .'
    'Right,' said Roberto, wondering why she was telling him this. 'Well, I suppose you want to - ?'
    'Only if you do,' she said eagerly.
    Roberto stared. He had been about to say, 'I suppose you want to know when the next DA meeting is?' but her response did not seem to fit.
    'I - er - ' he said.
    'Oh, it's OK if you don't,' she said, looking mortified. 'Don't worry. I - I'll see you around.'
    She walked away. Roberto stood staring after her, his brain working frantically. Then something clunked into place.
    'Paula! Hey - PAULA!'
    He ran after her, catching her halfway up the marble staircase.
    'Er - d'you want to come into Hogsmeade with me on Valentine s Day?'
    'Oooh, yes!' she said, blushing crimson and beaming at him.
    'Right . . . well . . . that's settled then,' said Roberto, and feeling that the day was not going to be a complete loss after all, he virtually bounced off to the library to pick up Diego and Carolina before their afternoon lessons.
    By six o'clock that evening, however, even the glow of having successfully asked out Paula Mejia could not lighten the ominous feelings that intensified with every step Roberto took towards Peralta's office.
    He paused outside the door when he reached it, wishing he were almost anywhere else, then, taking a deep breath, he knocked and entered.
    The shadowy room was lined with shelves bearing hundreds of glass jars in which slimy bits of animals and plants were suspended in variously coloured potions. In one corner stood the cupboard full of ingredients that Peralta had once accused Roberto - not without reason - of robbing. Roberto's attention was drawn towards the desk, however, where a shallow stone basin engraved with runes and symbols lay in a pool of candlelight. Roberto recognised it at once - it was Dominguez's Pensieve. Wondering what on earth it was doing there, he jumped when Peralta's cold voice came out of the shadows.
    'Shut the door behind you, Gonzales.'
    Roberto did as he was told, with the horrible feeling that he was imprisoning himself. When he turned back into the room, Peralta had moved into the light and was pointing silently at the chair opposite his desk. Roberto sat down and so did Peralta, his cold black eyes fixed unblinkingly upon Roberto, dislike etched in every line of his face.
    'Well, Gonzales, you know why you are here,' he said. 'The Headmaster has asked me to teach you Occlumency. I can only hope that you prove more adept at it than at Potions.'
    'Right,' said Roberto tersely.
    This may not be an ordinary class, Gonzales,' said Peralta, his eyes narrowed malevolently, 'but I am still your teacher and you will therefore call me "sir" or "Professor" at all times.'
    'Yes . . . sir,' said Roberto.
    Peralta continued to survey him through narrowed eyes for a moment, then said, 'Now, Occlumency. As I told you back in your dear godfather's kitchen, this branch of magic seals the mind against magical intrusion and influence.'
    'And why does Professor Dominguez think I need it, sir?' said Roberto looking directly into Peralta's eyes and wondering whether Peralta would answer.
    Peralta looked back at him for a moment and then said contemptuously, 'Surely even you could have worked that out by now, Gonzales? The Dark Lord is highly skilled at Legilimency - '
    'What's that? Sir?'
    'It is the ability to extract feelings and memories from another person's mind - '
    'He can read minds?' said Roberto quickly, his worst fears confirmed.
    'You have no subtlety, Gonzales,' said Peralta, his dark eyes glit-te'ing. 'You do not understand fine distinctions. It is one of the shortcomings that makes you such a lamentable potion-maker.'
    Peralta paused for a moment, apparently to savour the pleasure of insulting Roberto, before continuing.
    'Only Muggles talk of "mind-reading". The mind is not a book, to be opened at will and examined at leisure. Thoughts are not etched on the inside of skulls, to be perused by any invader, ihe mind is a complex and many-layered thing, Gonzales - or at least, most minds are.' He smirked. 'It is true, however, that those who have mastered Legilimency are able, under certain conditions, to delve into the minds of their victims and to interpret their findings correctly. The Dark Lord, for instance, almost always knows when somebody is lying to him. Only those skilled at Occlumency are able to shut down those feelings and memories that contradict the lie, and so can utter falsehoods in his presence without detection.'
    Whatever Peralta said, Legilimency sounded like mind-reading to Roberto, and he didn't like the sound of it at all.
    'So he could know what we're thinking right now? Sir?'
    The Dark Lord is at a considerable distance and the walls and grounds of Hogwarts are guarded by many ancient spells and charms to ensure the bodily and mental safety of those who dwell within them,' said Peralta. Time and space matter in magic, Gonzales. Eye contact is often essential to Legilimency.'
    'Well then, why do I have to learn Occlumency?'
    Peralta eyed Roberto, tracing his mouth with one long, thin finger as he did so.
    The usual rules do not seem to apply with you, Gonzales. The curse that failed to kill you seems to have forged some kind of connection between you and the Dark Lord. The evidence suggests that at times, when your mind is most relaxed and vulnerable - when you are asleep, for instance - you are sharing the Dark Lord's thoughts and emotions. The Headmaster thinks it inadvisable for this to continue. He wishes me to teach you how to close your mind to the Dark Lord.'
    Roberto's heart was pumping fast again. None of this added up.
    'But why does Professor Dominguez want to stop it?' he asked abruptly. 'I don't like it much, but it's been useful, hasn't it? I mean . . . I saw that snake attack Mr Lopez and if I hadn't, Professor Dominguez wouldn't have been able to save him, would he? Sir?'
    Peralta stared at Roberto for a few moments, still tracing his mouth with his finger. When he spoke again, it was slowly and deliberately, as though he weighed every word.
    'It appears that the Dark Lord has bee a unaware of the connection between you and himself until very recently. Up till now it seems that you have been experiencing his emotions, and sharing his thoughts, without his being any the wiser. However, the vision you had shortly before Christmas - '
    The one with the snake and Mr Lopez?'
    'Do not interrupt me, Gonzales,' said Peralta in a dangerous voice. 'As I was saying, the vision you had shortly before Christmas represented such a powerful incursion upon the Dark Lord's thoughts -
    'I saw inside the snake's head, not his!'
    'I thought I just told you not to interrupt me, Gonzales?'
    But Roberto did not care if Peralta was angry; at last he seemed to be getting to the bottom of this business; he had moved forwards in his chair so that, without realising it, he was perched on the very edge, tense as though poised for flight.
    'How come I saw through the snake's eyes if it's Salvador's thoughts I'm sharing?'
    'Do not say the Dark Lord's name!' spat Peralta.
    There was a nasty silence. They glared at each other across the Pensieve.
    'Professor Dominguez says his name.' said Roberto quietly.
    'Dominguez is an extremely powerful wizard,' Peralta muttered. 'While he may feel secure enough to use the name . . . the rest of us . . .' He rubbed his left forearm, apparently unconsciously, on the spot where Roberto knew the Dark Mark was burned into his skin.
    'I just wanted to know,' Roberto began again, forcing his voice back to politeness, 'why - '
    'You seem to have visited the snake's mind because that was where the Dark Lord was at that particular moment,' snarled Peralta. 'He was possessing the snake at the time and so you dreamed you were inside it, too.'
    'And Vol - he - realised I was there?'
    'It seems so,' said Peralta coolly.
    'How do you know?' said Roberto urgently. 'Is this just Professor Dominguez guessing, or - ?'
    'I told you,' said Peralta, rigid in his chair, his eyes slits, 'to call me "sir".
    'Yes, sir,' said Roberto impatiently, 'but how do you know - '?
    'It is enough that we know,' said Peralta repressively. The important point is that the Dark Lord is now aware that you are gaining access to his thoughts and feelings. He has also deduced that the process is likely to work in reverse; that is to say, he has realised that he might be able to access your thoughts and feelings in return - '
    'And he might try and make me do things?' asked Roberto. 'Sir?' he added hurriedly.
    'He might,' said Peralta, sounding cold and unconcerned. 'Which brings us back to Occlumency.'
    Peralta pulled out his wand from an inside pocket of his robes and Roberto tensed in his chair, but Peralta merely raised the wand to his temple and placed its tip into the greasy roots of his hair. When he withdrew it, some silvery substance came away, stretching from temple to wand like a thick gossamer strand, which broke as he pulled the wand away from it and fell gracefully into the Pensieve, where it swirled silvery-white, neither gas nor liquid. Twice more, Peralta raised the wand to his temple and deposited the silvery substance into the stone basin, then, without offering any explanation of his behaviour, he picked up the Pensieve carefully, removed it to a shelf out of their way and returned to face Roberto with his wand held at the ready.
    'Stand up and take out your wand, Gonzales.'
    Roberto got to his feet, feeling nervous. They faced each other with the desk between them.
    'You may use your wand to attempt to disarm me, or defend yourself in any other way you can think of,' said Peralta.
    'And what are you going to do?' Roberto asked, eyeing Peralta's wand apprehensively.
    'I am about to attempt to break into your mind,' said Peralta softly. 'We are going to see how well you resist. I have been told that you have already shown aptitude at resisting the Imperius Curse. You will find that similar powers are needed for this . . . brace yourself, now. Legilimens!'
    Peralta had struck before Roberto was ready, before he had even begun to summon any force of resistance. The office swam in front of his eyes and vanished; image after image was racing through his mind like a flickering film so vivid it blinded him to his surroundings.
    He was five, watching Leonardo riding a new red bicycle, and his heart was bursting with jealousy . . . he was nine, and Ripper the bulldog was chasing him up a tree and the Carrizos were laughing below on the lawn . . . he was sitting under the Sorting Hat, and it was telling him he would do well in Slytherin . . . Carolina was lying in the hospital wing, her face covered with thick black hair . . . a hundred Dementors were closing in on him beside the dark lake . . . Paula Mejia was drawing nearer to him under the mistletoe . . .
    No, said a voice inside Roberto's head, as the memory of Paula drew nearer, you're not watching that, you're not watching it, it's private - '
    He felt a sharp pain in his knee. Peralta's office had come back into view and he realised that he had fallen to the floor; one of his knees had collided painfully with the leg of Peralta's desk. He looked up at Peralta, who had lowered his wand and was rubbing his wrist. There was an angry weal there, like a scorch mark.
    'Did you mean to produce a Stinging Hex?' asked Peralta coolly.
    'No,' said Roberto bitterly, getting up from the floor.
    'I thought not,' said Peralta, watching him closely. 'You let me get in too far. You lost control.'
    'Did you see everything I saw?' Roberto asked, unsure whether he wanted to hear the answer.
    'Flashes of it,' said Peralta, his lip curling. To whom did the dog belong?'
    'My Aunt Marge,' Roberto muttered, hating Peralta.
    'Well, for a first attempt that was not as poor as it might have been,' said Peralta, raising his wand once more. 'You managed to stop me eventually, though you wasted time and energy shouting. You must remain focused. Repel me with your brain and you will not need to resort to your wand.'
    'I'm trying,' said Roberto angrily, 'but you're not telling me how!'
    'Manners, Gonzales,' said Peralta dangerously. 'Now, I want you to close your eyes.'
    Roberto threw him a filthy look before doing as he was told. He did not like the idea of standing there with his eyes shut while Peralta faced him, carrying a wand.
    'Clear your mind, Gonzales,' said Peralta's cold voice. 'Let go of all emotion . . .'
    But Roberto's anger at Peralta continued to pound through his veins like venom. Let go of his anger? He could as easily detach his legs . . .
    'You're not doing it, Gonzales . . . you will need more discipline than this . . . focus, now . . .'
    Roberto tried to empty his mind, tried not to think, or remember, or feel . . .
    'Let's go again . . . on the count of three . . . one - two - three - 'Legilimens!'
    A great black dragon was rearing in front of him . . . his father and mother were waving at him out of an enchanted mirror . . . Nicolas Ortega was lying on the ground with blank eyes staring at him . . .
    'NOOOOOOO!'
    Roberto was on his knees again, his face buried in his hands, his brain aching as though someone had been trying to pull it from his skull.
    'Get up!' said Peralta sharply. 'Get up! You are not trying, you are making no effort. You are allowing me access to memories you fear, handing me weapons!'
    Roberto stood up again, his heart thumping wildly as though he had really just seen Nicolas dead in the graveyard. Peralta looked paler than usual, and angrier, though not nearly as angry as Roberto was.
    'I - am - making - an - effort,' he said through clenched teeth.
    'I told you to empty yourself of emotion!'
    'Yeah? Well, I'm finding that hard at the moment,' Roberto snarled.
    Then you will find yourself easy prey for the Dark Lord!' said Peralta savagely. 'Fools who wear their hearts proudly on their sleeves, who cannot control their emotions, who wallow in sad memories and allow themselves to be provoked so easily - weak people, in other words - they stand no chance against his powers! He will penetrate your mind with absurd ease, Gonzales!'
    'I am not weak,' said Roberto in a low voice, fury now pumping through him so that he thought he might attack Peralta in a moment.
    'Then prove it! Master yourself!' spat Peralta. 'Control your anger, discipline your mind! We shall try again! Get ready, now! Legilimens!'
    He was watching Uncle Francisco hammering the letterbox shut . . . a hundred Dementors were drifting across the lake in the grounds towards him . . . he was running along a windowless passage with Mr Lopez . . . they were drawing nearer to the plain black door at the end of the corridor . . . Roberto expected to go through it . . . but Mr Lopez led him off to the left, down a flight of stone steps . . .
    'I KNOW! I KNOW!'
    He was on all fours again on Peralta's office floor, his scar was prickling unpleasantly, but the voice that had just issued from his mouth was triumphant. He pushed himself up again to find Peralta storing at him, his wand raised. It looked as though, this time, Peralta had lifted the spell before Roberto had even tried to fight back.
    'What happened then, Gonzales?' he asked, eyeing Roberto intently.
    'I saw - I remembered,' Roberto panted. 'I've just realised . . .'
    'Realised what?' asked Peralta sharply.
    Roberto did not answer at once; he was still savouring the moment of blinding realisation as he rubbed his forehead . . .
    He had been dreaming about a windowless corridor ending in a locked door for months, without once realising that it was a real place. Now, seeing the memory again, he knew that all along he had been dreaming about the corridor down which he had run with Mr Lopez on the twelfth of August as they hurried to the courtrooms in the Ministry; it was the corridor leading to the Department of Mysteries and Mr Lopez had been there the night that he had been attacked by Salvador's snake.
    He looked up at Peralta.
    'What's in the Department of Mysteries?'
    'What did you say?' Peralta asked quietly and Roberto saw, with deep satisfaction, that Peralta was unnerved.
    'I said, what's in the Department of Mysteries, sir?' Roberto said.
    'And why,' said Peralta slowly, 'would you ask such a thing?'
    'Because,' said Roberto, watching Peralta's face closely, 'that corridor I've just seen - I've been dreaming about it for montns - I've just recognised it - it leads to the Department of Mysteries . . . and I think Salvador wants something from - '
    'I have told you not to say the Dark Lord's name!'
    They glared at each other. Roberto's scar seared again, but he did not care. Peralta looked agitated; but when he spoke again he sounded as though he was trying to appear cool and unconcerned.
    There are many things in the Department of Mysteries, Gonzales, few of which you would understand and none of which concern you. Do I make myself plain?'
    'Yes,' Roberto said, still rubbing his prickling scar, which was becoming more painful.
    'I want you back here same time on Wednesday. We will continue work then.'
    'Fine,' said Roberto. He was desperate to get out of Peralta's office and find Diego and Carolina.
    'You are to rid your mind of all emotion every night before sleep; empty it, make it blank and calm, you understand?'
    'Yes,' said Roberto, who was barely listening.
    'And be warned, Gonzales . . . I shall know if you have not practised . . .'
    'Right,' Roberto mumbled. He picked up his schoolbag, swung it over his shoulder and hurried towards the office door. As he opened it, he glanced back at Peralta, who had his back to Roberto and was scooping his own thoughts out of the Pensieve with the tip of his wand and replacing them carefully inside his own head. Roberto left without another word, closing the door carefully behind him, his scar still throbbing painfully.
    Roberto found Diego and Carolina in the library, where they were working on Umbridge's most recent ream of homework. Other students, nearly all of them fifth-years, sat at lamp-lit tables nearby, noses close to books, quills scratching feverishly, while the sky outside the mullioned windows grew steadily blacker. The only other sound was the slight squeaking of one of Madam Pince's shoes, as the librarian prowled the aisles menacingly, breathing down the necks of those touching her precious books.
    Roberto felt shivery; his scar was still aching, he felt almost feverish.
    When he sat down opposite Diego and Carolina, he caught sight of himself in the window opposite; he was very white and his scar seemed to be showing up more clearly than usual.
    'How did it go?' Carolina whispered, and then, looking concerned. 'Are you all right, Roberto?'
    'Yeah . . . fine . . . I dunno,' said Roberto impatiently, wincing as pain shot through his scar again. 'Listen . . . I've just realised something . . .'
    And he told them what he had just seen and deduced.
    'So . . . so are you saying . . .' whispered Diego, as Madam Pince swept past, squeaking slightly 'that the weapon - the thing You-Know-Who's after - is in the Ministry of Magic?'
    'In the Department of Mysteries, it's got to be,' Roberto whispered. 'I saw that door when your dad took me down to the courtrooms for my hearing and it's definitely the same one he was guarding when the snake bit him.'
    Carolina let out a long, slow sigh.
    'Of course,' she breathed.
    'Of course what?' said Diego rather impatiently.
    'Diego, think about it. . . Sturgis Podmore was trying to get through a door at the Ministry of Magic . . . it must have been that one, it's too much of a coincidence!'
    'How come Sturgis was trying to break in when he's on our side?' said Diego.
    'Well, I don't know,' Carolina admitted. That is a bit odd . . .'
    'So what's in the Department of Mysteries?' Roberto asked Diego. 'Has your dad ever mentioned anything about it?'
    'I know they call the people who work in there "Unspeakables",' said Diego, frowning. 'Because no one really seems to know what they do - weird place to have a weapon.'
    'It's not weird at all, it makes perfect sense,' said Carolina. 'It will be something top secret that the Ministry has been developing, I expect . . . Roberto, are you sure you're all right?'
    For Roberto had just run both his hands hard over his forehead as though trying to iron it.
    'Yeah . . . fine . . .' he said, lowering his hands, which were trembling. 'I just feel a bit . . . I don't like Occlumency much.'
    I expect anyone would feel snaky if they'd had their mind attacked over and over again,' said Carolina sympathetically. 'Look, let's get back to the common room, we'll be a bit more comfortable there.'
    But the common room was packed and full of shrieks of laughter and excitement; Pablo and Luis were demonstrating their latest bit of joke shop merchandise.
    'Headless Hats!' shouted Luis, as Pablo waved a pointed hat decorated with a fluffy pink feather at the watching students. Two Galleons each, watch Pablo, now!'
    Pablo swept the hat on to his head, beaming. For a second he merely looked rather stupid; then both hat and head vanished.
    Several girls screamed, but everyone else was roaring with laughter.
    'And off again!' shouted Luis, and Pablo's hand groped for a moment in what seemed to be thin air over his shoulder; then his head reappeared as he swept the pink-feathered hat from it.
    'How do those hats work, then?' said Carolina, distracted from her homework and watching Pablo and Luis closely. 'I mean, obviously it's some kind of Invisibility Spell, but it's rather clever to have extended the field of invisibility beyond the boundaries of the charmed object . . . I'd imagine the charm wouldn't have a very long life though.'
    Roberto did not answer; he was feeling ill.
    'I'm going to have to do this tomorrow,' he muttered, pushing the books he had just taken out of his bag back inside it.
    'Well, write it in your homework planner then!' said Carolina encouragingly. 'So you don't forget!'
    Roberto and Diego exchanged looks as he reached into his bag, withdrew the planner and opened it tentatively.
    'Don't leave it till later, you big second-rater!' chided the book as Roberto scribbled down Umbridge's homework. Carolina beamed at it.
    'I think I'll go to bed,' said Roberto, stuffing the homework planner back into his bag and making a mental note to drop it in the fire the first opportunity he got.
    He walked across the common room, dodging Luis, who tried to put a Headless Hat on him, and reached the peace and cool of the stone staircase to the boys' dormitories. He was feeling sick again, just as he had the night he had had the vision of the snake, but thought that if he could just lie down for a while he would be all right.
    He opened the door of his dormitory and was one step inside it when he experienced pain so severe he thought that someone must have sliced into the top of his head. He did not know where be was, whether he was standing or lying down, he did not even know his own name.
    Maniacal laughter was ringing in his ears . . . he was happier than he had been in a very long time . . . jubilant, ecstatic, triumphant . . . a wonderful, wonderful thing had happened . . .
    'Roberto? ROBERTO!'
    Someone had hit him around the face. The insane laughter was punctuated with a cry of pain. The happiness was draining out of him, but the laughter continued . . .
    He opened his eyes and, as he did so, he became aware that the wild laughter was coming out of his own mouth. The moment he realised this, it died away; Roberto lay panting on the floor, staring up at the ceiling, the scar on his forehead throbbing horribly. Diego was bending over him, looking very worried.
    'What happened?' he said.
    'I . . . dunno . . .' Roberto gasped, sitting up again. 'He's really happy . . . really happy . . .'
    'You-Know-Who is?'
    'Something good's happened,' mumbled Roberto. He was shaking as badly as he had done after seeing the snake attack Mr Lopez and felt very sick. 'Something he's been hoping for.'
    The words came, just as they had back in the Gryffindor changing room, as though a stranger was speaking them through Roberto's mouth, yet he knew they were true. He took deep breaths, willing himself not to vomit all over Diego. He was very glad that Dean and Seamus were not here to watch this time.
    'Carolina told me to come and check on you,' said Diego in a low voice, helping Roberto to his feet. 'She says your defences will be low at the moment, after Peralta's been fiddling around with your mind . . . still, I suppose it'll help in the long run, won't it?' He looked doubtfully at Roberto as he helped him towards his bed. Roberto nodded without any conviction and slumped back on his pillows, aching all over from having fallen to the floor so often that evening, his scar still prickling painfully. He could not help feeling that his first foray into Occlumency had weakened his mind's resistance rather than strengthening it, and he wondered, with a feeling of great trepidation, what had happened to make Lord Salvador the happiest he had been in fourteen years.
- CHAPTER TWENTY-FIVE -
The Beetle at Bay
Roberto's question was answered the very next morning. When Carolina's Daily Prophet arrived she smoothed it out, gazed for a moment at the front page and gave a yelp that caused everyone in the vicinity to stare at her.
    'What?' said Roberto and Diego together.
    For answer she spread the newspaper on the table in front of them and pointed at ten black-and-white photographs that filled the whole of the front page, nine showing wizards' faces and the tenth, a witch's. Some of the people in the photographs were silently jeering; others were tapping their fingers on the frame of their pictures, looking insolent. Each picture was captioned with a name and the crime for which the person had been sent to Azkaban.
    Antonin Dolohov, read the legend beneath a wizard with a long, pale, twisted face who was sneering up at Roberto convicted of the brutal murders of Gideon and Fabian Prewett.
    Algernon Rookwood, said the caption beneath a pockmarked man with greasy hair who was leaning against the edge of his picture, looking bored, convicted of leaking Ministry of Magic secrets to He Who Must Not Be Named.
    But Roberto's eyes were drawn to the picture of the witch. Her face had leapt out at him the moment he had seen the page. She had long, dark hair that looked unkempt and straggly in the picture, though he had seen it sleek, thick and shining. She glared up at him through heavily lidded eyes, an arrogant, disdainful smile playing around her thin mouth. Like Gustavo, she retained vestiges of great good looks, but something - perhaps Azkaban - had taken most of her beauty.
    Miranda Gimenez, convicted of the torture and permanent mca-pacitation of Frank and Alice LongbotWm.
    Carolina nudged Roberto and pointed at the headline over the pictures, which Roberto, concentrating on Miranda, had not yet read.
MASS BREAKOUT FROM AZKABAN
MINISTRY FEARS MARTINEZ IS 'RALLYING POINT'
FOR OLD DEATH EATERS
'Martinez?' said Roberto loudly. 'Not - ?'
    'Shhh!' whispered Carolina desperately. 'Not so loud - 'just read it!'
The Ministry of Magic announced late last night that there has been a mass breakout from Azkaban.
    Speaking to reporters in his private office, Cornelius Fudge, Minister for Magic, confirmed that ten high-security prisoners escaped in the early hours of yesterday evening and that he has already informed the Muggle Prime Minister of the dangerous nature of these individuals.
    'We find ourselves, most unfortunately, in the same position we were two and a half years ago when the murderer Gustavo Martinez escaped,' said Fudge last night. 'Nor do we think the two breakouts are unrelated. An escape of this magnitude suggests outside help, and we must remember that Martinez, as the first person ever to break out of Azkaban, would be ideally placed to help others follow in his footsteps. We think it likely that these individuals, who include Martinez's cousin, Miranda Gimenez, have rallied around Martinez as their leader. We are, however, doing all we can to round up the criminals, and we beg the magical community to remain alert and cautious. On no account should any of these individuals be approached.'
There you are, Roberto,' said Diego, looking awestruck. That's why he was happy last night.'
    'I don't believe this,' snarled Roberto, 'Fudge is blaming the breakout on Gustavo?'
    'What other options does he have?' said Carolina bitterly. 'He can hardly say, "Sorry, everyone, Dominguez warned me this might happen, the Azkaban guards have joined Lord Salvador" - stop whimpering, Diego - "and now Salvador's worst supporters have broken out, too." I mean, he's spent a good six months telling everyone you and Dominguez are liars, hasn't he?'
    Carolina ripped open the newspaper and began to read the report inside while Roberto looked around the Great Hall. He could not understand why his fellow students were not looking scared or at least discussing the terrible piece of news on the front page, but very few of them took the newspaper every day like Carolina. There they all were, talking about homework and Quidditch and who knew what other rubbish, when outside these walls ten more Death Eaters had swollen Salvador's ranks.
    He glanced up at the staff table. It was a different story there: Dominguez and Professor Romero were deep in conversation, both looking extremely grave. Professor Sprout had the Prophet propped against a bottle of ketchup and was reading the front page with such concentration that she was not noticing the gentle drip o egg yolk falling into her lap from her stationary spoon. Meanwhile, at the far end of the table, Professor Umbridge was tucking into a bowl of porridge. For once her pouchy toad's eyes were not sweeping the Great Hall looking for misbehaving students. She scowled as she gulped down her food and every now and then she shot a malevolent glance up the table to where Dominguez and Romero were talking so intently.
    'Oh my - ' said Carolina wonderingly, still staring at the newspaper.
    'What now?' said Roberto quickly; he was feeling jumpy.
    'It's . . . horrible,' said Carolina, looking shaken. She folded back page ten of the newspaper and handed it to Roberto and Diego.
TRAGIC DEMISE OF MINISTRY OF MAGIC WORKER
St Mungo's Hospital promised a full inquiry last night after Ministry of Magic worker Broderich Bode, 49, was discovered dead in his bed, strangled by a pot plant. Healers called to the scene were unable to revive Mr Bode, who had been injured in a workplace accident some weeks prior to his death.
    Healer Miriam Strout, who was in charge of Mr Bodes ward at the time of the incident, has been suspended on full pay and was unavailable for comment yesterday, but a spokeswizard for the hospital said in a statement:
    'St Mungo's deeply regrets the death of Mr Bode, whose health was improving steadily prior to this tragic accident.
    'We have strict guidelines on the decorations permitted on our wards but it appears that Healer Strout, busy over the Christmas period, overlooked the dangers of the plant on Mr Bode's bedside table. As his speech and mobility improved, Healer Strout encouraged Mr Bode to look after the plant himself, unaware that it was not an innocent Flitterbloom, but a cutting of Devil's Snare which, when touched by the convalescent Mr Bode, throttled him instantly.
    'St Mungo's is as vet unable to account for the presence of the plant on the ward and asks any witch or wizard with information to come forward.'
'Bode . . .' said Diego. 'Bode. It rings a bell . . .'
    'We saw him,' Carolina whispered. In St Mungo's, remember? He was in the bed opposite Lockhart's, just lying there, staring at the ceiling. And we saw the Devil's Snare arrive. She - the Healer - said it was a Christmas present.'
    Roberto looked back at the story. A feeling of horror was rising like bile in his throat.
    'How come we didn't recognise Devil's Snare? We've seen it before . . . we could've stopped this from happening.'
    'Who expects Devil's Snare to turn up in a hospital disguised as a pot plant?' said Diego sharply. 'It's not our fault, whoever sent it to the bloke is to blame! They must be a real prat, why didn't they check what they were buying?'
    'Oh, come on, Diego!' said Carolina shakily. 'I don't think anyone could put Devil's Snare in a pot and not realise it tries to kill whoever touches it? This - this was murder . . . a clever murder, as well . . . if the plant was sent anonymously, how's anyone ever going to find out who did it?'
    Roberto was not thinking about Devil's Snare. He was remembering taking the lift down to the ninth level of the Ministry on the day of his hearing and the sallow-faced man who had got in on the Atrium level.
    'I met Bode,' he said slowly. 'I saw him at the Ministry with your dad.'

    'I've heard Dad talk about him at home! He was an Unspeakable
    ' - he worked in the Department of Mysteries!'

    'Where are you going?' said Diego, startled.
    To send a letter,' said Carolina, swinging her bag on to her shoulder. 'It . . . well, I don't know whether . . . but it's worth trying . . . and I'm the only one who can.'
    'I hate it when she does that,' grumbled Diego, as he and Roberto got up from the table and made their own, slower way out of the Great Hall. 'Would it kill her to tell us what she's up to for once? It'd take her about ten more seconds - hey, Villalba!'
    Villalba was standing beside the doors into the Entrance Hall, waiting for a crowd of Ravenclaws to pass. He was still as heavily bruised as he had been on the day he had come back from his mission to the giants and there was a new cut right across the bridge of his nose.
    'All righ', you two?' he said, trying to muster a smile but managing only a kind of pained grimace.
    'Are you OK, Villalba?' asked Roberto, following him as he lumbered after the Ravenclaws.
    'Fine, fine,' said Villalba with a feeble assumption of airiness; he w aved a hand and narrowly missed concussing a frightened-looking Professor Vector, who was passing. 'Jus' busy, yeh know, usual stuff
    ' - lessons ter prepare - couple o' salamanders got scale rot - an' I'm on probation,' he mumbled.
    'You're on probation?' said Diego very loudly, so that many of the passing students looked around curiously. 'Sorry - I mean - you're on probation?' he whispered.
    'Yeah,' said Villalba. ' 'S'no more'n I expected, ter tell yen the truth. Yeh migh' not've picked up on it, bu' that inspection didn' go too well, yeh know . . . anyway,' he sighed deeply. 'Bes' go an' rub a bit more chilli powder on them salamanders or their tails'll be hangin' off 'em next. See yeh, Roberto . . . Diego . . .'
    He trudged away, out of the front doors and down the stone steps into the damp grounds. Roberto watched him go, wondering how much more bad news he could stand.
*
The fact that Villalba was now on probation became common knowledge within the school over the next few days, but to Roberto's indignation, hardly anybody appeared to be upset about it; indeed, some people, Javier Sosa prominent among them, seemed positively gleeful. As for the freakish death of an obscure Department of Mysteries employee in St Mungo's, Roberto, Diego and Carolina seemed to be the only people who knew or cared. There was only one topic of conversation in the corridors now: the ten escaped Death Eaters, whose story had finally filtered through the school from those few people who read the newspapers. Rumours were flying that some of the convicts had been spotted in Hogsmeade, that they were supposed to be hiding out in the Shrieking Shack and that they were going to break into Hogwarts, just as Gustavo Martinez had once done.
    Those who came from wizarding families had grown up hearing the names of these Death Eaters spoken with almost as much fear as Salvadors; the crimes they had committed during the days of Salvador's reign of terror were legendary. There were relatives cf their victims among the Hogwarts students, who now found themselves the unwilling objects of a gruesome sort of reflected fame as they walked the corridors: Susan Bones, whose uncle, aunt and cousins had all died at the hands of one of the ten, said miserably during Herbology that she now had a good idea what it felt like to be Roberto.
    'And I don't know how you stand it - it's horrible,' she said bluntly, dumping far too much dragon manure on her tray of Screechsnap seedlings, causing them to wriggle and squeak in discomfort.
    It was true that Roberto was the subject of much renewed muttering and pointing in the corridors these days, yet he thought he detected a slight difference in the lone of the whisperers' voices. They sounded curious rather than hostile now, and once or twice he was sure he overheard snatches of conversation that, suggested that the speakers were not satisfied with the Prophet's version of how and why ten Death Eaters had managed to break out of the Azkaban fortress. In their confusion and fear, these doubters now seemed to be turning to the only other explanation available to them: the one that Roberto and Dominguez had been expounding since the previous year.
    It was not only the students' mood that had changed. It was now quite common to come across two or three teachers conversing in low, urgent whispers in the corridors, breaking off their conversations the moment they saw students approaching.
    They obviously can't talk freely in the staff room any more,' said Carolina in a low voice, as she, Roberto and Diego passed Professors Romero, Flitwick and Sprout huddled together outside the Charms classroom one day. 'Not with Umbridge there.'
    'Reckon they know anything new?' said Diego, gazing back over his shoulder at the three teachers.
    'If they do, we're not going to hear about it, are we?' said Roberto angrily. 'Not after Decree . . . what number are we on now?' For new notices had appeared on the house noticeboards the morning after news of the Azkaban breakout:
BY ORDER OF THE HIGH INQUISITOR OF HOGWARTS
Teachers are hereby banned from giving students any information
that is not strictly related to the subjects they are paid to teach.
The above is in accordance with Educational Decree
Number Twenty-six.
Signed: Dolores Jane Umbridge, High Inquisitor
This latest Decree had been the subject of a great number of jokes among the students. Lee Jordan had pointed out to Umbridge that by the terms of the new rule she was not allowed to tell Pablo and Luis off for playing Exploding Snap in the back of the class.
    'Exploding Snap's got nothing to do with Defence Against the Dark Arts, Professor! That's not information relating to your subject!'
    When Roberto next saw Lee, the back of his hand was bleeding rather badly. Roberto recommended essence of Murtlap.
    Roberto had thought the breakout from Azkaban might have humbled Umbridge a little, that she might have been abashed at the catastrophe that had occurred right under the nose of her beloved Fudge. It seemed, however, to have only intensified her furious desire to bring every aspect of life at Hogwarts under her personal control. She seemed determined at the very least to achieve a sacking before long, and the only question was whether it would be Professor Trelawney or Villalba who went first.
    Every single Divination and Care of Magical Creatures lesson was now conducted in the presence of Umbridge and her clipboard. She lurked by the fire in the heavily perfumed tower room, interrupting Professor Trelawney's increasingly hysterical talks with difficult questions about ornithomancy and heptomology, insisting that she predicted students' answers before they gave them and demanding that she demonstrate her skill at the crystal ball, the tea leaves and the rune stones in turn. Roberto thought Professor Trelawney might soon crack under the strain. Several times he passed her in the corridors - in itself a very unusual occurrence as she generally remained in her tower room - muttering wildly to herself, wringing her hands and shooting terrified glances over her shoulder, and all the while giving off a powerful smell of cooking sherry. If he had not been so worried about Villalba, he would have felt sorry for her - but if one of them was to be ousted from their job, there could be only one choice for Roberto as to who should remain.
    Unfortunately, Roberto could not see that Villalba was putting up a better show than Trelawney. Though he seemed to be following Carolina's advice and had shown them nothing more frightening than a Crup - a creature indistinguishable from a Jack Russell terrier except for its forked tail - since before Christmas, he too seemed to have lost his nerve. He was oddly distracted and jumpy during lessons, losing the thread of what he was saying to the class, answering questions wrongly, and all the time glancing anxiously at Umbridge. He was also more distant with Roberto, Diego and Carolina than he had ever been before, and had expressly forbidden them to visit him after dark.
    'If she catches yeh, it'll be all of our necks on the line,' he told ;:hem flatly, and with no desire to do anything that might jeopardise his job further they abstained from walking down to his hut :.n the evenings.
    It seemed to Roberto that Umbridge was steadily depriving him of everything that made his life at Hogwarts worth living: visits to Villalba's house, letters from Gustavo, his Firebolt and Quidditch. He took his revenge the only way he could - by redoubling his efforts for the DA.
    Roberto was pleased to see that all of them, even Zacharias Smith, had been spurred on to work harder than ever by the news that ten more Death Eaters were now on the loose, but in nobody was this improvement more pronounced than in Mauricio. The news of his parents' attackers' escape had wrought a strange and even slightly alarming change in him. He had not once mentioned his meeting with Roberto, Diego and Carolina on the closed ward in St Mungo's and, taking their lead from him, they had kept quiet about it too. Nor had he said anything on the subject of Miranda and her fellow torturers' escape. In fact, Mauricio barely spoke during the DA meetings any more, but worked relentlessly on every new jinx and counter-curse Roberto taught them, his plump face screwed up in concentration, apparently indifferent to injuries or accidents and working harder than anyone else in the room. He was improving so fast it was quite unnerving and when Roberto taught them, the Shield Charm - a means of deflecting minor jinxes so that they rebounded upon the attacker - only Carolina mastered the charm faster than Mauricio.
    Roberto would have given a great deal to be making as much progress at Occlumency as Mauricio was making during the DA meetings. Roberto's sessions with Peralta, which had started badly enough, were not improving. On the contrary, Roberto felt he was getting \vorse with every lesson.
    Before he had started studying Occlumency, his scar had prickled occasionally, usually during the night, or else following one of those strange flashes of Salvador's thoughts or mood that he experienced every now and then. Nowadays, however, his scar hardly ever stopped prickling, and he often felt lurches of annoyance or cheerfulness that were unrelated to what was happening to him at the time, which were always accompanied by a particularly painful twinge from his scar. He had the horrible impression that he was slowly turning into a kind of aerial that was tuned in to tiny fluctuations in Salvador's mood, and he was sure he could date this increased sensitivity firmly from his first Occlumency lesson with Peralta. What was more, he was now dreaming about walking down the corridor towards the entrance to the Department of Mysteries almost every night, dreams which always culminated in him standing longingly in front of the plain black door.
    'Maybe it's a bit like an illness,' said Carolina, looking concerned when Roberto confided in her and Diego. 'A fever or something. It has to get worse before it gets better.'
    The lessons with Peralta are making it worse,' said Roberto flatly 'I'm getting sick of my scar hurting and I'm getting bored with walking down that corridor every night.' He rubbed his forehead angrily. 'I just wish the door would open, I'm sick of standing staring at it - '
    That's not funny,' said Carolina sharply. 'Dominguez doesn't want you to have dreams about that corridor at all, or he wouldn't have asked Peralta to teach you Occlumency. You're just going to have to work a bit harder in your lessons.'
    'I am working!' said Roberto, nettled. "You try it some time - Peralta: trying to get inside your head - it's not a bundle of laughs, you know!'
    'Maybe . . .' said Diego slowly.
    'Maybe what?' said Carolina, rather snappishly.
    'Maybe it's not Roberto's fault he can't close his mind,' said Diego darkly.
    'What do you mean?' said Carolina.
    'Well, maybe Peralta isn't really trying to help Roberto . . .'
    Roberto and Carolina stared at him. Diego looked darkly and meaningfully from one to the other.
    'Maybe,' he said again, in a lower voice, 'he's actually trying to open Roberto's mind a bit wider . . . make it easier for You-Know-
    'Shut up, Diego,' said Carolina angrily. 'How many times have you suspected Peralta, and when have you ever been right? Dominguez trusts him, he works for the Order, that ought to be enough.'
    'He used to be a Death Eater,' said Diego stubbornly. 'And we've never seen proof that he really swapped sides.'
    'Dominguez trusts him,' Carolina repeated. 'And if we can't trust Dominguez, we can't trust anyone.'
*
With so much to worry about and so much to do - startling amounts of homework that frequently kept the fifth-years working until past midnight, secret DA sessions and regular classes with Peralta - 'January seemed to be passing alarmingly fast. Before Roberto knew it, February had arrived, bringing with it wetter and warmer weather and the prospect of the second Hogsmeade visit of the year. Roberto had had very little time to spare for conversations with Paula since they had agreed to visit the village together, but suddenly found himself facing a Valentine's Day spent entirely in her company.
    On the morning of the fourteenth he dressed particularly carefully. He and Diego arrived at breakfast just in time for the arrival of the post owls, Hedwig was not there - not that Roberto had expected her - but Carolina was tugging a letter from the beak of an unfamiliar brown owl as they sat down.
    'And about time! If it hadn't come today . . .' she said, eagerly tearing open the envelope and pulling out a small piece of parchment. Her eyes sped from left to right as she read through the message and a grimly pleased expression spread across her face.
    'Listen, Roberto,' she said, looking up at him, 'this is really important. Do you think you could meet me in the Three Broomsticks around midday?'
    'Well . . . I dunno,' said Roberto uncertainly. 'Paula might be expecting me to spend the whole day with her. We never said what we were going to do.'
    Well, bring her along if you must,' said Carolina urgently. 'But will you come?'
    'Well . . . all right, but why?'
    'I haven't got time to tell you now, I've got to answer this quickly.'
    And she hurried out of the Great Hall, the letter clutched in one hand and a piece of toast in the other.
    'Are you coming?' Roberto asked Diego, but he shook his head, looking glum.
