    Wormtail turned slightly pink, but Ricardo grinned.
    'If it bothers you,' he said, stuffing the Snitch back in his pocket. Roberto had the distinct impression that Gustavo was the only one for whom Ricardo would have stopped showing off.
    'I'm bored,' said Gustavo. 'Wish it was full moon.'
    'You might,' said Cardozo darkly from behind his book. We've still got Transfiguration, if you're bored you could test me. Here . . .' and he held out his book.
    But Gustavo snorted. 'I don't need to look at that rubbish, I know it all.'
    'This'll liven you up, Padfoot,' said Ricardo quietly. 'Look who it is Gustavo's head turned. He became very still, like a dog that has scented a rabbit.
    'Excellent,' he said softly. 'Snivellus.'
    Roberto turned to see what Gustavo was looking at.
    Peralta was on his feet again, and was stowing the OWL paper in his bag. As he left the shadows of the bushes and set off across the grass, Gustavo and Ricardo stood up.
    Cardozo and Wormtail remained sitting: Cardozo was still staring down at his book, though his eyes were not moving and a faint frown line had appeared between his eyebrows; Wormtail was looking from Gustavo and Ricardo to Peralta with a look of avid anticipation on his face.
    'All right, Snivellus?' said Ricardo loudly.
    Peralta reacted so fast it was as though he had been expecting an attack: dropping his bag, he plunged his hand inside his robes and his wand was halfway into the air when Ricardo shouted, 'Expelliarmus!'
    Peralta's wand flew twelve feet into the air and fell with a little thud in the grass behind him. Gustavo let out a bark of laughter.
    'Impedimenta!' he said, pointing his wand at Peralta, who was knocked off his feet halfway through a dive towards his own fallen wand.
    Students all around had turned to watch. Some of them had got to their feet and were edging nearer. Some looked apprehensive, others entertained.
    Peralta lay panting on the ground. Ricardo and Gustavo advanced on him, wands raised, Ricardo glancing over his shoulder at the girls at the water's edge as he went. Wormtail was on his feet now, watching hungrily, edging around Cardozo to get a clearer view.
    'How'd the exam go, Snivelly?' said Ricardo.
    'I was watching him, his nose was touching the parchment,' said Gustavo viciously. There'll be great grease marks all over it, they won't be able to read a word.'
    Several people watching laughed; Peralta was clearly unpopular. Wormtail sniggered shrilly. Peralta was trying to get up, but the jinx was still operating on him; he was struggling, as though bound by invisible ropes.
    'You - wait,' he panted, staring up at Ricardo with an expression of purest loathing, 'you - wait!'
    'Wait for what?' said Gustavo coolly. 'What're you going to do, Snivelly, wipe your nose on us?'
    Peralta let out a stream of mixed swear words and hexes, but with his wand ten feet away nothing happened.
    'Wash out your mouth,' said Ricardo coldly. 'Scourgify!'
    Pink soap bubbles streamed from Peralta's mouth at once; the froth was covering his lips, making him gag, choking him - '
    'Leave him ALONE!'
    Ricardo and Gustavo looked round. Ricardo's free hand immediately jumped to his hair.
    It was one of the girls from the lake edge. She had thick, dark red hair that fell to her shoulders, and startlingly green almond-shaped eyes - Roberto's eyes.
    Roberto's mother.
    'All right, Evans?' said Ricardo, and the tone of his voice was suddenly pleasant, deeper, more mature.
    'Leave him alone,' Sofia repeated. She was looking at Ricardo with every sign of great dislike. 'What's he done to you?'
    'Well,' said Ricardo, appearing to deliberate the point, 'it's more the fact that he exists, if you know what I mean . . .'
    Many of the surrounding students laughed, Gustavo and Wormtail included, but Cardozo, still apparently intent on his book, didn't, and nor did Sofia.
    'You think you're funny,' she said coldly. 'But you're just an arrogant, bullying toerag, Gonzales. Leave him alone.'
    'I will if you go out with me, Evans,' said Ricardo quickly. 'Go on . . . go out with me and I'll never lay a wand on old Snivelly again.'
    Behind him, the Impediment Jinx was wearing off. Peralta was beginning to inch towards his fallen wand, spitting out soapsuds as he crawled.
    'I wouldn't go out with you if it was a choice between you and the giant squid,' said Sofia.
    'Bad luck, Prongs,' said Gustavo briskly, and turned back to Peralta. 'OI!'
    But too late; Peralta had directed his wand straight at Ricardo; there was a flash of light and a gash appeared on the side of Ricardo's face, spattering his robes with blood. Ricardo whirled about: a second flash of light later, Peralta was hanging upside-down in the air, his robes falling over his head to reveal skinny, pallid legs and a pair of greying underpants.
    Many people in the small crowd cheered; Gustavo, Ricardo and Wormtail roared with laughter.
    Sofia, whose furious expression had twitched for an instant as though she was going to smile, said, 'Let him down!'
    'Certainly,' said Ricardo and he jerked his wand upwards; Peralta fell into a crumpled heap on the ground. Disentangling himself from his robes he got quickly to his feet, wand up, but Gustavo said, 'Petrificus Totalus!' and Peralta keeled over again, rigid as a board.
    'LEAVE HIM ALONE!' Sofia shouted. She had her own wand out now. Ricardo and Gustavo eyed it warily.
    'Ah, Evans, don't make me hex you,' said Ricardo earnestly.
    Take the curse off him, then!'
    Ricardo sighed deeply, then turned to Peralta and muttered the counter-curse.
    There you go,' he said, as Peralta struggled to his feet. 'You're lucky Evans was here, Snivellus - '
    'I don't need help from filthy little Mudbloods like her!'
    Sofia blinked.
    'Fine,' she said coolly. 'I won't bother in future. And I'd wash your pants if I were you, Snivellus.'
    'Apologise to Evans!' Ricardo roared at Peralta, his wand pointed threateningly at him.
    'I don't want you to make him apologise,' Sofia shouted, rounding on Ricardo. 'You're as bad as he is.'
    'What?' yelped Ricardo. 'Id NEVER call you a - you-know-what!'
    'Messing up your hair because you think it looks cool to look like you've just got off your broomstick, showing off with that stupid Snitch, walking down corridors and hexing anyone who annoys you just because you can - I'm surprised your broomstick can get off the ground with that fat head on it. You make me SICK.'
    She turned on her heel and hurried away.
    'Evans!' Ricardo shouted after her. 'Hey, EVANS!'
    But she didn't look back.
    'What is it with her?' said Ricardo, trying and failing to look as though this was a throwaway question of no real importance to him.
    'Reading between the lines, I'd say she thinks you're a bit conceited, mate,' said Gustavo.
    'Right,' said Ricardo, who looked furious now, 'right - '
    There was another flash of light, and Peralta was once again hanging upside-down in the air.
    'Who wants to see me take off Snivelly's pants?'
    But whether Ricardo really did take off Peralta's pants, Roberto never found out. A hand had closed tight over his upper arm, closed with a pincer-like grip. Wincing, Roberto looked round to see who had hold of him, and saw, with a thrill of horror, a fully grown, adult-sized Peralta standing right beside him, white with rage.
    'Having fun?'
    Roberto felt himself rising into the air; the summer's day evaporated around him; he was floating upwards through icy blackness, Peralta's hand still tight upon his upper arm. Then, with a swooping feeling as though he had turned head-over-heels in midair, his feet hit the stone floor of Peralta's dungeon and he was standing again beside the Pensieve on Peralta's desk in the shadowy, present-day Potion master's study.
    'So,' said Peralta, gripping Roberto's arm so tightly Roberto's hand was starting to feel numb. 'So . . . been enjoying yourself, Gonzales?'
    'N-no,' said Roberto, trying to free his arm.
    It was scary: Peralta's lips were shaking, his face was white, his teeth were bared.
    'Amusing man, your father, wasn't he?' said Peralta, shaking Roberto so hard his glasses slipped down his nose.
    'I - didn't - '
    Peralta threw Roberto from him with all his might. Roberto fell hard on to the dungeon floor.
    'You will not repeat what you saw to anybody!' Peralta bellowed.
    'No,' said Roberto, getting to his feet as far from Peralta as he could. 'No, of course I w-
    'Get out, get out, I don't want to see you in this office ever again!'
    And as Roberto hurtled towards the door, a jar of dead cockroaches exploded over his head. He wrenched the door open and Hew along the corridor, stopping only when he had put three floors between himself and Peralta. There he leaned against the wall, panting, and rubbing his bruised arm.
    He had no desire at all to return to Gryffindor Tower so early, nor to tell Diego and Carolina what he had just seen. What was making Roberto feel so horrified and unhappy was not being shouted at or having jars thrown at him; it was that he knew how it felt to be humiliated in the middle of a circle of onlookers, knew exactly how Peralta had felt as his father had taunted him, and that judging from what he had just seen, his father had been every bit as arrogant as Peralta had always told him.
- CHAPTER TWENTY-NINE -
Careers Advice

'But why haven't you got Occlumency lessons any more?' said Carolina, frowning.
    'I've told you,' Roberto muttered. 'Peralta reckons I can carry on by myself now I've got the basics.'
    'So you've stopped having funny dreams?' said Carolina sceptically.
    'Pretty much,' said Roberto, not looking at her.
    'Well, I don't think Peralta should stop until you're absolutely sure you can control them!' said Carolina indignantly. 'Roberto, I think you should go back to him and ask - '
    'No,' said Roberto forcefully. 'Just drop it, Carolina, OK?'
    It was the first day of the Easter holidays and Carolina, as was her custom, had spent a large part of the day drawing up revision timetables for the three of them. Roberto and Diego had let her do it; ii. was easier than arguing with her and, in any case, they might come in useful.
    Diego had been startled to discover there were only six weeks left until their exams.
    'How can that come as a shock?' Carolina demanded, as she tapped each little square on Diego's timetable with her wand so that il flashed a different colour according to its subject.
    'I dunno,' said Diego, 'there's been a lot going on.'
    'Well, there you are,' she said, handing him his timetable, 'if you follow that you should do fine.'
    Diego looked down it gloomily, but then brightened.
    'You've given me an evening off every week!'
    'That's for Quidditch practice,' said Carolina.
    The smile faded from Diego's face.
    'What's the point?' he said dully. 'We've got about as much chance of winning the Quidditch Cup this year as Dad's got of becoming Minister for Magic.'
    Carolina said nothing; she was looking at Roberto, who was staring blankly at the opposite wall of the common room while Crookshanks pawed at his hand, trying to get his ears scratched.
    'What's wrong, Roberto?'
    'What?' he said quickly. 'Nothing.'
    He seized his copy of Defensive Magical Theory and pretended to be looking something up in the index. Crookshanks gave him up as a bad job and slunk away under Carolina's chair.
    'I saw Paula earlier,' said Carolina tentatively. 'She looked really miserable, too . . . have you two had a row again?'
    'Wha- oh, yeah, we have,' said Roberto, seizing gratefully on the excuse.
    'What about?'
    That sneak friend of hers, Marietta,' said Roberto.
    'Yeah, well, I don't blame you!' said Diego angrily, setting down his revision timetable. 'If it hadn't been for her . . .'
    Diego went into a rant about Marietta Edgecombe, which Roberto found helpful; all he had to do was look angry, nod and say 'Yeah' and That's right' whenever Diego drew breath, leaving his mind free to dwell, ever more miserably, on what he had seen in the Pensieve.
    He felt as though the memory of it was eating him from inside. He had been so sure his parents were wonderful people that he had never had the slightest difficulty in disbelieving the aspersions Peralta cast on his father's character. Hadn't people like Villalba and Gustavo told Roberto how wonderful his father had been? (Yeah, well, look what Gustavo was like himself, said a nagging voice inside Roberto's head . . . he was as bad, wasn't he?) Yes, he had once overheard Professor Romero saying that his father and Gustavo had been troublemakers at school, but she had described them as forerunners of the Lopez twins, and Roberto could not imagine Pablo and Luis dangling someone upside-down for the fun of it . . . not unless they really loathed them . . . perhaps Sosa or somebody who really deserved it .
    Roberto tried to make a case for Peralta having deserved what he had suffered at Ricardo's hands: but hadn't Sofia asked, 'What's he done to you?' And hadn't Ricardo replied, 'It's more the fact that he exists, if you know what I mean.' Hadn't Ricardo started it all simply because Gustavo had said he was bored? Roberto remembered Cardozo saying back in Grimmauld Place that Dominguez had made him prefect in the hope that he would be able to exercise some control over Ricardo and Gustavo . . . but in the Pensieve, he had sat there and let it all happen . . .
    Roberto kept reminding himself that Sofia had intervened; his mother had been decent. Yet, the memory of the look on her face as she had shouted at Ricardo disturbed him quite as much as anything else; she had clearly loathed Ricardo, and Roberto simply could not understand how they could have ended up married. Once or twice he even wondered whether Ricardo had forced her into it . . .
    For nearly five years the thought of his father had been a source of comfort, of inspiration. Whenever someone had told him he was like Ricardo, he had glowed with pride inside. And now . . . now he felt cold and miserable at the thought of him.
    The weather grew breezier, brighter and warmer as the Easter holidays passed, but Roberto, along with the rest of the fifth- and seventh-years, was trapped inside, revising, traipsing back and forth to the library. Roberto pretended his bad mood had no other cause but the approaching exams, and as his fellow Gryffindors were sick of studying themselves, his excuse went unchallenged.
    'Roberto, I'm talking to you, can you hear me?'
    'Huh?'
    He looked round. Martina Lopez, looking very windswept, had joined him at the library table where he had been sitting alone. It was late on Sunday evening: Carolina had gone back to Gryffindor Tower to revise Ancient Runes, and Diego had Quidditch practice.
    'Oh, hi,' said Roberto, pulling his books towards him. 'How come you're not at practice?'
    'It's over,' said Martina. 'Diego had to take Jack Sloper up to the hospital wing.'
    'Why?'
    'Well, we're not sure, but we think he knocked himself out with
    his own bat.' She sighed heavily. 'Anyway . . . a package just arrived, it's only just got through Umbridge's new screening process.'
    She hoisted a box wrapped in brown paper on to the table; it had clearly been unwrapped and carelessly re-wrapped. There was a scribbled note across it in red ink, reading: Inspected and Passed by the Hogwarts High Inquisitor.
    'It's Easter eggs from Mum,' said Martina. There's one for you . . . there you go.'
    She handed him a handsome chocolate egg decorated with small, iced Snitches and, according to the packaging, containing a bag of Fizzing Whizzbees. Roberto looked at it for a moment, then, to his horror, felt a lump rise in his throat.
    'Are you OK, Roberto?' Martina asked quietly.
    'Yeah, I'm fine,' said Roberto gruffly. The lump in his throat was painful. He did not understand why an Easter egg should have made him feel like this.
    'You seem really down lately,' Martina persisted. 'You know, I'm sure if you just talked to Paula . . .'
    'It's not Paula I want to talk to,' said Roberto brusquely.
    'Who is it, then?' asked Martina, watching him closely.
    'I . . .'
    He glanced around to make quite sure nobody was listening. Madam Pince was several shelves away, stamping out a pile cf books for a frantic-looking Hannah Abbott.
    'I wish I could talk to Gustavo,' he muttered. 'But I know I can't.'
    Martina continued to watch him thoughtfully. More to give himself something to do than because he really wanted any, Roberto unwrapped his Easter egg, broke off a large bit and put it into his mouth.
    'Well,' said Martina slowly, helping herself to a bit of egg, too, 'if you really want to talk to Gustavo, I expect we could think of a way to do it.'
    'Come on,' said Roberto dully. 'With Umbridge policing the fires and reading all our mail?'
    The thing about growing up with Pablo and Luis,' said Martina thoughtfully, 'is that you sort of start thinking anything's possible if you've got enough nerve.'
    Roberto looked at her. Perhaps it was the effect of the chocolate - '- Cardozo had always advised eating some after encounters with Dementors - or simply because he had finally spoken aloud the wish that had been burning inside him for a week, but he felt a bit more hopeful.
    'WHAT DO YOU THINK YOU ARE DOING?'
    'Oh damn,' whispered Martina, jumping to her feet. 'I forgot - '
    Madam Pince was swooping down on them, her shrivelled face contorted with rage.
    'Paulacolate in the library!' she screamed. 'Out - out - OUT!' And whipping out her wand, she caused Roberto's books, bag and ink bottle to chase him and Martina from the library, whacking them repeatedly over the head as they ran.
*
As though to underline the importance of their upcoming examinations, a batch of pamphlets, leaflets and notices concerning various wizarding careers appeared on the tables in Gryffindor Tower shortly before the end of the holidays, along with yet another notice on the board, which read:
CAREERS ADVICE
All fifth-years are required to attend a short meeting with their
Head of House during the first week of the summer term to discuss
their future careers. Times of individual appointments are listed below.
Roberto looked down the list and found that he was expected in Professor Romero's office at half past two on Monday, which would mean missing most of Divination. He and the other fifth-years spent a considerable part of the final weekend of the Easter break reading all the careers information that had been left there for their perusal.
    'Well, I don't fancy Healing,' said Diego on the last evening of the holidays. He was immersed in a leaflet that carried the crossed bone-and-wand emblem of St Mungo's on its front. 'It says here you need at least "E" at NEWT level in Potions, Herbology, Transfiguration, Charms and Defence Against the Dark Arts. I mean . . . blimey . . . don't want much, do they?'
    'Well, it's a very responsible job, isn't it?' said Carolina absently.
    She was poring over a bright pink and orange leaflet, that was headed, 'SO YOU THINK YOU'D LIKE TO WORK IN MUGGLE RELATIONS?' 'You don't seem to need many qualifications to liaise with Muggles; all they want is an OWL in Muggle Studies: Much more important is your enthusiasm, patience and a good sense of fun!'
    'You'd need more than a good sense of fun to liaise with my uncle,' said Roberto darkly. 'Good sense of when to duck, more like.' He was halfway through a pamphlet on wizard banking. 'Listen to this: Are you seeking a challenging career involving travel, adventure and substantial, danger-related treasure bonuses? Then consider a position with Gringotts Wizarding Bank, who are currently recruiting Curse-Breakers for thrilling opportunities abroad . . . They want Arithmancy, though; you could do it, Carolina!'
    'I don't much fancy banking,' said Carolina vaguely, now immersed in: 'HAVE YOU GOT WHAT IT TAKES TO TRAIN SECURITY TROLLS?'
    'Hey,' said a voice in Roberto's ear. He looked round; Pablo and Luis had come to join them. 'Martina's had a word with us about you,' said Pablo, stretching out his legs on the table in front of them and causing several booklets on careers with the Ministry of Magic to slide off on to the floor. 'She says you need to talk to Gustavo?'
    'What?' said Carolina sharply, freezing with her hand halfway towards picking up 'MAKE A BANG AT THE DEPARTMENT OF MAGICAL ACCIDENTS AND CATASTROPHES'.
    'Yeah . . .' said Roberto, trying to sound casual, 'yeah, I thought I'd like - '
    'Don't be so ridiculous,' said Carolina, straightening up and looking at him as though she could not believe her eyes. 'With Umbridge groping around in the fires and frisking all the owls?'
    'Well, we think we can find a way around that,' said Luis, stretching and smiling. 'It's a simple matter of causing a diversion. Now, you might have noticed that we have been rather quiet on the mayhem front during the Easter holidays?'
    'What was the point, we asked ourselves, of disrupting leisure time?' continued Pablo. 'No point at all, we answered ourselves. And of course, we'd have messed up people's revision, too, which would be the very last thing we'd want to do.'
    He gave Carolina a sanctimonious little nod. She looked rather taken aback by this thoughtfulness.
    'But it's business as usual from tomorrow,' Pablo continued briskly. 'And if we're going to be causing a bit of uproar, why not do it so that Roberto can have his chat with Gustavo?'
    'Yes, but still,' said Carolina, with an air of explaining something very simple to somebody very obtuse, 'even if you do cause a diversion, how is Roberto supposed to talk to him?'
    'Umbridge's office,' said Roberto quietly.
    He had been thinking about it for a fortnight and could come up with no alternative. Umbridge herself had told him that the only fire that was not being watched was her own.
    'Are - you - insane?' said Carolina in a hushed voice.
    Diego had lowered his leaflet on jobs in the Cultivated Fungus Trade and was watching the conversation warily.
    'I don't think so,' said Roberto, shrugging.
    'And how are you going to get in there in the first place?'
    Roberto was ready for this question.
    'Gustavo's knife,' he said.
    'Excuse me?'
    'Christmas before last Gustavo gave me a knife that'll open any lock,' said Roberto. 'So even if she's bewitched the door so Alahomora won't work, which I bet she has - '
    'What do you think about this?' Carolina demanded of Diego, and Roberto was reminded irresistibly of Mrs Lopez appealing to her husband during Roberto's first dinner in Grimmauld Place.
    'I dunno,' said Diego, looking alarmed at being asked to give an opinion. 'If Roberto wants to do it, it's up to him, isn't it?'
    'Spoken like a true friend and Lopez,' said Pablo, clapping Diego hard on the back. 'Right, then. We're thinking of doing it tomorrow, just after lessons, because it should cause maximum impact ii everybody's in the corridors - Roberto, we'll set it off in the east wing somewhere, draw her right away from her own office - I reckon we should be able to guarantee you, what, twenty minutes?' he said, looking at Luis.
    'Easy,' said Luis.
    'What sort of diversion is it?' asked Diego.
    'You'll see, little bro', said Pablo, as he and Luis got up again. 'At least, you will if you trot along to Gregory the Smarmy's corridor round about five o'clock tomorrow.'
*
Roberto awoke very early the next day, feeling almost as anxious as he had done on the morning of his disciplinary hearing at the Ministry of Magic. It was not only the prospect of breaking into Umbridge's office and using her fire to speak to Gustavo that was making him feel nervous, though that was certainly bad enough; today also happened to be the first time Roberto would be in close proximity to Peralta since Peralta had thrown him out of his office.
    After lying in bed for a while thinking about the day ahead, Roberto got up very quietly and moved across to the window beside Mauricio's bed, and stared out on a truly glorious morning. The sky was a clear, misty, opalescent blue. Directly ahead of him, Roberto could see the towering beech tree below which his father had once tormented Peralta. He was not sure what Gustavo could possibly say to him that would make up for what he had seen in the Pensieve, but he was desperate to hear Gustavo's own account of what had happened, to know of any mitigating factors there might have been, any excuse at all for his fathers behaviour . . .
    Something caught Roberto's attention: movement on the edge of the Forbidden Forest. Roberto squinted into the sun and saw Villalba emerging from between the trees. He seemed to be limping. As Roberto watched, Villalba staggered to the door of his cabin and disappeared inside it. Roberto watched the cabin for several minutes. Villalba did not emerge again, but smoke furled from the chimney, so Villalba could not be so badly injured that he was unequal tc stoking the fire.
    Roberto turned away from the window, headed back to his trunk and started to dress.
    With the prospect of forcing entry into Umbridge's office ahead. Roberto had never expected the day to be a restful one, but he had not reckoned on Carolina's almost continual attempts to dissuade him from what he was planning to do at five o'clock. For the first time ever, she was at least as inattentive to Professor Binns in
    History of Magic as Roberto and Diego were, keeping up a stream of whispered admonitions that Roberto tried very hard to ignore.
    '. . . and if she does catch you there, apart from being expelled, she'll be able to guess you've been talking to Snuffles and this time I expect she'll force you to drink Veritaserum and answer her questions . . .'
    'Carolina,' said Diego in a low and indignant voice, 'are you going to stop telling Roberto off and listen to Binns, or am I going to have to take my own notes?'
    'You take notes for a change, it won't kill you!'
    By the time they reached the dungeons, neither Roberto nor Diego was speaking to Carolina. Undeterred, she took advantage of their silence to maintain an uninterrupted flow oi dire warnings, all uttered under her breath in a vehement hiss that caused Seamus to waste five whole minutes checking his cauldron for leaks.
    Peralta, meanwhile, seemed to have decided to act as though Roberto were invisible. Roberto was, of course, well-used to this tactic, as it was one of Uncle Franciscos favourites, and on the whole was grateful he had to suffer nothing worse. In fact, compared to what he usually had to endure from Peralta in the way of taunts and snide remarks, he found the new approach something of an improvement, and was pleased to find that when left well alone, he was able to concoct an Invigoration Draught quite easily. At the end of the lesson he scooped some of the potion into a flask, corked it and took it up to Peralta's desk for marking, feeling that he might at last have scraped an 'E'.
    He had just turned away when he heard a smashing noise. Sosa gave a gleeful yell of laughter. Roberto whipped around. His potion sample lay in pieces on the floor and Peralta was surveying him with a look of gloating pleasure.
    'Whoops,' he said softly. 'Another zero, then, Gonzales.'
    Roberto was too incensed to speak. He strode back to his cauldron, intending to fill another flask and force Peralta to mark it, but saw to his horror that the rest of the contents had vanished.
    'I'm sorry!' said Carolina, with her hands over her mouth. I'm really sorry, Roberto. I thought you'd finished, so I cleared up!'
    Roberto could not bring himself to answer. When the bell rang, he hurried out of the dungeon without a backwards glance, and made sure that he found himself a seat between Mauricio and Seamus for lunch so that Carolina could not start nagging him again about using Umbridge's office.
    He was in such a bad mood by the time he got to Divination that he had quite forgotten his careers appointment with Professor Romero, remembering it only when Diego asked him why he wasn't in her office. He hurtled back upstairs and arrived out of breath, only a few minutes late.
    'Sorry, Professor,' he panted, as he closed the door. 'I forgot.'
    'No matter, Gonzales,' she said briskly, but as she spoke, somebody else sniffed from the corner. Roberto looked round.
    Professor Umbridge was sitting there, a clipboard on her knee, a fussy little pie-frill around her neck and a small, horribly smug smile on her face.
    'Sit down, Gonzales,' said Professor Romero tersely. Her hands shook slightly as she shuffled the many pamphlets littering her desk.
    Roberto sat down with his back to Umbridge and did his best to pretend he could not hear the scratching of her quill on her clipboard.
    'Well, Gonzales, this meeting is to talk over any career ideas you might have, and to help you decide which subjects you should continue into the sixth and seventh years,' said Professor Romero. 'Have you had any thoughts about what you would like to do after you leave Hogwarts?'
    'Er - ' said Roberto.
    He was finding the scratching noise from behind him very distracting.
    'Yes?' Professor Romero prompted Roberto.
    'Well, I thought of, maybe, being an Auror,' Roberto mumbled.
    'You'd need top grades for that,' said Professor Romero, extracting a small, dark leaflet from under the mass on her desk and opening it. They ask for a minimum of five NEWTs, and nothing under "Exceeds Expectations" grade, I see. Then you would be required to undergo a stringent series of character and aptitude tests at the Auror office. It's a difficult career path, Gonzales, they only take the best. In fact, I don't think anybody has been taken on in the last three years.'
    At this moment, Professor Umbridge gave a very tiny cough, as though she was trying to see how quietly she could do it. Professor Romero ignored her.
    'You'll want to know which subjects you ought to take, I suppose?' she went on, talking a little louder than before.
    'Yes,' said Roberto. 'Defence Against the Dark Arts, I suppose?'
    'Naturally,' said Professor Romero crisply. 'I would also advise -'
    Professor Umbridge gave another cough, a little more audible this time. Professor Romero closed her eyes for a moment, opened them again, and continued as though nothing had happened.
    'I would also advise Transfiguration, because Aurors frequently need to Transfigure or Untransfigure in their work. And I ought to tell you now, Gonzales, that I do not accept students into my NEWT classes unless they have achieved "Exceeds Expectations" or higher at Ordinary Wizarding Level. I'd say you're averaging "Acceptable" at the moment, so you'll need to put in some good hard work before the exams to stand a chance of continuing. Then you ought to do Charms, always useful, and Potions. Yes, Gonzales, Potions,' she added, with the merest flicker of a smile. 'Poisons and antidotes are essential study for Aurors. And I must tell you that Professor Peralta absolutely refuses to take students who get anything other than "Outstanding" in their OWLs, so - '
    Professor Umbridge gave her most pronounced cough yet.
    'May I offer you a cough drop, Dolores?' Professor Romero asked curtly, without looking at Professor Umbridge.
    'Oh, no, thank you very much,' said Umbridge, with that simpering laugh Roberto hated so much. 'I just wondered whether I could make the teensiest interruption, Elena?'
    'I daresay you'll find you can,' said Professor Romero through tightly gritted teeth.
    'I was just wondering whether Mr Gonzales has quite the temperament for an Auror?' said Professor Umbridge sweetly.
    'Were you?' said Professor Romero haughtily. 'Well, Gonzales,' she continued, as though there had been no interruption, if you are serious in this ambition, I would advise you to concentrate hard on bringing your Transfiguration and Potions up to scratch. I see Professor Flitwick has graded you between "Acceptable" and "Exceeds Expectations" for the last two years, so your Charmwork seems satisfactory. As for Defence Against the Dark Arts, your marks have been generally high, Professor Cardozo in particular thought you - are you quite sure you wouldn't like a cough drop, Dolores?'
    'Oh, no need, thank you, Elena,' simpered Professor Umbridge, who had just coughed her loudest yet. 'I was just concerned that you might not have Roberto's most recent Defence Against the Dark Arts marks in front of you. I'm quite sure I slipped in a note.'
    'What, this thing?' said Professor Romero in a tone of revulsion, as she pulled a sheet of pink parchment from between the leaves of Roberto's folder. She glanced down it, her eyebrows slightly raised, then placed it back into the folder without comment.
    'Yes, as I was saying, Gonzales, Professor Cardozo thought you showed a pronounced aptitude for the subject, and obviously for an Auror - '
    'Did you not understand my note, Elena?' asked Professor Umbndge in honeyed tones, quite forgetting to cough.
    'Of course I understood it,' said Professor Romero, her teeth clenched so tightly the words came out a little muffled.
    'Well, then, I am confused . . . I'm afraid I don't quite understand how you can give Mr Gonzales false hope that - '
    'False hope?' repeated Professor Romero, still refusing to look round at Professor Umbridge. 'He has achieved high marks in all his Defence Against the Dark Arts tests - '
    'I'm terribly sorry to have to contradict you, Elena, but as you will see from my note, Roberto has been achieving very poor results in his classes with me - '
    'I should have made my meaning plainer,' said Professor Romero, turning at last to look Umbridge directly in the eyes. 'He has achieved high marks in all Defence Against the Dark Arts tests set by a competent teacher.'
    Professor Umbridge's smile vanished as suddenly as a light bulb blowing. She sat back in her chair, turned a sheet on her clipboard and began scribbling very fast indeed, her bulging eyes rolling from side to side. Professor Romero turned back to Roberto, her thin nostrils flared, her eyes burning.
    'Any questions, Gonzales?'
    'Yes,' said Roberto. 'What sort of character and aptitude tests do the Ministry do on you, if you get enough NEWTs?'
    'Well, you'll need to demonstrate the ability to react well to pressure and so forth,' said Professor Romero, 'perseverance and dedication, because Auror training takes a further three years, not to mention very high skills in practical Defence. It will mean a lot more study even after you've left school, so unless you're prepared to - '
    'I think you'll also find,' said Umbridge, her voice very cold now, 'that the Ministry looks into the records of those applying to be Aurors. Their criminal records.'
    '- unless you're prepared to take even more exams after Hogwarts, you should really look at another - '
    'Which means that this boy has as much chance of becoming an Auror as Dominguez has of ever returning to this school.'
    'A very good chance, then,' said Professor Romero.
    'Gonzales has a criminal record,' said Umbridge loudly.
    'Gonzales has been cleared of all charges,' said Romero, even more loudly.
    Professor Umbridge stood up. She was so short that this did not make a great deal of difference, but her fussy, simpering demeanour had given place to a hard fury that made her broad, flabby face look oddly sinister.
    'Gonzales has no chance whatsoever of becoming an Auror!'
    Professor Romero got to her feet, too, and in her case this was a much more impressive move: she towered over Professor Umbridge.
    'Gonzales,' she said in ringing tones, 'I will assist you to become an Auror if it is the last thing I do! If I have to coach you nightly, I will make sure you achieve the required results!'
    The Minister for Magic will never employ Roberto Gonzales!' said Umbridge, her voice rising furiously.
    There may well be a new Minister for Magic by the time Gonzales is ready to join!' shouted Professor Romero.
    'Aha! shrieked Professor Umbridge, pointing a stubby linger at Romero. 'Yes! Yes, yes, yes! Of course! That's what you want, isn't it, Elena Romero? You want Cornelius Fudge replaced by Alfonso Dominguez! You think you'll be where I am, don't you: Senior Undersecretary to the Minister and Headmistress to boot!'
    'You are raving,' said Professor Romero, superbly disdainful. Totter, that concludes our careers consultation.'
    Roberto swung his bag over his shoulder and hurried out of the room, not daring to look at Professor Umbridge. He could hear her and Professor Romero continuing to shout at each other all the way back along the corridor.
    Professor Umbridge was still breathing as though she had just run a race when she strode into their Defence Against the Dark Arts lesson that afternoon.
    'I hope you've thought better of what you were planning to do, Roberto,' Carolina whispered, the moment they had opened their books to 'Chapter Thirty-four, Non-Retaliation and Negotiation'. 'Umbridge looks like she's in a really bad mood already . . .'
    Every now and then Umbridge shot glowering looks at Roberto, who kept his head down, staring at Defensive Magical Theory, his eyes unfocused, thinking . . .
    He could just imagine Professor Romero's reaction if he was caught trespassing in Professor Umbridge's office mere hours after she had vouched for him . . . there was nothing to stop him simply going back to Gryffindor Tower and hoping that some time during the next summer holidays he would have a chance to ask Gustavo about the scene he had witnessed in the Pensieve . . . nothing, except that the thought of taking this sensible course of action made him feel as though a lead weight had dropped into his stomach . . . and then there was the matter of Pablo and Luis, whose diversion was already planned, not to mention the knife Gustavo had given him, which was currently residing in his schoolbag along with his father's old Invisibility Cloak.
    But the fact remained that if he was caught . . .
    'Dominguez sacrificed himself to keep you in school, Roberto!' whispered Carolina, raising her book to hide her face from
    Umbridge. 'And if you get thrown out today it will all have been for nothing!'
    He could abandon the plan and simply learn to live with the memory of what his father had done on a summer's day more than twenty years ago . . .
    And then he remembered Gustavo in the fire upstairs in the Gryffindor common room . . .
    You're less like your father than I thought . . . the risk would've been what made it fun for Ricardo . . .
    But did he want to be like his father any more?
    'Roberto, don't do it, please don't do it!' Carolina said in anguished tones as the bell rang at the end of the class.
    He did not answer; he did not know what to do.
    Diego seemed determined to give neither his opinion nor his advice; he would not look at Roberto, though when Carolina opened her mouth to try dissuading Roberto some more, he said in a low voice, 'Give it a rest, OK? He can make up his own mind.'
    Roberto's heart beat very fast as he left the classroom. He was halfway along the corridor outside when he heard the unmistakeable sounds of a diversion going off in the distance. There were screams and yells reverberating from somewhere above them; people exiting the classrooms all around Roberto were stopping in their tracks and looking up at the ceiling fearfully - '
    Umbridge came pelting out of her classroom as fast as her short legs would carry her. Pulling out her wand, she hurried off in the opposite direction: it was now or never.
    'Roberto - please!' Carolina pleaded weakly.
    But he had made up his mind; hitching his bag more securely on to his shoulder, he set off at a run, weaving in and out of students now hurrying in the opposite direction to see what all the fuss was about in the east wing.
    Roberto reached the corridor to Umbridge's office and found it deserted. Dashing behind a large suit of armour whose helmet creaked around to watch him, he pulled open his bag, seized Gustavo's knife and donned the Invisibility Cloak. He then crept slowly and carefully back out from behind the suit of armour and along the corridor until he reached Umbridge's door.
    He inserted the blade of the magical knife into the crack around it and moved it gently up and down, then withdrew it. There was a tiny click, and the door swung open. He ducked inside the office, closed the door quickly behind him and looked around.
    Nothing was moving except the horrible kittens that were still frolicking on the wall plates above the confiscated broomsticks.
    Roberto pulled off his Cloak and, striding over to the fireplace, found what he was looking for within seconds: a small box containing glittering Floo powder.
    He crouched down in front of the empty grate, his hands shaking. He had never done this before, though he thought he knew how it must work. Sticking his head into the fireplace, he took a large pinch of powder and dropped it on to the logs stacked neatly beneath him. They exploded at once into emerald green flames.
    'Number twelve, Grimmauld Place!' Roberto said loudly and clearly
    It was one of the most curious sensations he had ever experienced. He had travelled by Floo powder before, of course, but then it had been his entire body that had spun around and around ir. the flames through the network of wizarding fireplaces that stretchec over the country. This time, his knees remained firm upon the cole floor of Umbridge's office, and only his head hurtled through the emerald fire . . .
    And then, as abruptly as it had begun, the spinning stopped. Feeling rather sick and as though he were wearing an exceptionally hot muffler around his head, Roberto opened his eyes to find that he was looking up out of the kitchen fireplace at the long, wooden table, where a man sat poring over a piece of parchment.
    'Gustavo?'
    The man jumped and looked around. It was not Gustavo, bu. Cardozo.
    'Roberto!' he said, looking thoroughly shocked. 'What are you - 'what's happened, is everything all right?'
    'Yeah,' said Roberto. 'I just wondered - I mean, I just fancied a - 'a chat with Gustavo.'
    'I'll call him,' said Cardozo, getting to his feet, still looking perplexed, 'he went upstairs to look for Kreacher, he seems to be hiding in the attic again . . .'
    And Roberto saw Cardozo hurry out of the kitchen. Now he was left with nothing to look at but the chair and table legs. He wondered why Gustavo had never mentioned how very uncomfortable it was to speak out of the fire; his knees were already objecting painfully to their prolonged contact with Umbridge's hard stone floor.
    Cardozo returned with Gustavo at his heels moments later.
    'What is it?' said Gustavo urgently, sweeping his long dark hair out of his eyes and dropping to the ground in front of the fire, so that he and Roberto were on a level. Cardozo knelt down too, looking very concerned. 'Are you all right? Do you need help?'
    'No,' said Roberto, 'it's nothing like that . . . I just wanted to talk . . . about my dad.'
    They exchanged a look of great surprise, but Roberto did not have time to feel awkward or embarrassed; his knees were becoming sorer by the second and he guessed five minutes had already passed from the start of the diversion; Luis had only guaranteed him twenty. He therefore plunged immediately into the story of what he had seen in the Pensieve.
    When he had finished, neither Gustavo nor Cardozo spoke for a moment. Then Cardozo said quietly, 'I wouldn't like you to judge your father on what you saw there, Roberto. He was only fifteen - '
    'I'm fifteen' said Roberto heatedly.
    'Look, Roberto' said Gustavo placatingly, 'Ricardo and Peralta hated each other from the moment they set eyes on each other, it was just one of those things, you can understand that, can't you? I think Ricardo was everything Peralta wanted to be - he was popular, he was good at Quidditch - good at pretty much everything. And Peralta was just this little oddball who was up to his eyes in the Dark Arts, and Ricardo - whatever else he may have appeared to you, Roberto - always hated the Dark Arts.'
    'Yeah,' said Roberto, 'but he just attacked Peralta for no good reason, just because - well, just because you said you were bored,' he finished, with a slightly apologetic note in his voice.
    'I'm not proud of it,' said Gustavo quickly.
    Cardozo looked sideways at Gustavo, then said, 'Look, Roberto, what you've got to understand is that your father and Gustavo were the best in the school at whatever they did - everyone thought they were the height of cool - if they sometimes got a bit carried away - '
    'If we were sometimes arrogant little berks, you mean,' said Gustavo.
    Cardozo smiled.
    'He kept messing up his hair,' said Roberto in a pained voice.
    Gustavo and Cardozo laughed.
    'I'd forgotten he used to do that,' said Gustavo affectionately.
    'Was he playing with the Snitch?' said Cardozo eagerly.
    'Yeah,' said Roberto, watching uncomprehendingly as Gustavo and Cardozo beamed reminiscently. 'Well . . . I thought he was a bit of an idiot.'
    'Of course he was a bit of an idiot!' said Gustavo bracingly, 'we were all idiots! Well - not Moony so much,' he said fairly, looking at Cardozo.
    But Cardozo shook his head. 'Did I ever tell you to lay off Peralta?' he said. 'Did I ever have the guts to tell you I thought you were out of order?'
    'Yeah, well,' said Gustavo, 'you made us feel ashamed of ourselves sometimes . . . that was something . . .'
    'And,' said Roberto doggedly, determined to say everything that was on his mind now he was here, 'he kept looking over at the girls by the lake, hoping they were watching him!'
    'Oh, well, he always made a fool of himself whenever Sofia was around,' said Gustavo, shrugging, 'he couldn't stop himself showing off whenever he got near her.'
    'How come she married him?' Roberto asked miserably. 'She hated him!'
    'Nah, she didn't,' said Gustavo.
    'She started going out with him in seventh year,' said Cardozo.
    'Once Ricardo had deflated his head a bit,' said Gustavo.
    'And stopped hexing people just for the fun of it,' said Cardozo.
    'Even Peralta?' said Roberto.
    'Well,' said Cardozo slowly, 'Peralta was a special case. I mean, he never lost an opportunity to curse Ricardo so you couldn't really expect Ricardo to take that lying down, could you?'
    'And my mum was OK with that?'
    'She didn't know too much about it, to tell you the truth,' said Gustavo. 'I mean, Ricardo didn't take Peralta on dates with her and jinx him in front of her, did he?'
    Gustavo frowned at Roberto, who was still looking unconvinced.
    'Look,' he said, 'your father was the best friend I ever had and he was a good person. A lot of people are idiots at the age of fifteen. He grew out of it.'
    'Yeah, OK,' said Roberto heavily. 'I just never thought I'd feel sorry for Peralta.'
    'Now you mention it,' said Cardozo, a faint crease between his eyebrows, 'how did Peralta react when he found you'd seen all this?'
    'He told me he'd never teach me Occlumency again,' said Roberto indifferently, 'like that's a big disappoint-
    'He WHAT?' shouted Gustavo, causing Roberto to jump and inhale a mouthful of ashes.
    'Are you serious, Roberto?' said Cardozo quickly. 'He's stopped giving you lessons?'
    'Yeah,' said Roberto, surprised at what he considered a great over-reaction. 'But it's OK, I don't care, it's a bit of a relief to tell you the - '
    'I'm coming up there to have a word with Peralta!' said Gustavo forcefully, and he actually made to stand up, but Cardozo wrenched him back down again.
    'If anyone's going to tell Peralta it will be me!' he said firmly. 'But Roberto, first of all, you're to go back to Peralta and tell him that on no account is he to stop giving you lessons - when Dominguez hears - '
    'I can't tell him that, he'd kill me!' said Roberto, outraged. 'You didn't see him when we got out of the Pensieve.'
    'Roberto there is nothing so important as you learning Occlumency!' said Cardozo sternly. 'Do you understand me? Nothing!'
    'OK, OK,' said Roberto, thoroughly discomposed, not to mention annoyed. 'I'll . . . I'll try and say something to him . . . but it won't be - '
    He fell silent. He could hear distant footsteps.
    'Is that Kreacher coming downstairs?'
    'No,' said Gustavo, glancing behind him. 'It must be somebody your end.'
    Roberto's heart skipped several beats.
    'I'd better go!' he said hastily and pulled his head backwards out of the Grimmauld Place fire. For a moment his head seemed to be revolving on his shoulders, then he found himself kneeling in front of Umbridge's fire with it firmly back on and watching the emerald flames flicker and die.
    'Quickly, quickly!' he heard a wheezy voice mutter right outside the office door. 'Ah, she's left it open - '
    Roberto dived for the Invisibility Cloak and had just managed to pull it back over himself when Filch burst into the office. He looked absolutely delighted about something and was talking to himself feverishly as he crossed the room, pulled open a drawer in Umbridge's desk and began rifling through the papers inside it.
    'Approval for Whipping . . . Approval for Whipping . . . I can do it at last . . . they've had it coming to them for years . . .'
    He pulled out a piece of parchment, kissed it, then shuffled rapidly back out of the door, clutching it to his chest.
    Roberto leapt to his feet and, making sure he had his bag and that the Invisibility Cloak was completely covering him, he wrenched open the door and hurried out of the office after Filch, who was hobbling along faster than Roberto had ever seen him go.
    One landing down from Umbridge's office, Roberto thought it was safe to become visible again. He pulled off the Cloak, shoved it in his bag and hurried onwards. There was a great deal of shouting and movement coming from the Entrance Hall. He ran down the marble staircase and found what looked like most of the school assembled there.
    It was just like the night when Trelawney had been sacked. Students were standing all around the walls in a great ring (some of them, Roberto noticed, covered in a substance that looked very like Stinksap); teachers and ghosts were also in the crowd. Prominent among the onlookers were members of the Inquisitorial Squad, who were all looking exceptionally pleased with themselves, and Peeves, who was bobbing overhead, gazed down at Pablo and Luis who stood in the middle of the floor with the unmistakeable look of two people who had just been cornered.
    'So!' said Umbridge triumphantly. Roberto realised she was standing
    just a few stairs in front of him, once more looking down upon her prey. 'So - you think it amusing to turn a school corridor into a swamp, do you?'
    'Pretty amusing, yeah,' said Pablo, looking up at her without the slightest sign of fear.
    Filch elbowed his way closer to Umbridge, almost crying with happiness.
    'I've got the form, Headmistress,' he said hoarsely, waving the piece of parchment Roberto had just seen him take from her desk. 'I've got the form and I've got the whips waiting . . . oh, let me do it now . . .'
    'Very good, Argus,' she said. 'You two,' she went on, gazing down at Pablo and Luis, 'are about to learn what happens to wrongdoers in my school.'
    'You know what?' said Pablo. 'I don't think we are.'
    He turned to his twin.
    'Luis,' said Pablo, 'I think we've outgrown full-time education.'
    'Yeah, I've been feeling that way myself,' said Luis lightly.
    Time to test our talents in the real world, d'you reckon?' asked Pablo.
    'Definitely,' said Luis.
    And before Umbridge could say a word, they raised their wands and said together:
    'Accio brooms!'
    Roberto heard a loud crash somewhere in the distance. Looking to his left, he ducked just in time. Pablo and Luis's broomsticks, one still trailing the heavy chain and iron peg with which Umbridge had fastened them to the wall, were hurtling along the corridor towards their owners; they turned left, streaked down the stairs and stopped sharply in front of the twins, the chain clattering loudly on the flagged stone floor.
    'We won't be seeing you,' Pablo told Professor Umbridge, swinging his leg over his broomstick.
    'Yeah, don't bother to keep in touch,' said Luis, mounting his own.
    Pablo looked around at the assembled students, at the silent, watchful crowd.
    'It anyone fancies buying a Portable Swamp, as demonstrated upstairs, come to number ninety-three, Diagon Alley - Lopez' Wizarding Wheezes,' he said in a loud voice. 'Our new premises!'
    'Special discounts to Hogwarts students who swear they're going to use our products to get rid of this old bat,' added Luis, pointing at Professor Umbridge.
    'STOP THEM!' shrieked Umbridge, but it was too late. As the Inquisitorial Squad closed in, Pablo and Luis kicked off from the floor, shooting fifteen feet into the air, the iron peg swinging dangerously below. Pablo looked across the hall at the poltergeist bobbing on his level above the crowd.
    'Give her hell from us, Peeves.'
    And Peeves, who Roberto had never seen take an order from a student before, swept his belled hat from his head and sprang to a salute as Pablo and Luis wheeled about to tumultuous applause from the students below and sped out of the open front doors into the glorious sunset.
- CHAPTER THIRTY -
Grawp
The story of Pablo and Luis's flight to freedom was retold so often over the next few days that Roberto could tell it would soon become the stuff of Hogwarts legend: within a week, even those who had been eye-witnesses were half-convinced they had seen the twins dive-bomb Umbridge on their brooms and pelt her with Dungbombs before zooming out of the doors. In the immediate aftermath of their departure there was a great wave of talk about copying them. Roberto frequently heard students saying things like, 'Honestly, some days I just feel like jumping on my broom and leaving this place,' or else, 'One more lesson like that and I might just do a Lopez.'
    Pablo and Luis had made sure nobody was likely to forget them too soon. For one thing, they had not left instructions on how to remove the swamp that now filled the corridor on the fifth floor of the east wing. Umbridge and Filch had been observed trying different means of removing it but without success. Eventually, the area was roped off and Filch, gnashing his teeth furiously, was given the task of punting students across it to their classrooms. Roberto was certain that teachers like Romero or Flitwick could have removed the swamp in an instant but, just as in the case of Pablo and Luis's Wildfire Whiz-bangs, they seemed to prefer to watch Umbridge struggle.
    Then there were the two large broom-shaped holes in Umbridge's office door, through which Pablo and Luis's Cleansweeps had smashed to rejoin their masters. Filch fitted a new door and removed Roberto's Firebolt to the dungeons where, it was rumoured, Umbridge had set an armed security troll to guard it. However, her troubles were far from over.
    Inspired by Pablo and Luis's example, a great number of students were now vying for the newly vacant positions of Troublemakers-in-Chief. In spite of the new door, somebody managed to slip a hairy-snouted Niffler into Umbridge's office, which promptly tore the place apart in its search for shiny objects, leapt on Umbridge when she entered and tried to gnaw the rings off her stubby fingers. Dungbombs and Stink Pellets were dropped so frequently in the corridors that it became the new fashion for students to perform Bubble-Head Charms on themselves before leaving lessons, which ensured them a supply of fresh air, even though it gave them all the peculiar appearance of wearing upside-down goldfish bowls on their heads.
    Filch prowled the corridors with a horsewhip ready in his hands, desperate to catch miscreants, but the problem was that there were now so many of them he never knew which way to turn. The Inquisitorial Squad was attempting to help him, but odd things kept happening to its members. Warrington of the Slytherin Quidditch team reported to the hospital wing with a horrible skin complaint that made him look as though he had been coated in cornflakes; Pansy Parkinson, to Carolina's delight, missed all her lessons the following day as she had sprouted antlers.
    Meanwhile, it became clear just how many Skiving Snackboxes Pablo and Luis had managed to sell before leaving Hogwarts. Umbridge only had to enter her classroom for the students assembled there to faint, vomit, develop dangerous fevers or else spout blood from both nostrils. Shrieking with rage and frustration, she attempted to trace the mysterious symptoms to their source, but the students told her stubbornly they were suffering from 'Umbridge - 'itis'. Alter putting four successive classes in detention and failing to discover their secret, she was forced to give up and allow the bleeding, swooning, sweating and vomiting students to leave her classes in droves.
    But not even the users of the Snackboxes could compete with that master of chaos, Peeves, who seemed to have taken Pablo's parting words deeply to heart. Cackling madly, he soared through the school, upending tables, bursting out of blackboards, toppling statues and vases; twice he shut Mrs Norris inside a suit of armour,
    from which she was rescued, yowling loudly, by the furious caretaker. Peeves smashed lanterns and snuffed out candles, juggled burning torches over the heads of screaming students, caused neatly stacked piles of parchment to topple into fires or out of windows; flooded the second floor when he pulled off all the taps in the bathrooms, dropped a bag of tarantulas in the middle of the Great Hall during breakfast and, whenever he fancied a break, spent hours at a time floating along after Umbridge and blowing loud raspberries every time she spoke.
    None of the staff but Filch seemed to be stirring themselves to help her. Indeed, a week after Pablo and Luiss departure Roberto witnessed Professor Romero walking right past Peeves, who was determinedly loosening a crystal chandelier, and could have sworn he heard her tell the poltergeist out of the corner of her mouth, 'It unscrews the other way.'
    To cap matters, Montague had still not recovered from his sojourn in the toilet; he remained confused and disorientated and his parents were to be observed one Tuesday morning striding up the front drive, looking extremely angry.
    'Should we say something?' said Carolina in a worried voice, pressing her cheek against the Charms window so that she could see Mr and Mrs Montague marching inside. 'About what happened to him? In case it helps Madam Pomfrey cure him?'
    'Course not, he'll recover,' said Diego indifferently.
    'Anyway, more trouble for Umbridge, isn't it?' said Roberto in a satisfied voice.
    He and Diego both tapped the teacups they were supposed to be charming with their wands. Roberto's spouted four very short legs that could not reach the desk and wriggled pointlessly in midair. Diego's grew four very thin spindly legs that hoisted the cup off the desk with great difficulty, trembled for a few seconds, then folded, causing the cup to crack into two.
    'Reparo,' said Carolina quickly, mending Diego's cup with a wave of her wand. That's all very well, but what if Montague's permanently injured?'
    'Who cares?' said Diego irritably, while his teacup stood up drunkenly again, trembling violently at the knees. 'Montague shouldn't have tried to take all those points from Gryffindor, should he? If you want to worry about anyone, Carolina, worry about me!'
    'You?' she said, catching her teacup as it scampered happily away across the desk on four sturdy little willow-patterned legs, and replacing it in front of her. 'Why should I be worried about you?'
    'When Mum's next letter finally gets through Umbridge's screening process,' said Diego bitterly, now holding his cup up while its frail legs tried feebly to support its weight, 'I'm going to be in deep trouble. I wouldn't be surprised if she's sent another Howler.'
    'But - '
    'It'll be my fault Pablo and Luis left, you wait,' said Diego darkly. 'She'll say I should've stopped them leaving, I should've grabbed the ends of their brooms and hung on or something . . . yeah, it'll be all my fault.'
    'Well, if she dot's say that it'll be very unfair, you couldn't have done anything! But I'm sure she won't, I mean, if it's really true they've got premises in Diagon Alley, they must have been planning this for ages.'
    'Yeah, but that's another thing, how did they get premises?' said Diego, hitting his teacup so hard with his wand that its legs collapsed again and it lay twitching before him. 'It's a bit dodgy, isn't it? They'll need loads of Galleons to afford the rent on a place in Diagon Alley. She'll want to know what they've been up to, to get their hands on that sort of gold.'
    'Well, yes, that occurred to me, too,' said Carolina, allowing her teacup to jog in neat little circles around Roberto's, whose stubby little legs were still unable to touch the desktop, 'I've been wondering whether Mundungus has persuaded them to sell stolen goods or something awful.'
    'He hasn't,' said Roberto curtly.
    'How do you know?' said Diego and Carolina together.
    'Because - ' Roberto hesitated, but the moment to confess finally seemed to have come. There was no good to be gained in keeping silent if it meant anyone suspected that Pablo and Luis were criminals. 'Because they got the gold from me. I gave them my Triwizard winnings last June.'
    There was a shocked silence, then Carolina's teacup jogged right over the edge of the desk and smashed on the floor.
    'Oh, Roberto, you didn't!' she said.
    'Yes, I did,' said Roberto mutinously. 'And I don't regret it, either. I didn't need the gold and they'll be great at running a joke shop.'
    'But this is excellent!' said Diego, looking thrilled. 'It's all your fault, Roberto - Mum can't blame me at all! Can I tell her?'
    'Yeah, I suppose you'd better,' said Roberto dully, "specially if she thinks they're receiving stolen cauldrons or something.'
    Carolina said nothing at all for the rest of the lesson, but Roberto had a shrewd suspicion that her self-restraint was bound to crack before long. Sure enough, once they had left the castle for break and were standing around in the weak May sunshine, she fixed Roberto with a beady eye and opened her mouth with a determined air.
    Roberto interrupted her before she had even started.
    'It's no good nagging me, it's done,' he said firmly. 'Pablo and Luis have got the gold - spent a good bit of it, too, by the sounds of it - and I can't get it back from them and I don't want to. So save your breath, Carolina.'
    'I wasn't going to say anything about Pablo and Luis!' she said in an injured voice.
    Diego snorted disbelievingly and Carolina threw him a very dirty look.
    'No, I wasn't!' she said angrily. 'As a matter of fact, I was going to ask Roberto when he's going to go back to Peralta and ask for more Occlumency lessons!'
    Roberto's heart sank. Once they had exhausted the subject of Pablo and Luis's dramatic departure, which admittedly had taken many hours, Diego and Carolina had wanted to hear news of Gustavo. As Roberto had not confided in them the reason he had wanted to talk to Gustavo in the first place, it had been hard to think of what to tell them; he had ended up saying, truthfully, that Gustavo wanted Roberto to resume Occlumency lessons. He had been regretting this ever since; Carolina would not let the subject drop and kept reverting to it when Roberto least expected it.
    'You can't tell me you've stopped having funny dreams,' Carolina
    said now, 'because Diego told me you were muttering in your sleep again last night.'
    Roberto threw Diego a furious look. Diego had the grace to look ashamed of himself.
    'You were only muttering a bit,' he mumbled apologetically. 'Something about "just a bit further".'
    'I dreamed I was watching you lot play Quidditch,' Roberto lied brutally. 'I was trying to get you to stretch out a bit further to grab the Quaffle.'
    Diego's ears went red. Roberto felt a kind of vindictive pleasure; he had not, of course, dreamed anything of the sort.
    Last night, he had once again made the journey along the Department of Mysteries corridor. He had passed through the circular room, then the room full of clicking and dancing light, until he found himself again inside that cavernous room full of shelves on which were ranged dusty glass spheres.
    He had hurried straight towards row number ninety-seven, turned left and run along it . . . it had probably been then that he had spoken aloud . . . just a bit further . . . for he felt his conscious self struggling to wake . . . and before he had reached the end of the row, he had found himself lying in bed again, gazing up at the canopy of his four-poster.
    'You are trying to block your mind, aren't you?' said. Carolina, looking beadily at Roberto. 'You are keeping going with your Occlumency?'
    'Of course I am,' said Roberto, trying to sound as though this question was insulting, but not quite meeting her eye. The truth was he was so intensely curious about what was hidden in that room full of dusty orbs, that he was quite keen for the dreams to continue.
    The problem was that with just under a month to go until the exams and every free moment devoted to revision, his mind seemed so saturated with information when he went to bed he found it very difficult to get to sleep at all; and when he did, his overwrought brain presented him most nights with stupid dreams about the exams. He also suspected that part of his mind - the part that often spoke in Carolina's voice - now felt guilty on the occasions
    it strayed down that corridor ending in the black door, and sought to wake him before he could reach the journey's end.
    'You know,' said Diego, whose ears were still flaming red, 'if Montague doesn't recover before Slytherin play Hufflepuff, we might be in with a chance of winning the Cup.'
    'Yeah, I s'pose so,' said Roberto, glad of a change of subject.
    'I mean, we've won one, lost one - if Slytherin lose to Hufflepuff next Saturday - '
    'Yeah, that's right,' said Roberto, losing track of what he was agreeing to. Paula Mejia had just walked across the courtyard, determinedly not looking at him.
*
The final match of the Quidditch season, Gryffindor versus Ravenclaw, was to take place on the last weekend of May. Although Slytherin had been narrowly defeated by Hufflepuff in their last match, Gryffindor were not daring to hope for victory, due mainly (though of course nobody said it to him) to Diego's abysmal goal-keeping record. He, however, seemed to have found a new optimism.
    'I mean, I can't get any worse, can I?' he told Roberto and Carolina grimly over breakfast on the morning of the match. 'Nothing to lose now, is there?'
    'You know,' said Carolina, as she and Roberto walked down to the pitch a little later in the midst of a very excitable crowd, 'I think Diego might do better without Pablo and Luis around. They never exactly gave him a lot of confidence.'
    Gabriela Ortiz overtook them with what appeared to be a live eagle perched on top of her head.
    'Oh, gosh, I forgot!' said Carolina, watching the eagle flapping its wings as Gabriela walked serenely past a group of cackling and pointing Slytherins. 'Paula will be playing, won't she?'
    Roberto, who had not forgotten this, merely grunted.
    They found seats in the topmost row of the stands. It was a fine, ckar day; Diego could not wish for better, and Roberto found himself hoping against hope that Diego would not give the Slytherins cause for more rousing choruses of 'Lopez is our King'.
    Lee Jordan, who had been very dispirited since Pablo and Luis
    had left, was commentating as usual. As the teams zoomed out on to the pitch he named the players with something less than his usual gusto.
    '. . . Bradley . . . Davies . . . Mejia,' he said, and Roberto felt his stomach perform, less of a back flip, more a feeble lurch as Paula walked out on to the pitch, her shiny black hair rippling in the slight breeze.. He was not sure what he wanted to happen any more, except that he could not stand any more rows. Even the sight of her chatting animatedly to Roger Davies as they prepared to mount their brooms caused him only a slight twinge of jealousy.
    'And they're off!' said Lee. 'And Davies takes the Quaffle immediately, Ravenclaw Captain Davies with the Quaffle, he dodges Johnson, he dodges Bell, he dodges Spinnet as well . . . he's going straight for goal! He's going to shoot - and - and - ' Lee swore very loudly. 'And he's scored.'
    Roberto and Carolina groaned with the rest of the Gryffindors. Predictably, horribly the Slytherins on the other side of the stands began to sing:
'Lopez cannot save a thing
He cannot block a single ring . . .'
'Roberto,' said a hoarse voice in Roberto's ear. 'Carolina . . .'
    Roberto looked round and saw Villalba's enormous bearded face sticking between the seats. Apparently, he had squeezed his way all along the row behind, for the first- and second-years he had just passed had a ruffled, flattened look about them. For some reason, Villalba was bent double as though anxious not to be seen, though he was still at least four feet taller than everybody else.
    'Listen,' he whispered, 'can yeh come with me? Now? While ev'ryone's watchin' the match?'
    'Er . . . can't it wait, Villalba?' asked Roberto. till the match is over?' 'No,' said Villalba. 'No, Roberto, it's gotta be now . . . while ev'ryone's lookin' the other way . . . please?'
    Villalba's nose was gently dripping blood. His eyes were both blackened. Roberto had not seen him this close-up since his return to the school; he looked utterly woebegone.
    'Course,' said Roberto at once, 'course we'll come.'
    He and Carolina edged back along their row of seats, causing much grumbling among the students who had to stand up for them. The people in Villalba's row were not complaining, merely attempting to make themselves as small as possible.
    'I 'ppreciate this, you two, I really do,' said Villalba as they reached the stairs. He kept looking around nervously as they descended towards the lawn below. 'I jus' hope she doesn' notice us goin'.'
    'You mean Umbridge?' said Roberto. 'She won't, she's got her whole Inquisitorial Squad sitting with her, didn't you see? She must be expecting trouble at the match.'
    'Yeah, well, a bit o' trouble wouldn' hurt,' said Villalba, pausing to peer around the edge of the stands to make sure the stretch of lawn between there and his cabin was deserted. 'Give us more time.'
    'What is it, Villalba?' said Carolina, looking up at him with a concerned expression on her face as they hurried across the grass towards the edge of the Forest.
    'Yeh - yeh'll see in a mo',' said Villalba, looking over his shoulder as a great roar rose from the stands behind them. 'Hey - did someone jus' score?'
    'It'll be Ravenclaw,' said Roberto heavily.
    'Good . . . good . . .' said Villalba distractedly. 'Tha's good . . .'
    They had to jog to keep up with him as he strode across the lawn, looking around with every other step. When they reached his cabin, Carolina turned automatically left towards the front door. Villalba, however, walked straight past it into the shade of the trees on the outermost edge of the Forest, where he picked up a crossbow that was leaning against a tree. When he realised they were no longer with him, he turned.
    'We're goin' in here,' he said, jerking his shaggy head behind him.
    'Into the Forest?' said Carolina, perplexed.
    'Yeah,' said Villalba. 'C'mon now, quick, before we're spotted!'
    Roberto and Carolina looked at each other, then ducked into the cover of the trees behind Villalba, who was already striding away from them into the green gloom, his crossbow over his arm. Roberto and Carolina ran to catch up with him.
    'Villalba, why are you armed?' said Roberto.
    'Jus' a precaution,' said Villalba, shrugging his massive shoulders.
    'You didn't bring your crossbow the day you showed us the Thestrals,' said Carolina timidly.
    'Nah, well, we weren' goin' in so far then,' said Villalba. 'An' anyway, tha' was before Firenze left the Forest, wasn' it?'
    'Why does Firenze leaving make a difference?' asked Carolina curiously
    "Cause the other centaurs are good an' riled at me, tha's why,' said Villalba quietly, glancing around. They used ter be - well, yeh couldn' call 'em friendly - but we got on all righ'. Kept 'emselves to 'emselves, bu' always turned up if I wanted a word. Not any more.'
    He sighed deeply.
    'Firenze said they're angry because he went to work for Dominguez,' Roberto said, tripping on a protruding root because he was busy watching Villalba's profile.
    'Yeah,' said Villalba heavily. 'Well, angry doesn' cover it. Ruddy livid. If I hadn' stepped in, I reckon they'd've kicked Firenze ter death - '
    They attacked him?' said Carolina, sounding shocked.
    'Yep,' said Villalba gruffly, forcing his way through several low-hanging branches. 'He had half the herd on to him.'
    'And you stopped it?' said Roberto, amazed and impressed. 'By yourself?'
    'Course I did, couldn't stand by an' watch 'em kill 'im, cou!d I?' said Villalba. 'Lucky I was passin', really . . . an' I'd've thought Firenze mighta remembered tha' before he started sendin' me stup d warnin's!' he added hotly and unexpectedly.
    Roberto and Carolina looked at each other, startled, but Villalba, scowling, did not elaborate.
    'Anyway,' he said, breathing a little more heavily than usud, 'since then the other centaurs've bin livid with me, an' the trouble is they've got a lot of influence in the Forest . . . cleverest creatures in here.'
    'Is that why we're here, Villalba?' asked Carolina. The centaurs?'
    'Ah, no,' said Villalba, shaking his head dismissively, 'no, it's not them. Well, o' course, they could complicate the problem, yeah . . . but yeh'll see what I mean in a bit.'
    On this incomprehensible note he fell silent and forged a little ahead, taking one stride for every three of theirs, so that they had great trouble keeping up with him.
    The path was becoming increasingly overgrown and the trees grew so closely together as they walked further and further into the Forest that it was as dark as dusk. They were soon a long way past the clearing where Villalba had shown them the Thestrals, but Roberto felt no sense of unease until Villalba stepped unexpectedly off the path and began wending his way in and out of trees towards the dark heart of the Forest.
    'Villalba!' said Roberto, fighting his way through thickly knotted brambles, over which Villalba had stepped with ease, and remembering very vividly what had happened to him on the other occasion he had stepped off the Forest path. 'Where are we going?'
    'Bit further,' said Villalba over his shoulder. 'C'mon, Roberto . . . we need ter keep together now.'
    It was a great struggle to keep up with Villalba, what with branches and thickets of thorn through which Villalba marched as easily as if they were cobwebs, but which snagged Roberto and Carolina's robes, frequently entangling them so severely that they had to stop for minutes at a time to free themselves. Roberto's arms and legs were soon covered in small cuts and scratches. They were so deep in the Forest now that sometimes all Roberto could see of Villalba in the gloom was a massive dark shape ahead of him. Any sound seemed threatening in the muffled silence. The breaking of a twig echoed loudly and the tiniest rustle of movement, even though it might have been made by an innocent sparrow, caused Roberto to peer through the gloom for a culprit. It occurred to him that he had never managed to get this far into the Forest without meeting some kind of creature; their absence struck him as rather ominous.
    'Villalba, would it be all right if we lit our wands?' said Carolina quietly.
    'Er . . . all righ',' Villalba whispered back. Tn fact - '
    He stopped suddenly and turned around; Carolina walked right into him and was knocked over backwards. Roberto caught her just before she hit the Forest floor.
    'Maybe we bes' jus' stop fer a momen', so I can . . . fill yeh in,' said Villalba. 'Before we ge' there, like.'
    'Good!' said Carolina, as Roberto set her back on her feet. They both murmured 'Lumos/' and their wand-tips ignited. Villalba's face swam through the gloom by the light of the two wavering beams and Roberto saw again that he looked nervous and sad.
    'Righ',' said Villalba. 'Well . . . see . . . the thing is . . .'
    He took a great breath.
    'Well, there's a good chance I'm goin' ter be gettin' the sack any day now,' he said.
    Roberto and Carolina looked at each other, then back at him
    'But you've lasted this long - ' Carolina said tentatively. 'What makes you think - '
    'Umbridge reckons it was me that put tha' Niffler in her office.'
    'And was it?' said Roberto, before he could stop himself.
    'No, it ruddy well wasn'!' said Villalba indignantly. 'On'y any-thin' ter do with magical creatures an' she thinks it's got somethin' ter do with me. Yeh know she's bin lookin' fer a chance ter get rid of me ever since I got back. I don' wan' ter go, o' course, but if it wasn' fer . . . well . . . the special circumstances I'm abou' ter explain to yeh, I'd leave righ' now, before she's go' the chance ter do it in front o' the whole school, like she did with Trelawney'
    Roberto and Carolina both made noises of protest, but Villalba overrode them with a wave of one of his enormous hands.
    'It's not the end o' the world, I'll be able ter help Dumbledo-e once I'm outta here, I can be useful ter the Order. Air you lot'll have Grubbly-Plank, yeh'll - yeh'll get through yer exams fine . . .'
    His voice trembled and broke.
    'Don' worry abou' me,' he said hastily, as Carolina made to pat his arm. He pulled his enormous spotted handkerchief from the pocket of his waistcoat and mopped his eyes with it. 'Look, I wouldn' be tellin' yer this at all if I didn' have ter. See, if I go . . . well, I can' leave withou' . . . withou' tellin' someone . . . because I'll - I'll need yeh two ter help me. An' Diego, if he's willin'.'
    'Of course we'll help you,' said Roberto at once. 'What do you want us to do?'
    Villalba gave a great sniff and patted Roberto wordlessly on the shoulder with such force Roberto was knocked sideways into a tree.
    'I knew yeh'd say yes,' said Villalba into his handkerchief, 'but I won' . . . never . . . forget . . . well . . . c'mon . . . jus' a little bit further through here . . . watch yerselves, now, there's nettles . . .'
