    'You don't get it!' Roberto shouted at her, 'I'm not having nightmares, I'm not just dreaming! What d'you think all the Occlumency was for, why d'you think Dominguez wanted me prevented from seeing these things? Because they're REAL, Carolina - Gustavo is trapped, I've seen him. Salvador's got him, and no one else knows, and that means we're the only ones who can save him, and if you don't want to do it, fine, but I'm going, understand? And if I remember rightly, you didn't have a problem with my saving-people thing when it was you I was saving from the Dementors, or - ' he rounded on Diego - when it was your sister I was saving from the Basilisk - '
    'I never said I had a problem!' said Diego heatedly.
    'But Roberto, you've just said it,' said Carolina fiercely, 'Dominguez wanted you to learn to shut these things out of your mind, if you'd done Occlumency properly you'd never have seen this - '
    'IF YOU THINK I'M JUST GOING TO ACT LIKE I HAVEN'T SEEN - '
    'Gustavo told you there was nothing more important than you learning to close your mind!'
    'WELL, I EXPECT HE'D SAY SOMETHING DIFFERENT IF HE KNEW WHAT I'D JUST - '
    The classroom door opened. Roberto, Diego and Carolina whipped around. Martina walked in, looking curious, closely followed by Gabriela, who as usual looked as though she had drifted in accidentally.
    'Hi,' said Martina uncertainly. 'We recognised Roberto's voice. What are you yelling about?'
    'Never you mind,' said Roberto roughly.
    Martina raised her eyebrows.
    'There's no need to take that tone with me,' she said coolly, T was only wondering whether I could help.'
    'Well, you can't,' said Roberto shortly.
    'You're being rather rude, you know,' said Gabriela serenely.
    Roberto swore and turned away. The very last thing he wanted now was a conversation with Gabriela Ortiz.
    'Wait,' said Carolina suddenly. 'Wait . . . Roberto, they can help.'
    Roberto and Diego looked at her.
    'Listen,' she said urgently, 'Roberto, we need to establish whether Gustavo really has left Headquarters.'
    'I've told you, I saw - '
    'Roberto, I'm begging you, please!' said Carolina desperately. 'Please let's just check that Gustavo isn't at home before we go charging off to London. If we find out he's not there, then I swear I won't try to stop you. I'll come, I'll d - do whatever it takes to try and save him.'
    'Gustavo is being tortured NOW!' shouted Roberto. 'We haven't got time to waste.'
    'But if this is a trick of Salvador's, Roberto, we've got to check, we've got to.'
    'How?' Roberto demanded. 'How're we going to check?'
    'We'll have to use Umbridge's fire and see if we can contact him, said Carolina, who looked positively terrified at the thought. 'We'll draw Umbridge away again, but we'll need lookouts, and that's where we can use Martina and Gabriela.'
    Though clearly struggling to understand what was going on, Martina said immediately, 'Yeah, we'll do it,' and Gabriela said, 'When you say "Gustavo", are you talking about Stubby Boardman?'
    Nobody answered her.
    'OK,' Roberto said aggressively to Carolina, 'OK, if you can think of a way of doing this quickly, I'm with you, otherwise I'm going to the Department of Mysteries right now.'
    The Department of Mysteries?' said Gabriela, looking mildly surprised. 'But how are you going to get there?'
    Again, Roberto ignored her.
    'Right,' said Carolina, twisting her hands together and pacing up and down between the desks. 'Right . . . well . . . one of us has to go and find Umbridge and - and send her off in the wrong direction, keep her away from her office. They could tell her - I don't know - that Peeves is up to something awful as usual . . .'
    'I'll do it,' said Diego at once. 'I'll tell her Peeves is smashing up the Transfiguration department or something, it's miles away from her office. Come to think of it, I could probably persuade Peeves to do it if I met him on the way.'
    It was a mark of the seriousness of the situation that Carolina made no objection to the smashing up of the Transfiguration department.
    'OK,' she said, her brow furrowed as she continued to pace. 'Now, we need to keep students right away from her office while we force entry, or some Slytherin's bound to go and tip her off.
    'Gabriela and I can stand at either end of the corridor," said Martina promptly, 'and warn people not to go down there because someone's let off a load of Garrotting Gas.' Carolina looked surprised at the readiness with which Martina had come up with this lie; Martina shrugged and said, 'Pablo and Luis were planning to do it before they left.'
    'OK,' said Carolina. 'Well then, Roberto, you and I will be under the Invisibility Cloak and we'll sneak into the office and you can talk to Gustavo - '
    'He's not there, Carolina!'
    'I mean, you can - can check whether Gustavo is at home or not while I keep watch, I don't think you should be in there alone, Lee's already proved the windows a weak spot, sending those Nifflers through it.'
    Even through his anger and impatience, Roberto recognised Carolina's offer to accompany him into Umbridge's office as a sign of solidarity and loyalty.
    'I . . . OK, thanks,' he muttered.
    'Right, well, even if we do all of that, I don't think we're going to be able to bank on more than five minutes,' said Carolina, looking relieved that Roberto seemed to have accepted the plan, 'not with Filch and the wretched Inquisitorial Squad floating around.'
    'Five minutes'll be enough,' said Roberto 'C'mon, let's go - '
    'Now?' said Carolina, looking shocked.
    'Of course now!' said Roberto angrily. 'What did you think, we're going to wait until after dinner or something? Carolina, Gustavo is being tortured right now!'
    'I - oh, all right,' she said desperately. 'You go and get the Invisibility Cloak and we'll meet you at the end of Umbridge's corridor, OK?'
    Roberto didn't answer, but flung himself out of the room and began to fight his way through the milling crowds outside. Two floors up he met Seamus and Dean, who hailed him jovially and told him they were planning a dusk-till-dawn end-of-exams celebration in the common room. Roberto barely heard them. He scrambled through the portrait hole while they were still arguing about how many black-market Butterbeers they would need and was climbing back out of it, the Invisibility Cloak and Gustavo's knife secure in his bag, before they noticed he had left them.
    'Roberto, d'you want to chip in a couple of Galleons? Harold Dingle reckons he could sell us some Firewhisky - '
    But Roberto was already tearing away back along the corridor, and a couple of minutes later was jumping the last few stairs to join Diego, Carolina, Martina and Gabriela, who were huddled together at the end of Umbridge's corridor.
    'Got it,' he panted. 'Ready to go, then?'
    All right, whispered Carolina as a gang of loud sixth-years passed them. 'So Diego - you go and head Umbridge off . . . Martina, Gabriela, if you can start moving people out of the corridor . . . Roberto and I will get the Cloak on and wait until the coast is clear . . ."
    Diego strode away, his bright-red hair visible right to the end of the passage; meanwhile Martina's equally vivid head bobbed between the jostling students surrounding them in the other direction, trailed by. Gabriela's blonde one.
    'Get over here,' muttered Carolina, tugging at Roberto's wrist and pulling him back into a recess where the ugly stone head of a medieval wizard stood muttering to itself on a column. 'Are - are you sure you're OK, Roberto? You're still very pale.'
    'I'm fine,' he said shortly, tugging the Invisibility Cloak from out of his bag. In truth, his scar was aching, but not so badly that he thought Salvador had yet dealt Gustavo a fatal blow; it had hurt much worse than this when Salvador had been punishing Avery . . .
    'Here,' he said; he threw the Invisibility Cloak over both of them and they stood listening carefully over the Latin mumblings of the bust in front of them.
    'You can't come down here!' Martina was calling to the crowd. 'No, sorry, you're going to have to go round by the swivelling staircase, someone's let off Garrotting Gas just along here - '
    They could hear people complaining; one surly voice said, 'I can't see no gas.'
    That's because it's colourless,' said Martina in a convincingly exasperated voice, 'but if you want to walk through it, carry on, then we'll have your body as proof for the next idiot who doesn't believe us.'
    Slowly, the crowd thinned. The news about the Garrotting Gas seemed to have spread; people were not coming this way any more. When at last the surrounding area was quite clear, Carolina said quietly, 'I think that's as good as we're going to get, Roberto - cone on, let's do it.'
    They moved forwards, covered by the Cloak. Gabriela was standing with her back to them at the far end of the corridor. As they passed Martina, Carolina whispered, 'Good one . . . don't forget the signal.'
    'What's the signal?' muttered Roberto, as they approached Umbridge's door.
    'A loud chorus of "Lopez is our King" if they see Umbridge coming,' replied Carolina, as Roberto inserted the blade of Gustavo's knife in the crack between door and wall. The lock clicked open and they entered the office.
    The garish kittens were basking in the late-afternoon sunshine that was warming their plates, but otherwise the office was as still and unoccupied as last time. Carolina breathed a sigh of relief.
    'I thought she might have added extra security after the second Niffler.'
    They pulled off the Cloak; Carolina hurried over to the window and stood out of sight, peering down into the grounds with her wand out. Roberto dashed over to the fireplace, seized the pot of Floo powder and threw a pinch into the grate, causing emerald flames to burst into life there. He knelt down quickly, thrust his head into the dancing fire and cried, 'Number twelve, Grimmauld Place!'
    His head began to spin as though he had just got off a fairground ride though his knees remained firmly planted on the cold office floor. He kept his eyes screwed up against the whirling ash and when the spinning stopped he opened them to find himself looking out at the long, cold kitchen of Grimmauld Place.
    There was nobody there. He had expected this, yet was not prepared for the molten wave of dread and panic that seemed to burst through his stomach at the sight of the deserted room.
    'Gustavo?' he shouted. 'Gustavo, are you there?'
    His voice echoed around the room, but there was no answer except a tiny scuffing sound to the right of the tire.
    'Who's there?' he called, wondering whether it was just a mouse.
    Kreacher the house-elf crept into view. He looked highly delighted about something, though he seemed to have recently sustained a nasty injury to both hands, which were heavily bandaged.
    'It's the Gonzales boys head in the fire,' Kreacher informed the empty kitchen, stealing furtive, oddly triumphant glances at Roberto. 'What has he come for, Kreacher wonders?'
    'Where's Gustavo, Kreacher?' Roberto demanded.
    The house-elf gave a wheezy chuckle.
    'Master has gone out, Roberto Gonzales.'
    'Where's he gone? Where's he gone, Kreacher?'
    Kreacher merely cackled.
    'I'm warning you!' said Roberto, fully aware that his scope for inflicting punishment upon Kreacher was almost non-existent in this position. 'What about Cardozo? Mad-Eye? Any of them, are any of them there?'
    'Nobody here but Kreacher!' said the elf gleefully, and turning away from Roberto he began to walk slowly towards the door at the end of the kitchen. 'Kreacher thinks he will have a little chat with his mistress now, yes, he hasn't had a chance in a long time, Kreacher's master has been keeping him away from her - '
    'Where has Gustavo gone?' Roberto yelled after the elf. 'Kreacher, has he gone to the Department of Mysteries?'
    Kreacher stopped in his tracks. Roberto could just make out the back of his bald head through the forest of chair legs before him.
    'Master does not tell poor Kreacher where he is going,' said the elf quietly.
    'But you know!' shouted Roberto. 'Don't you? You know where he is!'
    There was a moment's silence, then the elf let out his loudest cackle yet.
    'Master will not come back from the Department of Mysteries!' he said gleefully. 'Kreacher and his mistress are alone again!'
    And he scurried forwards and disappeared through the door to the hall.
    'You - '!'
    But before he could utter a single curse or insult, Roberto felt a great pain at the top of his head; he inhaled a lot of ash and, choking, found himself being dragged backwards through the flames, until with a horrible abruptness he was staring up into the wide, pallid face of Professor Umbridge who had dragged him backwards out of the fire by the hair and was now bending his neck back as far as it would go, as though she were going to slit his throat.
    'You think,' she whispered, bending Roberto's neck back even further, so that he was looking up at the ceiling, 'that after two Nifflers
    I was going to let one more foul, scavenging little creature enter my office without my knowledge? I had Stealth Sensoring Spells placed all around my doorway after the last one got in, you foolish boy. Take his wand,' she barked at someone he could not see, and he felt a hand grope inside the chest pocket of his robes and remove the wand. 'Hers, too.'
    Roberto heard a scuffle over by the door and knew that Carolina had also just had her wand wrested from her.
    'I want to know why you are in my office,' said Umbridge, shaking the fist clutching his hair so that he staggered.
    'I was - trying to get my Firebolt!' Roberto croaked.
    'Liar.' She shook his head again. 'Your Firebolt is under strict guard in the dungeons, as you very well know, Gonzales. You had your head in my fire. With whom have you been communicating?'
    'No one - ' said Roberto, trying to pull away from her. He felt several hairs part company with his scalp.
    'Liar!' shouted Umbridge. She threw him from her and he slammed into the desk. Now he could see Carolina pinioned against the wall by Millicent Bulstrode. Sosa was leaning on the windowsill, smirking as he threw Roberto's wand into the air one-handed and caught it again.
    There was a commotion outside and several large Slytherins entered, each gripping Diego, Martina, Gabriela and - to Roberto's bewilderment - Mauricio, who was trapped in a stranglehold by Crabbe and looked in imminent danger of suffocation. All four of them had been gagged.
    'Got 'em all,' said Warrington, shoving Diego roughly forwards into the room. That one,' he poked a thick finger at Mauricio, 'tried to stop me taking her,' he pointed at Martina, who was trying to kick the shins of the large Slytherin girl holding her, 'so I brought him along too.'
    'Good, good,' said Umbridge, watching Martina's struggles. 'Well, it looks as though Hogwarts will shortly be a Lopez-free zone, doesn't it?'
    Sosa laughed loudly and sycophantically. Umbridge gave her wide, complacent smile and settled herself into a chintz-covered armchair, blinking up at her captives like a toad in a flowerbed.
    'So, Gonzales,' she said. 'You stationed lookouts around my office and you sent this buffoon,' she nodded at Diego - Sosa laughed even louder - 'to tell me the poltergeist was wreaking havoc in the Transfiguration department when I knew perfectly well that he was busy smearing ink on the eyepieces of all the school telescopes - 'Mr Filch having just informed me so.
    'Clearly, it was very important for you to talk to somebody. Was it Alfonso Dominguez? Or the half-breed, Villalba? I doubt it was Elena Romero, I hear she is still too ill to talk to anyone.'
    Sosa and a few of the other members of the Inquisitorial Squad laughed some more at that. Roberto found he was so full of rage and hatred he was shaking.
    'It's none of your business who I talk to,' he snarled.
    Umbridge's slack face seemed to tighten.
    'Very well,' she said in her most dangerous and falsely sweet voice. 'Very well, Mr Gonzales . . . I offered you the chance to tell me freely. You refused. I have no alternative but to force you. Javier
    ' - fetch Professor Peralta.'
    Sosa slowed Roberto's wand inside his robes and left the room smirking, but Roberto hardly noticed. He had just realised something; he could not believe he had been so stupid as to forget it. He had thought that all the members of the Order, all those who could help him save Gustavo, were gone - but he had been wrong. There was still a member of the Order of the Phoenix at Hogwarts - Peralta.
    There was silence in the office except for the fidgetings and scufflings resulting from the Slytherins' efforts to keep Diego and the others under control. Diego's lip was bleeding on to Umbridge's carpet as he struggled against Warrington's half-nelson; Martina was still trying to stamp on the feel of the sixth-year girl who had both her upper arms in a tight grip; Mauricio was turning steadily more purple in the face while lugging at Crabbe's arms; and Carolina was attempting, in vain, to throw Millicent Bulstrode off her. Gabriela, however, stood limply by the side of her captor, gazing vaguely out of the window as though rather bored by the proceedings.
    Roberto looked back at Umbridge, who was watching him closely. He kept his face deliberately smooth and blank as footsteps were heard in the corridor outside and Javier Sosa entered the room, closely followed by Peralta.
    'You wanted to see me, Headmistress?' said Peralta, looking around at all the pairs of struggling students with an expression of complete indifference.
    'Ah, Professor Peralta,' said Umbridge, smiling widely and standing up again. 'Yes, I would like another bottle of Veritaserum, as quick as you can, please.'
    'You took my last bottle to interrogate Gonzales,' he said, surveying her coolly through his greasy curtains of black hair. 'Surely you did not use it all? I told you that three drops would be sufficient.'
    Umbridge flushed.
    'You can make some more, can't you?' she said, her voice becoming more sweetly girlish as it always did when she was furious.
    'Certainly,' said Peralta, his lip curling. 'It takes a full moon-cycle to mature, so I should have it ready for you in around a month.'
    'A month?' squawked Umbndge, swelling toadishly. 'A month! But I need it this evening, Peralta! I have just found Gonzales using my fire to communicate with a person or persons unknown!'
    'Really?' said Peralta, showing his first, faint sign of interest as he looked round at Roberto. 'Well, it doesn't surprise me. Gonzales has never shown much inclination to follow school rules.'
    His cold, dark eyes were boring into Roberto's, who met his gaze unflinchingly, concentrating hard on what he had seen in his dream, willing Peralta to read it in his mind, to understand . . .
    'I wish to interrogate him!' repeated Umbridge angrily, and Peralta looked away from Roberto back into her furiously quivering lace. 'I wish you to provide me with a potion that will force him to tell me the truth!'
    'I have already told you,' said Peralta smoothly, 'that I have no further stocks of Veritaserum. Unless you wish to poison Gonzales - 'and I assure you I would have the greatest sympathy with you if you did - I cannot help you. The only trouble is that most venoms act too fast to give the victim much lime for truth-telling.'
    Peralta looked back at Roberto, who stared at him, frantic to communicate without words.
    Salvador's got Gustavo in the Department of Mysteries, he thought desperately. Salvadors got Gustavo - '
    'You are on probation!' shrieked Professor Umbridge, and Peralta looked back at her, his eyebrows slightly raised. 'You arc being deliberately unhelpful! I expected better, Mariano Sosa always speaks most highly of you! Now get out of my office!'
    Peralta gave her an ironic bow and turned to leave. Roberto knew his last chance of letting the Order know what was going on was walking out of the door.
    'He's got Padfoot!' he shouted. 'He's got Padfoot at the place where it's hidden!'
    Peralta had stopped with his hand on Umbridge's door handle.
    'Padfoot?' cried Professor Umbridge, looking eagerly from Roberto to Peralta. 'What is Padfoot? Where what is hidden? What does he mean, Peralta?'
    Peralta looked round at Roberto. His face was inscrutable. Roberto could not tell whether he had understood or not, but he did not dare speak more plainly in front of Umbridge.
    'I have no idea,' said Peralta coldly. 'Gonzales, when I want nonsense shouted at me I shall give you a Babbling Beverage. And Crabbe, loosen your hold a little. If Silva suffocates it will mean a lot of tedious paperwork and I am afraid I shall have to mention it on your reference if ever you apply for a job.'
    He closed the door behind him with a snap, leaving Roberto in a state of worse turmoil than before: Peralta had been his very last hope. He looked at Umbridge, who seemed to be feeling the same way; her chest was heaving with rage and frustration.
    'Very well,' she said, and she pulled out her wand. 'Very well . . . I am left with no alternative . . . this is more than a matter of school discipline . . . this is an issue of Ministry security . . . yes . . . yes . . .'
    She seemed to be talking herself into something. She was shifting her weight nervously from foot to foot, staring at Roberto, beating her wand against her empty palm and breathing heavily As he watched her, Roberto felt horribly powerless without his own wand.
    'You are forcing me, Gonzales . . . I do not want to,' said Umbridge, still moving restlessly on the spot, 'but sometimes circumstances justify the use . . . I am sure the Minister will understand that I had no choice . . .'
    Sosa was watching her with a hungry expression on his face.
    The Cruciatus Curse ought to loosen your tongue,' said Umbridge quietly.
    'No!' shrieked Carolina. 'Professor Umbridge - it's illegal.'
    But Umbridge took no notice. There was a nasty eager, excited look on her face that Roberto had never seen before. She raised her wand.
    The Minister wouldn't want you to break the law, Professor Umbridge!' cried Carolina.
    'What Cornelius doesn't know won't hurt him,' said Umbridge, who was now panting slightly as she pointed her wand at different parts of Roberto's body in turn, apparently trying to decide where it would hurt most. 'He never knew I ordered Dementors to go after Gonzales last summer, but he was delighted to be given the chance to expel him, all the same.'
    'It was you?' gasped Roberto. 'You sent the Dementors after me?'
    'Somebody had to act,' breathed Umbridge, as her wand came to rest pointing directly at Roberto's forehead. They were all bleating about silencing you somehow - discrediting you - but I was the one who actually did something about it . . . only you wriggled out of that one, didn't you, Gonzales? Not today though, not now - ' And taking a deep breath, she cried, 'Cruc-
    'NO!' shouted Carolina in a cracked voice from behind Millicent Bulstrode. 'No - Roberto - we'll have to tell her!'
    'No way!' yelled Roberto, staring at the little of Carolina he could see.
    'We'll have to, Roberto, she'll force it out of you anyway, what's . . . what's the point?'
    And Carolina began to cry weakly into the back of Millicent Bulstrode's robes. Millicent stopped trying to squash her against the wall immediately and dodged out of her way looking disgusted.
    'Well, well, well!' said Umbridge, looking triumphant. 'Little Miss Question-all is going to give us some answers! Come on then, girl, come on!'
    'Er - my - nee - no!' shouted Diego through his gag.
    Martina was staring at Carolina as though she had never seen her before. Mauricio, still choking for breath, was gazing at her, too. But Roberto had just noticed something. Though Carolina was sobbing desperately into her hands, there was no trace of a tear.
    'I'm - I'm sorry everyone,' said Carolina. 'But - I can't stand it - '
    That's right, that's right, girl!' said Umbridge, seizing Carolina by the shoulders, thrusting her into the abandoned chintz chair and leaning over her. 'Now then . . . with whom was Gonzales communicating just now?'
    'Well,' gulped Carolina into her hands, 'well, he was trying to speak to Professor Dominguez.'
    Diego froze, his eyes wide; Martina stopped trying to stamp on her Slytherin captor's toes; and even Gabriela looked mildly surprised. Fortunately, the attention of Umbridge and her minions was focused too exclusively upon Carolina to notice these suspicious signs
    'Dominguez?' said Umbridge eagerly. 'You know where Dominguez is, then?'
    'Well . . . no!' sobbed Carolina. 'We've tried the Leaky Cauldron in Diagon Alley and the Three Broomsticks and even the Hog's Head - '
    'Idiot girl - Dominguez won't be sitting in a pub when the whole Ministry's looking for him!' shouted Umbridge, disappointment etched in every sagging line of her face.
    'But - but we needed to tell him something important!' wailed Carolina, holding her hands more tightly over her face, not, Roberto knew, out of anguish, but to disguise the continued absence of tears.
    'Yes?' said Umbridge with a sudden resurgence of excitement. 'What was it you wanted to tell him?'
    'We . . . we wanted to tell him it's r - ready!' choked Carolina.
    'What's ready?' demanded Umbridge, and now she grabbed Carolina's shoulders again and shook her slightly. 'What's ready, girl?'
    The . . . the weapon,' said Carolina.
    'Weapon? Weapon?' said Umbridge, and her eyes seemed to pop with excitement. 'You have been developing some method of resistance? A weapon you could use against the Ministry? On Professor Dominguez's orders, of course?'
    'Y - y - yes,' gasped Carolina, 'but he had to leave before it was finished and n - n - now we've finished it for him, and we c - c - can't find him t - t - to tell him!'
    'What kind of weapon is it?' said Umbridge harshly, her stubby hands still tight on Carolina's shoulders.
    'We don't r - r - really understand it,' said Carolina, sniffing loudly. 'We j - j - just did what P - P - Professor Dominguez told us t - t - to do.'
    Umbridge straightened up, looking exultant.
    'Lead me to the weapon,' she said.
    'I'm not showing . . . them,' said Carolina shrilly, looking around at the Slytherins through her fingers.
    'It is not for you to set conditions,' said Professor Umbridge harshly.
    'Fine,' said Carolina, now sobbing into her hands again. Tine . . . let them see it, I hope they use it on you! In fact, I wish you'd invite loads and loads of people to come and see! Th - that would serve you right - oh, I'd love it if the wh - whole school knew where it was, and how to u - use it, and then if you annoy any of them they'll, be able to s - sort you out!'
    These words had a powerful impact on Umbridge: she glanced swiftly and suspiciously around at her Inquisitorial Squad, her bulging eyes resting for a moment on Sosa, who was too slow to disguise the look of eagerness and greed that had appeared on his lace.
    Umbridge contemplated Carolina for another long moment, then spoke in what she clearly thought was a motherly voice.
    'All right, dear, let's make it just you and me . . . and we'll take Gonzales, loo, shall we? Get up, now.'
    'Professor,' said Sosa eagerly, 'Professor Umbridge, I think some of the Squad should come with you to look after - '
    'I am a fully qualified Ministry official, Sosa, do you really think I cannot manage two wandless teenagers alone?' asked Umbridge sharply. 'In any case, it does not sound as though this weapon is something that schoolchildren should see. You will
    remain here until I return and make sure none of these - she gestured around at Diego, Martina, Mauricio and Gabriela ' - escape.'
    'All right,' said Sosa, looking sulky and disappointed.
    'And you two can go ahead of me and show me the way,' said Umbridge, pointing at Roberto and Carolina with her wand. 'Lead on.'
- CHAPTER THIRTY-THREE -
Fight and Flight
Roberto had no idea what Carolina was planning, or even whether she had a plan. He walked half a pace behind her as they headed down the corridor outside Umbridge's office, knowing it would look very suspicious if he appeared not to know where they were going. He did not dare attempt to talk to her; Umbridge was walking so closely behind them that he could hear her ragged breathing.
    Carolina led the way down the stairs into the Entrance Hall. The din of loud voices and the clatter of cutlery on plates echoed from out of the double doors to the Great Hall - it seemed incredible to Roberto that twenty feet away were people who were enjoying dinner, celebrating the end of exams, not a care in the world . . .
    Carolina walked straight out of the oak front doors and down the stone steps into the balmy evening air. The sun was falling towards the tops of the trees in the Forbidden Forest now, and as Carolina marched purposefully across the grass - Umbridge jogging to keep up - their long dark shadows rippled over the grass behind them like cloaks.
    'It's hidden in Villalba's hut, is it?' said Umbridge eagerly in Roberto's ear.
    'Of course not,' said Carolina scathingly. 'Villalba might have set it off accidentally.'
    'Yes,' said Umbridge, whose excitement seemed to be mounting. 'Yes, he would have done, of course, the great half-breed oaf.'
    She laughed. Roberto felt a strong urge to swing round and seize her by the throat, but resisted. His scar was throbbing in the soft evening air but it had not yet burned white-hot, as he knew it would if Salvador had moved in for the kill.
    'Then . . . where is it? asked Umbridge, with a hint or uncertainty in her voice as Carolina continued to stride towards the Forest.
    'In there, of course,' said Carolina, pointing into the dark trees. 'It had to be somewhere that students weren't going to find it accidentally, didn't it?'
    'Of course,' said Umbridge, though she sounded a little apprehensive now. 'Of course . . . very well, then . . . you two stay ahead of me.'
    'Can we have your wand, then, if we're going first?' Roberto asked her.
    'No, I don't think so, Mr Gonzales,' said Umbridge sweetly, poking him in the back with it. The Ministry places a rather higher value on my life than yours, I'm afraid.'
    As they reached the cool shade of the first trees, Roberto tried to catch Carolina s eye; walking into the Forest without wands seemed to him to be more foolhardy than anything they had done so far this evening. She, however, merely gave Umbridge a contemptuous glance and plunged straight into the trees, moving at such a pace that Umbridge, with her shorter legs, had difficulty in keeping up.
    'Is it very far in?' Umbridge asked, as her robe ripped on a bramble.
    'Oh yes,' said Carolina, 'yes, it's well hidden.'
    Roberto's misgivings increased. Carolina was not taking the path they had followed to visit Grawp, but the one he followed three years ago to the lair of the monster Aragog. Carolina had not been with him on that occasion; he doubted she had any idea what danger lay at the end of it.
    'Er - are you sure this is the right way?' he asked her pointedly.
    'Oh yes,' she said in a steely voice, crashing through the undergrowth with what he thought was a wholly unnecessary amount of noise. Behind them, Umbridge tripped over a fallen sapling. Neither of them paused to help her up again; Carolina merely strode on, calling loudly over her shoulder, 'It's a bit further in!'
    'Carolina, keep your voice down,' Roberto muttered, hurrying to catch up with her. 'Anything could be listening in here - '
    'I want us heard,' she answered quietly, as Umbridge jogged noisily after them. 'You'll see . . .'
    They walked on for what seemed a long time, until they were once again so deep into the Forest that the dense tree canopy blocked out all light. Roberto had the feeling he had had before in the Forest, one of being watched by unseen eyes.
    'How much further?' demanded Umbridge angrily from behind him.
    'Not far now!' shouted Carolina, as they emerged into a dim, dank clearing. 'Just a little bit - '
    An arrow flew through the air and landed with a menacing thud in the tree just over her head. The air was suddenly full of the sound of hooves; Roberto could feel the Forest floor trembling; Umbridge gave a little scream and pushed him in front of her like a shield - '
    He wrenched himself free of her and turned. Around fifty centaurs were emerging on every side, their bows raised and loaded, pointing at Roberto, Carolina and Umbridge. They backed slowly into the centre of the clearing, Umbridge uttering odd little whimpers of terror. Roberto looked sideways at Carolina. She was wearing a triumphant smile.
    'Who are you?' said a voice.
    Roberto looked left. The chestnut-bodied centaur called Magorian was walking towards them out of the circle: his bow, like those of the others, was raised. On Roberto's right, Umbridge was still whimpering, her wand trembling violently as she pointed it at the advancing centaur.
    'I asked you who are you, human,' said Magorian roughly.
    'I am Dolores Umbridge!' said Umbridge in a high-pitched, terrified voice. 'Senior Undersecretary to the Minister for Magic and Headmistress and High Inquisitor of Hogwarts!'
    'You are from the Ministry of Magic?' said Magorian, as many of the centaurs in the surrounding circle shifted restlessly.
    'That's right!' said Umbridge, in an even higher voice, 'so be very careful! By the laws laid down by the Department for the Regulation and Control of Magical Creatures, any attack by half-breeds such as yourselves on a human - '
    'What did you call us?' shouted a wild-looking black centaur, whom Roberto recognised as Bane. There was a great deal of angry muttering and tightening of bowstrings around them.
    'Don't call them that!' Carolina said furiously, but Umbridge did not appear to have heard her. Still pointing her shaking wand at Magorian, she continued, 'Law Fifteen "B" states clearly that "any attack by a magical creature who is deemed to have near-human intelligence, and therefore considered responsible for its actions - '
    ' "Near-human intelligence"?' repeated Magorian, as Bane and several others roared with rage and pawed the ground. 'We consider that a great insult, human! Our intelligence, thankfully, far outstrips your own.'
    'What are you doing in our Forest?' bellowed the hard-faced grey centaur Roberto and Carolina had seen on their last trip into the Forest. 'Why are you here?'
    'Your Forest?' said Umbridge, shaking now not only with fright but also, it seemed, with indignation. 'I would remind you that you live here only because the Ministry of Magic permits you certain areas of land - '
    An arrow flew so close to her head that it caught at her mousy hair in passing: she let out an ear-splitting scream and threw her hands over her head, while some of the centaurs bellowed their approval and others laughed raucously. The sound of their wild, neighing laughter echoing around the dimly lit clearing and the sight of their pawing hooves was extremely unnerving.
    'Whose Forest is it now, human?' bellowed Bane.
    'Filthy half-breeds!' she screamed, her hands still tight over her head. 'Beasts! Uncontrolled animals!'
    'Be quiet!' shouted Carolina, but it was too late: Umbridge pointed her wand at Magorian and screamed, 'Incarcerous!'
    Ropes flew out of midair like thick snakes, wrapping themselves tightly around the centaur's torso and trapping his arms: he gave a cry of rage and reared on to his hind legs, attempting to free himself, while the other centaurs charged.
    Roberto grabbed Carolina and pulled her to the ground; face down on the Forest floor, he knew a moment of terror as hooves thundered around him, but the centaurs leapt over and around them, bellowing and screaming with rage.
    'Nooooo!' he heard Umbridge shriek. 'Noooooo . . . I am Senior Undersecretary . . . you cannot - Unhand me, you animals . . . nooooo!'
    Roberto saw a flash of red light and knew she had attempted to Stun one of them; then she screamed very loudly. Lifting his head a few inches, Roberto saw that Umbridge had been seized from behind by Bane and lifted high into the air, wriggling and yelling with fright. Her wand fell from her hand to the ground, and Roberto's heart leapt. If he could just reach it - '
    But as he stretched out a hand towards it, a centaur's hoof descended upon the wand and it broke cleanly in half.
    'Now!' roared a voice in Roberto's ear and a thick hairy arm descended from thin air and dragged him upright. Carolina, too, had been pulled to her feet. Over the plunging, many-coloured backs and heads of the centaurs, Roberto saw Umbridge being borne away through the trees by Bane. Screaming non-stop, her voice grew fainter and fainter until they could no longer hear it over the trampling of hooves surrounding them.
    'And these?' said the hard-faced, grey centaur holding Carolina.
    'They are young,' said a slow, doleful voice from behind Roberto. 'We do not attack foals.'
    'They brought her here, Diegoan,' replied the centaur who had such a firm grip on Roberto. 'And they are not so young . . . he is nearing manhood, this one.'
    He shook Roberto by the neck of his robes.
    'Please,' said Carolina breathlessly, 'please, don't attack us, We don't think like her, we aren't Ministry of Magic employees! We only came in here because we hoped you'd drive her off for us.'
    Roberto knew at once, from the look on the face of the grey centaur holding Carolina, that she had made a terrible mistake in saying this. The grey centaur threw back his head, his back legs stamping furiously, and bellowed, 'You see, Diegoan? They already have the arrogance of their kind! So we were to do your dirty work, were we, human girl? We were to act as your servants, drive away your enemies like obedient hounds?'
    'No!' said Carolina in a horrorstruck squeak. 'Please - I didn't mean that! I just hoped you'd be able to - to help us - '
    But she seemed to be going from bad to worse.
    'We do not help humans!' snarled the centaur holding Roberto, tightening his grip and rearing a little at the same time, so that Roberto's feet left the ground momentarily. 'We are a race apart and proud to be so. We will not permit you to walk from here, boasting that we did your bidding!'
    'We're not going to say anything like that!' Roberto shouted. 'We know you didn't do what you did because we wanted you to - '
    But nobody seemed to be listening to him.
    A bearded centaur towards the back of the crowd shouted, They came here unasked, they must pay the consequences!'
    A roar of approval met these words and a dun-coloured centaur shouted, 'They can join the woman!'
    'You said you didn't hurt the innocent!' shouted Carolina, real tears sliding down her face now. 'We haven't done anything to hurt you, we haven't used wands or threats, we just want to go back to school, please let us go back - '
    'We are not all like the traitor Firenze, human girl!' shouted the grey centaur, to more neighing roars of approval from his fellows. 'Perhaps you thought us pretty talking horses? We are an ancient people who will not stand wizard invasions and insults! We do not recognise your laws, we do not acknowledge your superiority, we are - '
    But they did not hear what else centaurs were, for at that moment there came a crashing noise on the edge of the clearing so loud that all of them, Roberto, Carolina and the fifty or so centaurs filling the clearing, looked around. Roberto's centaur let him fall to the ground again as his hands flew to his bow and quiver of arrows. Carolina had been dropped, too, and Roberto hurried towards her as two thick tree trunks parted ominously and the monstrous form of Grawp the giant appeared in the gap.
    The centaurs nearest him backed into those behind; the clearing was now a forest of bows and arrows waiting to be fired, all pointing upwards at the enormous greyish face now looming over them from just beneath the thick canopy of branches. Grawp's lopsided mouth was gaping stupidly; they could see his bricklike yellow teeth glimmering in the half-light, his dull sludge-coloured eyes narrowed as he squinted down at the creatures at his feet. Broken ropes trailed from both ankles.
    He opened his mouth even wider.
    'Hagger.'
    Roberto did not know what 'hagger' meant, or what language it was from, nor did he much care; he was watching Grawp's feet, which were almost as long as Roberto's whole body. Carolina gripped his arm tightly; the centaurs were quite silent, staring up at the giant, whose huge, round head moved from side to side as he continued to peer amongst them as though looking for something he had dropped.
    'Hagger!' he said again, more insistently.
    'Get away from here, giant!' called Magorian. 'You are not welcome among us!'
    These words seemed to make no impression whatsoever on Grawp. He stooped a little (the centaurs' arms tensed on their bows), then bellowed, 'HAGGER!'
    A few of the centaurs looked worried now. Carolina, however, gave a gasp.
    'Roberto!' she whispered. 'I think he's trying to say "Villalba"!'
    At this precise moment Grawp caught sight of them, the only two humans in a sea of centaurs. He lowered his head another foot or so, staring intently at them. Roberto could feel Carolina shaking as Grawp opened his mouth wide again and said, in a deep, rumbling voice, 'Hermy.'
    'Goodness,' said Carolina, gripping Roberto's arm so tightly it was growing numb and looking as though she was about to faint, 'he - he remembered!'
    'HERMY!' roared Grawp. 'WHERE HAGGER?'
    'I don't know!' squealed Carolina, terrified. 'I'm sorry, Grawp, I don't know!'
    'GRAWP WANT HAGGER!'
    One of the giants massive hands reached down. Carolina let out a real scream, ran a few steps backwards and fell over. Devoid of a wand, Roberto braced himself to punch, kick, bite or whatever else it took as the hand swooped towards him and knocked a snow-white centaur off his legs.
    It was what the centaurs had been waiting for - Grawp's outstretched fingers were a foot from Roberto when fifty arrows soared through the air at the giant, peppering his enormous face, causing him to howl with pain and rage and straighten up, rubbing his face with his enormous hands, breaking off the arrow shafts but forcing the arrowheads in still deeper.
    He yelled and stamped his enormous feet and the centaur; scattered out of the way; pebble-sized droplets of Grawp's blood showered Roberto as he pulled Carolina to her feet and the pair of them ran as fast as they could for the shelter of the trees. Once there they looked back; Grawp was snatching blindly at the centaurs as blood ran down his face; they were retreating in disorder, galloping away through the trees on the other side of the clearing. Roberto and Carolina watched Grawp give another roar of fury and plunge after them, smashing more trees aside as he went.
    'Oh no,' said Carolina, quaking so badly that her knees gave way. 'Oh, that was horrible. And he might kill them all.'
    'I'm not that fussed, to be honest,' said Roberto bitterly.
    The sounds of the galloping centaurs and the blundering giant grew fainter and fainter. As Roberto listened to them, his scar gave another great throb and a wave of terror swept over him.
    They had wasted so much time - they were even further from rescuing Gustavo than they had been when he had had the vision. Not only had Roberto managed to lose his wand but they were stuck in the middle of the Forbidden Forest with no means of transport whatsoever.
    'Smart plan,' he spat at Carolina, having to release some of his fury. 'Really smart plan. Where do we go from here?'
    'We need to get back up to the castle,' said Carolina faintly.
    'By the time we've done that, Gustavo'll probably be dead!' said Roberto, kicking a nearby tree in temper. A high-pitched chattering started up overhead and he looked up to see an angry Bowtruckle flexing its long twiglike fingers at him.
    'Well, we can't do anything without wands,' said Carolina hopelessly, dragging herself up again. 'Anyway, Roberto, how exactly were you planning to get all the way to London?'
    'Yeah, we were just wondering that.' said a familiar voice from behind her.
    Roberto and Carolina moved together instinctively and peered through the trees.
    Diego came into sight, closely followed by Martina, Mauricio and Gabriela. All of them looked a little the worse for wear - there were several long scratches running the length of Martina's cheek; a large purple lump was swelling above Mauricio's right eye; Diego's lip was bleeding worse than ever - but all were looking rather pleased with themselves.
    'So,' said Diego, pushing aside a low-hanging branch and holding out Roberto's wand, 'had any ideas?'
    'How did you get away?' asked Roberto in amazement, taking his wand from Diego.
    'Couple of Stunners, a Disarming Charm, Mauricio brought off a really nice little Impediment Jinx,' said Diego airily, now handing back Carolina's wand, too. 'But Martina was best, she got Sosa - Bat Bogey Hex - it was superb, his whole face was covered in the great flapping things. Anyway, we saw you out of the window heading into the Forest and followed. What've you done with Umbridge?'
    'She got carried away,' said Roberto. 'By a herd of centaurs.'
    'And they left you behind?' asked Martina, looking astonished.
    'No, they got chased off by Grawp,' said Roberto.
    'Who's Grawp?' Gabriela asked interestedly.
    'Villalba's little brother,' said Diego promptly. 'Anyway, never mind that now. Roberto, what did you find out in the fire? Has You-Know-Who got Gustavo or - ?'
    'Yes,' said Roberto, as his scar gave another painful prickle, 'and I'm sure Gustavo is still alive, but I can't see how we're going to get there to help him.'
    They all fell silent, looking rather scared; the problem facing them seemed insurmountable.
    'Well, we'll have to fly, won't we?' said Gabriela, in the closest thing to a matter-of-fact voice Roberto had ever heard her use.
    'OK,' said Roberto irritably, rounding on her. 'First of all, "we" aren't doing anything if you're including yourself in that, and second of all, Diego's me only one with a broomstick that isn't being guarded by a security troll, so - '
    'I've got a broom!' said Martina.
    'Yeah, but you're not coming,' said Diego angrily.
    'Excuse me, but I care what happens to Gustavo as much as you do!' said Martina, her jaw set so that her resemblance to Pablo and Luis was suddenly striking.
    'You're too - ' Roberto began, but Martina said fiercely, 'I'm three years older than you were when you fought You-Know-Who over the Philosophers Stone, and it's because of me that Sosa's stuck back in Umbridge's office with giant flying bogies attacking him - '
    'Yeah, but - '
    'We were all in the DA together,' said Mauricio quietly. 'It was all supposed to be about fighting You-Know-Who, wasn't it? And this is the first chance we've had to do something real - or was that all just a game or something?'
    'No - of course it wasn't - ' said Roberto impatiently.
    'Then we should come too,' said Mauricio simply. 'We want to help.'
    'That's right,' said Gabriela, smiling happily.
    Roberto's eyes met Diego's. He knew Diego was thinking exactly what he was: if he could have chosen any members of the DA, in addition to himself, Diego and Carolina, to join him in the attempt to rescue Gustavo, he would not have picked Martina, Mauricio or Gabriela.
    'Well, it doesn't matter, anyway,' said Roberto through gritted teeth, 'because we still don't know how to get there - '
    'I thought we'd settled that,' said Gabriela maddeningly. 'We're flying!'
    'Look,' said Diego, barely containing his anger, 'you might be able to fly without a broomstick but the rest of us can't sprout wings whenever we - '
    There are ways of flying other than with broomsticks,' said Gabriela serenely.
    'I s'pose we're going to ride on the back of the Kacky Snorgle or whatever it is?' Diego demanded.
    The Crumple-Horned Snorkack can't fly,' said Gabriela in a dignified voice, 'but they can, and Villalba says they're very good at finding places their riders are looking for.'
    Roberto whirled round. Standing between two trees, their white eyes gleaming eerily, were two Thestrals, watching the whispered conversation as though they understood every word.
    'Yes!' he whispered, moving towards them. They tossed their reptilian heads, throwing back long black manes, and Roberto stretched out his hand eagerly and patted the nearest one's shining neck; how could he ever have thought them ugly?
    'Is it those mad horse things?' said Diego uncertainly, staring at a point slightly to the left of the Thestral Roberto was patting. 'Those ones you can't see unless you've watched someone snuff it?'
    'Yeah,' said Roberto.
    'How many?'
    'Just two.'
    'Well, we need three,' said Carolina, who was still looking a little shaken, but determined just the same.
    'Four, Carolina,' said Martina, scowling.
    'I think there are six of us, actually,' said Gabriela calmly, counting.
    'Don't be stupid, we can't all go!' said Roberto angrily. 'Look, you three - ' he pointed at Mauricio, Martina and Gabriela, 'you're not involved in this, you're not - '
    They burst into more protests. His scar gave another, more painful, twinge. Every moment they delayed was precious; he did not have time to argue.
    'OK, fine, it's your choice,' he said curtly, 'but unless we can find more Thestrals you're not going to be able - '
    'Oh, more of them will come,' said Martina confidently, who like Diego was squinting in quite the wrong direction, apparently under the impression that she was looking at the horses.
    'What makes you think that?'
    'Because, in case you hadn't noticed, you and Carolina are both covered in blood,' she said coolly, 'and we know Villalba lures Thestrals with raw meat. That's probably why these two turned up in the first place.'
    Roberto felt a soft tug on his robes at that moment and looked down to see the closest Thestral licking his sleeve, which was damp with Grawp's blood.
    'OK, then,' he said, a bright idea occurring, 'Diego and I will take these two and go ahead, and Carolina can stay here with you three and she'll attract more Thestrals - '
    'I'm not staying behind!' said Carolina furiously.
    There's no need,' said Gabriela, smiling. 'Look, here come more now . . . you two must really smell . . .'
    Roberto turned: no fewer than six or seven Thestrals were picking their way through the trees, their great leathery wings folded tight to their bodies, their eyes gleaming through the darkness. He had no excuse now.
    'All right,' he said angrily, 'pick one and get on, then.'
- CHAPTER THIRTY-FOUR -
The Department
Of Mysteries
Roberto wound his hand tightly into the mane of the nearest Thestral, placed a foot on a stump nearby and scrambled clumsily on to the horse's silken back. It did not object, but twisted its head around, fangs bared, and attempted to continue its eager licking of his robes.
    He found there was a way of lodging his knees behind the wing joints that made him feel more secure, then looked around at the others. Mauricio had heaved himself over the back of the next Thestral and was now attempting to swing one short leg over the creature's back. Gabriela was already in place, sitting side-saddle and adjusting her robes as though she did this every day. Diego, Carolina and Martina, however, were still standing motionless on the spot, open-mouthed and staring.
    'What?' he said.
    'How're we supposed to get on?' said Diego faintly. 'When we can't see the things?'
    'Oh, it's easy,' said Gabriela, sliding obligingly from her Thestral and marching over to him, Carolina and Martina. 'Come here . . .'
    She pulled them over to the other Thestrals standing around and one by one managed to help them on to the back of their mount. All three looked extremely nervous as she wound their hands into their horses mane and told them to grip tightly before she got back on to her own steed.
    This is mad,' Diego murmured, moving his free hand gingerly up and down his horses neck. 'Mad . . . if I could just see it - '
    'You'd better hope it stays invisible,' said Roberto darkly. 'We all ready, then?'
    They all nodded and he saw live pairs of knees tighten beneath their robes.
    'OK . . .'
    He looked down at the back of his Thestral's glossy black head and swallowed.
    'Ministry of Magic, visitors' entrance, London, then,' he said uncertainly. 'Er . . . if you know . . . where to go . . .'
    For a moment Roberto's Thestral did nothing at all; then, with a sweeping movement that nearly unseated him, the wings on either side extended; the horse crouched slowly, then rocketed upwards so fast and so steeply that Roberto had to clench his arms and legs tightly around the horse to avoid sliding backwards over its bony rump. He closed his eyes and pressed his face down into the horses silky mane as they burst through the topmost branches of the trees and soared out into a blood-red sunset.
    Roberto did not think he had ever moved so fast: the Thestral streaked over the castle, its wide wings hardly beating; the cooling air was slapping Roberto's face; eyes screwed up against the rushing wind, he looked round and saw his five fellows soaring along behind him, each of them bent as low as possible into the neck of their Thestral to protect themselves from his slipstream.
    They were over the Hogwarts grounds, they had passed Hogsmeade; Roberto could see mountains and gullies below them. As the daylight began to fail, Roberto saw small collections of lights as they passed over more villages, then a winding road on which a single car was beetling its way home through the hills . . .
    This is bizarre!' Roberto barely heard Diego yell from somewhere behind him, and he imagined how it must feel to be speeding along at this height with no visible means of support.
    Twilight fell: the sky was turning to a light, dusky purple littered with tiny silver stars, and soon only the lights of Muggle towns gave them any clue of how far from the ground they were, or how very fast they were travelling. Roberto's arms were wrapped tightly around his horse's neck as he willed it to go even faster. How much time had elapsed since he had seen Gustavo lying on the Department of Mysteries floor? How much longer would Gustavo be able to resist Salvador? All Roberto knew for sure was that his godfather had neither done as Salvador wanted, nor died, for he was convinced that either outcome would have caused him to feel Salvador's jubilation or fury course through his own body, making his scar sear as painfully as it had on the night Mr Lopez was attacked.
    On they flew through the gathering darkness; Roberto's face felt stiff and cold, his legs numb from gripping the Thestral's sides so tightly, but he did not dare shift his position lest he slip . . . he was deaf from the thundering rush of air in his ears, and his mouth was dry and frozen from the cold night wind. He had lost all sense of how far they had come; all his faith was in the beast beneath him, still streaking purposefully through the night, barely flapping its wings as it sped ever onwards.
    If they were too late . . .
    He's still alive, he's still fighting, I can feel it . . .
    If Salvador decided Gustavo was not going to crack . . .
    I'd know . . .
    Roberto's stomach gave a jolt; the Thestral's head was suddenly pointing towards the ground and he actually slid forwards a few inches along its neck. They were descending at last . . . he thought he heard a shriek behind him and twisted around dangerously, but could see no sign of a falling body . . . presumably they had all received a shock from the change of direction, just as he had.
    And now bright orange lights were growing larger and rounder on all sides; they could see the tops of buildings, streams of headlights like luminous insect eyes, squares of pale yellow that were windows. Quite suddenly, it seemed, they were hurtling towards the pavement; Roberto gripped the Thestral with every last ounce of his strength, braced for a sudden impact, but the horse touched the dark ground as lightly as a shadow and Roberto slid from its back, looking around at the street where the overflowing skip still stood a short way from the vandalised telephone box, both drained of colour in the flat orange glare of the streetlights.
    Diego landed a short way off and toppled immediately from his Thestral on to the pavement.
    'Never again,' he said, struggling to his feet. He made as though to stride away from his Thestral, but, unable to see it, collided with its hindquarters and almost tell over again. Never, ever again . . . that was the worst - '
    Carolina and Martina touched down on either side of him: both slid off their mounts a little more gracefully than Diego, though with similar expressions of relief at being back on firm ground; Mauricio jumped down, shaking; and Gabriela dismounted smoothly.
    'Where do we go from here, then?' she asked Roberto in a politely interested voice, as though this was all a rather interesting day-trip.
    'Over here,' he said. He gave his Thestral a quick, grateful pat, then led the way quickly to the battered telephone box and opened the door. 'Come on!' he urged the others, as they hesitated.
    Diego and Martina marched in obediently; Carolina, Mauricio and Gabriela squashed themselves in after them; Roberto took one glance back at the Thestrals, now foraging for scraps of rotten food inside the skip, then forced himself into the box after Gabriela.
    'Whoever's nearest the receiver, dial six two four four two!' he said.
    Diego did it, his arm bent bizarrely to reach the dial; as it whirred back into place the cool female voice sounded inside the box.
    'Welcome to the Ministry of Magic. Please state your name and business.'
    'Roberto Gonzales, Diego Lopez, Carolina Fernandez,' Roberto said very quickly, 'Martina Lopez, Mauricio Silva, Gabriela Ortiz . . . we're here to save someone, unless your Ministry can do it first!'
    Thank you,' said the cool female voice. 'Visitors, please take the badges and attach them to the front of your robes.'
    Half a dozen badges slid out of the metal chute where returned coins normally appeared. Carolina scooped them up and handed them mutely to Roberto over Martina's head; he glanced at the topmost one, Roberto Gonzales, Rescue Mission.
    'Visitors to the Ministry, you are required to submit to a search and present your wands for registration at the security desk, which is located at the far end of the Atrium.'
    'Fine!' Roberto said loudly, as his scar gave another throb. 'Now can we move?'
    The floor of the telephone box shuddered and the pavement rose up past its glass windows; the scavenging Thestrals were sliding out of sight; blackness closed over their heads and with a dull grinding noise they sank down into the depths of the Ministry of Magic.
    A chink of soft golden light hit their feet and, widening, rose up their bodies. Roberto bent his knees and held his wand as ready as he could in such cramped conditions as he peered through the glass to see whether anybody was waiting for them in the Atrium, but it seemed, to be completely empty. The light was dimmer than it had been by day; there were no fires burning under the mantelpieces set into the walls, but as the lift slid smoothly to a halt he saw that golden symbols continued to twist sinuously in the dark blue ceiling.
    The Ministry of Magic wishes you a pleasant evening,' said the woman's voice.
    The door of the telephone box burst open; Roberto toppled out of it, closely followed by Mauricio and Gabriela. The only sound in the Atrium was the steady rush of water from the golden fountain, where jets from the wands of the witch and wizard, the point of the centaur's arrow, the tip of the goblin's hat and the house-elf's ears continued to gush into the surrounding pool.
    'Come on, said Roberto quietly and the six of them sprinted off down the hall, Roberto in the lead, past the fountain towards the desk where the watchwizard who had weighed Roberto's wand had sat, and which was now deserted.
    Roberto felt sure there ought to be a security person there, sure their absence was an ominous sign, and his feeling of foreboding increased as they passed through the golden gates to the lifts. He pressed the nearest 'down' button and a lift clattered into sight almost immediately, the golden grilles slid apart with a great, echoing clanking and they dashed inside. Roberto stabbed the number nine button; the grilles closed with a bang and the lift began to descend, jangling and rattling. Roberto had not realised how noisy the lifts were on the day he had come with Mr Lopez; he was sure the din would raise every security person within the building, yet when the lilt halted, the cool female voice said, 'Department of Mysteries,' and the grilles slid open. They stepped out into the corridor where nothing was moving out but the nearest torches, flickering in the rush of air from the lift.
    Roberto turned towards the plain black door. After months and months of dreaming about it, he was here at last.
    'Let's go,' he whispered, and he led the way down the corridor, Gabriela right behind him, gazing around with her mouth slightly open.
    'OK, listen,' said Roberto, stopping again within six feet of the door. 'Maybe . . . maybe a couple of people should stay here as a - as a lookout, and - '
    'And how're we going to let you know something's coming?' asked Martina, her eyebrows raised. 'You could be miles away.'
    'We're coming with you, Roberto,' said Mauricio.
    'Let's get on with it,' said Diego firmly.
    Roberto still did not want to take them all with him, but it seemed he had no choice. He turned to face the door and walked forwards . . . just as it had in his dream, it swung open and he marched over the threshold, the others at his heels.
    They were standing in a large, circular room. Everything in here was black including the floor and ceiling; identical, unmarked, handleless black doors were set at intervals all around the black walls, interspersed with branches of candles whose flames burned blue; their cool, shimmering light reflected in the shining marble floor made it look as though there was dark water underfoot.
    'Someone shut the door,' Roberto muttered.
    He regretted giving this order the moment Mauricio had obeyed it. Without the long chink of light from the torchlit corridor behind them, the place became so dark that for a moment the only things they could see were the bunches of shivering blue flames on the walls and their ghostly reflections in the floor.
    In his dream, Roberto had always walked purposefully across this room to the door immediately opposite the entrance and walked on. But there were around a dozen doors here. Just as he was gazing ahead at the doors opposite him, trying to decide which was the right one, there was a great rumbling noise and the candles began to move sideways. The circular wall was rotating.
    Carolina grabbed Roberto's arm as though frightened the floor might move, too, but it did not. For a few seconds, the blue flames around them were blurred to resemble neon lines as the wall sped around; then, quite as suddenly as it had started, the rumbling stopped and everything became stationary once again.
    Roberto's eyes had blue streaks burned into them; it was all he could see.
    'What was that about?' whispered Diego fearfully.
    'I think it was to stop us knowing which door we came in through,' said Martina in a hushed voice.
    Roberto realised at once she was right: he could no sooner identify the exit door than locate an ant on the jet-black floor; and the door through which they needed to proceed could be any one of the dozen surrounding them.
    'How're we going to get back out?' said Mauricio uncomfortably.
    'Well, that doesn't matter now,' said Roberto forcefully, blinking to try to erase the blue lines from his vision, and clutching his wand tighter than ever, 'we won't need to get out till we've found Gustavo - '
    'Don't go calling for him, though!' Carolina said urgently; but Roberto had never needed her advice less, his instinct was to keep as quiet as possible.
    'Where do we go, then, Roberto?' Diego asked.
    'I don't - ' Roberto began. He swallowed. 'In the dreams I went through the door at the end of the corridor from the lifts into a dark room - that's this one - and then I went through another door into a room that kind of . . . glitters. We should try a few doors,' he said hastily, 'I'll know the right way when I see it. C'mon.'
    He marched straight at the door now facing him, the others following close behind him, set his left hand against its cool, shining surface, raised his wand ready to strike the moment it opened, and pushed.
    It swung open easily.
    After the darkness of the first room, the lamps hanging low on golden chains from this ceiling gave the impression that this long rectangular room was much brighter, though there were no glittering, shimmering lights as Roberto had seen in his dreams. The place was quite empty except for a few desks and, in the very middle of the room, an enormous glass tank of deep green liquid, big enough for all of them to swim in; a number of pearly-white objects were drifting around lazily in it.
    'What're those things?' whispered Diego.
    'Dunno,' said Roberto.
    'Are they fish?' breathed Martina.
    'Aquavirius Maggots!' said Gabriela excitedly. 'Dad said the Ministry were breeding - '
    'No,' said Carolina. She sounded odd. She moved forward to look through the side of the tank. They're brains.'
    'Brains?'
    'Yes . . . I wonder what they're doing with them?'
    Roberto joined her at the tank. Sure enough, there could be no mistake now he saw them at close quarters. Glimmering eerily, they drifted in and out of sight in the depths of the green liquid, looking something like slimy cauliflowers.
    'Let's get out of here,' said Roberto. This isn't right, we need to try another door.'
    There are doors here, too,' said Diego, pointing around the walls. Roberto's heart sank; how big was this place?
    'In my dream I went through that dark room into the second one,' he said. 'I think we should go back and try from there.'
    So they hurried back into the dark, circular room; the ghostly shapes of the brains were now swimming before Roberto's eyes instead of the blue candle flames.
    'Wait!' said Carolina sharply, as Gabriela made to close the door of the brain room behind them. 'Flagrate!'
    She drew with her wand in midair and a fiery 'X' appeared on the door. No sooner had the door clicked shut behind them than there was a great rumbling, and once again the wall began to revolve very fast, but now there was a great red-gold blur in amongst the faint blue and, when all became still again, the fiery cross still burned, showing the door they had already tried.
    'Good thinking,' said Roberto. 'OK, let's try this one - '
    Again, he strode directly at the door facing him and pushed it open, his wand still raised, the others at his heels.
    This room was larger than the last, dimly lit and rectangular, and the centre of it was sunken, forming a great stone pit some twenty feet deep. They were standing on the topmost tier of what seemed to be stone benches running all around the room and descending in steep steps like an amphitheatre, or the courtroom in which Roberto had been tried by the Wizengamot. Instead, of a chained chair, however, there was a raised stone dais in the centre of the pit, on which stood a stone archway that looked so ancient, cracked and crumbling that Roberto was amazed the thing was still standing. Unsupported by any surrounding wall, the archway was hung with a tattered black curtain or veil which, despite the complete stillness of the cold surrounding air, was fluttering very slightly as though it had just been touched.
    'Who's there?' said Roberto, jumping down on to the bench below. There was no answering voice, but the veil continued to flutter and sway.
    'Careful!' whispered Carolina.
    Roberto scrambled down the benches one by one until he reached the stone bottom of the sunken pit. His footsteps echoed loudly as he walked slowly towards the dais. The pointed archway looked much taller from where he now stood than it had when he'd been looking down on it from above. Still the veil swayed gently, as though somebody had just passed through it.
    'Gustavo?' Roberto spoke again, but more quietly now that he was nearer.
    He had the strangest feeling that there was someone standing right behind the veil on the other side of the archway. Gripping his wand very tightly, he edged around the dais, but there was nobody there; all that could be seen was the other side of the tattered black veil.
    'Let's go,' called Carolina from halfway up the stone steps. This isn't right, Roberto, come on, let's go.'
    She sounded scared, much more scared than she had in the room where the brains swam, yet Roberto thought the archway had a kind of beauty about it, old though it was. The gently rippling veil intrigued him; he felt a very strong inclination to climb up on the dais and walk through it.
    Marry, lets go, OK? Said Carolina more forcefully.
    'OK,' he said, but did not move. He had just heard something. There were faint whispering, murmuring noises coming from the other side of the veil.
    'What are you saying?' he said, very loudly, so that his words echoed all around the stone benches.
    'Nobody's talking, Roberto!' said Carolina, now moving over to him.
    'Someone's whispering behind there,' he said, moving out of her reach and continuing to frown at the veil. 'Is that you, Diego?'
    'I'm here, mate,' said Diego, appearing around the side of the archway.
    'Can't anyone else hear it?' Roberto demanded, for the whispering and murmuring was becoming louder; without really meaning to put it there, he found his foot was on the dais.
    'I can hear them too,' breathed Gabriela, joining them around the side of the archway and gazing at the swaying veil. 'There are people in there!'
    'What do you mean, "in there"?' demanded Carolina, jumping down from the bottom step and sounding much angrier than the occasion warranted, 'there isn't any "in there", it's just an archway, there's no room for anybody to be there. Roberto, stop it, come away - '
    She grabbed his arm and pulled, but he resisted.
    'Roberto, we are supposed to be here for Gustavo!' she said in a high-pitched, strained voice.
    'Gustavo,' Roberto repeated, still gazing, mesmerised, at the continuously swaying veil. 'Yeah . . .'
    Something finally slid back into place in his brain; Gustavo, captured, bound and tortured, and he was staring at this archway . . .
    He took several paces back from the dais and wrenched his eyes from the veil.
    'Let's go,' he said.
    That's what I've been trying to - well, come on, then!' said Carolina, and she led the way back around the dais. On the other side, Martina and Mauricio were staring, apparently entranced, at the veil too. Without speaking, Carolina took hold of Martina's arm,
    Diego grabbed Mauricio's, and they marched them firmly back to the lowest stone bench and clambered all the way back up to the door.
    'What d'you reckon that arch was?' Roberto asked Carolina as they regained the dark circular room.
    'I don't know, but whatever it was, it was dangerous,' she said firmly, again inscribing a fiery cross on the door.
    Once more, the wall span and became still again. Roberto approached another door at random and pushed. It did not move.
    'What's wrong?' said Carolina.
    'It's . . . locked . . .' said Roberto, throwing his weight at the door, but it didn't budge.
    This is it, then, isn't it?' said Diego excitedly, joining Roberto in the attempt to force the door open. 'Bound to be!'
    'Get out of the way!' said Carolina sharply. She pointed her wand at the place where a lock would have been on an ordinary door and said, 'Alohomora!'
    Nothing happened.
    'Gustavo's knife!' said Roberto. He pulled it out from inside his robes and slid it into the crack between the door and the wall. The others all watched eagerly as he ran it from top to bottom, withdrew it and then flung his shoulder again at the door. It remained as firmly shut as ever. What was more, when Roberto looked down at the knife, he saw the blade had melted.
    'Right, we're leaving that room,' said Carolina decisively.
    'But what if that's the one?' said Diego, staring at it with a mixture of apprehension and longing.
    'It can't be, Roberto could get through all the doors in his dream,' said Carolina, marking the door with another fiery cross as Roberto replaced the now-useless handle of Gustavo's knife in his pocket.
    'You know what could be in there?' said Gabriela eagerly, as the wall started to spin yet again.
    'Something blibbering, no doubt,' said Carolina under her breath and Mauricio gave a nervous little laugh.
    The wall slid to a halt and Roberto, with a feeling of increasing desperation, pushed the next door open.
    This is it!'
    He knew it at once by the beautiful, dancing, diamond-sparkling light. As Roberto's eyes became accustomed to the brilliant glare, he saw clocks gleaming from every surface, large and small, grandfather and carriage, hanging in spaces between the bookcases or standing on desks ranging the length of the room, so that a busy, relentless ticking filled the place like thousands of minuscule, marching footsteps. The source of the dancing, diamond-bright light was a towering crystal bell jar that stood at the far end of the room.
    'This way!'
    Roberto's heart was pumping frantically now that he knew they were on the right track; he led the way down the narrow space between the lines of desks, heading, as he had done in his dream, for the source of the light, the crystal bell jar quite as tall as he was that stood on a desk and appeared to be full of a billowing, glittering wind.
    'Oh, took!' said Martina, as they drew nearer, pointing at the very heart of the bell jar.
    Drifting along in the sparkling current inside was a tiny, jewel-bright egg. As it rose in the jar, it cracked open and a hummingbird emerged, which was carried to the very top of the jar, but as it fell on the draught its feathers became bedraggled and damp again, and by the time it had been borne back to the bottom of the jar it had been enclosed once more in its egg.
    'Keep going!' said Roberto sharply, because Martina showed signs of wanting to stop and watch the egg's progress back into a bird.
    'You dawdled enough by that old arch!' she said crossly, but followed him past the bell jar to the only door behind it.
    This is it,' Roberto said again, and his heart was now pumping so hard and fast he felt it must interfere with his speech, 'it's through here - '
    He glanced around at them all; they had their wands out and looked suddenly serious and anxious. He looked back at the door and pushed. It swung open.
    They were there, they had found the place: high as a church and full of nothing but towering shelves covered in small, dusty glass orbs. They glimmered dully in the light issuing from more candle-brackets set at intervals along the shelves. Like those in the circular room behind them, their flames were burning blue. The room was very cold.
    Roberto edged forward and peered down one of the shadowy aisles between two rows of shelves. He could not hear anything or see the slightest sign of movement.
    'You said it was row ninety-seven,' whispered Carolina.
    'Yeah,' breathed Roberto, looking up at the end of the closest row. Beneath the branch of blue-glowing candles protruding from it glimmered the silver figure fifty-three.
    'We need to go right, I think,' whispered Carolina, squinting to the next row. 'Yes . . . that's fifty-four . . . '
    'Keep your wands ready,' Roberto said softly.
    They crept forward, glancing behind them as they went on down the long alleys of shelves, the further ends of which were in near-total darkness. Tiny, yellowing labels had been stuck beneath each glass orb on the shelves. Some of them had a weird, liquid glow; others were as dull and dark within as blown light bulbs.
    They passed row eighty-four . . . eighty-five . . . Roberto was listening hard for the slightest sound of movement, but Gustavo might be gagged now, or else unconscious . . . or, said an unbidden voice inside his head, he might already be dead . . .
    I'd have felt it, he told himself, his heart now hammering against his Adam's apple, I'd already know . . .
    'Ninety-seven!' whispered Carolina.
    They stood grouped around the end of the row, gazing down the alley beside it. There was nobody there.
    'He's right down at the end,' said Roberto, whose mouth had become slightly dry. 'You can't see properly from here.'
    And he led them between the towering rows of glass balls, some of which glowed softly as they passed . . .
    'He should be near here,' whispered Roberto, convinced that every step was going to bring the ragged form of Gustavo into view on the darkened floor. 'Anywhere here . . . really close . . .'
    'Roberto?' said Carolina tentatively, but he did not want to respond. His mouth was very dry.
    'Somewhere about . . . here . . .' he said.
    They had reached the end of the row and emerged into more dim candlelight, There was nobody there. All was echoing, dusty silence.
    'He might be . . .' Roberto whispered hoarsely, peering down the next alley. 'Or maybe . . .' He hurried to look down the one beyond that.
    'Roberto?' said Carolina again.
    'What?' he snarled.
    'I . . . I don't think Gustavo is here.'
    Nobody spoke. Roberto did not want to look at any of them. He felt sick. He did not understand why Gustavo was not here. He had to be here. This was where he, Roberto, had seen him . . .
    He ran up the space at the end of the rows, staring down them. Empty aisle after empty aisle flickered past. He ran the other way, back past his staring companions. There was no sign of Gustavo anywhere, nor any hint of a struggle.
    'Roberto?' Diego called.
    'What?'
    He did not want to hear what Diego had to say; did not want to hear Diego tell him he had been stupid or suggest that they ought to go back to Hogwarts, but the heat was rising in his face and h; felt as though he would like to skulk down here in the darkness for a long while before facing the brightness of the Atrium above and the others' accusing stares . . .
    'Have you seen this?' said Diego.
