    'What?' said Roberto, but eagerly this time - it had to be a sign that Gustavo had been there, a clue. He strode back to where they were all standing, a little way down row ninety-seven, but found nothing except Diego staring at one of the dusty glass spheres on the shelf.
    'What?' Roberto repeated glumly.
    'It's - it's got your name on,' said Diego.
    Roberto moved a little closer. Diego was pointing at one of the small glass spheres that glowed with a dull inner light, though it was very dusty and appeared not to have been touched for many years.
    'My name?' said Roberto blankly.
    He stepped forwards. Not as tall as Diego, he had to crane his neck to read the yellowish label affixed to the shelf right beneath
    the dusty glass ball. In spidery writing was written a date of some sixteen years previously, and below that:
S.P.T. to A.P.W.B.D.
Dark Lord
and (?)Roberto Gonzales
Roberto stared at it.
    'What is it?' Diego asked, sounding unnerved. 'What's your name doing down here?'
    He glanced along at the other labels on that stretch of shelf.
    'I'm not here,' he said, sounding perplexed. 'None of the rest of us are here.'
    'Roberto, I don't think you should touch it,' said Carolina sharply, as he stretched out his hand.
    'Why not?' he said. 'It's something to do with me, isn't it?'
    'Don't, Roberto,' said Mauricio suddenly. Roberto looked at him. Mauricio's round face was shining slightly with sweat. He looked as though he could not take much more suspense.
    'It's got my name on,' said Roberto.
    And feeling slightly reckless, he closed his fingers around the dusty ball's surface. He had expected it to feel cold, but it did not. On the contrary, it felt as though it had been lying in the sun for hours, as though the glow of light within was warming it. Expecting, even hoping, that something dramatic was going to happen, something exciting that might make their long and dangerous journey worth while after all, Roberto lifted the glass ball down from its shelf and stared at it.
    Nothing whatsoever happened. The others moved in closer around Roberto, gazing at the orb as he brushed it free of the clogging dust.
    And then, from right behind them, a drawling voice spoke.
    'Very good, Gonzales. Now turn around, nice and slowly, and give that to me.'
- CHAPTER THIRTY-FIVE -
Beyond the Veil
Martinez shapes were emerging out of thin air all around them, blocking their way left and right; eyes glinted through slits in hoods, a dozen lit wand tips were pointing directly at their hearts; Martina gave a gasp of horror.
    'To me, Gonzales,' repeated the drawling voice of Mariano Sosa as he held out his hand, palm up.
    Roberto's insides plummeted sickeningly. They were trapped, and outnumbered two to one.
    'To me,' said Sosa yet again.
    'Where's Gustavo?' Roberto said.
    Several of the Death Eaters laughed; a harsh female voice from the midst of the shadowy figures to Roberto's left said triumphantly, The Dark Lord always knows!'
    'Always,' echoed Sosa softly. 'Now, give me the prophecy, Gonzales.'
    'I want to know where Gustavo is!'
    'I want to know where Gustavo is!' mimicked the woman to his left.
    She and her fellow Death Eaters had closed in so that they were mere feet away from Roberto and the others, the light from their wands dazzling Roberto's eyes.
    'You've got him,' said Roberto, ignoring the rising panic in his chest, the dread he had been fighting since they had first entered the ninety-seventh row. 'He's here. I know he is.'
    'The little baby woke up fwightened and fort what it dweamed was twoo,' said the woman in a horrible, mock baby voice. Roberto felt Diego stir beside him.
    'Don't do anything,' Roberto muttered. 'Not yet - '
    The woman who had mimicked him let out a raucous scream of laughter.
    'You hear him? You hear him? Giving instructions to the other children as though he thinks of fighting us!'
    'Oh, you don't know Gonzales as I do, Miranda,' said Sosa softly. 'He has a great weakness for heroics; the Dark Lord understands this about him. Now give me the prophecy, Gonzales.'
    'I know Gustavo is here,' said Roberto, though panic was causing his chest to constrict and he felt as though he could not breathe properly. 'I know you've got him!'
    More of the Death Eaters laughed, though the woman laughed loudest of all.
    'It's time you learned the difference between life and dreams, Gonzales,' said Sosa. 'Now give me the prophecy, or we start using wands.'
    'Go on, then,' said Roberto, raising his own wand to chest height. As he did so, the five wands of Diego, Carolina, Mauricio, Martina and Gabriela rose on either side of him. The knot in Roberto's stomach tightened. If Gustavo really was not here, he had led his friends to their deaths for no reason at all . . .
    But the Death Eaters did not strike.
    'Hand over the prophecy and no one need get hurt,' said Sosa coolly.
    It was Roberto's turn to laugh.
    'Yeah, right!' he said. 'I give you this - prophecy, is it? And you'll just let us skip off home, will you?'
    The words were hardly out of his mouth when the female Death Eater shrieked: 'Accio proph-
    Roberto was just ready for her: he shouted 'Protego' before she had finished her spell, and though the glass sphere slipped to the tips of his fingers he managed to cling on to it.
    'Oh, he knows how to play, little bitty baby Gonzales,' she said, her mad eyes staring through the slits in her hood. 'Very well, then - '
    'I TOLD YOU, NO!' Mariano Sosa roared at the woman. 'If you smash it - !'
    Roberto's mind was racing. The Death Eaters wanted this dusty spun-glass sphere. He had no interest in it. He just wanted to get them all out of this alive, to make sure none of his friends paid a terrible price for his stupidity . . .
    The woman stepped forward, away from her fellows, and pulled off her hood. Azkaban had hollowed Miranda Gimenez's face, making it gaunt and skull-like, but it was alive with a feverish, fanatical glow.
    'You need more persuasion?' she said, her chest rising and falling rapidly. 'Very well - take the smallest one,' she ordered the Death Eaters beside her. 'Let him watch while we torture the little girl. I'll do it.'
    Roberto felt the others close in around Martina; he stepped sideways so that he was right in front of her, the prophecy held up to his chest.
    'You'll have to smash this if you want to attack any of us,' he told Miranda. 'I don't think your boss will be too pleased if you come back without it, will he?'
    She did not move; she merely stared at him, the tip of her tongue moistening her thin mouth.
    'So,' said Roberto, 'what kind of prophecy are we talking about, anyway?'
    He could not think what to do but to keep talking. Mauricio's arm was pressed against his, and he could feel him shaking; he could feel one of the others' quickened breath on the back of his head. He was hoping they were all thinking hard about ways to get out of this, because his mind was blank.
    'What kind of prophecy?' repeated Miranda, the grin fading from her face. 'You jest, Roberto Gonzales.'
    'Nope, not jesting,' said Roberto, his eyes flicking from Death Eater to Death Eater, looking for a weak link, a space through which they could escape. 'How come Salvador wants it?
    Several of the Death Eaters let out low hisses.
    'You dare speak his name?' whispered Miranda.
    'Yeah,' said Roberto, maintaining his tight grip on the glass ball, expecting another attempt to bewitch it from him. 'Yeah, I've got no problem with saying Vol-
    'Shut your mouth!' Miranda shrieked. 'You dare speak his name with your unworthy lips, you dare besmirch it with your half-blood's tongue, you dare - '
    'Did you know he's a half-blood too?' said Roberto recklessly. Carolina gave a little moan in his ear. 'Salvador? Yeah, his mother was a witch but his dad was a Muggle - or has he been telling you lot he's pure-blood?'
    'STUPEF-'
    'NO!'
    A jet of red light had shot from the end of Miranda Gimenez's wand, but Sosa had deflected it; his spell caused hers to hit the shelf a foot to the left of Roberto and several of the glass orbs there shattered.
    Two figures, pearly-white as ghosts, fluid as smoke, unfurled themselves from the fragments of broken glass upon the floor and each began to speak; their voices vied with each other, so that only fragments of what they were saying could be heard over Sosa and Miranda's shouts.
    '. . . at the solstice will come a new . . .' said the figure of an old, bearded man.
    'DO NOT ATTACK! WE NEED THE PROPHECY!'
    'He dared - he dares - ' shrieked Miranda incoherently, 'he stands there - filthy half-blood - '
    'WAIT UN'I'LL WE'VE GOT THE PROPHECY!' bawled Sosa.
    '. . . and none will come after . . .' said the figure of a young woman.
    The two figures that had burst from the shattered spheres had melted into thin air. Nothing remained of them or their erstwhile homes but fragments of glass upon the floor. They had, however, given Roberto an idea. The problem was going to be conveying it to the others.
    'You haven't told me what's so special about this prophecy I'm supposed to be handing over,' he said, playing for time. He moved his foot slowly sideways, feeling around for someone else's.
    'Do not play games with us, Gonzales,' said Sosa.
    'I'm not playing games,' said Roberto, half his mind on the conversation, half on his wandering foot. And then he found someone's toes and pressed down upon them. A sharp intake of breath behind him told him they were Carolina's.
    'What?' she whispered.
    'Dominguez never told you the reason you bear that scar was hidden in the bowels of the Department of Mysteries?' Sosa sneered.
    'I - what?' said Roberto. And for a moment he quite forgot his plan. 'What about my scar?'
    'What?' whispered Carolina more urgently behind him.
    'Can this be?' said Sosa, sounding maliciously delighted; some of the Death Eaters were laughing again, and under cover of their laughter, Roberto hissed to Carolina, moving his lips as little as possible, 'Smash shelves - '
    'Dominguez never told you?' Sosa repeated. 'Well, this explains why you didn't come earlier, Gonzales, the Dark Lord wondered why - '
    ' - when I say now - '
    ' - you didn't come running when he showed you the place where it was hidden in your dreams. He thought natural curiosity would make you want to hear the exact wording . . .'
    'Did he?' said Roberto. Behind him he felt rather than heard Carolina passing his message to the others and he sought to keep talking, to distract the Death Eaters. 'So he wanted me to come and get it, did he? Why?'
    'Why?' Sosa sounded incredulously delighted. 'Because the only people who are permitted to retrieve a prophecy from the Department of Mysteries, Gonzales, are those about whom it was made, as the Dark Lord discovered when he attempted to use others .o steal it for him.'
    'And why did he want to steal a prophecy about me?'
    'About both of you, Gonzales, about both of you . . . haven't you ever wondered why the Dark Lord tried to kill you as a baby?'
    Roberto stared into the slitted eye-holes through which Sosa's grey eyes were gleaming. Was this prophecy the reason Roberto's parents had died, the reason he carried his lightning-bolt scar? Was the answer to all of this clutched in his hand?
    'Someone made a prophecy about Salvador and me?' he said quietly, gazing at Mariano Sosa, his fingers tightening over the warm glass sphere in his hand. It was hardly larger than a Snitch and still gritty with dust. 'And he's made me come and get it for him? Why couldn't he come and get it himself?'
    'Get it himself?' shrieked Miranda, over a cackle of mad laughter.
    The Dark Lord, walk into the Ministry of Magic, when they are so sweetly ignoring his return? The Dark Lord, reveal himself to the Aurors, when at the moment they are wasting their time on my dear cousin?'
    'So, he's got you doing his dirty work for him, has he?' said Roberto. 'Like he tried to get Sturgis to steal it - and Bode?'
    'Very good, Gonzales, very good . . .' said Sosa slowly. 'But the Dark Lord knows you are not unintell-
    'NOW!' yelled Roberto.
    Five different voices behind him bellowed, 'REDUCTO!' Five curses flew in five different directions and the shelves opposite them exploded as they hit; the towering structure swayed as a hundred glass spheres burst apart, pearly-white figures unfurled into the air and floated there, their voices echoing from who knew what long-dead past amid the torrent of crashing glass and splintered wood now raining down upon the floor - '
    'RUN!' Roberto yelled, as the shelves swayed precariously and more glass spheres began to fall from above. He seized a handful of Carolina's robes and dragged her forwards, holding one arm over his head as chunks of shelf and shards of glass thundered down upon them. A Death Eater lunged forwards through the cloud of dust and Roberto elbowed him hard in the masked face; they were all yelling, there were cries of pain, and thunderous crashes as the shelves collapsed upon themselves, weirdly echoing fragments of the Seers unleashed from their spheres - '
    Roberto found the way ahead clear and saw Diego, Martina and Gabriela sprint past him, their arms over their heads; something heavy struck him on the side of the face but he merely ducked his head and sprinted onwards; a hand caught him by the shoulder; he: heard Carolina shout, 'Stupefy!' The hand released him at once - '
    They were at the end of row ninety-seven; Roberto turned right and began to sprint in earnest; he could hear footsteps right behind him and Carolina's voice urging Mauricio on; straight ahead, the door through which they had come was ajar; Roberto could see the glittering light of the bell jar; he pelted through the doorway, the prophecy still clutched tight and safe in his hand, and waited for the others to hurtle over the threshold before slamming the door behind them - '
    'Colloportus!' gasped Carolina and the door sealed itself with an odd squelching noise.
    'Where - where are the others?' gasped Roberto.
    He had thought Diego, Gabriela and Martina were ahead of them, that they would be waiting in this room, but there was nobody there.
    'They must have gone the wrong way!' whispered Carolina, terror in her face.
    'Listen!' whispered Mauricio.
    Footsteps and shouts echoed from behind the door they had just sealed; Roberto put his ear close to the door to listen and heard Mariano Sosa roar, 'Leave Nott, leave him, I say - his injuries will be nothing to the Dark Lord compared to losing that prophecy. Jugson, come back here, we need to organise! We'll split into pairs and search, and don't forget, be gentle with Gonzales until we've got the prophecy, you can kill the others if necessary - 'Miranda, Rodolphus, you take the left; Crabbe, Rabastan, go right - 'Jugson, Dolohov, the door straight ahead - Macnair and Avery, through here - Rookwood, over there - Mulciber, come with me!'
    'What do we do?' Carolina asked Roberto, trembling from head to foot.
    'Well, we don't stand here waiting for them to find us, for a start,' said Roberto. 'Let's get away from this door.'
    They ran as quietly as they could, past the shimmering bell jar where the tiny egg was hatching and unhatching, towards the exit into the circular hallway at the far end of the room. They were almost there when Roberto heard something large and heavy collide with the door Carolina had charmed shut.
    'Stand aside!' said a rough voice. 'Alohomora!'
    As the door flew open, Roberto, Carolina and Mauricio dived under desks. They could see the bottom of the two Death Eaters' robes drawing nearer, their feet moving rapidly.
    They might've run straight through to the hall,' said the rough voice.
    'Check under the desks,' said another.
    Roberto saw the knees of the Death Eaters bend; poking his wand out from under the desk, he shouted, 'STUPEFY!'
    A jet of red light hit the nearest Death Eater; he fell backwards into a grandfather clock and knocked it over; the second Death Eater, however, had leapt aside to avoid Roberto's spell and was pointing his own wand at Carolina, who was crawling out from under the desk to get a better aim.
    'Avada -'
    Roberto launched himself across the floor and grabbed the Death Eater around the knees, causing him to topple and his aim to go awry. Mauricio overturned a desk in his anxiety to help; and pointing his wand wildly at the struggling pair, he cried:
    'EXPELLIARMUS!'
    Both Roberto's and the Death Eater's wands flew out of their hands and soared back towards the entrance to the Hall of Prophecy; both scrambled to their feet and charged after them, the Death Eater in front, Roberto hot on his heels, and Mauricio bringing up the rear, plainly horrorstruck by what he had done.
    'Get out of the way, Roberto!' yelled Mauricio, clearly determined to repair the damage.
    Roberto flung himself sideways as Mauricio took aim again and shouted:
    'STUPEFY!'
    The jet of red light flew right over the Death Eaters shoulder and hit a glass-fronted cabinet on the wall full of variously shaped hour-glasses; the cabinet fell to the floor and burst apart, glass flying everywhere, sprang back up on to the wall, fully mended, then fell down again, and shattered - '
    The Death Eater had snatched up his wand, which lay on the floor beside the glittering bell jar. Roberto ducked down behind another desk as the man turned; his mask had slipped so that he couldn't see. He ripped it off with his free hand and shouted: 'STUP-'
    'STUPEFY!' screamed Carolina, who had just caught up with them. The jet of red light hit the Death Eater in the middle of his chest: he froze, his arm still raised, his wand fell to the floor with a flatter and he collapsed backwards towards the bell jar. Roberto expected to hear a clunk, for the man to hit solid glass and slide off the jar on to the floor, but instead, his head sank through the surface of the bell jar as though it were nothing but a soap bubble and he came to rest, sprawled on his back on the table, with his head lying inside the jar full of glittering wind.
    'Accio wand!' cried Carolina. Roberto's wand flew from a dark corner into her hand and she threw it to him.
    'Thanks,' he said. 'Right, let's get out of - '
    'Look out!' said Mauricio, horrified. He was staring at the Deati Eater's head in the bell jar.
    All three of them raised their wands again, but none of them struck: they were all gazing, open-mouthed, appalled, at what was happening to the man's head.
    It was shrinking very fast, growing balder and balder, the black hair and stubble retracting into his skull; his cheeks becoming smooth, his skull round and covered with a peachlike fuzz . . .
    A baby's head now sat grotesquely on top of the thick, muscled neck of the Death Eater as he struggled to get up again; but even as they watched, their mouths open, the head began to swell to its previous proportions again; thick black hair was sprouting frori the pate and chin . . .
    'It's Time,' said Carolina in an awestruck voice. Time . . .'
    The Death Eater shook his ugly head again, trying to clear it, but before he could pull himself together it began to shrink back to babyhood once more . . .
    There was a shout from a room nearby, then a crash and a scream.
    'DIEGO?' Roberto yelled, turning quickly from the monstrous transformation taking place before them. 'MARTINA? GABRIELA?'
    'Roberto!' Carolina screamed.
    The Death Eater had pulled his head out of the bell jar. His appearance was utterly bizarre, his tiny baby's head bawling loudly while his thick arms flailed dangerously in all directions, narrowly missing Roberto, who had ducked. Roberto raised his wand but to his amazement Carolina seized his arm.
    'You can't hurt a baby!'
    There was no time to argue the point; Roberto could hear more footsteps growing louder from the Hall of Prophecy and knew, too late, that he ought not to have shouted and given away their position.
    'Come on!' he said, and leaving the ugly baby-headed Death Eater staggering behind them they took off for the door that stood open at the other end of the room, leading back into the black hallway.
    They had run halfway towards it when Roberto saw through the open door two more Death Eaters running across the black room towards them; veering left, he burst instead into a small, dark, cluttered office and slammed the door behind them.
    'Collo - ' began Carolina, but before she could complete the spell the door had burst open and the two Death Eaters had come hurtling inside.
    With a cry of triumph, both yelled:
    'IMPEDIMENTA.'
    Roberto, Carolina and Mauricio were all knocked backwards off their feet; Mauricio was thrown over the desk and disappeared from view; Carolina smashed into a bookcase and was promptly deluged in a cascade of heavy books; the back of Roberto's head slammed into the stone wall behind him, tiny lights burst in front of his eyes and for a moment he was too dizzy and bewildered to react.
    'WE'VE GOT HIM!' yelled the Death Eater nearest Roberto. 'IN AN OFFICE OFF -'
    'Silencio!' cried Carolina and the man's voice was extinguished. He continued to mouth through the hole in his mask, but no sound came out. He was thrust aside by his fellow Death Eater.
    'Petrificus Totalus!' shouted Roberto, as the second Death Eater raised his wand. His arms and legs snapped together and he fell forwards, face down on to the rug at Roberto's feet, stiff as a board and unable to move.
    'Well done, Ha-'
    But the Death Eater Carolina had just struck dumb made a sudden slashing movement with his wand; a streak of what looked like purple flame passed right across Carolina's chest. She gave a tiny 'Oh!' as though of surprise and crumpled on to the floor, where she lay motionless.
    'CAROLINA!'
    Roberto fell to his knees beside her as Mauricio crawled rapidly towards her from under the desk, his wand held up in front of him. The Death Eater kicked out hard at Mauricio's head as he emerged - his foot broke Mauricio's wand in two and connected with his face. Mauricio gave a howl of pain and recoiled, clutching his mouth and nose. Roberto twisted around, his own wand held high, and saw that the Death Eater had ripped off his mask and was pointing his wand directly at Roberto, who recognised the long, pale, twisted face from the Daily Prophet: Antonin Dolohov, the wizard who had murdered the Prewetts.
    Dolohov grinned. With his free hand, he pointed from the prophecy still clutched in Roberto's hand, to himself, then at Carolina. Though he could no longer speak, his meaning could not have been clearer. Give me the prophecy, or you get the same as her . . .
    'Like you won't kill us all anyway, the moment I hand it over!' said Roberto.
    A whine of panic inside his head was preventing him thinking properly: he had one hand on Carolina's shoulder, which was still warm, yet did not dare look at her properly. Don't let her be dead, don't let her be dead, it's my fault if she's dead . . .
    "Whaddever you do, Roberto,' said Mauricio fiercely from under the desk, lowering his hands to show a clearly broken nose and blood pouring down his mouth and chin, 'don'd gib it to him!'
    Then there was a crash outside the door and Dolohov looked over his shoulder - the baby-headed Death Eater had appeared in the doorway, his head bawling, his great fists still flailing uncontrollably at everything around him. Roberto seized his chance:
    'PETRIF1CUS TOTALUS!'
    The spell hit Dolohov before he could block it and he toppled forwards across his comrade, both of them rigid as boards and unable to move an inch.
    'Carolina,' Roberto said at once, shaking her as the baby-headed Death Eater blundered out of sight again. 'Carolina, wake up
    'Whaddid he do to her?' said Mauricio, crawling out from under the desk to kneel at her other side, blood streaming from his rapidly swelling nose.
    'I dunno . . . '
    Mauricio groped for Carolina's wrist.
    'Dat's a pulse, Roberto, I'b sure id is.'
    Such a powerful wave of relief swept through Roberto that for a moment he felt light-headed.
    'She's alive?'
    'Yeah, I dink so.'
    There was a pause in which Roberto listened hard for the sound of more footsteps, but all he could hear were the whimpers and blunderings of the baby-headed Death Eater in the next room.
    'Mauricio, we're not far from the exit,' Roberto whispered, 'we're right next to that circular room . . . if we can just get you across it and find the right: door before any more Death Eaters come, I'll bet you can get Carolina up the corridor and into the lift . . . then you could find someone . . . raise the alarm . . .'
    'And whad are you going do do?' said Mauricio, mopping his bleeding nose with his sleeve and frowning at Roberto.
    'I've got to find the others,' said Roberto.
    'Well, I'b going do find dem wid you,' said Mauricio firmly.
    'But Carolina - '
    'We'll dake her wid us,' said Mauricio firmly. 'I'll carry her - you're bedder at fighding dem dan I ab -
    He stood up and seized one of Carolina's arms, glaring at Roberto, who hesitated, then grabbed the other and helped hoist Carolina's limp form over Mauricio's shoulders.
    'Wait,' said Roberto, snatching up Carolina's wand from the floor and shoving it into Mauricio's hand, 'you'd better take this.'
    Mauricio kicked aside the broken fragments of his own wand as they walked slowly towards the door.
    'My gran's going do kill be,' said Mauricio thickly, blood spattering from his nose as he spoke, 'dat was by dad's old wand.'
    Roberto stuck his head out of the door and looked around cautiously. The baby-headed Death Eater was screaming and banging into things, toppling grandfather clocks and overturning desks, bawling and confused, while the glass-fronted cabinet that Roberto now suspected had contained Time-Turners continued to fall, shatter and repair itself on the wall behind them.
    'He's never going to notice us, he whispered. 'C'mon . . . keep close behind me . . .'
    They crept out of the office and back towards the door into the black hallway, which now seemed completely deserted. They walked a few steps forwards, Mauricio tottering slightly due to Carolina's weight; the door of the Time Room swung shut behind them and the walls began to rotate once more. The recent blow on the back of Roberto's head seemed to have unsteadied him; he narrowed his eyes, swaying slightly, until the walls stopped moving again. With a sinking heart, Roberto saw that Carolina's fiery crosses had faded from the doors.
    'So which way d'you reck-?'
    But before they could make a decision as to which way to try, a door to their right sprang open and three people fell out of it.
    'Diego!' croaked Roberto, dashing towards them. 'Martina - are you all - ?'
    'Roberto,' said Diego, giggling weakly, lurching forwards, seizing the front of Roberto's robes and gazing at him with unfocused eyes, 'there you are . . . ha ha ha . . . you look funny, Roberto . . . you're all messed up . . .'
    Diego's face was very white and something dark was trickling from the corner of his mouth. Next moment his knees had given way, but he still clutched the front of Roberto's robes, so that Roberto was pulled into a kind of bow.
    'Martina?' Roberto said fearfully. 'What happened?'
    But Martina shook her head and slid down the wall into a sitting position, panting and holding her ankle.
    'I think her ankle's broken, I heard something crack,' whispered Gabriela, who was bending over her and who alone seemed to be unhurt. 'Four of them chased us into a dark room full of planets; it was a very odd place, some of the time we were just floating in the dark - '
    'Roberto, we saw Uranus up close!' said Diego, still giggling feebly. 'Get it, Roberto? We saw Uranus - ha ha ha - '
    A bubble of blood grew at the corner of Diego's mouth and burst.
    ' - anyway, one of them grabbed Martina's foot, I used the Reductcr Curse and blew up Pluto in his face, but . . .'
    Gabriela gestured hopelessly at Martina, who was breathing in a very shallow way, her eyes still closed.
    'And what about Diego?' said Roberto fearfully, as Diego continued to giggle, still hanging off the front of Roberto's robes.
    'I don't know what they hit him with,' said Gabriela sadly, 'but he's gone a bit funny, I could hardly get him along at all.'
    'Roberto,' said Diego, pulling Roberto's ear down to his mouth and still giggling weakly, 'you know who this girl is, Roberto? She's Loony . . . Loony Ortiz . . . ha ha ha . . .'
    'We've got to get out of here,' said Roberto firmly. 'Gabriela, can you help Martina?'
    'Yes,' said Gabriela, sticking her wand behind her ear for safekeeping, then putting an arm around Martina's waist and pulling her up.
    'It's only my ankle, I can do it myself!' said Martina impatiently, but next moment she had collapsed sideways and grabbed Gabriela for support. Roberto pulled Diego's arm over his shoulder just as, so many months ago, he had pulled Leonardo's. He looked around: they had a one in twelve chance of getting the exit right first time - '
    He heaved Diego towards a door; they were within a few feet of it when another door across the hall burst open and three Death Eaters sped in, led. by Miranda Gimenez.
    'There they are!' she shrieked.
    Stunning Spells shot across the room: Roberto smashed his way through the door ahead, flung Diego unceremoniously from him and ducked back to help Mauricio in with Carolina: they were all over the threshold just in time to slam the door against Miranda.
    'Colloportus!' shouted Roberto, and he heard three bodies slam into the door on the other side.
    'It doesn't matter!' said a man's voice. There are other ways in - WE'VE GOT THEM, THEY'RE HERE!'
    Roberto span around; they were back in the Brain Room and, sure enough, there were doors all around the walls. He could hear footsteps in the hall behind them as more Death Eaters came running to join the first.
    'Gabriela - Mauricio - help me!'
    The three of them tore around the room, sealing the doors as they went; Roberto crashed into a tbale and rolled over the top of it in his haste to reach the next door:
    'Colloportus!'
    There were footsteps running along behind the doors, every now and then another heavy body would launch itself against one, so it creaked and shuddered; Gabriela and Mauricio were bewitching the doors along the opposite wall - then, as Roberto reached the very top of the room, he heard Gabriela cry:
    'Collo- aaaaaaaaargh . . .'
    He turned in time to see her flying through the air; five Death Eaters were surging into the room through the door she had not reached in time; Gabriela hit a desk, slid over its surface and on to the floor on the other side where she lay sprawled, as still as Carolina.
    'Get Gonzales!' shrieked Miranda, and she ran at him; he dodged her and sprinted back up the room; he was safe as long as they thought they might hit the prophecy - '
    'Hey!' said Diego, who had staggered to his feet and was now tottering drunkenly towards Roberto, giggling. 'Hey, Roberto, there are brains in here, ha ha ha, isn't that weird, Roberto?'
    'Diego, get out of the way, get down - '
    But Diego had already pointed his wand at the tank.
    'Honest, Roberto, they're brains - look - Accio brain!'
    The scene seemed momentarily frozen. Roberto, Martina and Mauricio and each of the Death Eaters turned in spite of themselves to watch the top of the tank as a brain burst from the green liquid like a leaping fish: for a moment it seemed suspended in midair, then t soared towards Diego, spinning as it came, and what looked like ribbons of moving images flew from it, unravelling like rolls of film -
    'Ha ha ha, Roberto, look at it - ' said Diego, watching it disgorge its gaudy innards, 'Roberto, come and touch it; bet it's weird - '
    'DIEGO, NO!'
    Roberto did not know what would happen if Diego touched the tentacles of thought now flying behind the brain, but he was sure it would not be anything good. He darted forwards but Diego had already caught the brain in his outstretched hands.
    The moment they made contact with his skin, the tentacles began wrapping themselves around Diego's arms like ropes.
    'Roberto, look what's happen- No - no - I don't like it - no, stop - stop - '
    But the thin ribbons were spinning around Diego's chest now; he tugged and tore at them as the brain was pulled tight against him like an octopus's body.
    'Diffindo!' yelled Roberto, trying to sever the feelers wrapping themselves tightly around Diego before his eyes, but they would not break. Diego fell over, still thrashing against his bonds.
    'Roberto, it'll suffocate him!' screamed Martina, immobilised by her broken ankle on the floor - then a jet of red light flew from one of the Death Eater's wands and hit her squarely in the face. She keeled over sideways and lay there unconscious.
    'STUBEFY!' shouted Mauricio, wheeling around and waving Carolina's wand at the oncoming Death Eaters, 'STUBEFY, STUBEFY!'
    But nothing happened.
    One of the Death Eaters shot their own Stunning Spell at Mauricio; it missed him by inches. Roberto and Mauricio were now the only two left fighting the five Death Eaters, two of whom sent off streams of silver light like arrows which missed but left craters in the wall behind them. Roberto ran for it as Miranda Gimenez raced right at him: holding the prophecy high above his head, he sprinted back up the room; all he could think of doing was to draw the Death Eaters away from the others.
    It seemed to have worked; they streaked after him, knocking chairs and tables flying but not daring to bewitch him in case they hurt the prophecy, and he dashed through the only door still open, the one through which the Death Eaters themselves had come; inwardly praying that Mauricio would stay with Diego and find some way of releasing him. He ran a few feet into the new room and felt the floor vanish - '
    He was falling down steep stone step after steep stone step, bouncing on every tier until at last, with a crash that knocked all the breath out of his body, he landed flat on his back in the sunken p t where the stone archway stood on its dais. The whole room was ringing with the Death Eater's laughter: he looked up and saw the five who had been in the Brain Room descending towards him, while as many more emerged through other doorways and began leaping from bench to bench towards him. Roberto got to his feet though his legs were trembling so badly they barely supported him: the prophecy was still miraculously unbroken in his left hand, his wand clutched tightly in his right. He backed away, looking around, trying to keep all the Death Eaters within his sight. The back of his legs hit something solid: he had reached the dais where the archway stood. He climbed backwards onto it.
    The Death Eaters all halted, gazing at him. Some were panting as hard as he was. One was bleeding badly; Dolohov, freed of the Body-Bind Curse, was leering, his wand pointing straight at Roberto's face.
    'Gonzales, your race is run,' drawled Mariano Sosa, pulling off his mask, 'now hand me the prophecy like a good boy.'
    'Let - let the others go, and I'll give it to you!' said Roberto desperately.
    A few of the Death Eaters laughed.
    'You are not in a position to bargain, Gonzales,' said Mariano Sosa, his pale face flushed with pleasure. 'You see, there are ten of us and only one of you . . . or hasn't Dominguez ever taught you how to count?'
    'He's dot alone!' shouted a voice from above them. 'He's still god be!'
    Roberto's heart sank: Mauricio was scrambling down the stone benches towards them, Carolina's wand held fast in his trembling hand.
    'Mauricio - no - go back to Diego - '
    'STUBEFY!' Mauricio shouted again, pointing his wand at each Death Eater in turn. 'STUBEFY! 'STUBE - '
    One of the largest Death Eaters seized Mauricio from behind, pinioning his arms to his sides. He struggled and kicked; several of the Death Eaters laughed.
    'It's Silva, isn't it?' sneered Mariano Sosa. 'Well, your grandmother is used to losing family members to our cause . . . your death will not come as a great shock.'
    'Silva?' repeated Miranda, and a truly evil smile lit her gaunt face. 'Why, I have had the pleasure of meeting your parents, boy.'
    'I DOE YOU HAB!' roared Mauricio, and he fought so hard against his captor's encircling grip that the Death Eater shouted, 'Someone Stun him!'
    'No, no, no,' said Miranda. She looked transported, alive with excitement as she glanced at Roberto, then back at Mauricio. 'No, let's see how long Silva lasts before he cracks like his parents . . . unless Gonzales wants to give us the prophecy.'
    'DON'D GIB ID DO DEM!' roared Mauricio, who seemed beside himself, kicking and writhing as Miranda drew nearer to him and his captor, her wand raised. 'DON'D GIB ID DO DEM, ROBERTO!'
    Miranda raised her wand. 'Crucio!'
    Mauricio screamed, his legs drawn up to his chest so that the Death Eater holding him was momentarily holding him off the ground. The Death Eater dropped him and he fell to the floor, twitching and screaming in agony.
    'That was just a taster!' said Miranda, raising her wand so that Mauricio's screams stopped and he lay sobbing at her feet. She turned and gazed up at Roberto. 'Now, Gonzales, either give us the prophecy, or watch your little friend die the hard way!'
    Roberto did not have to think; there was no choice. The prophecy was hot with the heat of his clutching hand as he held it out. Sosa jumped forwards to take it.
    Then, high above them, two more doors burst open and five more people sprinted into the room: Gustavo, Cardozo, Acosta, Perez and Hector.
    Sosa turned, and raised his wand, but Perez had already sent a Stunning Spell right at him. Roberto did not wait to see whether it had made contact, but dived off the dais out of the way. The Death Eaters were completely distracted by the appearance of the members of the Order, who were now raining spells down upon them as they jumped from step to step towards the sunken floor. Through the darting bodies, the flashes of light, Roberto could see Mauricio crawling along. He dodged another jet of red light and flung himself flat on the ground to reach Mauricio.
    Are you OK? he yelled, as another spell soared inches over their heads.
    'Yes,' said Mauricio, trying to pull himself up.
    'And Diego?'
    'I dink he's all righd - he was still fighding de brain when I lefd - '
    The stone floor between them exploded as a spell hit it, leaving a crater right where Mauricio's hand had been only seconds before; both scrambled away from the spot, then a thick arm came out of nowhere, seized Roberto around the neck and pulled him upright, so that his toes were barely touching the floor.
    'Give it to me,' growled a voice in his ear, 'give me the prophecy - '
    The man was pressing so tightly on Roberto's windpipe that he could not breathe. Through watering eyes he saw Gustavo duelling with a Death Eater some ten feet away; Hector was fighting two at once; Perez, still halfway up the tiered seats, was firing spells down at Miranda - nobody seemed to realise that Roberto was dying. He turned his wand backwards towards the man's side, but had no breath to utter an incantation, and the man's free hand was groping towards the hand in which Roberto was grasping the prophecy - '
    'AARGH!'
    Mauricio had come lunging out of nowhere; unable to articulate a spell, he had jabbed Carolina's wand hard into the eyehole of the Death Eater's mask. The man relinquished Roberto at once with a howl of pain. Roberto whirled around to face him and gasped:
    'STUPEFY!'
    The Death Eater keeled over backwards and his mask slipped off: it was Macnair, Buckbeak's would-be killer, one of his eyes now swollen and bloodshot.
    Thanks!' Roberto said to Mauricio, pulling him aside as Gustavo and his Death Eater lurched past, duelling so fiercely that their wands were blurs; then Roberto's foot made contact with something round and hard and he slipped. For a moment he thought he had dropped the prophecy, but then he saw Acosta's magical eye spinning away across the floor.
    Its owner was lying on his side, bleeding from the head, and
    his attacker was now bearing down upon Roberto and Mauricio: Dolohov, his long pale face twisted with glee.
    'Tarantallegra!' he shouted, his wand pointing at Mauricio, whose legs went immediately into a kind of frenzied tap-dance, unbalancing him and causing him to fall to the floor again. 'Now, Gonzales - '
    He made the same slashing movement with his wand that he had used on Carolina just as Roberto yelled, 'Protego!'
    Roberto felt something streak across his face like a blunt knife; the force of it knocked him sideways and he fell over Mauricio's jerking legs, but the Shield Charm had stopped the worst of the spell.
    Dolohov raised his wand again. 'Accio proph-'
    Gustavo had hurtled out of nowhere, rammed Dolohov with his shoulder and sent him flying out of the way. The prophecy had again flown to the tips of Roberto's fingers but he had managed to cling on to it. Now Gustavo and Dolohov were duelling, their wands flashing like swords, sparks flying from their wand-tips - '
    Dolohov drew back his wand to make the same slashing movement he had used on Roberto and Carolina. Springing up, Roberto yelled, 'Petrificus Totalus!' Once again, Dolohov's arms and legs snapped together and he keeled over backwards, landing with a crash on his back.
    'Nice one!' shouted Gustavo, forcing Roberto's head down as a pair of Stunning Spells flew towards them. 'Now I want you to get out of- '
    They both ducked again; a jet of green light had narrowly missed Gustavo. Across the room Roberto saw Perez fall from halfway up the stone steps, her limp form toppling from stone seat to stone seat and Miranda, triumphant, running back towards the fray.
    'Roberto, take the prophecy, grab Mauricio and run!' Gustavo yelled, dashing to meet Miranda. Roberto did not see what happened next: Hector swayed across his field of vision, battling with the pockmarked and no longer masked Rookwood; another jet of green light flew over Roberto's head as he launched himself towards Mauricio - '
    'Can you stand?' he bellowed in Mauricio's ear, as Mauricio's legs jerked and twitched uncontrollably. 'Put your arm round my neck -
    Mauricio did so - Roberto heaved - Mauricio's legs were still lying in every direction, they would not support him, and then, out of nowhere, a man lunged at them: both fell backwards, Mauricio's legs waving wildly like an overturned beetle's, Roberto with his left arm held up in the air to try to save the small glass ball from being smashed.
    'The prophecy, give me the prophecy, Gonzales!' snarled Lucus Sosa's voice in his ear, and Roberto felt the tip of Sosa's wand pressing hard between his ribs.
    'No - get - off - me . . . Mauricio - catch it!'
    Roberto flung the prophecy across the floor, Mauricio span himself around on his back and scooped the ball to his chest. Sosa pointed the wand instead at Mauricio, but Roberto jabbed his own wand back over his shoulder and yelled, 'Impedimenta!'
    Sosa was blasted off his back. As Roberto scrambled up again he looked around and saw Sosa smash into the dais on which Gustavo and Miranda were now duelling. Sosa aimed his wand at Roberto and Mauricio again, but before he could draw breath to strike, Cardozo had jumped between them.
    'Roberto, round up the others and GO!'
    Roberto seized Mauricio by the shoulder of his robes and lifted him bodily on to the first tier of stone steps; Mauricio's legs twitched and jerked and would not support his weight; Roberto heaved again with all the strength he possessed and they climbed another step - '
    A spell hit the stone bench at Roberto's heel; it crumbled away and he fell back to the step below. Mauricio sank to the ground, his legs still jerking and thrashing, and he thrust the prophecy into his pocket.
    'Come on!' said Roberto desperately, hauling at Mauricio's robes. 'Just try and push with your legs -'
    He gave another stupendous heave and Mauricio's robes tore all along the left seam - the small spun-glass ball dropped from his pocket and, before either of them could catch it, one of Mauricio's floundering feet kicked it: it flew some ten feet to their right and smashed on the step beneath them. As both of them stared at the place where it had broken, appalled at what had happened, a pearly-white figure with hugely magnified eyes rose into the air, unnoticed by any but them. Roberto could see its mouth moving, but in all the crashes and screams and yells surrounding them, not one word of the prophecy could he hear. The figure stopped speaking and dissolved into nothingness.
    'Roberto, I'b sorry!' cried Mauricio, his face anguished as his legs continued to flounder. Tb so sorry, Roberto, I didn'd bean do - '
    'It doesn't matter!' Roberto shouted. 'Just try and stand, let's get out of - '
    'Dubbledore!' said Mauricio, his sweaty face suddenly transported, staring over Roberto's shoulder.
    'What?'
    'DUBBLEDORE!'
    Roberto turned to look where Mauricio was staring. Directly above them, framed in the doorway from the Brain Room, stood Alfonso Dominguez, his wand aloft, his face white and furious. Roberto felt a kind of electric charge surge through every particle of his body - they were saved.
    Dominguez sped down the steps past Mauricio and Roberto, who had no more thoughts of leaving. Dominguez was already at the foot of the steps when the Death Eaters nearest realised he was there and yelled to the others. One of the Death Eaters ran for it, scrabbling like a monkey up the stone steps opposite. Dominguez's spell pulled him back as easily and effortlessly as though he had hooked him with an invisible line - '
    Only one pair was still battling, apparently unaware of the new arrival. Roberto saw Gustavo duck Miranda's jet of red light: he was laughing at her.
    'Come on, you can do better than that!' he yelled, his voice echoing around the cavernous room.
    The second jet of light hit him squarely on the chest.
    The laughter had not quite died from his face, but his eyes widened in shock.
    Roberto released Mauricio, though he was unaware of doing so. He was jumping down the steps again, pulling out his wand, as Dominguez, too, turned towards the dais.
    It seemed to take Gustavo an age to tall: his body curved in a graceful arc as he sank backwards through the ragged veil hanging from the arch.
    Roberto saw the look of mingled fear and surprise on his godfathers wasted, once-handsome face as he fell through the ancient doorway and disappeared behind the veil, which fluttered for a moment as though in a high wind, then fell back into place.
    Roberto heard Miranda Gimenez's triumphant scream, but knew it meant nothing - Gustavo had only just fallen through the archway, he would reappear from the other side any second . . .
    But Gustavo did not reappear.
    'GUSTAVO!' Roberto yelled. 'GUSTAVO!'
    He had reached the floor, his breath coming in searing gasps. Gustavo must be just behind the curtain, he, Roberto, would pull him back out . . .
    But as he reached the ground and sprinted towards the dais, Cardozo grabbed Roberto around the chest, holding him back.
    There's nothing you can do, Roberto - '
    'Get him, save him, he's only just gone through!'
    ' - it's too late, Roberto.'
    'We can still reach him - ' Roberto struggled hard and viciously, but Cardozo would not let go . . .
    There's nothing you can do, Roberto . . . nothing . . . he's gone.'
- CHAPTER THIRTY-SIX -
The Only One
He Ever Feared
'He hasn't gone!' Roberto yelled.
    He did not believe it; he would not believe it; still he fought Cardozo with every bit of strength he had. Cardozo did not understand; people hid behind that curtain; Roberto had heard them whispering the first time he had entered the room. Gustavo was hiding, simply lurking out of sight - '
    'GUSTAVO!' he bellowed. 'GUSTAVO!'
    'He can't come back, Roberto,' said Cardozo, his voice breaking as he struggled to contain Roberto. 'He can't come back, because he's d-
    'HE - IS - NOT - DEAD!' roared Roberto. 'GUSTAVO!'
    There was movement going on around them, pointless bustling, the flashes of more spells. To Roberto it was meaningless noise, the deflected curses flying past them did not matter, nothing mattered except that Cardozo should stop pretending that Gustavo - who was standing feet from them behind that old curtain - was not going to emerge at any moment, shaking back his dark hair and eager to re-enter the battle.
    Cardozo dragged Roberto away from the dais. Roberto still staring at the archway, was angry at Gustavo now for keeping him waiting - '
    But some part of him realised, even as he fought to break free from Cardozo, that Gustavo had never kept him waiting before . . . Gustavo had risked everything, always, to see Roberto to help him . . . if Gustavo was not reappearing out of that archway when Roberto was yelling for him as though his life depended on it, the only possible explanation was that he could not come back . . . that he really was - '
    Dominguez had most of the remaining Death haters grouped in the middle of the room, seemingly immobilised by invisible ropes; Mad-Eye Acosta had crawled across the room to where Perez lay, and was attempting to revive her; behind the dais there were still flashes of light, grunts and cries - Hector had run forward to continue Gustavo's duel with Miranda.
    'Roberto?'
    Mauricio had slid down the stone benches one by one to the place where Roberto stood. Roberto was no longer struggling against Cardozo, who maintained a precautionary grip on his arm nevertheless.
    'Roberto . . . I'b really sorry . . .' said Mauricio. His legs were still dancing uncontrollably. 'Was dad man - was Gustavo Martinez a - a friend of yours?'
    Roberto nodded.
    'Here,' said Cardozo quietly, and pointing his wand at Mauricio's legs he said, 'Finite.' The spell was lifted: Mauricio's legs fell back to the floor and remained still. Cardozo's face was pale. 'Let's - let's find the others. Where are they all, Mauricio?'
    Cardozo turned away from the archway as he spoke. It sounded as though every word was causing him pain.
    'Dey're all back dere,' said Mauricio. 'A brain addacked Diego bud I dink he's all righd - and Herbione's unconscious, bud we cou'.d feel a bulse - '
    There was a loud bang and a yell from behind the dais. Roberto saw Hector hit the ground yelling in pain: Miranda Gimenez turned tail and ran as Dominguez whipped around. He aimed a spell at her but she deflected it; she was halfway up the steps now - '
    'Roberto - no!' cried Cardozo, but Roberto had already ripped his arm from Cardozo's slackened grip.
    'SHE KILLED GUSTAVO!' bellowed Roberto. 'SHE KILLED HIM - 'I'LL KILL HER!'
    And he was off, scrambling up the stone benches; people were shouting behind him but he did not care. The hem of Miranda's robes whipped out of sight ahead and they were back in the room where the brains were swimming . . .
    She aimed a curse over her shoulder. The tank rose into the air and tipped. Roberto was deluged in the foul-smelling potion within: the brains slipped and slid over him and began spinning their long coloured tentacles, but he shouted, "Wingardium Leviosa!' and they flew off him up into the air. Slipping and sliding, he ran on towards the door; he leapt over Gabriela, who was groaning on the floor, past Martina, who said, 'Roberto - what - ?', past Diego, who giggled feebly, and Carolina, who was still unconscious. He wrenched open the door into the circular black hall and saw Miranda disappearing through a door on the other side of the room; beyond her was the corridor leading back to the lifts.
    He ran, but she had slammed the door behind her and the walls were already rotating. Once more, he was surrounded by streaks of blue light from the whirling candelabra.
    'Where's the exit?' he shouted desperately, as the wall rumbled to a halt again. 'Where's the way out?'
    The room seemed to have been waiting for him to ask. The door right behind him flew open and the corridor towards the lifts stretched ahead of him, torch-lit and empty. He ran . . .
    He could hear a lift clattering ahead; he sprinted up the passageway, swung around the corner and slammed his fist on to the button to call a second lift. It jangled and banged lower and lower; the grilles slid open and Roberto dashed inside, now hammering the button marked 'Atrium'. The doors slid shut and he was rising . . .
    He forced his way out of the lift before the grilles were fully open and looked around. Miranda was almost at the telephone lift at the other end of the hall, but she looked back as he sprinted towards her and aimed another spell at him. He dodged behind the Fountain of Magical Brethren: the spell zoomed past him and hit the wrought-gold gates at the other end of the Atrium so that they rang like bells. There were no more footsteps. She had stopped running. He crouched behind the statues, listening.
    'Come out, come out, little Roberto!' she called in her mock baby voice, which echoed off the polished wooden floors. 'What did you come after me for, then? I thought you were here to avenge my dear cousin!'
    'I am!' shouted Roberto, and a score of ghostly Roberto's seemed to chorus I am! I am! I am! all around the room.
    'Aaaaaah . . . did you love him, little baby Gonzales?
    Hatred rose in Roberto such as he had never known before; he flung himself out from behind the fountain and bellowed, 'Crucio!'
    Miranda screamed: the spell had knocked her off her feet, but she did not writhe and shriek with pain as Mauricio had - she was already back on her feet, breathless, no longer laughing. Roberto dodged behind the golden fountain again. Her counter-spell hit the head of the handsome wizard, which was blown off and landed twenty feet away, gouging long scratches into the wooden floor.
    'Never used an Unforgivable Curse before, have you, boy?' she yelled. She had abandoned her baby voice now. 'You need to mean them, Gonzales! You need to really want to cause pain - to enjoy it - righteous anger won't hurt me for long - I'll show you how it is done, shall I? I'll give you a lesson - '
    Roberto was edging around the fountain on the other side when she screamed, 'Crucio!' and he was forced to duck down again as the centaur's arm, holding its bow, span off and landed with a crash on the floor a short distance from the golden wizard's head.
    'Gonzales, you cannot win against me!' she cried.
    He could hear her moving to the right, trying to get a clear shot of him. He backed around the statue away from her, crouching behind the centaur's legs, his head level with the house-elf's.
    'I was and am the Dark Lord's most loyal servant. I learned the Dark Arts from him, and I know spells of such power that you, pathetic little boy, can never hope to compete - '
    'Stupefy!' yelled Roberto. He had edged right around to where the goblin stood beaming up at the now headless wizard and taken aim at her back as she peered around the fountain. She reacted so fast he barely had time to duck.
    'Protege!'
    The jet of red light, his own Stunning Spell, bounced back at him. Roberto scrambled back behind the fountain and one of the goblin's ears went flying across the room.
    'Gonzales, I'm going to give you one chance!' shouted Miranda. 'Give me the prophecy - roll it out towards me now - and I may spare your life!'
    'Well, you're going to have to kill me, because it's gone!' Roberto roared and, as he shouted it, pain seared across his forehead; his scar was on fire again, and he felt a surge of fury that was quite unconnected with his own rage. 'And he knows!' said Roberto, with a mad laugh to match Miranda's own. 'Your dear old mate Salvador knows it's gone! He's not going to be happy with you, is he?'
    'What? What do you mean?' she cried, and for the first time there was fear in her voice.
    The prophecy smashed when I was trying to get Mauricio up the steps! What do you think Salvador'll say about that, then?'
    His scar seared and burned . . . the pain of it was making his eyes stream . . .
    'LIAR!' she shrieked, but he could hear the terror behind the anger now. 'YOU'VE GOT IT, GONZALES, AND YOU WILL GIVE IT TO ME! Accio prophecy! ACCIO PROPHECY!'
    Roberto laughed again because he knew it would incense her, the pain building in his head so badly he thought his skull might burst. He waved his empty hand from behind the one-eared goblin and withdrew it quickly as she sent another jet of green light flying at him.
    'Nothing there!' he shouted. 'Nothing to summon! It smashed and nobody heard what it said, tell your boss that!'
    'No!' she screamed. 'It isn't true, you're lying! MASTER, I TRIED, I TRIED - DO NOT PUNISH ME - '
    'Don't waste your breath!' yelled Roberto, his eyes screwed up against the pain in his scar, now more terrible than ever. 'He can't hear you from here!'
    'Can't I, Gonzales?' said a high, cold voice.
    Roberto opened his eyes.
    Tall, thin and black-hooded, his terrible snakelike face white and gaunt, his scarlet, slit-pupilled eyes staring . . . Lord Salvador had appeared in the middle of the hall, his wand pointing at Roberto who stood frozen, quite unable to move.
    'So, you smashed my prophecy?' said Salvador softly, staring at Roberto with those pitiless red eyes. 'No, Bella, he is not lying . . . I see the truth looking at me from within his worthless mind . . . months of preparation, months of effort . . . and my Death Eaters have let Roberto Gonzales thwart me again . . .'
    'Master, I am sorry, I knew not, I was fighting the Animagus Martinez!' sobbed Miranda, flinging herself down at Salvador's feet as he paced slowly nearer. 'Master, you should know - '
    'Be quiet, Bella,' said Salvador dangerously. 'I shall deal with you in a moment. Do you think I have entered the Ministry of Magic to hear your snivelling apologies?'
    'But Master - he is here - he is below - '
    Salvador paid no attention.
    'I have nothing more to say to you, Gonzales,' he said quietly. 'You have irked me too often, for too long. AVADA KEDAVRA!'
    Roberto had not even opened his mouth to resist; his mind was blank, his wand pointing uselessly at the floor.
    But the headless golden statue of the wizard in the fountain had sprung alive, leaping from its plinth to land with a crash on the floor between Roberto and Salvador. The spell merely glanced off its chest as the statue flung out its arms to protect Roberto.
    'What - ?' cried Salvador, staring around. And then he breathed, 'Dominguez!'
    Roberto looked behind him, his heart pounding. Dominguez was standing in front of the golden gates.
    Salvador raised his wand and another jet of green light streaked at Dominguez, who turned and was gone in a whirling of his cloak. Next second, he had reappeared behind Salvador and waved his wand towards the remnants of the fountain. The other statues sprang to life. The statue of the witch ran at Miranda, who screamed and sent spells streaming uselessly off its chest, before it dived at her, pinning her to the floor. Meanwhile, the goblin and the house-elf scuttled towards the fireplaces set along the wall and the one-armed centaur galloped at Salvador, who vanished and reappeared beside the pool. The headless statue thrust Roberto backwards, away from the fight, as Dominguez advanced on Salvador and the golden centaur cantered around them both.
    'It was foolish to come here tonight, Oscar,' said Dominguez calmly. The Aurors are on their way - '
    'By which time I shall be gone, and you will be dead!' spat Salvador. He sent another killing curse at Dominguez but missed, instead hitting the security guard's desk, which burst into flame.
    Dominguez flicked his own wand: the force of the spell that emanated from it was such that Roberto, though shielded by his golden guard, felt his hair stand on end as it passed and this time Salvador was forced to conjure a shining silver shield out of thin air to deflect it. The spell, whatever it was, caused no visible damage to the shield, though a deep, gong-like note reverberated from it - an oddly chilling sound.
    'You do not seek to kill me, Dominguez?' called Salvador, his scarlet eyes narrowed over the top of the shield. 'Above such brutality, are you?'
    'We both know that there are other ways of destroying a man, Oscar,' Dominguez said calmly, continuing to walk towards Salvador as though he had not a fear in the world, as though nothing had happened to interrupt his stroll up the hall. 'Merely taking your life would not satisfy me, I admit - '
    There is nothing worse than death, Dominguez!' snarled Salvador.
    'You are quite wrong,' said Dominguez, still closing in upon Salvador and speaking as lightly as though they were discussing the matter over drinks. Roberto felt scared to see him walking along, undefended, shieldless; he wanted to cry out a warning, but his headless guard kept shunting him backwards towards the wall, blocking his every attempt to gel out from behind it. 'Indeed, your failure to understand that there are things much worse than death has always been your greatest weakness - '
    Another jet of green light flew from behind the silver shield. This time it was the one-armed centaur, galloping in front of Dominguez, that took the blast and shattered into a hundred pieces, but before the fragments had even hit the floor, Dominguez had drawn back his wand and waved it as though brandishing a whip. A long thin flame flew from the tip; it wrapped itself around Salvador, shield and all. For a moment, it seemed Dominguez had won, but then the fiery rope became a serpent, which relinquished its hold on Salvador at once and turned, hissing furiously, to face Dominguez.
    Salvador vanished; the snake reared from the floor, ready to strike - '
    There was a burst of flame in midair above Dominguez just as Salvador reappeared, standing on the plinth in the middle of the pool where so recently the five statues had stood.
    'Look out!' Roberto yelled.
    But even as he shouted, another jet of green light flew at Dominguez from Salvador's wand and the snake struck - '
    Fawkes swooped down in front of Dominguez, opened his beak wide and swallowed the jet of green light whole: he burst into flame and fell to the floor, small, wrinkled and flightless. At the same moment, Dominguez brandished his wand in one long, fluid movement - the snake, which had been an instant from sinking its fangs into him, flew high into the air and vanished in a wisp of dark smoke; and the water in the pool rose up and covered Salvador like a cocoon of molten glass.
    For a few seconds Salvador was visible only as a dark, rippling, faceless figure, shimmering and indistinct upon the plinth, clearly struggling to throw off the suffocating mass - '
    Then he was gone and the water fell with a crash back into its pool, slopping wildly over the sides, drenching the polished floor.
    'MASTER!' screamed Miranda.
    Sure it was over, sure Salvador had decided to flee, Roberto made to run out from behind his statue guard, but Dominguez bellowed: 'Stay where you are, Roberto!'
    For the first time, Dominguez sounded frightened. Roberto could not see why: the hall was quite empty but for themselves, the sobbing Miranda still trapped under the witch statue, and the baby phoenix Fawkes croaking feebly on the floor - '
    Then Roberto's scar burst open and he knew he was dead: it was pain beyond imagining, pain past endurance - '
    He was gone from the hall, he was locked in the coils of a creature with red eyes, so tightly bound that Roberto did not know where his body ended and the creatures began: they were fused together, bound by pain, and there was no escape - '
    And when the creature spoke, it used Roberto's mouth, so that in his agony he felt his jaw move . . .
    'Kill me now, Dominguez . . .'
    Blinded and dying, every part of him screaming for release, Roberto felt the creature use him again . . .
    'If death is nothing, Dominguez, kill the boy . . .'
    Let the pain stop, thought Roberto . . . let him kill us . . . end it, Dominguez . . . death is nothing compared to this . . .
    And I'll see Gustavo again . . .
    And as Roberto's heart filled with emotion, the creatures coils loosened, the pain was gone; Roberto was lying face down on the floor, his glasses gone, shivering as though he lay upon ice, not wood . . .
    And there were voices echoing through the hall, more voices than there should have been . . . Roberto opened his eyes, saw his glasses lying by the heel of the headless statue that had been guarding him, but which now lay flat on its back, cracked and immobile. He put them on and raised his head a little to find Dominguez's crooked nose inches from his own.
    'Are you all right, Roberto?'
    'Yes,' said Roberto, shaking so violently he could not hold his head up properly. 'Yeah, I'm - where's Salvador, where - who are all these - what's - '
    The Atrium was full of people; the floor was reflecting the emerald green flames that had burst into fire in all the fireplaces along one wall; and streams of witches and wizards were emerging from them. As Dominguez pulled him back to his feet, Roberto saw the tiny gold statues of the house-elf and the goblin, leading a stunned-looking Cornelius Fudge forward.
    'He was there!' shouted a scarlet-robed man with a ponytail, who was pointing at a pile of golden rubble on the other side of the hall, where Miranda had lain trapped only moments before. 'I saw him, Mr Fudge, I swear it was You-Know-Who, he grabbed a woman and Disapparated!'
    'I know, Williamson, I know, I saw him too!' gibbered Fudge, who was wearing pyjamas under his pinstriped cloak and was gasping as though he had just run miles. 'Merlin's beard - here - here! - in the Ministry of Magic! - great heavens above - it doesn't seem possible - my word - how can this be - ?'
    'If you proceed downstairs into the Department of Mysteries, Cornelius,' said Dominguez - apparently satisfied that Roberto was all right, and walking forwards so that the newcomers realised he was there for the first time (a few of them raised their wands; others simply looked amazed; the statues of the elf and goblin applauded and Fudge jumped so much that his slipper-clad feet left the floor) - 'you will find several escaped Death Eaters contained in the Death Chamber, bound by an Anti-Disapparation Jinx and awaiting your decision as to what to do with them.'
    'Dominguez!' gasped Fudge, beside himself with amazement. 'You - here - I - I - '
    He looked wildly around at the Aurors he had brought with him and it could not have been clearer that he was in half a mind to cry, 'Seize him!'
    'Cornelius, I am ready to fight your men - and win, again!' said Dominguez in a thunderous voice. 'But a few minutes ago you saw proof, with your own eyes, that I have been telling you the truth for a year. Lord Salvador has returned, you have been chasing the wrong man for twelve months, and it is time you listened to sense!'
    'I - don't - well -' blustered Fudge, looking around as though hoping somebody was going to tell him what to do. When nobody did, he said, 'Very well - Dawlish! Williamson! Go down to the Department of Mysteries and see . . . Dominguez, you - you will need to tell me exactly - the Fountain of Magical Brethren - what happened?' he added in a kind of whimper, staring around at the floor, where the remains of the statues of the witch, wizard and centaur now lay scattered.
    'We can discuss that after I have sent Roberto back to Hogwarts,' said Dominguez.
    'Roberto - Roberto Gonzales?'
    Fudge wheeled around and stared at Roberto, who was still standing against the wall beside the fallen statue that had guarded him during Dominguez and Salvador's duel.
    'He - here?' said Fudge, goggling at Roberto. 'Why - what's all this about?'
    'I shall explain everything,' repeated Dominguez, 'when Roberto is back at school.'
    He walked away from the pool to the place where the golden wizard's head lay on the floor. He pointed his wand at it and muttered, 'Portus.' The head glowed blue and trembled noisily against the wooden floor for a few seconds, then became still once more.
    'Now see here, Dominguez!' said Fudge, as Dominguez picked up the head and walked back to Roberto carrying it. 'You haven't got authorisation for that Portkey! You can't do things like that right in front of the Minister for Magic, you - you - '
    His voice faltered as Dominguez surveyed him magisterially over his half-moon spectacles.
    'You will give the order to remove Dolores Umbridge from Hogwarts,' said Dominguez. 'You will tell your Aurors to stop searching for my Care of Magical Creatures teacher so that he can return to work. I will give you . . .' Dominguez pulled a watch with twelve hands from his pocket and surveyed it. . . half an hour of my time tonight, in which I think we shall be more than able to cover the important points of what has happened here. After that, I shall need to return to my school. If you need more help from me you are, of course, more than welcome to contact me at Hogwarts. Letters addressed to the Headmaster will find me.'
    Fudge goggled worse than ever; his mouth was open and his round face grew pinker under his rumpled grey hair.
    'I - you - '
    Dominguez turned his back on him.
    'Take this Portkey, Roberto.'
    He held out the golden head of the statue and Roberto placed his hand on it, past caring what he did next or where he went.
    'I shall see you in half an hour,' said Dominguez quietly 'One . . . two . . . three
    Roberto felt the familiar sensation of a hook being jerked behind his navel. The polished wooden floor was gone from beneath his feet; the Atrium, Fudge and Dominguez had all disappeared and he was flying forwards in a whirlwind of colour and sound . . .
- CHAPTER THIRTY-SEVEN -
The Lost Prophecy
Roberto's feet hit solid ground; his knees buckled a little and the golden wizard's head fell with a resounding clunk to the floor. He looked around and saw that he had arrived in Dominguez's office.
    Everything seemed to have repaired itself during the Headmasters absence. The delicate silver instruments stood once more on the spindle-legged tables, puffing and whirring serenely. The portraits of the headmasters and headmistresses were snoozing in their frames, heads lolling back in armchairs or against the edge of the; picture. Roberto looked through the window. There was a cool line of pale green along the horizon: dawn was approaching.
    The silence and the stillness, broken only by the occasional grunt or snuffle of a sleeping portrait, was unbearable to him. If his surroundings could have reflected the feelings inside him, the pictures would have been screaming in pain. He walked around the quiet, beautiful office, breathing quickly, trying not to think. But he had to think . . . there was no escape . . .
    It was his fault Gustavo had died; it was all his fault. If he, Roberto, had not been stupid enough to fall for Salvador's trick, if he had not been so convinced that what he had seen in his dream was real, if he had only opened his mind to the possibility that Salvador was, as Carolina had said, banking on Roberto's love of playing the hero . . .
    It was unbearable, he would not think about it, he could not stand it . . . there was a terrible hollow inside him he did not want to feel or examine, a dark hole where Gustavo had been, where Gustavo had vanished; he did not want to have to be alone with that great, silent space, he could not stand it - '
    A picture behind him gave a particularly loud grunting snore, and a cool voice said, 'Ah . . . Roberto Gonzales . . .'
    Phineas Nigellus gave a long yawn, stretching his arms as he surveyed Roberto out of shrewd, narrow eyes.
    'And what brings you here in the early hours of the morning?' said Phineas eventually. This office is supposed to be barred to all but the rightful Headmaster. Or has Dominguez sent you here? Oh, don't tell me . . .' He gave another shuddering yawn. 'Another message for my worthless great-great-grandson?'
    Roberto could not speak. Phineas Nigellus did not know that Gustavo was dead, but Roberto could not tell him. To say it aloud would be to make it final, absolute, irretrievable.
    A few more of the portraits had stirred now. Terror of being interrogated made Roberto stride across the room and seize the doorknob.
    It would not turn. He was shut in.
    'I hope this means,' said the corpulent, red-nosed wizard who hung on the wall behind the Headmasters desk, 'that Dominguez will soon be back among us?'
    Roberto turned. The wizard was surveying him with great interest. Roberto nodded. He tugged again on the doorknob behind his back, but it remained immovable.
    'Oh good,' said the wizard. 'It has been very dull without him, very dull indeed.'
    He settled himself on the throne-like chair on which he had been painted and smiled benignly upon Roberto.
    'Dominguez thinks very highly of you, as I am sure you know,' he said comfortably. 'Oh yes. Holds you in great esteem.'
    The guilt filling the whole of Roberto's chest like some monstrous, weighty parasite, now writhed and squirmed. Roberto could not stand this, he could not stand being himself any more . . . he had never felt more trapped inside his own head and body, never wished so intensely that he could be somebody, anybody else . . .
    The empty fireplace burst into emerald green flame, making Roberto leap away from the door, staring at the man spinning inside the grate. As Dominguez's tall form unfolded itself from the fire, the wizards and witches on the surrounding walls jerked awake, many of them giving cries of welcome.
    Thank you,' said Dominguez softly.
    He did not look at Roberto at first, but walked over to the perch beside the door and withdrew, from an inside pocket of his robes, the tiny, ugly, featherless Fawkes, whom he placed gently on the tray of soft ashes beneath the golden post where the full-grown Fawkes usually stood.
    'Well, Roberto,' said Dominguez, finally turning away from the baby bird, 'you will be pleased to hear that none of your fellow students are going to suffer lasting damage from the night's events.'
    Roberto tried to say, 'Good,' but no sound came out. It seemed to him that Dominguez was reminding him of the amount of damage he had caused, and although Dominguez was for once looking at him directly, and although his expression was kindly rather than accusatory, Roberto could not bear to meet his eyes.
    'Madam Pomfrey is patching everybody up,' said Dominguez 'Viviana Perez may need to spend a little time in St Mungos, but it seems she will make a full recovery.'
    Roberto contented himself with nodding at the carpet, which was growing lighter as the sky outside grew paler. He was sure all the: portraits around the room were listening closely to every wore! Dominguez spoke, wondering where Dominguez and Roberto had been, and why there had been injuries.
    'I know how you're feeling, Roberto,' said Dominguez very quietly.
    'No, you don't,' said Roberto, and his voice was suddenly loud and strong; white-hot anger leapt inside him; Dominguez knew nothing about his feelings.
    'You see, Dominguez?' said Phineas Nigellus slyly. 'Never try to understand the students. They hate it. They would much rather be tragically misunderstood, wallow in self-pity, stew in their own - '
    That's enough, Phineas,' said Dominguez.
    Roberto turned his back on Dominguez and stared determinedly out of the window. He could see the Quidditch stadium in the distance. Gustavo had appeared there once, disguised as the shaggy black dog, so he could watch Roberto play . . . he had probably come to see whether Roberto was as good as Ricardo had been . . . Roberto had never asked him . . .
    There  is  no  shame   in  what  you  are   feeling,  Roberto,'  said Dominguez's voice. 'On the contrary . . . the fact that you can feel pain like this is your greatest strength.'
    Roberto felt the white-hot anger lick his insides, blazing in the terrible emptiness, filling him with the desire to hurt Dominguez for his calmness and his empty words.
    'My greatest strength, is it?' said Roberto, his voice shaking as he stared out at the Quidditch stadium, no longer seeing it. 'You haven't got a clue . . . you don't know . . ."
    'What don't I know?' asked Dominguez calmly.
    It was too much. Roberto turned around, shaking with rage.
    'I don't want to talk about how I feel, all right?'
    'Roberto, suffering like this proves you are still a man! This pain is part of being human - '
    'THEN - I - DON'T - WANT - TO - BE - HUMAN!' Roberto roared, and he seized the delicate silver instrument from the spindle-legged table beside him and flung it across the room; it shattered into a hundred tiny pieces against the wall. Several of the pictures let out yells of anger and fright, and the portrait of Armando Dippet said, 'Really!'
    'I DON'T CARE!' Roberto yelled at them, snatching up a lunascope and throwing it into the fireplace. 'I'VE HAD ENOUGH, I'VE SEEN ENOUGH, I WANT OUT, I WANT IT TO END, I DON'T CARE ANY MORE - '
    He seized the table on which the silver instrument had stood and threw that, too. It broke apart on the floor and the legs rolled in different directions.
    'You do care,' said Dominguez. He had not flinched or made a single move to stop Roberto demolishing his office. His expression was calm, almost detached. 'You care so much you feel as though you will bleed to death with the pain of it.'
    'I - DON'T!' Roberto screamed, so loudly that he felt his throat might tear, and for a second he wanted to rush at Dominguez and break him, too; shatter that calm old face, shake him, hurt him, make him feel some tiny part of the horror inside himself.
    'Oh, yes, you do,' said Dominguez, still more calmly. 'You have now lost your mother, your father, and the closest thing to a parent you have ever known. Of course you care.'
    'YOU DON'T KNOW HOW I FEEL!' Roberto roared. 'YOU - STANDING THERE - YOU - '
    But words were no longer enough, smashing things was no more help; he wanted to run, he wanted to keep running and never look back, he wanted to be somewhere he could not see the clear blue eyes staring at him, that hatefully calm old face. He turned on his heel and ran to the door, seized the doorknob again and wrenched at it.
    But the door would not open.
    Roberto turned back to Dominguez.
    'Let me out,' he said. He was shaking from head to foot.
    'No,' said Dominguez simply.
    For a few seconds they stared at each other.
    'Let me out,' Roberto said again.
    'No,' Dominguez repeated.
    'If you don't - if you keep me in here - if you don't let me - '
